","sourceId":null},{"id":40805,"label":"Chronomantic Orb","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Evocation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

The caster pulls from the demiplane of time a swirling orb, 4 inches in diameter, made of the mist-smoke of that plane, which is then hurled at a target. The rotation of the momentum of time causes havoc on impact with any object or linear creature.

\r\n

Damage: The caster makes an attack roll.  It that attack roll hits, the orb deals 2d8 damage as random parts of the target accelerate, pause, slow, or reverse in time, causing significant temporal stress.

\r\n

Damage may be increased by casting with higher level spell slots.

\r\n

Effect: In addition to this damage, the normal flow of time is disrupted for the target, causing their senses to perceive the world slightly out of phase for 1 round. During this time, they lose any positive Dex modifier, have Disadvantage on all attacks, and have a 50% chance of having any spells they cast fail.

\r\n

The temporal effect of the orb may be changed by casting at higher odd-level spell slots.

\r\n

The material component is a tanzanite shard that has spent one subjective day in the demiplane of time, which must simply be kept on the caster's person.

\r\n

At Higher Levels:
Damage: Every spell slot level above 1st adds an additional 1d8 to the damage.
Effect: A 1st level slot orb causes the victim to Wis save or be affected byTemporal Disjuction for 1 round (Victim loses any positive Dex modifier, has Disadvantage on all attacks, and has a 50% chance of having any spells they cast fail). A 3rd level slot orb causes the victim to Wis save or be Slowed for 1d4 rounds (As per standard spell). A 5th level slot orb causes the victim to Wis save or be affected by Time Loop for 1d4 + 1 rounds (Victim must repeat the action taken this round, or attempt to repeat it, no matter what). A 7th level slot orb causes the victim to Wis save or become Temporal Pushed (Victim is thrown forward in time 1 round plus up to 1 round per caster level - chosen by caster). A 9th level slot orb causes the victim to Wis save or become trapped in Temporal Stasis indefinitely (Victim is suspended in time and cannot move, act, age, nor die).

\r\n

This spell is an original work.

","sourceId":null},{"id":40810,"label":"Precognitive Sense","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Divination)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Range: 6 hours into the future / level

\r\n

Upon casting this spell, the caster may gain general knowledge of a single event to come. The event must affect the caster in some way. (An event that would affect another character in the party might count, especially if the caster relies on other party members for safety.)

\r\n

The chronal range is six hours into the future per caster level, and the spell automatically centers on the most important event in that time range. Information is frequently misleading--the caster might discover that gambling will bring good fortune, only to discover after losing 50 gp that the winner wishes to hire them for an adventure--and there is always a 10% chance that the information is simply wrong.

\r\n

The material component is a rose quartz held to the caster's forehead.

\r\n

Based on 2e AD&D spell of the same name, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40812,"label":"Preserve/Decay","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Duration: Preserve: (1 + spell slot level used) months / caster level up to 10 years ; Decay:1 month / level

\r\n

Preserve:
By the use of the Preserve spell, the caster can halt the decay (including shelf ripening) of any nonliving matter. In the case of food or drink, the substance must first be placed in a closed container of some kind. Preserve is dispelled when the container is unsealed. For other material, the spell runs its full duration unless dispelled by some other means. If the target is a corpse, it must be packaged completely in a container (sack, trunk, etc), and a spell slot of 2nd level or higher must be used.

\r\n

The material component required is a small vial of salt sealed with wax.

\r\n

Decay:
The reverse of this spell, Decay, causes immediate decay equal to one month per caster level.

\r\n

The material component required is a pinch of dung or mold.

\r\n

Based on 2e AD&D spell Preserve, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40815,"label":"Slow/Haste Metabolism","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Duration: 12 hours / level up to 7 days, or until next meal

\r\n

Slow Metabolism:
When cast on a creature, this spell can drastically increase the length of time between required meals. The recipient only requires food and drink once every 12 hours per level, up to 7 days. Also, if the creature has been poisoned, this spell slows the onset of damage and effect by one hour per level (assuming the full effect of the poison has not already take place), but a cure still needs to be found.

\r\n

The material component is a small wafer that the recipient consumes.

\r\n

Haste Metabolism:
The reverse of the spell requires an attack roll. It quickly weakens a creature from lack of food and water. If a Constitution save is failed, the target's Constitution and Strength are each reduced by 1 point for every two levels of the caster (minimum of 1), until the victim next eats a full meal. This does not kill the victim unless the Hit Dice modifier drops it below 0 current hit points.

\r\n

The material component is a piece of spoiled food that is hurled at the target.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell Accelerate Metabolism.

","sourceId":null},{"id":40816,"label":"Sustained Uncertainty","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Duration: In combat/frantic situation: up to 1 round ; Out of combat: up to 5 minutes

\r\n

Channelling energy from the demiplane of time, the caster causes two contradictory possible immediate futures to both be realized simultaneously for a target creature. Whatever actions the creature takes for the next round, they gain Advantage on all rolls. All rolls made against the target, including contesting rolls, have Disadvantage.

\r\n

This spell requires more focus than the average concentration spell.  In combat, or in highly stressful or frantic situations, the caster can concentrate as normal for only up to 1 round.  In calmer situations, the caster can concentrate on maintaining the spell for up to 5 minutes.

\r\n

The caster cannot target themselves with this spell.

\r\n

The material component for this spell is a small sealed container whose contents cannot be directly observed.

\r\n

At Higher Levels:
You can target one additional creature for each additional slot level above 1st.

\r\n

This spell is an original work.

","sourceId":null},{"id":40877,"label":"Hourglasses","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Divination)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n
Focus on an object or feature in sight.  As the caster concentrates, their left eye begins to witness time in reverse, seeing further and further into the past.  Simultaneously, their right eye begins to see time progress at an accelerated rate, seeing further and further into the (currently-most statistically-probable) future.  Through their left eye, they might see burnt paper unburn, and become readable, then as time continued back, watch the words \"unwrite\" themselves off the page, leaving a blank parchment.  They might see people or creatures pass through a space in reverse.  Through their right eye, they might see an unused new journal begin to form words on its pages as they \"write themselves\" in, then after some time, get torn, or scribbled over, or fade.  This might allow the caster to view the combination of a currently-secured lock at some time when it was (or will be) solved and open.  They might also attempt to read a lost spell scroll, or examine a destroyed piece of evidence.  Maybe determine what someone else is planning based on what they write, or how an object will be primed in the future, and then prepare against that outcome beforehand.
\r\n
Area of Effect:
Typically, this spell is cast and then the caster spends all of their attention on the focused-upon object or area.  However, the caster may wish to look around at their surroundings with anachronistic vision, or even walk about and observe the area as it once was or likely someday will be.  This requires a Wisdom saving throw of DC 15.  Failure means the caster becomes disoriented with a sense of vertigo, and must cease movement and focus solely on the original target of the spell in order to avoid losing concentration.  They cannot attempt to look around at their surroundings again until the spell is cast anew.
\r\n
Rate of Change and Control of Flow:
For the entire round spent actually casting the spell, the caster sees the past/next 24 hours (4 hours per second).  They may change or pause the perceived flow of time by performing a Wisdom save, as though 0 rounds have passed so far.  After this first round has passed, the caster may change the rate of the vision once per round.
\r\n
Rates are:
> > > > Stopped,
> > > One second per round,
> > One minute per round,
> One hour per round,
One day per round (DEFAULT),
> One week per round,
> > One month per round,
> > > One year per round,
> > > > One decade per round,
> > > > > One century per round
\r\n
Each attempt to change this rate may only shift over a number of rate categories equal to or less than the caster's Wisdom modifier.  Each change in rate prompts an immediate Wisdom check of
[ DC (9 - 1 per every 2 caster levels) + (number of rounds spent concentrating so far) + (number of rate categories attempting to change this round) ]
\r\n
So for example, shifting from days/round to full-stop is a difference of 4 rates.  If the caster is Level 3 and was concentrating for 6 rounds at this point, then the DC is (9 - (level 3 / 2)) + 6 rounds + 4 rate = DC 18.  Shifting from centuries/round to full-stop after concentrating for a minute would be (9 - (level 3 / 2)) + 10 rounds + 9 rate = DC 27.  A level 20 caster would attempt the same shift as (9 - (level 20 / 2)) + 10 rounds + 9 rate = DC 18.  Shifting one rate category per round prompts more checks, but each check will have a lower DC to contend with, and may be necessary for lower-level casters who wish ultimately to shift across many rate categories.
\r\n
Failing this Wisdom save causes the caster to immediately suffer a debilitating migraine for 1d20 minutes (Disadvantage to all Int and Wis skills and saves).  This also immediately ends the spell, unless the caster chooses to suffer one level of exhaustion.  No rate shift can be attempted while the caster is suffering a migraine, and additional castings of this spell automatically fail until the migraine clears.
\r\n
Observing only events of either only the past or only the future exclusively requires the caster to cover or close the opposite eye.  Casters missing one or both eyes, or otherwise blinded, can actually still see out of the appropriate eye socket(s) for the duration of this spell, and still need to go through the same physical motions to block one side or the other.
\r\n
The material components of this spell are a piece of red glass and a piece of blue glass, each of which are held up to the caster's eyes.
\r\n
This spell is an original work.
","sourceId":null},{"id":41897,"label":"Corrosive Spit","description":"

Your saliva becomes highly acidic, and you gain the ability to spit at long distances. When you cast this spell, you may make an ranged attack spell against a target (range 30/90). If the attack hits, the target takes 3d4 acid damage.

\r\n

As a bonus action, you can repeat the attack against any creature. You can also forgo an attack to store saliva, up to two stores of saliva. As a bonus action, you may expend stores to make additional attacks equal to the number of expended stores. Make separate attack rolls for each attack.

","sourceId":null},{"id":43462,"label":"Xin's Arcane Smelter","description":"

Created by the famed artificer and spellwright Xin al-Qasim, this spell was designed to smelt raw ore or refined metal into ingots suitable for sale or metal-smithing.

\r\n

When cast this spell will melt, refine, shape and cool to room temperature any piece of metallic ore. Once shaped the ingots can be utilized as any other. If examined the ingots will be found to be of the best quality of refinement and quality.

","sourceId":null},{"id":50500,"label":"Rust • HB-MDM","description":"

You target a creature wearing metal armor or barding, or a construct made of metal that you can see within range forcing the target to make a Constitution saving throw. A creature that fails this saving throw has their AC decreased by 2 for the duration. On a successful save the next attack made against the target for the duration has advantage, and the spell ends at the start of your next turn.

","sourceId":null},{"id":55985,"label":"Maximilian's Mineral Transmutation","description":"

 You transmute up to 100 gp worth of coins into a precious gem of the same value, called a spellforged gem. If you cast this spell multiple times, you may create a gem with a total value of all coins used as material components for consecutive castings of this spell.

\r\n

Gems created by this spell are distinguishable from naturally occuring gems by a trained eye with a DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) check. As an action, any arcane spellcaster can discern the exact value of a spellforged gem by touching it.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the maximum amount of coins you can transmute increases by 100 gp for each slot level above 1st.

","sourceId":null},{"id":58087,"label":"Discretion Bubble","description":"

A 10-foot-radius invisible and immobile dome springs into existence around and above you and remains stationary for the duration. The hemisphere includes a floor. The spell ends if you leave its area.

Nine creatures of Medium size or smaller can fit inside the dome with you. The spell fails if its area includes a larger creature or more than nine creatures. Any sound made from within the dome can only be heard by the creatures inside the dome, while sound coming from outside the dome can still be heard from within. 

\r\n

The dome doesn't prevent spellcasting or offer any other protection. 

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":64079,"label":"Repair","description":"

A structure, construct, living construct, or homunculus you touch regains a number of hit points equal to 1d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier. This spell has no effect on undead or biological creatures.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the healing increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.

","sourceId":null},{"id":64103,"label":"Pre-/Post-Image","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Illusion)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

Post-Image:
When Post-Image is cast, the target is surrounded by a thin magical aura that bends time slightly, causing the person's image to appear one second behind the present. This distorted view of the target disorients attackers, and gives the recipient +2 AC and +1 to saves against direct magical attacks. This spell can be used in conjunction with other AC-affecting spells, but it is not cumulative with itself.

\r\n

Pre-Image:
The reverse of this spell, Pre-Image, creates a false image of the target from half a second into the future. This disorienting effect gives the target +2 to hit, and increases their spell DC by +1, as opponents misjudge the target's movements and attacks.

\r\n

At Higher Levels:
With more experience, the caster can strobe the image between past, present and future, increasing the disorienting effects.
Caster level 5: Post-Image grants +3 AC, +2 saves vs direct magic attack ; Pre-Image grants +3 to hit, +2 spell DC
Caster level 10: Post-Image grants +4 AC, +3 saves vs direct magic attack ; Pre-Image grants +4 to hit, +3 spell DC
Caster level 15: Post-Image grants +5 AC, +4 saves vs direct magic attack ; Pre-Image grants +5 to hit, +4 spell DC

\r\n

Inspired by the 2e AD&D spell Delay Image, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":68360,"label":"Transfusion","description":"

You siphon the life of others trough touch, taking away their blood into an orb then transfusing it to you and your allies. Make a melee spell attack against a creature within your reach. On a hit, the target takes 1d6 necrotic damage, and you store the hit points equal to half the amount of necrotic damage dealt. Until the spell ends, you can transfer those hit points to a target or make the attack again on each of your turns as an action, each attack adds up to the amount saved.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 1rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":70720,"label":"Alter Voice","description":"

You alter the voice of one creature you can see that is within range. You can cause the voice to change accent, gender, tone, quality, or even to perfectly resemble a voice you have heard before if speaking. The spell has no affect on what the target chooses to say only the sound of the voice when they speak. You cannot change speech into other sounds like barks or music or alter what they say: if they speak, the words remain the same and likewise you cannot change a bark or growl into words but you can make a bark sound like a squeak or a bird's call sound like a monstrous roar and similar such things. There is an exception: if a creature targeted by this spell is normally capable of speech but cannot due to a physical restriction such as damage to vocal chords or a Druid's Wild Shape form this spell allows them to speak as long as they retain the mental capacity for it (since a creature's mental statistics are replaced this exception does not apply to those affected by Polymorph).

\r\n

You can use this spell to render a creature voiceless: a person becomes unable to speak, dogs cannot bark, etc. rendering the target silent. A target silenced by this effect cannot provide verbal components of spells.

\r\n

An unwilling creature targeted by this spell must succeed on a Constitution saving throw to avoid the spell. Any target affected by this spell can, if they wish, make Constitution saving throw at the end of their turns to end the spell effect on them on success.

\r\n

At higher levels. When you cast this spell using a 2nd level spell slot or higher you can target an additional creature within range for each level above 1st level.

","sourceId":null},{"id":72153,"label":"Create or Destroy Air","description":"

You either create or destroy air.

\r\n

Create Air. You create, replenish, and refresh the air around any creature within range, including air poisoned/tainted by spells such as cloudkill and stinking cloud.  If the air is fouled (low or no oxygen), the air is freshened with 1d10 minutes of clean air.  If used within a cloud-based spell (such as cloudkill and stinking cloud) the creature is allowed an immediate save against the effects of the spell.

\r\n

Destroy Air. The air around a target creature within range immediately is reduced to fouled status. If air is already fouled status, the air becomes deadly. Fouled and deadly air will quickly disperse the same round in an open environment, but if the target is in a airtight area less then 5 square feet or in a personal air bubble in space, they suffer the full effects.  

\r\n

Anyone breathing fouled air suffers disadvantage on all attacks & proficiency checks.

\r\n

Anyone breathing deadly air must make a constitution save versus poison each turn or become unconscious. The DC for the save is 10 plus the number of rounds spent breathing the deadly air. Anyone remaining in the deadly air while unconscious will automatically lose 10 hp each round.

\r\n

At higher levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you may target one additional creature for each slot above 1st .

\r\n

You either create or destroy earth.

\r\n

Destroy Earth. You destroy up to 1 cubic foot of mundane soil, stone, clay, or sand within range.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you create or destroy 1 additional cubic foot of earth for each slot level above 1st.

","sourceId":null},{"id":78319,"label":"Contagious Affliction","description":"

Speaking words of illness and death, you cause a creature's blood to cloud with toxins and their skin to erupt in lesions.  Make a ranged spell attack against one creature within range.  On a hit, the target takes 2d12 poison damage and becomes infected with a contagious affliction.  On a miss the target takes half damage and is not infected.  

\r\n

While the target is infected in this way it is poisoned and it must make a Constitution saving throw at the start of each of its turns, ending this effect on a success.  Each time the target fails a saving throw against this effect, it's affliction erupts in a cloud of disease.  This cloud is a sphere with a radius of 10ft centered on the target, and each creature within this sphere when the target fails its saving throw takes 1d6 poison damage.  

\r\n

This affliction counts as a disease, and can be removed with a Lesser Restoration spell or similar magic.  Undead and constructs are immune to the effects of this spell.  

\r\n

At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the initial poison damage increases by 1d12 for each slot level above 1st and the damage of the poisonous eruptions increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 1st.  Additionally, when you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the target takes a -1 penalty to saving throws made against the effects of this spell.  This penalty increases to -2 for a spell slot of 5th level or higher,  -3 for a slot of 7th level or higher, and -4 for a 9th level spell slot.

You channel the essence of death into your weapon and use it to pry loose your enemy's soul, exposing it for your allies to feast upon.  As part of the action used to cast this spell, you must make a melee attack with a weapon against one creature and hit, otherwise the spell fails and the spell slot is wasted. On a hit, the target suffers the attack’s normal effects plus an additional 2d8 necrotic damage, and some of the targets life energy is pried out and exposed.  After your attack and until the end of your next turn, any creature that hits the target with an attack regains hit points equal to 2d4 plus your spellcasting ability modifier.  A creature can only regain hit points in this way once for each casting of this spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":86025,"label":"Summon Planar Minion","description":"

You pluck an entity from its home and force it to fight on your behalf. You conjure a Fey, Elemental, Fiend, or Celestial of Challenge rating 1/8 or lower. It appears in unoccupied spaces that you can see within range.

\r\n


The creature is forced to obey you, but will do so reluctantly (depending on the creature’s disposition). it disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or you lose concentration. The creature can make a concentration check equal to your spellcasting DC to remain on the plane for one round. If it succeeds, it acts according to its own will. While under your control a nearly invisible chain of magical energy binds the creature to your hand. While bound, the creature cannot move more than 60 feet from you.

\r\n

The summoned creature obeys your orders as best as it can, but may twist them to get a result it prefers over your own. Roll initiative for the summoned creature, which has its own turns. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it as a bonus action. If you don't issue any commands to it, it defends itself from hostile creatures, but otherwise take no actions.

\r\n

The GM has the stats for the creature  

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using higher-level spell slots, you can increase the challenge rating. 2nd level calls a Challenge 1/4 creature, 3rd level calls a Challenge 1/2 creature, 4th level conjures a Challenge 1, and so increasing a step with each level until 9th level with Challenge 7 creatures. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":88425,"label":"Transmosis","description":"

This spell has the ability to transfer the magic of one common magical item, to another nonmagical or magical item. If the magic of the item is compatible with the type of item being transferred to — a warhammer could not absorb the power of a vorpal sword for instance — then the caster can spend time engaged in a process to transfer the magic from one to the other. If an item requires attunement for it to be used, then the caster must be attuned to it during the casting of this spell. Any magic within the item receiving the transfer is destroyed and replaced by the new powers. The item being transferred from loses its magic at the completion of this spell.

\r\n

Casting this spell requires 24 hours of continual contact with each item involved in the process. Platinum, in any form, to a certain value dependant on the rarity of the item being drained, is required as a catalyst during the process and is consumed by the spell. At the end of the process, the caster suffers one level of exhaustion for each successive level of rarity of the item above mundane. Transferring the magic of a legendary item would therefore inflict five levels of exhaustion on the caster.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can transfer the magic from an uncommon magical item to your chosen item. With a 5th level slot, the item being transferred from can be rare, a 7th level slot allows you to transfer from a very rare item, and a 9th level slot is required to transfer the magic of a legendary item.

","sourceId":null},{"id":98698,"label":"Pustulent Growth","description":"

Patches of fungus on various exposed parts of your body begin to swell up with toxic puss. You become covered in large, putrid pustules.

\r\n

While active, you gain temporary hit points equal to your character level plus your Constitution modifier, and enemies attacking you with bludgeoning damage roll to hit with disadvantage. If your temporary hit points from Pustulent Growth are depleted, all creatures, excluding yourself, within 10 feet of you take 1d4 poison damage and 1d4 necrotic damage.

\r\n

If your temporary hit points from Pustulent Growth are not depleted by the time it expires, you lose all temporary hit points from this ability, and must either - inflict 1d4 necrotic damage to yourself - or - use your action to slowly drain the pustules.

\r\n

Roll an extra 1d4 at levels 4, 7, 10, 13, and 16. This scaling applies to all dice for this ability; the necrotic and poison explosion damage, and the necrotic self-damage.

","sourceId":null},{"id":99004,"label":"Fey Spirit","description":"

You gain the service of a fey spirit that takes an animal form you choose. Appearing in an unoccupied space within range, the fey spirit has the statistics of the chosen form, though it is a fey instead of a beast.

\r\n

Your class level determines the beasts you can choose, as shown in the fey spirit table. At 2nd level, for example, you can summon any beast that has a challenge rating of 1/4 or lower that doesn't have a flying or swimming speed.

\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
LevelMax. CRLimitationsExample
2nd1/4No flying or swimming speedWolf
4th1/2No flying speedCrocodile
8th1—Giant eagle
\r\n

 

\r\n

Your fey spirit acts independently of you, but it always obeys your commands. In combat, it rolls its own initiative and acts on its own turn. A familiar can't attack, but it can take other actions as normal.

\r\n

When the fey spirit drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. It reappears after you cast this spell again.

\r\n

While your fey spirit is within 100 feet of you, you can communicate with it telepathically. Additionally, as an action, you can see through your fey spirit's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of your next turn, gaining the benefits of any special senses that the fey spirit has. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses.

\r\n

As an action, you can temporarily dismiss your fey spirit. It disappears into a pocket dimension where it awaits your summons. Alternatively, you can dismiss it forever. As an action while it is temporarily dismissed, you can cause it to reappear in any unoccupied space within 30 feet of you.

\r\n

You can't have more than one fey spirit at a time. If you cast this spell while you already have a fey spirit, you instead cause it to adopt a new form. Choose one of the forms from the avaible list. Your fey spirit transforms into the chosen creature.

","sourceId":null},{"id":102351,"label":"Hadar's Embrace","description":"

The next time you hit a creature with a weapon attack before this spell ends, you leave behind a writhing mass of mucous coated tentacles. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be restrained by the pallid appendages until the spell ends. A Large or larger creature has advantage on this saving throw. If the target succeeds on the save, the tentacles tear and dissolve away into a puddle of foul smelling goo.

While restrained by this spell, the target takes 1d6 acid damage at the start of each of its turns, as the caustic slime etches their flesh. A creature restrained by the tentacles or one that can touch the creature can use its action to make a Strength check against your spell save DC. On a success, the target is freed. 

\r\n

At Higher Levels. If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 1st.

You gain the ability to easily read a person's intentions and body language. Choose a creature you can see and that can hear. You gain advantage on all Investigation, Insight and Perception checks made against the target creature, as well they have disadvantage on all Deception and Sleight of Hand checks against you while you maintain concentration. As well as the normal rules for concentration, the spell ends if the target would succeed in a Deception/Sleight of Hand check against your Spell Save DC, or your Investigation/Insight/Perception check, whichever is higher.

\r\n

","sourceId":null},{"id":111371,"label":"Allana's Library Rats","description":"

Describe key words about a topic. This spell creates 1d4+1 rats made of force energy that run from your hand towards written materials, such as books or scrolls.

\r\n

When a rat of force hits a written material containing one or more key words, the rat is absorbed by the item, which starts glowing with yellow light. The item hit in such way will remain glowing for up ten minutes or until dispelled.

\r\n

The spell can locate a specific book or scroll or written material known to you, as long as you have clear recollection of its name or the author's or even its contents. And only if the said item is really present at the place, since the spell cannot create the item out of thin air, only locate it within range.

\r\n

Similar to Locate Objects spell, this spell can't locate an object if any thickness of lead, even a thin sheet, blocks a direct path between you and the object.

They take 1d10 poison damage. Whenever they attempt to speak (including casting a spell with verbal components), the target must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell DC. On a success they are able to articulate themselves; on a failure their words are garbled and unintelligible.

","sourceId":null},{"id":113302,"label":"Joshua's Pocket Library","description":"

You create small pocket dimension. It can be used to store pens, quills, ink bottles, parchment, books, scrolls, or other written material. This pocket dimension is accessible to you and only you through any container, though the opening of the container must be large enough to allow the item to pass through it. This small pocket dimension contains no air and may only to used to store these sorts of items. The spell caster upon casting the spell has access to this pocket dimension for up to 1 hour and can use it to store written or writing materials or to retrieve any such items previously place there. This may store any number of such items however, after the first 20 items the caster must make a Intelligence or Wisdom DC 15 check (increasing by 1 for every 5 extra items) to see if they can find what they are looking for. On a fail they either give up or pull out a random item.

","sourceId":null},{"id":121575,"label":"Mark Tracks","description":"

","sourceId":null},{"id":129583,"label":"Blossom's Book Binder","description":"

This spell binds a book to a person and a place. The book is marked with a rune of binding (a faintly visible version of the caster's sigil) and will always return to its person first, its place second.

\r\n

If the person that is the subject of the binding be dead of imprisoned on another plane, the book returns to its place. If the place this book is bound to is damaged, moved, or destroyed, the book will return as close as possible to its place. 

\r\n

If the book is destroyed by fire, water, frost, or any other means, it will return after a year and a day. 

\r\n

The specific way in which the book is returned to its owner or place is not specified. It could be returned by teleportation, messenger, owl, or by any other appropriate means. The universe conspires to put this book with its person and/or in its place.

\r\n

No more than one publication, book, tome, title, treatise, opus, or manual may be bound to a person in this way. Each additional time this spell is cast by the caster, the current binding is broken and replaced by the new biding. Books unbound in this manner are \"lost\" if they were in the process of returning.

\r\n

This spell has no effect on sentient books or books that qualify as wondrous items.

\r\n

Some bards claim that this spell is the first spell, the very oldest spell in all of creation, and that it was wrought for the first magical apprentice.

","sourceId":null},{"id":129951,"label":"Regeneration","description":"

You touch a creature and stimulate its natural healing ability. The target regains 1d4 + 1 hit points. For the duration of the spell, the target regains 1d4 + 1 hit points at the start of each of its turns.

\r\n

If the target has a severed body member (fingers, legs, tails, and so on) and you hold it to the stump, the spell instantaneously causes the limb to knit to the body and return to full function.

\r\n

When cast at higher levels the duration is extended by 2 rounds per level. If cast at 7th level or higher missing body members will be regrown completely over the course of the spell.

\r\n

At higher levels, it does +2 additional damage to hit. 4th level: +2 damage, 8th level: +4 damage, 12th level: +6 damage, 15th level: +8 damage, 19th level: +10 damage.

","sourceId":null},{"id":136894,"label":"Repair","description":"

A still-functional object or construct you touch regains a number of hit points equal to 1d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier. This has no effect on living creatures, undead, or objects/constructs that have been damaged to the point they no longer function.

\r\n

For the spell to work, the caster must have observed the object or construct in its fully functional state. In the case of mundane objects, the caster can still perform the spell as long as they have observed an object that is similar or functions in the same manner. (ie, having observed a rapier, a rapier can be repaired, but not a longsword)

\r\n

A spell slot MUST be consumed to repair magical objects or constructs, UNLESS the caster is a Transmutation Wizard.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the healing increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.

","sourceId":null},{"id":139321,"label":"Rancid Visitations","description":"

The Sorcerer reaches out his hand and laughs, engulfing his enemies in an extremely contagious infection that rots their organs causing 2d8 poison damage. The creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for one turn.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.

","sourceId":null},{"id":139504,"label":"Invention - Parachute","description":"

You create three inventions which function as parachutes. A creature can activate and deactivate the parachute with a reaction, bonus action or action at any time. A falling creature's rate of descent slows to 30 feet per round while falling with a parachute equipped and activated. A creature landing after a fall with a parachute activated takes no falling damage and can land on its feet. 

\r\n

The inventions get worn out and have a 75% chance of working the next time they are used if not repared with components.

\r\n

The inventions get worn out and have a 50% chance of working the third time they are used if not repared with components.

\r\n

The inventions get worn out and have a 25% chance of working the fourth time they are used if not repared with components.

\r\n

The inventions get worn out and are destroyed after the forth time they are used if not repare with components.

","sourceId":null},{"id":141992,"label":"Assemble","description":"

","sourceId":null},{"id":149164,"label":"Putrefy Food and Drink","description":"

Any creature that eats the food or drink must make a Constitution saving throw or take 3d6 Poison damage and be poisoned for 1 minute. While poisoned in this way, they take an addition 3d6 poison damage at the start of each of their turns. They are allowed a save at the end of each of their turns to end the poisoned condition.

","sourceId":null},{"id":149887,"label":"Alter Spell","description":"

When you perceive a spell being cast, as a reaction, you can cast this spell to alter one aspect of the spell. If the spell is higher than first level, make an Intelligence Check DC 10 + spell level of the altered spell.

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Target: When you alter a spell that has a single target, you can change the target to your self or the caster. To change it to the caster, make a Intelligence Check against the caster's Wisdom Saving Throw. If the caster succeeds, the target is changed to your self.
    • \r\n
  • Increase: You can increase the number of die rolled for the spell by 1. (Example: If you alter a 3rd level fireball spell with Increase, it does 9d6 fire damage instead of 8d6 fire damage.)
    • \r\n
  • Decrease: You can decrease the number of die rolled for the spell by 1. (Example: If you alter a 3rd level fireball spell with Increase, it does 7d6 fire damage instead of 8d6 fire damage.)
    • \r\n
\r\n

At Higher Levels: You do not need to make the Intelligence Check for Spells that are equal or lower level than the spell slot used to cast this spell. In addition, the number of die Increase or Decrease is increased by 1 for each spell level higher than 1st(Example: if Alter Spell is cast at 2nd Level, Decrease decreases the number of die rolled by 2)

","sourceId":null},{"id":149979,"label":"Merge / Sunder","description":"

This is a dual purpose spell allowing the caster to change the state of any single type of substance. 

\r\n

The caster chooses 1 specific type of material, such as sandstone, copper, ruby, diamond, iron, steel or marble.

\r\n

The caster can work the amount available into a different physical state, such as turning a pile of rubies into either 1 large ruby, or a pile of ruby chips, or dust. The physical amount of the substance does not change, but the change can go either way, dust to single block, or back again.

\r\n

When combining, the caster can only choose a basic shape, such as a rectangle or sphere to make it easier to transport the item.  When separating into tiny pieces like chips or dust, the spell assists in placing the material into a container.

\r\n

The rate at which this can be done is as follows:

\r\n

Soft stone: 10 cubic feet per level per hour.  Soft metal: 5 cubic feet per hour per level.  Hard stone: 1 cubic foot per hour per level. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":153562,"label":"Rejuvenation","description":"

You envelop one living creature within range with a blessing that rapidly closes wounds and rejuvenates the target.

\r\n

The target regains 1d4 hit points. At the start of their turn each round, the target must roll a d20. On an 11 or higher, they continue to benefit from and maintain the spell.

\r\n

Constructs gain no benefit from this spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":156053,"label":"Alchemical Transmutation","description":"

As part of the casting of this spell, you draw a magical transmutation circle up to 5 feet in diameter on a flat surface.  Non-magical objects with a volume of up to  5 cubic feet, may be placed within the circle.  When you finish casting this spell, objects within the circle instantly and permanently take on a new shape of your choice.  The new objects are composed of the same material as the objects placed within the circle.  You can create as many new objects as you like, so long as their combined volume is not greater than the original volume of objects placed within the circle.  For example, you might transform a log into 10 javelins,  100 arrows,  1000 toothpicks, or another other wooden object or objects that do not exceed the volume of the original log, subject to DM discretion.  Your DM might require you to make an Intelligence check in order to create complex or intricate objects with this spell.

\r\n

An alternative use of this spell is to alter the very surface upon which the transmutation circle is drawn.  This usage of the spell must follow the same rules as above.  The surface must not be magical, and its new shape can not have more volume than a 5 foot cube.  Otherwise, the surface takes on any shape you desire.

\r\n

You may cast this spell to greater effect at higher levels.  For each level spell slot you use beyond first level, the maximum volume of objects you can transmute increases by 5 cubic feet.  For example, if you cast this spell using a second level spell slot, you could affect a volume of objects up to 10 cubic feet, 15 cubic feet for a third level slot, and so on.

","sourceId":null},{"id":172965,"label":"Division","description":"

Reaching out and touching a simple object or corpse, you channel slivers of magic into your target and break it down to its base components. This spell is often used to efficiently gather materials in a very short amount of time or to recover materials from broken objects.

\r\n

Upon casting this spell and touching a Medium or smaller inanimate object (such as a hammer, unenchanted shield, small fallen tree, or corpse not under the effects of necromancy), you divide it cleanly into the raw materials it is made from. These components normally separate into small piles that are sorted however you wish. For example, casting this spell on a woodcutting axe would create a lump of iron or steel from the blade and either a single portion of wood or a pile of sticks from the wooden handle. A corpse could be divided into meat, organs, skin/hide, bones, and blood. The blood would simply pour onto the ground unless given a vessel to be collected in at the time of casting.

\r\n

This spell does not affect living creatures, animated dead, reinforced structures, magical items, or objects currently under magical effects.

","sourceId":null},{"id":184468,"label":"Gravity Lapse","description":"

All creatures make a DEX saving throw or take 2d6 bludgeoning damage and are knocked prone on a failed save or half as much on a successful save and land safely.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 1st.

Make a ranged spell attack against that creature. On a hit, the target takes 2d6 necrotic damage and the caster heals 1d4 health, and on each of your turns for the duration, you can use your action to deal 2d6 necrotic damage to the target automatically and heal 1d4 health. The spell ends if you use your action to do anything else. The spell also ends if the target is ever outside the spell’s range or if it has total cover from you.

Spell has no effect on uninjured, undead or constructs.

","sourceId":null},{"id":210376,"label":"Malthael's Magic Item Creation","description":"

To create a magic item, you must first meet several requirements before the actual creation. First, you must be at or above the required spellcaster level (not combined level for multi-classing). Second, you must have the required amount of gold pieces that will be consumed upon the spells completion. Third, you must have the amount of ingredients required that will be consumed upon the spells completion. If the spell is interrupted (e.g. counterspell or dispel magic), then the spell ends and no gold or ingredients are consumed, yet your spell slot is used. Additionally, you need to possess and be proficient with the tool kit related to the item if the item is not already made (e.g. Need to have and be proficient with a leather works kit and possess leather to craft sufficient leather armor for magical creation). Upon creation of the magic item, the caster can choose whether or not to attune to the item if it requires it.

\r\n

During the process of magical creation, the caster must make a constitution saving throw for every 8 hours or suffer 1 point of exhaustion. The DC = 8 + The spell level + # of exhaustion points. Allies can assist by feeding or casting magic to help make sure the caster doesn't suffer additional points of exhaustion due to lack of nourishment.

\r\n

Any complications in the creation process is up to the DM's discretion. (e.g. curses, person's of interest, enemies, wilderness)

\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
Rarity LevelSpellcaster LevelGold requiredIngredients RequiredCasting Time
Common1st (1st level)50gp41 minute
Uncommon5th (3rd level)500gp81 hour
Rare9th (5th level)5,000gp128 hours
Very Rare13th (7th level)50,000gp1624 hours
Legendary17th (9th level)50,000+ gp20+3 days
\r\n

 

\r\n

The power and amount of properties you can have on your magic item relate to the rarity of the item (e.g. Common = 1, Legendary = 5). Consult with your DM on properties for your magic item.

\r\n

 Properties include but are not limited to: Effects, conditions, spellcasting, extra damage, attunement, abilities.

","sourceId":null},{"id":211149,"label":"Crystal recorder","description":"

When casting this spell the caster starts a crystaline spindel to spin.  as long as the caster concentrates the crystal will keep spinning, and while it does, all sound that can be heard at that location is recorded, and the crystal then becomes opaque with a small rune mark appearing at the top.  the change is perminant as is the recording (subject to the crystal not being broken).

\r\n

once the created the crystal can then be used as a focus for illusionary magics to allow the sounds to be played back. the illusion spell used to play back effects how it works, minor illusion allows a quiet playback, phantasmal force - silent playback for the target of the spell, larger illusions can give more powerful volumes and control (for example fast forwarding and rewinding).

\r\n

While the playback is illusionary, it is also verbatum, however people may not believe that it is real even though it will always be the same each time.

","sourceId":null},{"id":222132,"label":"Reconstruct Contraption","description":"

You can completely reconstruct any contraption that is less than 5ft x 5ft. You need a part of the original contraption you're working with, having less parts means taking longer time to reconstruct. You also use scrap metals worth at least 35gp, the more complicated the contraption, the more scrap metals you'll need. If the contraption has magic embed to it, do a DC 15 (spellcasting ability) with the proper modifier. In a success, proceed to make reconstruction. However, in a fail, it will require an extra time of at least 5 mins. The DM will decide how much time it takes, worth/amount of scrap metal, and the extra time given. 

\r\n

While reconstructing, you can make one new modification to the contraption on a successful DC 20 INT check, only have one chance. At a fail, proceed to reconstruct the contraption without any new modifications. You can ask the DM what modification you will make, and he/she can allow it or not.

","sourceId":null},{"id":232287,"label":"Create or Destroy Air","description":"

You either create or destroy air. When creating: The bearings rust dispapers as it the oxides becomes oxygen. When destroying: The bearings are rapidly oxidized depliting the air within the barrier. Both cases alter the bearing to such a degree they are broken down into iron dust afterwards.

\r\n

Create Air. You create up to 30 minutes worth of breathable cool air within range in an container. Alternatively, the air pushes outwards as bubble in a 30-foot sphere within range, all water and aquatic creatures in it are pushed away and the water is repelled for 30 minutes before the bubble collapses (if underwater it will flood back in from all directions).

\r\n

Destroy Air. You destroy up to 30 minutes worth of air in an open container within range. Alternatively, the air is pushed outwards in a 30-foot sphere within range, all creature sin this area must hold their breath or suffocate in a perfect vacuum, this lasts for 30 minutes before the bubble collapses causes the air to rush back into this space.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you create or destroy 30 additional minutes of water, or the size of the sphere increases by 5 feet, for each slot level above 1st.

","sourceId":null},{"id":234362,"label":"Extradimensional Expansion","description":"

You cause the interior dimensions of an object such as a bag or a chest to expand into an extradimensional space with a volume equal to four times the object’s original interior space. This extradimensional space is not bound to the shape of the original space, and can accommodate any item that can fit through the opening as long as the total volume of that item does not exceed the total available space. The extradimensional space can hold up to 5 pounds for each cubic foot. The object’s weight does not change, regardless of its contents.

\r\n

Placing an item in the space follows the normal rules for interacting with objects. Retrieving an item from the space requires you use an action. When you reach into the space for a specific item, the item is always magically on top.

\r\n

The space has a few limitations. If it is overloaded, or if a sharp object pierces it or tears it, the spell ends. When the spell ends, the interior dimensions revert to their original form. Should the volume of the contents exceed the volume of the space’s normal dimensions at this time, items inside the space are jettisoned at random into the Astral Plane until the volume of the contents in the space no longer exceeds its regular dimensions. If a breathing creature is placed within the space, the creature can survive for up to 10 minutes, after which time it begins to suffocate.

\r\n

Placing an item affected by this spell inside an extradimensional space created by a bag of holding, portable hole, or similar item instantly destroys both items and opens a gate to the Astral Plane. The gate originates where one item was placed inside the other. Any creature within 10 feet of the gate is sucked through it and deposited in a random location on the Astral Plane. The gate then closes. The gate is one-way only and it can’t be reopened.

\r\n

Casting this spell on a bag fashioned from the silk of a phase spider every day for one month permanently transforms the object into a bag of holding. At the DM’s discretion, this process might involve additional steps that may not be commonly known and which may be the substance of a quest. Additionally, the DM can allow other similar objects can be created using similar methods.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the interior dimensions of the object are expanded to eight times the original size and the space can hold 10 pounds for each cubic foot. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the interior dimensions of the object are expanded to twelve times the original size and the space can hold 15 pounds for each cubic foot. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the interior dimensions of the object are expanded to sixteen times the original size and the space can hold 20 pounds for each cubic foot. When you cast this spell using a 9th-level spell slot, the interior dimensions of the object are expanded to twenty times the original size and the space can hold 25 pounds for each cubic foot.

","sourceId":null},{"id":248468,"label":"Obfuscate","description":"

You target any number of willing creatures within range that you can see, obfuscating your conversation from others. You and any target that remain within range of you, will be able to understand each other, but to anyone else your conversation will sounds like meaningless noise, which is almost completely unnoticeable in a noisy area. A creature actively trying to eavesdrop or scry must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw in order to hear through the illusion.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the duration is concentration, up to 10 minutes. If you use a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the duration is 1 hour. If you use a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the duration is 8 hours. If you use a 9th level spell slot, the duration is 24 hours. Using a spell slot of 5th level or higher grants a duration that doesn't require concentration.

","sourceId":null},{"id":259953,"label":"Scholar's Touch","description":"

While concentrating on this spell, you can touch one book or scroll and absorb the knowledge contained within as if you had just read it. This is equivalent to a solid reading but not deep study. You do not gain perfect recall of the information, only what you would have gleaned from reading it completely once. The spell ends after 1 minute, when you lose concentration, or after you've absorbed 1 book or scroll.

\r\n

If you cannot read the language of the source, the spell has no effect. This spell also has no effect on a magical source (such as a tome of understanding or a spell scroll).

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can touch and absorb one more book or scroll for each level above 2nd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":266350,"label":"Eldritch Cloak","description":"

A misty veil radiates from you, masking you and your companions from detection. For the duration, each creature you choose within 30 feet of you (including you) has a +10 bonus to Dexterity (Stealth) checks and can't be tracked except by magical means. A creature that receives this bonus leaves behind no tracks or other traces of its passage but upon leaving the range of the spell a creature affected by it must make another check at disadvantage as they suddenly become more visible.

","sourceId":null},{"id":266934,"label":"Capture Essence","description":"

You can capture the essence of a creature inside a gemstone for use in crafting magic items.

\r\n

The spell requires the target to be deceased, and you must have a gemstone that is grand enough to hold the creature’s essence. The spell takes 5 minutes, must be performed within 5 feet of the creature, and only within 10 minutes of the creature’s death.

\r\n

Powerful creatures have volatile essences. To complete the spell, roll a d20 adding your Spellcasting Ability Modifier. If this beats the CR of the creature, the spell is a success; otherwise the essence is lost. If the gemstone is grand enough to hold the essence, it does not get destroyed. However if the spell is attempted with a gemstone that cannot hold the essence, or on a critical failure, it shatters and both the gemstone and the essence are lost.

\r\n

Once the spell is complete, you have a gemstone enchanted with the creature’s essence. Successfully crafting a magic item that contains this gemstone will imbue the item with abilities that correspond to the creature’s strengths, and on occasion, their weaknesses.

","sourceId":null},{"id":274409,"label":"Sculpt Corpse","description":"

You alter the appearance of a corpse in one of several ways:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Edit Appearance: You mold the appearance of the corpse to look like another creature; you may only copy specific faces if you have a solid understanding of their appearance.

    • \r\n
  • Restore Form: You restore the corpse and bring it back into a more pristine condition - removing any wounds or damages done to it by nature and time.

    • \r\n
  • Doctor Evidence:  You doctor the evidence leading toward this creature's death.

    • \r\n
  • Clean Corpse: You make the corpse presentable.

    • \r\n
  • Remove Flesh: You turn the corpse into a skeleton.

    • \r\n
  • Add Flesh: You turn a skeleton into a full corpse.
    • \r\n
\r\n

At higher levels. When you cast this spell at a higher level, you may use this spell on a number of corpses equal to the level that the spell was cast at.

\r\n","sourceId":null},{"id":282175,"label":"Skill Transfer","description":"

You and a willing humanoid prick your fingers and allow a drop of blood each to mix in a small bowl as you exchange a small essence of yourself. For the next 8 hours you may swap one skill proficiency with another. You use your own modifier for the skill obtained.

\r\n

A skill the humanoid has expertise in cannot be transferred as it is too ingrained to be forgotten. When the spell ends, the skills transfer back in the exhalation of a breath or other manner. This spell can be ended early if both participants are willing.

","sourceId":null},{"id":282283,"label":"Bestow Minor Magicka","description":"

You pluck a strand of hair from your body and wrap it around a willing creatures finger or wrist. Upon completing the spell you reach into their mind and plant the subconscious ability to cast one cantrip from your list of cantrips. The target gains the ability to cast that cantrip using constitution as their spellcasting modifier. This effect ends either once the cantrip is cast or you finish a long rest. 

\r\n

This spell can only be cast on one willing target at a time, and should it be cast a second time the original spell fades from the targets subconscious.

","sourceId":null},{"id":314698,"label":"Bone Armor","description":"

If you are attacked by a melee attack, the attacker must roll a Dexterity save as the spinning bones may hinder the strike. If they fail the save, your Spellcasting Modifier (a minimum of +1) is added to your Armor Class for 1 round as the bones bolster the defense in the direction of the attack.

\r\n

If you are still hit by a melee attack, reduce the damage taken by 2 per casting level. 

\r\n

Bone Armor has 5 charges which are expended when it repels an attack, if cast at a higher level, add 1 more charge per casting level.

","sourceId":null},{"id":315668,"label":"Anesthesia","description":"

You touch one humanoid creature over a span of one minute, after that minute the creature gains the unconscious condition and will not wake up for the spells duration. while unconscious, the creature feels no pain and cannot be brought back to consciousness until the spell ends.

\r\n

unwilling creatures can make a constitution saving throw with disadvantage to resist the spell’s effect

\r\n

When the spell ends for any reason, the creature will gain one level of exhaustion and will regain consciousness. If the creature was already unconscious when cast, their current condition will instead be suspended for the duration of the spell.

\r\n

If this spell is cast onto a creature already under the spell's effects, or the creature is immune to the unconscious condition, the spell automatically fails and no spell slot or material components will be consumed.

","sourceId":null},{"id":383659,"label":"Hamund's Harvesting Hands","description":"

Target a dead creature within range that has a CR of 3 or less.This spell conjures an invisible pair of hands that harvest that creature for any useful materials as listed in their harvesting table. No ability check is required to harvest these materials, the hands automatically succeed in harvesting them, and then place them next to the creature's carcass. You still need to provide any requisite containers such as vials or bags, but the hands harvest all materials in half the time it would normally take. You may direct the hands to harvest certain materials first. Once all of a creatures useful materials have been harvested, the hands disappear.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the CR of the creature harvestable increases by 3 for each spell slot level above 1st

","sourceId":null},{"id":446180,"label":"Dowsing Chain","description":"

A phantom chain with a small ball-like weight appears in the caster's hand. The weight and chain act like a dowsing rod, helping the user locate objects or individuals. The spell caster must state their intent when casting the spell, such as what or who they are trying to locate.

\r\n

If trying to locate a person, the target will make a Dexterity (Stealth) check. In order to remain hidden the check must exceed the caster's Save DC. If the check fails, the spell will be able to locate the target. If it succeeds, the target will remain hidden and the spell will fail.

Once conjured the ball and chain will begin to sway slowly, and as the holder moves closer to their target it will move faster and faster. Once directly next to or standing over their target, the ball will stop moving completely. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":448303,"label":"Construct Helper","description":"

You construct an Inventor's Helper to assist you with your activities.  The tiny construct is magically sentient.

\r\n

Your helper acts independently of you, but it always obeys your commands. In combat, it rolls its own initiative and acts on its own turn. A helper can't attack, but it can take other actions as normal.

\r\n

When the helper drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind a collection of ruined mechanical parts.

\r\n

While your helper is within 100 feet of you, you can communicate with it through the interface in your tinker's tools. Additionally, as an action, you can see through your helper's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of your next turn, gaining the benefits of any special senses that the familiar has. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses.

\r\n

As an action, you can power down your helper. It compresses into a tiny mechanical cube that can be reactivated with an action.

\r\n

You can't have more than one helper at a time. If you cast this spell while you already have a helper, your existing helper is repaired to its original form and settings.

\r\n

Finally, when you cast a spell with a range of touch, your helper can deliver the spell as if it had cast the spell. Your helper must be within 100 feet of you, and it must use its reaction to deliver the spell when you cast it. If the spell requires an attack roll, you use your attack modifier for the roll.

","sourceId":null},{"id":451069,"label":"Hamund's Harvesting Hands","description":"

Target a dead creature within range that has a CR of 3 or less. This spell conjures an invisible pair of hands that harvest a creature for any useful materials as listed in their harvesting table. No ability check is required to harvest these materials, the hands automatically succeed in harvesting them, and then place them next to the creatures carcass. You still need to provide any requisite containers such as vials or bags, but the hands harvest all materials in half the time it would normally take. You may direct the hands to harvest certain materials first. Once all of the creature's useful materials have been harvested, the hands disappear.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the CR of the creature harvestable increases by 3 for each slot level above 1st.

","sourceId":null},{"id":461615,"label":"Murmur's Massive Mending","description":"

As you cast the spell, you draw a transmutation circle on the ground up to 5 ft in diameter, and select a time up to 5 years in the past using the pocket watch. 

\r\n

This spell attempts to reconstitute entities of your choice within a 5-foot-high cylinder centred on the transmutation circle (The cylinder diameter is defined by the transmutation circle) to the state they were in at a select time in the past.

\r\n

Once the spell has been cast, the entities will be repaired over the next minute. This process can only be stopped if the transmutation circle is dispelled. If the caster concentrates on the spell for it's duration, they can choose materials that they can see within range equivalent to double the material missing from the entities. These materials are consumed by the spell over it's duration. If the caster is not concentrating on the spell or chooses incorrect/insufficient materials, the transmutation circle pulls in compatible material from within 120 ft. If no material is found, the spell fails, and your pocket watch breaks. It can be repaired over a long rest.

\r\n

The spell cannot extract materials from an unwilling creature or restore magic to an entity.

\r\n

As part of the casting, make a spellcasting ability check. This will determine what materials can be transmuted by the spell. A check of 20 is required to reproduce complex information such as writing or artwork.

\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
MaterialDifficulty
Cloth, Paper, RopeDC 6
Crystal, Glass, IceDC 8
Wood, BoneDC 10
StoneDC 13
Iron, SteelDC 17
MithralDC 21
AdamantineDC 25
\r\n

If a creature starts it's turn in the path of the repair process, it must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking up to 2d10 force damage (At the DM's discretion) on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the casting time increases by 10 minutes, the inflicted necrotic/force damage is increased by 1d10, the height of the cylinder and maximum diameter of the transmutation circle increase by 15 ft, and the maximum time displacement of the target state is doubled, for each slot level above 1st.

\r\n

A note on material compatibility. The materials used must have come from the same raw material as that which you are trying to repair. For example, you can reconstitute the missing half of an iron banded barrel using a broken wooden bookshelf, and an iron sword. Mending living entities can be tricky as the only compatible material is other parts of that same entity. When reconstituting part of a living entity using another part of it’s form, they receive no healing, instead taking 4d10 necrotic damage (Halved if the caster is concentrating on the spell). “Sometimes it's worth losing a hand to reattach an arm.”

","sourceId":null},{"id":474178,"label":"Climate Adaptation (Homebrew)","description":"

Choose up to 10 creatures that you can see

\r\n

A creature under the effect of this spell can is treated as resistant to Extreme Hot and Extreme Cold environments. They are not however granted resistance to Fire or Cold Damage whilst under this spell.

\r\n

This spell also does not grant the ability to breathe underwater, nor does it solve the strain of extreme altitudes. This simply solves the problem of extreme temperatures.

\r\n
\r\n

The Homebrew title is just for relevancy within my own campaigns, for the DM to decide whether or not to allow the spell.

\r\n

When the casting is complete, the chosen creature's skin becomes translucent, revealing any broken bones,  foreign objects, or trauma to the creatures body. The spell also reveals any poison or cures affecting the creature's body but does not reveal how to remove it. While this spell is active on the creature, any medicine check to help them is made with advantage.

","sourceId":null},{"id":495179,"label":"Blightwood's Lightened Load","description":"

","sourceId":null},{"id":502040,"label":"Create and Destroy Air","description":"

You either create or destroy air.

\r\n

Create Air

\r\n

You replace, replenish, and refresh the air in a personal air envelope for 10 minutes for any creature within range, including air poisoned/tained by spells such as Cloudkill and Stinking Cloud. This does not create a larger in size envelope, but simply replenishes the air in the envelope that the creature drags with it. If the air is fouled, the air turns fresh again and the air timer resets to 10 minutes. If used within a spell or effect that causes a cloud (similar to the Fog Cloud, Cloudkill and Stinking Cloud spells) the creature is allowed an immediate save against the effects of the spell.

\r\n

Destroy Air

\r\n

The air envelope of a target creature within range immediately is reduced to Fouled status, with all effects of Fouled status. If air is already Fouled status, this spell has no effect.

\r\n

At higher levels

\r\n

When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you may target one additional creature for each slot above 1st.

","sourceId":null},{"id":513742,"label":"Time Pause","description":"

You briefly stop the flow of time for everyone but yourself. No time passes for other creatures, while you take 1 another turn right after whoever is next in the infinitive. During which, you cant use actions or move as normal. You can only take any action but attacking or casting a spell. If you do any thing, it will have appeared to other creatures as if it was done very fast. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":516368,"label":"Lesser Shapechange","description":"

You assume the form of a different creature for the duration. The new form can be of any creature with a challenge rating equal to your level or lower. The creature can't be a construct or an undead, and you must have seen the sort of creature at least once. You transform into an average example of that creature, one without any class levels or the Spellcasting trait.

\r\n

Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the chosen creature, though you retain your alignment and Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiencies, in addition to gaining those of the creature. If the creature has the same proficiency as you and the bonus listed in its statistics is higher than yours, use the creature's bonus in place of yours. You can't use any legendary actions or lair actions of the new form.

\r\n

You don't retain the benefit of any features from your class, race, or other source and can use them. You can only speak if the creature can normally speak.

\r\n

When you transform, you choose whether your equipment falls to the ground, merges into the new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal. During this spell's duration, you can use your action to assume a different form following the same restrictions and rules for the original form, with one exception: if your new form has more hit points than your current one, your hit points remain at their current value.

","sourceId":null},{"id":527857,"label":"Restore","description":"

This is the spell that people think Mending is. This spell repairs and restores large to huge objects such as a broken statue to its original state. The spell can fully restore objects such as a 20 foot tall statue and a 20 foot by 20 foot area of broken buildings or bridges. Using the spell on something like burned documents restores the documents but cannot restore the writing that was on them.

\r\n

This spell can physically repair a magic item or construct, but the spell can't restore magic to such an object.

","sourceId":null},{"id":528653,"label":"Monstrous Summoning","description":"

You summon a monster in a space near you. It can be any from the monster manual, but its CR must be equal to or less than half your character level plus your spellcasting ability modifier. The monster is under your control and obeys your commands. The monster remains until it is killed, or until you dismiss it. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":539377,"label":"Create Air Envelope","description":"

This spell creates an envelope of air, surrounding the caster, that lasts for 10 minutes in a planetary body with or without air. Within the phlogiston or on a spelljammer ship, the air lasts for 3 days. This spells isolates a volume of air from its surroundings. The \"barrier\" it forms offers only the slightest resistance to any person or thing that travels through it. All the barrier does is keep the air inside of it from mixing with the air outside.

\r\n

For instance, a volume of air would be unaffected even if the Stinking Cloud was cast near it. It would also keep the noxious gas inside if it the spell was cast there. If cast while underwater, the envelope of air would rise to the surface, leaving any creatures who were inside of it where they are.

\r\n

Also, it allows spells and other effects requiring air to function. However, if a burning fire is within the envelope, any remaining time is reduced by half.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, increase its duration within the phlogiston or on a spelljammer ship by one month (30 days) for each slot level above 1st.

","sourceId":null},{"id":547922,"label":"Decipher","description":"

The caster can decipher hidden messages they hear or read for the duration.

","sourceId":null},{"id":550715,"label":"Astral Bookshelf","description":"

A medium sized 3ft by 3ft bookshelf materializes in front of the caster. For the duration of the spell you may take an action to add or remove books from the bookshelf. When the bookshelf is dispelled all books on the shelf are safely transported into an extra dimensional space.

The bookshelf can hold 27 tomes or 54 small books/pamphlets.

","sourceId":null},{"id":561040,"label":"Unseen Crafter","description":"

This lesser variant of Unseen Servant spell is a boon to artificers and wizards who spend their time creating magic items.  This spell functions as Unseen Servant except that it will only work on crafting items or magic items associated with the artisan’s tools or kit used for the material component of the spell.  The Unseen Crafter will never move more than 25 feet away from the item it is crafting.

\r\n

 

\r\n

The Unseen Crafter is consider proficient in the use of the artisan’s tools or kit and can produce an item on its own provided it has sufficient materials and an appropriate work space.  The Unseen Crafter’s work can also be combined with the spellcaster’s proficiency to reduce crafting time and grant Advantage on any associated skill checks.

\r\n

 

\r\n

The Unseen Crafter will harmlessly dissipate when the item it is crafting is completed, the Unseen Crafter is more than 25 feet from the item it is crafting, or the spellcaster casts the spell again.
