","sourceId":null},{"id":3265,"label":"Burrow","description":"

\"Ever had roast armadillo my dear apprentice?\"
\"No sir, can't say I have. Sounds rather... tough.\"
\"Indeed. However, much like castles, I think you'll find it's a matter of finding the softer underbelly.\"

\r\n

You touch a willing creature. You imbue the target with magic allowing it to part earth, sand, mud, or ice, giving it a burrowing speed of 10 feet. The spell does not allow creatures to burrow through solid rock. While burrowing, a creature can breathe normally and leaves a tunnel behind them, large enough for a creature the same size to travel through prone.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":3301,"label":"Spellsteal","description":"

\"Stop fireballing yourself, stop fireballing yourself\"

\r\n

If a creature is casting a 1st level spell,  you may use your reaction to redirect and siphon the spell. Any material components required for the spell are consumed from the creature casting it and that creature loses a spell slot like normal. If you have stolen a spell, you can cast it on your next turn without requiring materials, without having known the spell, and without using a spell slot. If you do not cast the spell by the end of your next turn, the spell fails with no effects.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. The level of spells that can be stolen increases by 1 for every level of spell slot above 4th used.

","sourceId":null},{"id":3401,"label":"Unburn","description":"

When you cast this spell, an unnaturally cold but harmless fire erupts from your hands. Choose one of the following options.

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Restore Corpse. You target the majority of what's left of a burned, charred, cremated, dismembered, or dissolved corpse or the remains of a corpse of a Large or smaller creature that has been dead for no longer than 48 hours. The fire erupts from the remains and assembles an undamaged, intact corpse of the targeted creature. The fire cleans the body, closes all wounds, restores lost limbs, and neutralizes any poison or disease that was affecting the creature when it died.
    • \r\n
  • Recover Scriptures. You target an area that's no larger than 15 ft. in any dimension that contains burned, charred, destroyed, or dissolved papers, scrolls, books, and parchment. The fire will restore such items to their original, untarnished form in its entirety. This will not restore any magic contained in the scripture or images of such items.
    • \r\n
  • Reverse Rust. You target up to three of the following within range that have been destroyed or damaged, whether by misuse or by a harmful effect (such as a rust monster's Rust Metal ability); weapons, pieces of ammunition, armors, shields. The fire cleanses the objects of damage, and restores them to working order.
    • \r\n
\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th or higher, each spell option changes. Restore Corpse can target an additional corpse that's within range for each slot level above 3rd. Recover Scriptures can target an area that's 5 ft. larger in each dimension for each slot level above 3rd. Reverse Rust can target an addition weapon, armor, shield, or piece of ammunition for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":5528,"label":"Malferius's Grasp","description":"

Make a melee spell attack against a creature you can reach. On a hit, the target takes 3d10 necrotic damage. If this damage would being the creature to 0 HP, it makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failure it dies, and becomes a primed corpse. You can detonate a primed corpse with a verbal command, all creatures within 15 ft must make a dex save, 3d6 dmg, half damage on save.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the initial damage increases by 1d10 for each slot level above 1st.

","sourceId":null},{"id":6131,"label":"Tutor","description":"

A caster begins the spell by holding the material component and repeating the desire for the knowledge/experience sought. Gestures are used for emphasis and to indicate the target.

\r\n

Before casting the spell, the caster must keep in their mind what knowledge/experience is sought specifically. Vague requests will result in random knowledge/experience possibly retrieved. When casting the spell, the caster must target an individual and establish a link between the individual and the material component. The target makes a wisdom saving throw. If they fail, they are unaware of the spell. Roll a d20 roll to see how much is recorded from the target. Keep in mind that a target may have some, none, or all of the knowledge and experience the caster seeks. If they have none of the experience and knowledge that the caster seeks then the spell fails at this point (they still might know who cast the spell depending on the previous saving throw).

\r\n
    \r\n
  • A one through fives results in very little recorded.
    • \r\n
  • Six through ten results in recording in the material component enough information for someone to become an amateur (if the target posses at least that level of competency).
    • \r\n
  • Eleven through fifteen records you enough a competent level of information (again assuming they have at least that level of competency).
    • \r\n
  • Sixteen through nineteen records the full information and experience of the target.
    • \r\n
  • On a critical roll not only is the record of the knowledge/experience sought created but also mystically added is additional information and experience that the target might not even have had. 
    • \r\n
\r\n

At this point the spell itself is considered complete. The material components become magical items containing the knowledge/experience sought.

\r\n

The information/experience sought is contained either in the book or the crystal. Any individual may attempt to gain the the contents. Holding the material component with bare hands results in the knowledge/experience being transferred into the holder's mind at a rate equal to their ability to learn. The holder must make a wisdom saving throw against a simulated spell dc based on the type of information sought. The chart below will tell how to calculate the dice roll to beat. On a failure the holder will suffer one level of exhaustion and be unable to learn what is contained in the magical material component . On a critical failure the holder suffers an additional level of exhaustion in addition to learning nothing. Subsequent attempts can be made but run the risk of higher levels of exhaustion (up to and eventually including killing oneself). Once the information is successfully transferred, the material component becomes non-magical and loses whatever records it has on it. If the holder wants to avoid exhaustion they can also wear gloves and 1.) in the case of the book, simply read the content written and attempt to understand through written word the target's experience/knowledge or 2.) in the case of the crystal, look through the crystal and see the memories as the target remembers them and also hear the sounds as well. In both cases the experience/knowledge isn't directly transferred and therefore only a little of the information can be understood per day. A lifetime of experience resulting in masterful ability would require a lifetime to comprehend fully this way but roughly the equivalent of six months to a year of studying the crystal or book could lead the holder to achieve proficiency instead without the need to pay anyone (except in terms of using the material component) or convince anyone to become a teacher.

\r\n

For every spell slot above third level used to cast this spell, the holder of the magical component can subtract an additional one from the below calculation. (A higher level caster is better at casting the spell and therefore the transfer from whomever is holding the magical component has an easier time with the information/knowledge/or experience contained being transferred). An individual who has benefited from this spell in the past incurs a penalty of adding +4 to the below calculation for each time they have gained some knowledge as a result of this spell as their magical resistance to the spell increases each time they are successfully exposed. There is no way to get around this penalty even if the holder's mind is wiped as the penalty is permanent in nature.

\r\n

Spell DC calculation:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • If the experience/knowledge is physical in nature calculate (18-proficiency bonus)-strength or dexterity modifier
    • \r\n
  • If the experience/knowledge is skill based then take the skill and whatever bonus applies to it by (18-proficiency bonus)-skill's ability modifier (example: stealth would lead to adding your dexterity modifier)
    • \r\n
  • If the experience/knowledge is related to the arcane, complicated reasoning, science, math, etc then apply (18-proficiency bonus)-intelligence modifier
    • \r\n
  • If the experience is spiritual, religious, or otherwise relates to comprehension and understanding of some kind then apply (18-proficiency bonus)-wisdom modifier
    • \r\n
  • If the experience is artistic, political, relationship, or something else then apply (18-proficiency bonus)-charisma modifier.
    • \r\n
\r\n

Example: A Bard who plays a harp wants to learn a new instrument, and casts Tutor on another Bard who knows the flute. He attains a competent amount of information in the crystal he used for the spell and his fellow Bard fails his wisdom saving throw and is therefore none the wiser. The bard (who is wearing gloves) takes his crystal someplace quiet and attempts to touch it after taking one glove off. His charisma is 16 and he is level 5 so he will roll a d20 and needs to beat (18-3)-3 which is 12. He rolls and makes it with a 13 on his d20. He learns how to play a flute with an average competency level (nothing to write home about but enough to entertain a bit). If he had rolled a anywhere from a two to a ten he would have suffered one level of exhaustion. The bard then decides to do it again with a different entertainer who plays the piano but this time he must beat a 16 because of the penalty(4+12). Again, the entertainer fails his wisdom saving throw.  The bard is again also the holder as he takes it off someplace private. He rolls a 16 for his d20. On a tie, nothing happens meaning no information is learned but no exhaustion occurs either. He rolls again, and this time he rolls a nine which results in one level of exhaustion. He decides to quit while he is ahead and takes a long rest. After a long rest, he rolls again and this time gets nineteen. The bard is now able to play the piano, harp, and flute, but next time he uses the spell and holds the created magical object with his bare hands he will suffer a +8 penalty and therefore must overcome ((18-3)-3) +8 which is twenty and therefore impossible for him to overcome (the best he can hope for is a tie) unless he gains levels or increases his ability score in some way. He can still cast the spell and give or sell the magical material component to someone else.

","sourceId":null},{"id":7460,"label":"Diving Orb","description":"

You create a bubble of air that can propel you and your allies through water. When you cast this spell, you create a bubble that encases you and up to four Medium-sized creatures standing within 5 feet of you. While the spell persists, you gain a swimming speed of 30 feet, and the magical air of the bubble allows you to breathe normally. Allied creatures inside the bubble can use their reaction to travel with it, staying within 5 feet of you whenever you move using this swimming speed.

\r\n

Creatures traveling through water in the bubble are not considered to be immersed in that water.

\r\n

When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the duration increases by 1 hour for each slot level above 3rd.

\r\n

 

\r\n

\"With this magic, no longer will we be confined by the sea. The secrets of Panaquia shall soon be our plunder.\" -High Weaver Nadir

","sourceId":null},{"id":7920,"label":"Burrow","description":"

You touch a willing creature. The target gains a burrowing speed of 60 feet for the duration. When the spell ends, the target is stuck if it is burrowing.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":8915,"label":"Toxic Orbs","description":"

You create eighteen tiny balls of poison in your space.  They float in the air and orbit you for the spell’s duration.  When you cast the spell—and as a bonus action on each of your turns thereafter—you can expend one to four of the balls, sending them streaking toward a point or points you choose within 120 feet of you. Once a ball reaches its destination or impacts against a solid surface, it explodes. Each creature within 5 feet of the point where the ball explodes must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 1d4 poison damage on a failed save, or no damage on a successful one.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the number of balls created increases by six for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":13395,"label":"Agitate Wounds","description":"

You choose one creature that you see within range that is not at full hit points and magically force it to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failure, that creature’s wounds open and bleed profusely and it takes 2d6 damage from blood loss. On each subsequent turn, the creature must make a new saving throw or take damage equal to your spellcasting attribute modifier (minimum 1 point). This effect ends if the creature succeeds at three saving throws (these do not need to be successive) or is treated with healing magic or by nonmagical means, such as with a healer’s kit.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":23405,"label":"Shred Veins","description":"

You manifest razor-edged shards of metal in the veins of all creatures in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you can see within range.  A target must make a Constitution saving throw, taking 2d8 necrotic damage and 4d8 slashing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.  A creature that rolls a natural 1 on its saving throw is also blinded until it regains all hit points lost to this spell. 

\r\n

The metal shards dissipate into nothingness after the damage is dealt. 

\r\n

This spell has no effect on undead or constructs. 

\r\n

At Higher Levels.  When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the slashing damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":28727,"label":"Curse of the Putrid Husk","description":"

This illusion forces the subject to believe his flesh is rotting and falling off his body, and that his internal organs are spilling out. If the target fails his Wisdom saving throw, he is horrified during his next round, suffers from the stunned condition, and takes 1d8 necrotic and 1d8 psychic damage. During each of the end of the target’s turns, the target can repeat his Wisdom saving throw (the difficulty of the saving throw decreases by 1 every round). Also, when the target takes damage, he can repeat his Wisdom saving throw with disadvantage (this is because the damage may contradict with the illusion - for instance, the damage inflicted may cause pain in an arm that the target believes has already rotted off). If the target succeeds on any of these saves, the spell ends. If he fails, he again takes the damage listed above and remains horrified (stunned).

","sourceId":null},{"id":30036,"label":"Eternal Librarian","description":"

Once the spell is cast it will not dispell until it has found all that you are looking for or until the book is full. The book will follow you or remain dormant during your downtime. If you approach books (a library for example) it will write down any information it finds on what you have requested. It can also serve as a journal writing or making sketches for you to go back to. Upon reaching a large source of knowledge you can give it a command to wander freely. After doing so the book and pen will take off and on its own accord. Not to worry once it is finished it will return to you. You may also make it return by speaking another command. Once the book is full the pen will dispell and the book will come to rest in your hands. You may put the book on a shelf in your private quarters or sanctuary. Before laying to rest you must give this book a name. After naming the book, you may speak its name to bring it to life and have it bring itself to you. Where it will present itself for your request of knowledge. if it contains said knowledge it will instantly flip to the page presenting you with your request. The book is only able to write in the language it finds the information in. For example, if an elf where to tell it to find information on fire, and it finds information but in draconic, it will be written in draconic. In order for this elf to then read it, he or she would have to either learn draconic or to find someone either in the party or an NPC to read it for them. This spell was originally created by ArchMage Fauhtz as a way of making his research easier. He has been known to set these books free in his mega library to find the material he so chooses. Or in many cases, he has assigned a name to previously written books. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":30613,"label":"Build","description":"

Choose an area of terrain no larger than 100 feet on a side within range. You can reshape available stones, earth, and clay, in the area in any manner you choose for the duration. You can raise or lower the area's elevation, create or fill in a trench, erect or flatten a wall, or form a pillar. The extent of any such changes can't exceed half the area's largest dimension. So, if you affect a 100-foot square, you can create a pillar up to 50 feet high, raise or lower the square's elevation by up to 50 feet, dig a trench up to 50 feet deep, and so on. It takes 10 minutes for these changes to complete.

\r\n

At the end of every 10 minutes you spend concentrating on the spell, you can choose a new area of terrain to affect.

\r\n

Because the terrain's transformation occurs slowly, creatures in the area can't usually be trapped or injured by the ground's movement.

\r\n

This spell dose not affect nature.

\r\n

Similarly, this spell doesn't directly affect plant growth. The moved earth carries any plants along with it.

","sourceId":null},{"id":32307,"label":"Conjure Minor Fiends","description":"

You summon fiends that appear in unoccupied spaces that you can see within range. If you decide to summon a mixture of devils and demons, you must have both the meat and charcoal when casting this spell. Choose one of the following options for what appears:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • One fiend of challenge rating 2 or lower
    • \r\n
  • Two fiends of challenge rating 1 or lower
    • \r\n
  • Four fiends of challenge rating 1/2 or lower
    • \r\n
  • Eight fiends of challenge rating 1/4 or lower
    • \r\n
\r\n

Each fiend disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The summoned creatures are friendly to you and your companions. Roll initiative for the summoned creatures as a group, which has its own turns. They loosely obey verbal commands that you issue to them (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to them, they defend themselves against hostile creatures, but may also take actions that might not be wanted and lead to mischief.

\r\n

The DM has the fiends' statistics.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using certain higher-level spell slots, you choose one of the summoning options above, and more creatures appear: twice as many with a 5th-level slot, three times as many with a 7th-level slot, and four times as many with a 9th-level slot.

","sourceId":null},{"id":32827,"label":"Stolen Vitality","description":"

Bolstering yourself with a necromantic facsimile of life, a target creature you have damaged in the last minute makes a wisdom saving throw.

\r\n

On a failed saving throw,The creature loses 4d4 temporary hit points for the duration of the spell and you gain temporary hit points equal to the amount the creature lost. Additionally, choose one of the following:

\r\n

1) The creature loses 1d4 temporary strength, dexterity, or constitution for the duration of the spell and you gain temporary strength equal to the amount the creature lost.

\r\n

2) The creature unwillingly informs you of opportunity providing your allies advantage against it for the duration of the spell.

\r\n

On a successful saving throw, you lose 2d4 temporary hit points for the duration of the spell and the target gains temporary hit points equal to the amount you lost.

\r\n

 

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you gain 10 additional temporary hit points for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":40832,"label":"Optimized Combat","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

By use of this spell, the caster manipulates time so that the recipient gains more use out of a single combat round. The creature does not move faster, but rather accellerates their ability to perceive and react.  This extra awareness and control grants multiple bonuses. Such an effected creature has previously been described as performing the most graceful and fluid of deadly dances, as every single movement is perfectly utilized to its fullest combat potential.

\r\n

The target gains 1 extra melee attack for every 5 caster levels (up to four total attacks). Also, a +1 bonus is applied to the target's Initiative and AC, and enemies get Disadvantage against being surprised by the target, due to the extra attention that they can pay to fine details. This spell is not cumulative with itself or any other spell granting extra attacks. Also, it does not allow for casting of extra spells per round, or the extra use of magical items.

\r\n

The material component required is a drop of mercury.

\r\n

Based on 2e AD&D spell Melee Manager, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40834,"label":"Extension","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

By use of an Extension spell, the caster prolongs the duration of a single previously cast 1st-, 2nd-, or 3rd-level spell by 50%. Thus, a Levitation spell can be made to function up to 15 minutes (rather than 10), a Hold Person spell made to work for up to 90 seconds (rather than 60), etc. Naturally, the spell affects only spells that have a duration. This spell must be cast immediately after the target spell which the caster wishes to extend, either by the original caster (extend one's own spells) or another spellcaster (extend someone else's spell). If one full round or more elapses between the target spell's casting and the casting of Extension, it cannot be extended, and this spell fails, and its slot wasted.

\r\n

At Higher Levels:
4th level slot - This spell is the same as the 3rd-level slot Extension spell, except it extends the duration of 1st-through 4th-level spells by 50%.
5th level slot - This spell is the same as the 3rd-level slot Extension spell, except that it will extend the duration of 1st- through 3rd-level spells by 100%, and will extend the duration of 4th- and 5th-level spells by 50%.

\r\n

Inspired by the 2e AD&D Wizard spells Extension I, Extension II, and Extension III.

","sourceId":null},{"id":40835,"label":"Lifeline Tether","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

When this spell is cast on a creature of Intelligence 2 or greater, it fastens a magical tether to the creature's lifeline. The creature must be close enough for the caster to recognize it by sight, and it can attempt a Wisdom save to avoid the effect. This sets the range at 60 yards for typical conditions. Items such as Eyes of the Eagle would extend this range, but psionic powers like Clairvoyance or any type of scrying would not.

\r\n

If the caster slips to the demiplane of time, he appears next to the affected creature's lifeline. The tether is seen as a thin white cord linking it and the caster. As with Timeslip, a large amount of turbulence may displace the caster, but they remain tethered to that lifeline. If Lifeline Tether is cast directly on a lifeline, no save is permitted. Slipping back to reality places the caster within 1d100 x 10 yards of the creature.

\r\n

Casting Detect Temporal Anomaly always leads the caster right to the tethered creature. This application is useful for finding out who a particular lifeline belongs to.

\r\n

The material component is a 1-foot length of cord braided with strands of silver.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell Life Tether, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40837,"label":"Create Minor Paradox","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Range: 2 rounds into the past / level

\r\n

When this spell is cast, the caster may take back an action performed sometime within the last 2 rounds per caster level, or insert an additional action if timing permits. The caster could take back something said, or decide not to kiss the king's daughter. They could NOT insert another attack into a combat round (unless an attack was intentionally skipped during the target round), but COULD insert an attack into the round BEFORE combat.

\r\n

If an action is taken back that would've prevented combat (insulting the goblin king) or another major event, the caster and DM will need to work out a reasonable course of events that would make up for that lost time.

\r\n

Turbulence created by this spell has a 1% per round affected chance of attracting a Time Demielemental or Chronomancer guardian from the demiplane of time.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell Minor Paradox, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40838,"label":"Time Loop","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Enchantment)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

Upon casting this spell, the caster creates a time loop in the creature's mind that causes it to repeat this round's action indefinitely. If the creature attacked, it attacks the same person again. If it drank a potion, it drinks from the same bottle again. Even if something happens to prevent this attempt (eg. the opponent is dead, or someone takes the bottle away), the subject still strives to repeat its last action.

\r\n

The victim gains a Wisdom save at the end of every round it is affected by the spell, until the loop is broken. Starting with the second saving throw, the creature gains a cumulative +1 bonus to this save every round.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell Time Snare, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40839,"label":"Undo","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

In reaction to the sudden demise of an ally in sight, to the caster receiving lethal damage, or to the destruction or loss of some highly valued object, the caster immediately winds time back a single round inside a space no larger than a 10 foot cube containing the fateful subject, allowing the caster or his allies to correct a single fatal mistake. The reason this spell can reverse a death, while other time spells such as Timeheal cannot, is because this spell is necessarily used in the moments of death, while the lifeline of the dying individual has not yet terminated; their life force has not fully departed.

\r\n

Use of this spell causes turbulence in the demiplane of time and has a 10% chance of attracting attention from its inhabitants.

\r\n

The material component of this spell is a zircon gem.

\r\n

This spell is an original work.

","sourceId":null},{"id":45811,"label":"Ockham's Razor","description":"

You manipulate air into a vibrating razor-like edge and with a cutting motion fling the blade towards the target at extremely high speed.  The target must make a Dexterity saving throw, on a failed save the target takes 4d12 slashing damage, or half as much damage on a successful one.

\r\n

When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d12 for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":46131,"label":"Arcane Carriage Disk","description":"

This spell creates a circular, horizontal plane of force, 5 feet in diameter and 1 inch thick, that floats 3 feet above the ground in a space of your choice that you can see within range. If the space is occupied the disc appears flat along the ground below and rises up to the 3 feet lifting what was on it. If that which was on it cannot be lifted such as being too heavy (greater than 500 lbs) or fixed in place the spell fails but the spell slot is not wasted. When created the disk remains for the duration, and can hold up to 500 pounds. If more weight is placed on it then it cannot move and if the total weight exceeds 1,000 lbs the spell ends, and everything on the disk falls to the ground.

\r\n

The disk has 3 modes: follow, control, elevation. You can use a bonus action to change the mode. It begins in follow mode unless you choose otherwise (for example you can create a disk in elevation mode allowing you to create it in the air up to 100 feet above the ground - useful if you need to descend safely from a great height).

\r\n

Follow mode:

For this mode the disk must be within 1 to 3 feet from the ground. It cannot enter this mode if it is outside of these limits. In this mode the disk is immobile while you are within 20 feet of it. If you are, or you move, more than 20 feet away from it, the disk follows you so that it remains within 20 feet of you. It can move across uneven terrain, up or down stairs, slopes and the like, but it can’t cross an elevation change of 10 feet or more. For example, the disk can’t move across a 10-foot-deep pit, nor could it leave such a pit if it was created at the bottom. If you move more than 100 feet from the disk (typically because it can’t move around an obstacle to follow you), the spell ends.

\r\n

Control mode:

For this mode the disk must be within 1 to 3 feet from the ground. It cannot enter this mode if it is outside of these limits. In this mode the disk is immobile unless you use your action to move it. With your action you can move it up to 30 feet and this movement follows the same rules as in the follow mode. You cannot actively move the disk a distance that would make it greater than 100 feet from you. If you move more than 100 feet from the disk the spell ends. If you move the disk to a space where the ground is greater than 10 feet below you can do so only by combining it with your bonus action to immediately change it to Elevation mode otherwise the move attempt fails.

\r\n

Elevation mode:

\r\n

In this mode the disk is immobile unless you use your action to move it. With your action you can move it up to 30 feet but can only move it up or down in a straight line. You cannot move it beyond 100 feet of the ground or from you. When not being moved it remains at the current elevated level until you move it again or the spell ends. If the spell ends (except as a result of too much weight described above) while in Elevation mode the disk remains and you cannot control it as the disk falls evenly at a rate of 60 feet per round until it is within 3 feet of a solid surface and then disappears causing whatever was on it to fall. While in this mode you can use your action to move the disk 5 feet to the side to be over ground if you combine it with your bonus action to switch to Control mode.

\r\n

For any mode, while the disk remains you may also use your action to end the spell early.

","sourceId":null},{"id":46397,"label":"Lung Spout","description":"

Make a ranged spell attack against a creature within 30ft. The fluid in its throat, lungs and stomach becomes enchanted with a sickening energy, leaking upwards out of its nostrils or mouth into a sphere of bile and stomach juices about a tenth of its size. The orb of bile follows the target doggedly, floating around 1ft above its head, even if the target is invisible. Anything coming into contact with this sphere takes 2d6 acid damage.

\r\n

For the duration of the spell, the creature shivers uncontrollably as its throat parches and its body weakens, and it has disadvantage on constitution saving throws. Any attack rolls against the creature have advantage. When the spell's effect ends, the orb of bile is dropped on the target, and it must make a dexterity save. On a failed save, it takes 2d6 acid damage.

\r\n

At higher levels: When this spell is cast using a slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each level above the 3rd

","sourceId":null},{"id":61025,"label":"Strangulate","description":"

An invisible hand of death grabs a creature’s throat and begins strangling them. The target makes a Constitution saving throw. If it fails, the target takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage, is restrained, and can’t speak or breathe.

\r\n

   On each subsequent turn, you may use a bonus action to continue the spell. If you do, the creature takes 1d6 necrotic damage and makes a Constitution saving throw. On a successful save, or if you don’t use your bonus action to continue the spell, the effect ends.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the initial damage increases by 2d6 for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":69839,"label":"Rusting Touch","description":"

Make a melee spell attack against one creature within range. On a hit, all metal objects being worn or carried by the target become brittle and covered in rust. Non-magical armor affected by this spell suffer a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to AC. If the AC of armor drops below 10 the armor is destroyed. Non-magical weapons affected by this spell suffer a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to attack and damage rolls. If the penalty ever becomes -5, the weapon is destroyed. Any other non-magical metal object being worn or carried by the target immediately turns into a pile of rust and is destroyed. 

\r\n

The rust created by this spell is non-magical and is not affected by spells like dispel magic. However, a lesser restoration spell removes all rust and penalties from one weapon or piece of armor. 

\r\n

When casting this spell as a ritual, you may not target armor, weapons, or objects that are being worn or carried.

","sourceId":null},{"id":69961,"label":"Merochite's Arcane Embroidery","description":"

You stitch an arcane pattern into a piece of clothing. Choose a damage type: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder. For the next 24 hours, the embroidered item grants its wearer resistance to that damage type.

\r\n

If the clothing being embroidered already grants resistance to your chosen damage type, the spell fails. If it is otherwise a magical item with one enchantment on it, you must make a successful DC 15 check with your spellcasting ability. Add 1 to the DC for each subsequent preexisting enchantment. (So, for instance, if you start with a Cloak of Elvenkind, and wish to add one type of damage resistance to it, the DC is 15. If after that you wish to add another damage resistance type, the DC goes up to 16, and so forth. If you start with a plain nonmagical cloak, there is no check for the first damage resistance type, and a DC 15 check for the second, DC 16 for the third.)  On a successful check, the item grants the resistance in addition to its preexisting effects. On a failed check, the spell fails, and the materials are still consumed. Additionally, if this is your first time casting the spell with the specified resistance on this item, on a critical failure the item's existing magical properties are lost. Subsequent castings to extend the same pattern and make the spell permanent do not run the risk of destroying previous enchantments, though they can still fail harmlessly.

\r\n

You may only cast this spell on a given item once per day. If you successfully cast this spell on the same item 10 times, adding onto the initial pattern each time, the effect becomes permanent and the clothing is now considered a magical item. (These castings need not be on consecutive days.) Unless the item already requires attunement, it does not require attunement after the spell is made permanent.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell at 5th level or higher, you may choose to grant resistance to radiant or necrotic damage instead.

","sourceId":null},{"id":72801,"label":"Pestilent Breath","description":"

You unleash a torrent of sickly green bile from your mouth in a 30-foot cone in a direction you choose. All creatures within range must succeed a Dexterity saving throw. Creatures suffer 4d6 poison damage, 4d6 acid damage and become poisoned. Creatures that succeed the save suffer half damage and do not become poisoned for one minute. Creatures who fail the saving throw also suffer a further 2d6 acid damage at the start of their next turn.

\r\n

You can also cast this spell at 6th and 9th level. At 6th level, you deal 6d6 poison damage and 6d6 acid damage. At 9th level, this spell deals 8d6 poison damage and 8d6 acid damage and creatures automatically become poisoned regardless of their saving throw.

","sourceId":null},{"id":77156,"label":"Minor Wild Shape","description":"

This spell transforms you into any small or medium beast whose challenge rating is less than or equal to 1/4. The beast cannot have a fly or swim speed. 

\r\n

The transformation lasts for the duration, or until you drop to 0 hit points or die.  Your game statistics, excluding mental ability scores, are replaced by the statistics of the chosen beast. You retain you alignment and personality.

\r\n

You assume the hit points of your new form. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before transforming. If you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. As long as the excess damage doesn't reduce your normal form to 0 hit points, you aren't knocked unconscious.

\r\n

You are limited in the actions you can perform in beast shape by the nature of your new form. You can't speak, cast spells, or take any other action that requires hands or speech.

\r\n

Your gear melds into the new form. You can't activate, use, wield, or otherwise benefit from any of your equipment.

","sourceId":null},{"id":78153,"label":"Thought to Action","description":"

With great mental focus and a powerful expenditure of will, you create a small magical effect within range by thought alone.  The effects of this spell are subtle and easy to miss, a creature's passive perception (or its Wisdom(perception) check, if it is actively watching for it) must meet or exceed your spell save DC for that creature to notice that a spell has been cast and you are the caster.  

\r\n

Chose one of the following effects:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • You extinguish a flame no bigger than a torch.
    • \r\n
  • You ignite a flammable object with a flame the size of a candle's.  The inherent flammability of the object you chose to ignite, along with the availability of further fuel and oxygen will determine whether or not the fire spreads or goes out.  
    • \r\n
  • You cause one small object to break or tear, such as a key ring, a belt loop, or a length of rope.
    • \r\n
  • You manipulate a small object to turn, slide along a surface, or be pushed or pulled.  The object must fit within a 1ft cube and can weigh no more than 1 pound.
    • \r\n
  • You create a harsh flash of magical energy that deals 1d4 acid, cold, fire, lightning, necrotic, radiant, or thunder damage (your choice) to a creature or object. 
    • \r\n
  • You create a short harmless sensory effect such as the sound of breaking glass, a pungent odor, or a brief flash of light.  You can make the source of this effect appear to be up to 50ft away from you.  
    • \r\n
  •  You throw your voice and can speak up to ten words in as loud a shout or as quiet as a whisper as you are normally capable of.  The source of you voice can be up to 50ft away from you and you can speak normally even if you are muted or gagged.  
    • \r\n
\r\n

This spell can be cast without components of any kind, and you can cast this spell even when you are restrained, paralyzed or otherwise incapacitated, though not if you are unconscious, petrified, or stunned.

\r\n

\"Fireball's a fine spell, but it's of no good gal-dern use when you're stuffed in a sack and trussed up like a turkey\" -Dawnli, dwarf warrior of Kielton.  

","sourceId":null},{"id":79855,"label":"Regeneration","description":"

As you concentrate, you regenerate 2d6 + 3 hp per round until the caster ends the spell or the casters concentration is broken. This spell can be used to close wounds, heal conditions, and regenerate body parts.

","sourceId":null},{"id":83774,"label":"Parasitic Fungus","description":"

Your touch allows you to temporarily infect a close by target with parasitic fungus spores, slowly draining them of their hp and life in order to help you regain your own. Every round once this spell is in play, you can use an Action point to invoke it's name with no material cost to make the fungus within the infected grow. This makes the the target takes 3d6 necrotic damage, and you regain hit points equal to half the amount of necrotic damage dealt. Until the spell ends, you can make the attack again on each of your turns as an action. The spell can be removed with Burning Hands and other flame-based spells, or if you go unconscious.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":83953,"label":"Health Transfer","description":"

You lay your hands on one willing creature and absorb their wounds onto yourself. For every 6 points of damage you heal (rounded up) on the affected creature, you take 1d6 necrotic damage. This damage can’t be reduced by resistance, immunity, or any other means as you’re absorbing it, but once you’ve taken the damage, it can be healed normally. A target creature can’t heal more than 60 hit points from one casting of this spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":86558,"label":"Forge","description":"

\"Everything melts...eventually.\"

\r\n

Hammersmith Godrickson

\r\n

Choose a materiel that you can see within range. You cause the materiel to begin to glow red-hot. Every round the object will get hotter until it eventually melts or burns.  If you maintain concentration, you can heat the materiel to any desired temperature.  With practice, you can maintain rigid control of the heat, enabling the forging of superior items.

\r\n

Note: Objects that are held, cannot be melted.  The amount of time it takes an object to melt or burn is dependent on the materiel.  (This is determined by the GM to take into account the mineral, its melting point, and any other possible effects that might affect the minerals forging characteristics.)

\r\n

Any creature in physical contact with the object takes 1d8 fire damage when you cast the spell.  Every round that the spell is held in place, will increase this damage 1d8 up to a maximum of 5d8 after 5 rounds. Until the spell ends you must use a bonus action on each of your subsequent turns to maintain the spell.

\r\n

If a creature is holding or wearing the object and takes the damage from it, the creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or drop the object if it can. If it doesn't drop the object, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the start of your next turn.

","sourceId":null},{"id":86774,"label":"Dark Wings","description":"

You sprout a pair of bat wings on your back. If you already have wings, they become magically enhanced. You gain a flying speed of 50 feet for the duration. When the spell ends, the wings disappear and the target falls if it is still aloft, unless it can stop the fall.

\r\n

If you are knocked prone while flying with these wings, you descend 100 feet on the turn when you fall (instead of 500 feet as other creatures do since the magic of the wings slows your fall). If you start any of your later turns still falling, you can halt the fall on your turn by spending half your flying speed to counter the prone condition (as if you were standing up in midair). 

\r\n

When a creature that you can see attacks a target other than you that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to shield that target with your wings. That target gains a +2 bonus to AC against the triggering attack.

\r\n

As an action, you can buffet creatures with your wings. Up to three creatures of your choice within 5 feet of you must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 1d6 bludgeoning damage plus your Strength modifier. A Medium or smaller creature is also knocked prone.  

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the duration becomes 10 minutes when using a 4th level slot, and 1 hour when using a 5th level slot or higher. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":87784,"label":"Unseen Crew","description":"

This spell creates ten invisible, mindless, shapeless forces which act as the crew of a vehicle within range until the spell ends. The servant springs into existence in an unoccupied space on the ground within range. It has AC 10, 1 hit point, and a Strength of 2, and it can't attack. If it drops to 0 hit points, the spell ends.

\r\n

Once on each of your turns as a bonus action, you can mentally command them to perform simple tasks that a human crew could do, such as swabbing the deck, loading shipboard weapons, moving cargo, and manning the rigging. Once you give the command, the crew performs the task to the best of its ability until it completes the task, then waits for your next command.

\r\n

If you command the servant to perform a task that would move it more than 60 feet away from you, the spell ends.

\r\n

(Adapted from Izzy's Guide to Fight and Flight.)

","sourceId":null},{"id":89796,"label":"Contracted Summoning","description":"

When a creature accepts a contract with you, the name of the creature marks the top of your hand(max 2). You summon a creature of challenge rating 3 or lower. It appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. The summoned creature teleports back to where it was before it was summoned when it hits to 0 hit points or when the spell ends

\r\n

The summoned creature is friendly to you and your companions for the duration. Roll initiative for the creature, which has its own turns. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you), as long as it doesn't directly harm the creature. If you don't issue any commands to the summoned creature, it defends itself from hostile creatures but otherwise takes no actions.

\r\n

If your concentration is broken, the summoned creature doesn't disappear. Instead, you lose control of the creature. The uncontrolled creature can't be dismissed by you, and it disappears 1 hour after you summoned it.

\r\n

When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the challenge rating increases by 1 for each slot level above 3th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":93157,"label":"Bind Person","description":"

Choose a humanoid that you can see within range.  The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or be restrained by glowing magical ropes for the duration.  The target can use its action to make another Dexterity saving throw.  On a success, the spell ends on the target. 

\r\n

At Higher Levels.  When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you can target one additional humanoid for each slot level above 3rd.  The humanoids must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":106462,"label":"Enchant Magic Item","description":"

Magic drawn from the weave of the universe infuses the item you hold in your hands. Casting this ritual allows you to create a magic item or upgrade an existing magic item using a quantity of gold or residuum equal to the cost of the magic item. To create a magical item, the component cost is the price of magical item. For an existing magical item that your are magically upgrading, the component cost is the difference in price between the existing item and the upgraded magical item. A magic item can only be enchanted by magic users with a spell casting level that matches the rarity of the magic item according to the table below.

\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
RaritySpell Casting LevelCasting TimeValue*
Common3rd Level+1 Hour100gp
Uncommon3rd Level+1 Hour400gp
Rare5th Level+2 Hours4,000gp
Very Rare7th Level+4 Hours40,000gp
Legendary9th Level+8 Hours400,000gp
\r\n

*Halved for a consumable item like a potion or scroll

","sourceId":null},{"id":111207,"label":"Bone Shield","description":"

The following spell name is directly taken from Blizzard, but I owe nothing related to World of Warcraft nor Blizzard. I merely wish to bring the spell to the masses. All rights go to Blizzard Entertainment.

\r\n

Creator note: This spell might feel extremely powerful, and probably is, so make sure to consult your DM before use. I made it with the Death Knights from the World of Warcraft universe in mind, therefor making it powerful.    

\r\n

Magical bones start to rotate around the caster, warding off incoming damage. You summon bones equal to you casting ability modifier. Each charge of Bone Shield reduces the next incoming damage (magical or not) equal to player’s level plus Constitution modifier (minimum of 1). The bones lasts for 1 minute. 

\r\n

At Higher Levels. Add 2 additional Bone Shield for each spell slot used above 3rd level.  

","sourceId":null},{"id":112406,"label":"Improved Feather Fall","description":"

Choose up to ten willing creatures. For the duration of the spell, the targets falling speed is reduced to 60 feet per second. Each round, a target of the spell may make an Acrobatics check with a DC of 8 to change speed up to 30 feet per round in any horizontal direction, up to a maximum speed of 120 feet per round. (In other words, the target may not use this action to increase or decrease their falling speed.) A person who lands on the ground while this spell is in effect takes no falling damage.

\r\n

For each additional level beyond third, the spell can affect five additional creatures.

","sourceId":null},{"id":114732,"label":"Create Common Magical Item","description":"

You spend an hour preparing an enchantment, scribing sigils, glyphs, and evoking transmutative magics to imprint an item of your choosing with magical properties.

\r\n

The magical item created cannot be of a rarity higher than common, and cannot already be magical in nature. 

\r\n

The spell can alter the appearance of the item, but cannot increase its size or weight categories. The spell cannot alter or change the material an item is made from unless the materials are provided during the ritual in the necessary quantities.

\r\n

(See DMG and other supplemental materials for lists of possible common magical items, though items created can be customized and tweaked within reason and consent of the DM)

    • \r\n

","sourceId":null},{"id":136293,"label":"Merchants Quick Sell","description":"

You create a chalk circle that is connected to another circle that can allow one person to send an item as big as a greataxe or as small as a mouse in exchange for its market value exactly. The recipients circle must not be obstructed  otherwise the spell ends. The recipient is notified of who sent it and has the option to remove the item to inspect it but otherwise must place the value of the item within the circle to keep it. If nothing is sent back the item will return to the owner. The sender can also send money instead and can receive an item or items of equal value. The recipient is notified of what item the sender is requesting. If nothing is sent back then all of the money sent is returned to the owner. The spell must be cast in the open and with a clear view to the sky. The recipient and the sender must also be on the same plane of existence.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a 4th level spell slot of higher, the range increases by 5 miles for every spell slot above 3rd

","sourceId":null},{"id":138543,"label":"Blossom of Flesh","description":"

The caster touches an injured creature and begins to chant a daunting spell healing the target by 4d10 plus your spell attack modifier by making his flesh to grow and twist in an unnatural pace around injuries.

\r\n

The target of the spell them must make a Constitution saving throw to prevent his flesh to go wild, on a successful save the injury is perfectly healed not leaving even a scar, on a failed save roll 1d8 in the table below.

\r\n
    \r\n
  • 8       The injury heals but leaves a scar in the form of a spiral that can be easily be identified (rolling an 8 again undoes the scar).
    • \r\n
  • 7-6    The injury heals in a very painful manner giving you disadvantage in attack rolls and strength checks for one round.
    • \r\n
  • 5-4    The injury heals but leaves the skin of the target thin and fragile giving him vulnerability to slashing and piercing damage for 1 minute (You can repeat the CON save at the end            of your turn to end the effect sooner).
    • \r\n
  • 3-2    The twisting flesh was not controlled completely making the injury bleed dangerously dealing 5d4 necrotic damage after the healing. 
    • \r\n
  • 1        The flesh goes wild not healing you and dealing 4d4 of necrotic damage and an additional 1d4 at the end of every turn until treated with a medic kit or with a Wisdom                             (medicine) check against the caster spell save DC.
    • \r\n
\r\n

Casting this spell with a higher spell slot increases the healing by 1d10 for every spell slot level above 3. Additionally, if cast with a level 5 spell slot or higher gives the target advantage in the Constitution saving throw and +1 in the 1d8 used to roll in the table.

Those creatures regain 10 hit points at the start of their turns. If the creature takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of their next turn. While the spell is active the creature dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

","sourceId":null},{"id":142191,"label":"Time Bandit","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

You steal the next 6 seconds of a target's future.

\r\n

Select a living creature you can see within 60'.  They lose all actions on their next turn, but are still able to take their movement.  Draining your victim of time itself, you find that you are somehow able to take an additional 1 Action, 1 Reaction, and 1 Bonus Action this turn.  A victim may only be drained of their immediate future with this spell once per round.

\r\n

This process is strenuous.  Each time you cast this spell, make a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw, or gain 1 level of exhaustion.

\r\n

Casting this spell on a non-linear creature (for example, a native of the Demiplane of Time) has an unusual effect.  Instead of causing them to lose their actions, you deal 2d8 + 1/level Force damage to them.  You still gain the additional 1 Action, 1 Reaction, and 1 Bonus Action this turn.

\r\n

At Higher Levels:
For each level of spell slot above 3rd, you may target 1 additional creature.  You also gain an additional Action, Reaction, and Bonus Action this turn for each target.

\r\n

This spell is an original work.

","sourceId":null},{"id":148728,"label":"Transpose Wounds","description":"

You regain 3d6 hitpoints. Choose a creature you can see within range, it makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save it takes necrotic damage equal to the amount healed, taking half that on a success. 

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the healing increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":155874,"label":"Crushing Singularity","description":"

You create an overwhelming gravitational singularity at a point within range. When you cast this spell, any creature within 15 feet of the point must make a Strength saving throw. Creatures that fail their saving throw are moved to the closest available space adjacent to the singularity and take 2d6 bludgeoning damage, and an additional 1d6 bludgeoning damage for each other creature that failed the saving throw, up to a maximum of 6d6 bludgeoning damage. Creatures make their saving throw with disadvantage if they are between the center of the area another creature that fails their saving throw.

\r\n


Until the spell ends, moving away from the singularity while within 15 feet of it requires twice as much movement. Any creature that ends their turn within 15 feet of the singularity must repeat the Strength saving throw, being pulled back to center and taking 1d6 bludgeoning damage on failure.

","sourceId":null},{"id":157931,"label":"Horrid Form","description":"

Your bones break and your skin tears itself apart as your physical form reveals the true horror within. Your body grows in size, and your skin becomes black as absolute darkness. A mass of writhing and pulsating tentacles protrudes from all over your body.

\r\n

Your size doubles in all dimensions, and your weight is multiplied by eight. This growth increases your size category-- from Medium to Large, for example. If there isn't enough room for your size to double, you attain the maximum possible size in the space available. Until the spell ends, you also have advantage on Strength and Charisma checks. The mass of tentacles protruding from your body enhance your natural morphic abilities. While in this form your attacks deal an additional 1d4 damage. 

\r\n

For the duration of this form you gain temporary hit points equal to your spellcasting modifier at the start of each of your turns. The temporary hit points gained by this spell are doubled if your current hit points is less than half your maximum hit points.

\r\n

Until this spells ends, you cannot cast any other spells other than Eldritch Blast, you cannot concentrate on any spells, and any spells relying on concentration end when this spell is cast.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a 4th level spell slot, the duration increases to 1 minute. When you use a spell slot of 5th level or higher, you can maintain this form for 1 hour.

","sourceId":null},{"id":158344,"label":"Dark Everglade","description":"

The caster creates a vacuumed space that makes the area around difficult to breath or move. The creatures that are trapped in the area must make a dex save. On failed saves the creature(s) will take a full 3d8 of necrotic damage and their speed will be reduced to 10 ft. The creatures will have disadvantage on sight and verbal based attacks. On successful saves the creature(s) will take half damage and be able to move 25 ft. The ability must be recharged using 1d6 and can be used again if the roll is a 5 or 6.

","sourceId":null},{"id":165416,"label":"Raise Beast","description":"

This spell creates an undead beast servant. Choose a corpse of a Medium or Small beast within range. Your spell imbues the target with a foul mimicry of life, raising it as an undead creature. The target becomes an undead version of the beast.

\r\n

On each of your turns, you can use a bonus action to mentally command any creature you made with this spell if the creature is within 60 feet of you (if you control multiple creatures, you can command any or all of them at the same time, issuing the same command to each one). You decide what action the creature will take and where it will move during its next turn, or you can issue a general command, such as to guard a particular chamber or corridor. If you issue no commands, the creature only defends itself against hostile creatures. Once given an order, the creature continues to follow it until its task is complete. The creature also gains an extra 2d6 necrotic damage to its attacks and gains dark vision of 60 ft. if it doesnt already have it.

\r\n

The creature is under your control for 48 hours, after which it stops obeying any command you've given it. To maintain control of the creature for another 24 hours, you must cast this spell on the creature again before the current 48-hour period ends. This use of the spell reasserts your control over up to four creatures you have animated with this spell, rather than animating a new one.

\r\n

Casting this spell on the same creature for 30 days makes the affect permanent and the creature stays your companion. If the creature falls again you will have to animate them another straight 30 days.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you animate or reassert control over two additional undead creatures for each slot level above 3rd. Each of the creatures must come from a different corpse or pile of bones.

","sourceId":null},{"id":167170,"label":"Reshape Metal","description":"

At your touch, a metal object (up to 50 lbs) becomes soft and malleable like clay. You can reshape it into any form you want. You must knead and mold the metal to reshape it, but you don’t need artistic talent to make it look the way you want. You only need to picture the desired form in your mind, and the magic accomplishes in a single round what your hands can’t. Once the object takes its new form, the metal returns to its original hardness in the new shape.

\r\n

If the item is shaped into a weapon, its damage matches its new form. The spell does not work on an item held by an unwilling creature or on creatures made of metal. It can’t increase or decrease the amount of metal in the object.

","sourceId":null},{"id":168875,"label":"Siege Bolt","description":"

 

\r\n

A grey bolt of magic with a red tail streaks from your hand. Upon impacting a large or smaller creature, they take 1d6+1 piercing damage. Upon impacting a huge or larger creature, or a wooden structure 2 feet thick, a stone wall 10 inches thick, or a metal plate 1 inch thick, the bolt explodes in a 5 foot radius, and a 15 foot cone behind the point of impact in the direction the magic was cast, causing 5d6 force damage. All creatures within this area must make a dexterity saving throw against the spell DC. on a successful saving throw, creatures take half accumulated force damage. All huge or larger creatures hit directly with the magic bolt must make a successful constitution saving throw, or be stunned for one round of combat. Huge or larger creatures do not take extra damage from multiple spaces taken up in the cone.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the force damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":169077,"label":"Danger Sense","description":"

\"My danger sense be itchin.\" -Bug-Dude

\r\n

You gain an uncanny ability to know when you're in any immediate danger. You feel an unmistakable itch in the back of your head under any of the following conditions:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • A ranged weapon, spell or projectile within 300 feet is aimed in your direction.
    • \r\n
  • Someone within 100 feet is intent on hurting you within the next minute.
    • \r\n
  • Someone within 30 feet draws a weapon.
    • \r\n
  • Something is going to explode in the next 12 seconds and you're in the blast radius.
    • \r\n
  • A large object is going to impact you in the next 6 seconds.
    • \r\n
  • Something is going to fall on you in the next 6 seconds.
    • \r\n
  • Anything the DM thinks would set off your danger sense.
    • \r\n
\r\n

When your danger sense goes off, you gain the following properties until the spell ends or the danger has passed, unless it lasts longer than 12 seconds, after which you lose the following properties:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • If the source of your danger sense forces you to make a Dexterity saving throw, as a reaction, you can give yourself advantage on that saving throw. After using your reaction, the spell ends.
    • \r\n
  • If the source of your danger sense makes an attack roll against you, as a reaction, you can force them to roll with disadvantage. After using your reaction, the spell ends
    • \r\n
  • As a bonus action, you can give yourself advantage on acrobatics checks for the next 12 seconds. After using your bonus action, the spell ends.
    • \r\n
  • A a bonus action, you can increase your speed by 15 feet for the next 12 seconds. After using your bonus action, the spell ends.
    • \r\n
  • As a bonus action, you can make a wisdom check to determine the general direction of whatever set off your danger sense. The DC is equal to your distance from the source of your danger sense in feet. If you succeed, you know if it is in front, behind, underneath, above, to the left, or to the right of you.
    • \r\n
\r\n

If you are concentrating on a spell, there is a 50% chance that your danger sense will not go off. If a possible trigger of your danger sense is undetectable by divination, it will not set off your danger sense. Once your danger sense has gone off 5 times, the spell ends.

","sourceId":null},{"id":185532,"label":"Faskasas’s Skeletal Armor","description":"

You can use an action to make skeletal bones cover your arms, legs and chest. While wearing this armor you gain resistance to necrotic damage and gain an bonus to AC equal to your spellcasting modifier.

","sourceId":null},{"id":187130,"label":"Eruptive Postules","description":"

Your skin erupts in swollen, pus-filled bumps for the duration. You can end the spell early by using an action to dismiss it. Whenever a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, the pustules burst open. The attacker takes 2d4 points of acid damage and must make a Constitution saving throw or be blinded until the end of its next turn.

","sourceId":null},{"id":189699,"label":"Impeding Affliction","description":"

You make a ranged spell attack.  On a hit the target takes 4d6 necrotic damage and makes a Constitution saving throw against your Spell Save DC.  On a successful save the the target receives half damage.  If the target is proficient in Constitution saving throws it may make an additional Constitution saving throw.  On a successful save, on the additional saving throw, it can nullify one of the three effects for the duration of this spell.       

\r\n

Calculate the total damage received, then implement the following effects accordingly: 

\r\n

For every 4 points of damage dealt: The target's speed is reduced by 5 feet, until the start of your next turn.

\r\n

For every 8 points of damage dealt: The target's max HP is reduced by 5 points, until the start of your next turn.

\r\n

For every 12 points of damage dealt:  The target is afflicted for 1 addition round.

\r\n

At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":189937,"label":"Hemorrhage (Blood Magic)","description":"

You take control of a large volume of a target’s blood and force it out through their mouth, nose, and eyes. Unless they succeed at a Constitution save vs Spellcaster DC, the target takes 4d6 (+ your spellcasting ability modifier) HP damage; if successful only 2d6 damage. Regardless of whether the target succeeds, the horrific nature of this spell demoralizes the target's allies enemies; causing any within 10 feet of the target to have disadvantage on any attacks or skill checks they make until the end of their next turn.

","sourceId":null},{"id":195762,"label":"Find Greater Familiar","description":"

You gain the service of a familiar, a spirit that takes the form of a beast, fey, fiend, or celestial who's challenge rating is 1 or lower. The creatures size must also be no larger than a medium creature, and it cannot be a humanoid of any kind. Appearing in an unoccupied space within range, the familiar has the statistics of the chosen form, though if it is a beast, it is considered a celestial, fey, or fiend (your choice) instead of a beast.

\r\n

Your familiar acts independently of you, but it always obeys your commands. In combat, it rolls its own initiative and acts on its own turn. A familiar can make only one attack per turn, but it takes other actions as normal. If the familiar is able to cast spells then all spells it cast take up the familiars action and reaction.

\r\n

When the familiar drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. It reappears after you cast this spell again.

\r\n

While your familiar is within 100 feet of you, you can communicate with it telepathically. Additionally, as an action, you can see through your familiar's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of your next turn, gaining the benefits of any special senses that the familiar has. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses.

\r\n

As an action, you can temporarily dismiss your familiar. It disappears into a pocket dimension where it awaits your summons. Alternatively, you can dismiss it forever. As an action while it is temporarily dismissed, you can cause it to reappear in any unoccupied space within 30 feet of you. If your familiar loses hit points and is transported into the pocket dimension, the familiar regains 5 hit points for every hour it remains. Additionally any status effects or conditions that the familiar suffers from are cured if the familiar remains in the pocket dimension for the length of a long rest. Curses however remain, and cannot be cured in this way.

\r\n

You can't have more than one familiar at a time. If you cast this spell while you already have a familiar, you instead cause it to adopt a new form, of which must be as specified above.

\r\n

Finally, when you cast a spell with a range of touch, your familiar can deliver the spell as if it had cast the spell. Your familiar must be within 100 feet of you, and it must use its reaction to deliver the spell when you cast it. If the spell requires an attack roll, you use your attack modifier for the roll.

","sourceId":null},{"id":207224,"label":"Corrosive Skin","description":"

You touch a creature, infecting them with a flesh-eating magical disease that corrodes their skin. Make a melee spell attack, on a hit afflicting the target with this curse. At the start of each of the creature's turns, it must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or suffer 1d8 necrotic damage. Additionally, the creature cannot be affected by any healing magic for the duration. The curse may be ended early with a remove curse spell or other similar effect.

","sourceId":null},{"id":210383,"label":"Transmute Blood","description":"

You manipulate the life essence within your blood, releasing a surge of primal energy that alters the properties of your blood so that it is more acidic, or so that when exposed to the air it spontaneously combusts or freezes (your choice when you initially case the spell).

\r\n

When you take piercing or slashing damage you spray blood back in the direction of the attacker out to 5ft., with the following effects depending on the element chosen:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Ignite: The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 3d6 fire damage and be coated in searing blood, suffering disadvantage on attack rolls until the end of their next turn.
    • \r\n
  • Freeze: The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take 3d6 cold damage and have their speed reduced by 10ft. until the start of their next turn.
    • \r\n
  • Caustic: The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 3d6 acid damage and must roll a d10, on a 1 corroding their armor and reducing its AC by 1.
    • \r\n
\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.

","sourceId":null},{"id":214649,"label":"Caerius' Circle of Vile Repugnance","description":"

All Creatures within the spell's radius are caught in an eruption of noxious gasses from the ground and must make a constitution saving throw or be knocked prone as several powerful waves of nausea produce gagging and vomiting causing 3D8 poison damage on their first turn. On a failed save all the target can do for the next turn is heave and cannot take any actions or movements. They may make another saving throw at the end of their next turn and if they fail they remain prone and take 2D8 acid damage. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":216250,"label":"Mind Rot","description":"

You utter a curse and send necrotic magic coursing through a creatures mind causing them to suffer a bout of dementia and forgetfulness. Select one creature you can see within 30ft and either name 2 skills or choose to affect either two level 1 spell slots or one level 2 spell slot. That creature then rolls an Intelligence Saving Throw.

\r\n

On a successful saving throw nothing happens.

\r\n

On a failed saving throw the affect creatures temporarily loses proficiency in the two skills named or loses the number of spell slots chosen. If the creature does not have proficiency in the chosen skills or if the creature has no level 1 or 2 spell slots they suffer no effect from this spell.

\r\n

The skill proficiencies and spells slots return after the creatures next short rest.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":221744,"label":"Abomination Gut (Necrograft)","description":"

In a dangerous surgery, you remove your stomach and replace it with a monstrous version from a creature such as a plague spewer, plague walker, or famine spirit. It generates a revolting bile that you can vomit at your foes.  It bulges against your skin. 

\r\n

Whether you have to make Medicine checks to perform the surgery and whether you had to go on a quest to acquire the stomach, are details best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first.  If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC.  Any spells that you cast through this necrograft require no verbal, somatic, or material components, even expensive ones. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

You can Vomit Bile as an action.  You can use Vomit Bile in two different ways.  One acts as the Acid Splash cantrip, except the range is only 15 feet and it deals additional damage equal to your Constitution modifier.

\r\n

The second way acts as the Grease spell, except that all the affected squares must be within 15 feet of you and any creatures that fail their saving throw take acid damage equal to your Constitution modifier.

\r\n

You can spend two uses of Vomit Bile to use it as a bonus action.  However, you cannot use Vomit Bile more than once a round.

\r\n

You can Vomit Bile three times between rests. When you finish a short or long rest, you regain your expended uses.

\r\n

You can spend an action to belch forth noxious gases from your gut.  You gain the Belch ability.  This acts as Fog Cloud, but it requires no concentration, the area of effect is adjacent to you and is green in color, and the duration is 10 minutes.  You must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.  You cannot use Belch and Vomit Bile in the same round.

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

When you use Vomit Bile to reproduce Acid Splash, affected creatures now take half damage on a successful saving throw instead of no damage.

\r\n

When Vomit Bile is used to reproduce Grease, any creatures that fail their saving throw take 1d4 plus your Constitution modifier acid damage.

\r\n

You can use Vomit Bile four times between rests.

\r\n

When you use Belch, you can make the cloud poisonous. Each creature that is within the cloud at the start of its turn must make a Constitution saving throw against poison. On a failed save, the creature is poisoned until the start of its next turn. Creatures that don’t need to breathe automatically succeed on this saving throw.  This version of Belch lasts 1 minute.  You are immune to this gas. 

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

When you use Vomit Bile to reproduce Acid Splash, creatures that fail their saving throw have their speed reduced by 10 feet until the end of their next turn. 

\r\n

If you use Vomit Bile to reproduce Grease, any creatures that fail their saving throw take 2d4 plus your Constitution modifier acid damage.

\r\n

You can use Vomit Bile five times between rests.

\r\n

When you use Belch, you can make the cloud even more powerful.  It acts like Stinking Cloud except that it requires no concentration and the area of effect is adjacent to you.  You are immune to it.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

You can use your action to Vomit Everything, unleashing a devastating breath weapon in a 15-foot cone.  Creatures within the area must make a Dexterity saving throw.  Creatures that fail take 12d6 acid damage  and have their speed halved as they are covered in thick vomit.  Creatures that succeed take half damage and are not covered in vomit.  Creatures covered in vomit can spend an action to attempt to free themselves from the viscous bile.  If they succeed on a Strength saving throw, the effect ends.  After you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you complete a long rest. You can’t use Vomit Everything and Vomit Bile in the same turn.

\r\n

If you use Vomit Bile to reproduce Grease, any creature that fail their saving throw take 3d4 plus your Constitution modifier acid damage.

\r\n

If you use Vomit Bile to reproduce Acid Splash, it deals d8s damage instead of d6s.

\r\n
