When you use Belch, you can create a lethal cloud of gas.  This acts as Cloudkill, except that it requires no concentration and the area of effect is adjacent to you.  You are immune to it. 

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221752,"label":"Bonemail (Necrograft)","description":"

In a lengthy and painful operation, you graft protective bone plating over practically all of your body.  The bones may have originated from almost any sort of creature. 

\r\n

Whether you have to make Medicine checks to perform the surgery and whether you had to go on a quest to acquire the bones are details best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first.  If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond.  It is intended to be used with the spell Unhallowed Arts, which can also be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

Your gain a +1 bonus to AC as long as you are not wearing heavy armor.

\r\n

As a reaction when you suffer a critical hit, you can turn that attack into a normal hit. Any effects triggered by a critical hit are canceled. Once you use this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

\r\n

Additionally, you get the Bone Shield ability, allowing you to temporarily extend your plating to protect a nearby ally. When a creature you can see attacks a target other than you that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll.  Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

You can use Bone Shield three times between rests. Additionally, you can now use it to protect a target within 10 feet of you.

\r\n

You can use Bone Shield in a limited offensive capacity.  If you take the Attack action on your turn, you may after attacking spend a use of Bone Shield as a bonus action to try to shove an opponent within 10 feet of you. 

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

You can now use Bone Shield to protect an ally within 15 feet of you. Additionally, when you use Bone Shield, instead of imposing disadvantage on an attack, you can give an ally within 15 feet of you advantage on a Dexterity saving throw against an effect for half damage.  If the target succeeds, they take no damage.

\r\n

You can use your iron-hard bones to pummel your foes.  When you hit with an unarmed melee strike that deals bludgeoning damage, you can make a Marrow Whack.  The target takes additional damage equal to your character level and the next attack against it before the end of your next turn has advantage as it reels from the impact. Once you use this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

\r\n

You can attempt to shove enemies within 15 feet of you. When you successfully shove an opponent with Bone Shield, it takes damage as if hit by one of your unarmed strikes. 

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

When you use Bone Shield to impose disadvantage on an attack roll, the creature making the attack has disadvantage on not only that attack, but subsequent attacks on the same target for the rest of its turn.

\r\n

When you extend your Bone Shield to give advantage on a Dexterity saving throw, the target takes half damage even if they fail their saving throw.

\r\n

You gain an additional special use of your ability to extend your bone plating, Immortal Bone Shield.  You can protect yourself and all allies within 15 feet of you as a reaction.  Until the beginning of your next turn, you and all allies within range have advantage on Dexterity saving throws and all attack rolls against you and your allies within range have disadvantage.  If you or your allies succeed on a Dexterity saving throw while affected, no damage is taken. If they fail, they take half damage anyway.  Allies that move more than 15 feet away from you lose the protection given by this ability.

\r\n

Once you use this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221756,"label":"Bone Spikes (Necrograft)","description":"

In a laborious procedure, you graft onto your body a number of wicked bone spikes that you can fire like needles and afterward regrow.  You can deal piercing damage with your unarmed strikes.  This spell and the abilities it grants can't be used while you are wearing heavy armor.

\r\n

Whether you have to make Medicine checks to perform the surgery and whether you had to go on a quest to acquire the bone spikes, are details best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first.  If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond. It is intended to be used with the spell Unhallowed Arts, which can also be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

You can fire up to 15 bone spikes between rests. They now have a range of 60 feet.  Despite being a ranged attack, you may add your Strength modifier instead of your Dexterity modifier to the attack and damage rolls. The bone spikes deal piercing damage equal to your unarmed strike damage. When you use the Attack action to use Bone Spikes, as a bonus action, you can fire a second bone spike as long as you are not wielding a shield.  If you have the Extra Attack feature or have cast Unhallowed Arts at a 3rd level or higher slot, you can fire two bone spikes as an action and a third as a bonus action if you are not wielding a shield/

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

Your bones spikes also threaten those who get too close to you.  You gain the Impaling Revenge ability.  If a creature hits you with a melee attack, you can immediately use your reaction to make an unarmed melee attack against that creature.  The damage is piercing.  Using this ability counts as one of your Bone Spikes uses.

\r\n

You can fire up to 20 bone spikes between rests. 

\r\n

When firing your bone spikes as ranged attacks, the range is now 90 feet.

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

Your numerous spikes can help you hold onto surfaces.  You can spend a Bone Spikes use as a reaction to reroll any Strength and Dexterity checks and saving throws to avoid being shoved, Strength (Athletics) checks to climb, and Dexterity (Acrobatics) checks and Dexterity saving throws to avoid slipping and take the higher result.  If you rolled with advantage, reroll only one of the dice.

\r\n

You can now use Impaling Revenge when a creature misses you with a melee attack.

\r\n

You can fire up to 25 bone spikes between rests.

\r\n

When firing your bone spikes as ranged attacks, the range is now 120 feet.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

You can now fire up to 30 bone spikes between rests.

\r\n

You gain the Osteo-Impalement ability.  You can spend your action to rapidly regrow all of your expended bone spikes and then fire them all in a ferocious burst around you once per day.  You can angle the spines to affect a desired area.  Each time you use this ability, it can either affect all creatures adjacent to you, all creatures within 10 feet of you, creatures within 15 feet of you, or all creatures within 20 feet of you.  All affected creatures must make a Dexterity saving throw and take 10d8 piercing damage on a failed save or half on a successful save.  Like your unarmed strikes, this damage counts as from a magical weapon.  If you have the Elemental Cadaver necrograft, you can use Elemental Surge to increase this damage. 

\r\n

After you use this ability, all of your bone spikes regrow, up to the maximum of 30.  Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

When firing your bone spikes as ranged attacks, the range is now 150 feet.

\r\n

Additionally, you can use Impaling Revenge as a ranged retaliation.  After a creature hits you with an attack, misses you with an attack, or forces you to make a saving throw, you can use your reaction to immediately fire a bone spike at it.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221765,"label":"Ghoul Claws (Necrograft)","description":"

You remove your fingernails and replace them with the claws of a ghoul.  You can deal slashing damage with your unarmed strikes.  Some go a step further and entirely replace their hands, but this is not necessary.

\r\n

Whether you have to make a Medicine check to implant the claws and go on a quest to acquire them are details best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first.  If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond.  It is intended to be used with the spell Unhallowed Arts, which can also be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

Once per round, when you hit another creature with an unarmed melee strike, you can make a Ghoul Strike.  Choose one of the options below:

\r\n

Paralyze: The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be partially paralyzed until the end of your next turn.  Creature that fail are crippled as if affected by the Slow spell. For the purposes of immunities and other abilities and effects, this counts as being paralyzed.  Undead are immune to this effect.

\r\n

Gouge: You rip into your foe’s flesh.  You deal additional damage equal to your Strength modifier.

\r\n

You can use Ghoul Strike three times between rests. When you finish a short or long rest, you regain your expended uses.

\r\n

When you use Ghoul Strike, you cannot simultaneously use Profane Smite (from the Paladin's Tomb necrograft) or Wight Strike (from the Wight's Heart necrograft).

\r\n

Your claws can easily move grave dirt and similar matter.  You gain a burrow speed of 10 feet.

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

Ghoul Strike increases in power.

\r\n

When you choose the Paralyze option, a target that fails its saving throw is affected for 1 minute.  The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

\r\n

When you choose the Gouge option, you deal an additional damage die plus your Strength modifier damage.

\r\n

Your burrow speed increases to 15 feet.

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

When you use Ghoul Strike, you can simultaneously use both the Paralyze and Gouge options.

\r\n

You gain the Sharp Claws feature.  When you score a critical hit with an unarmed strike that deals slashing damage, roll an additional damage die.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

Ghoul Strike now truly paralyzes your prey. A creature that fails its saving throw is paralyzed for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

\r\n

Ghoul Strike now deals an additional damage die plus twice your Strength modifier damage.

\r\n

Your burrow speed is now the same as your base speed.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221767,"label":"Lich's Skull (Necrograft)","description":"

You take the skull of a lich and break it into several pieces.  You then graft the pieces to your own skull, forming a sort of crude helmet.

\r\n

Whether you have to make a Medicine check to graft the skull pieces and whether you had to go a quest to acquire the lich skull are details best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first. If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC. Any spells that you cast through this necrograft require no verbal, somatic, or material components, even expensive ones. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

You gain proficiency in Arcana and History.  Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any check you make using those proficiencies.

\r\n

Choose two cantrips from the wizard spell list.  You know them. 

\r\n

Choose two 1st level spells from the wizard spell list.  You know them. You can cast any wizard spell you know as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag.  If the spell has a focus component, the skull itself acts as the spellcasting focus.

\r\n

You have one 1st level spell slot. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest. 

\r\n

You gain the Shield Mind ability. When forced to make an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw, you can roll 1d4 and add the number rolled to your result. Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

You can use Shield Mind twice between long rests.

\r\n

You gain resistance to psychic damage.

\r\n

You learn two 2nd level spells from the wizard spell list. 

\r\n

You have one 2nd level spell slot.  

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

You can use Shield Mind three times between long rests.

\r\n

You gain a +1 bonus to your Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

\r\n

You learn two 3rd level spells from the wizard spell list.    

\r\n

You have one 3rd level spell slot.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

You gain the Impenetrable Mind ability.  You can cast Mindblank on yourself as a reaction against any effect that it mentions (for example, an attack dealing psychic damage or someone trying to scry on you).  Using this feature does not consume your reaction and can be used even if you have already used your reaction.  When used this way, Mindblank lasts for 1 minute.  Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

You now have a +2 bonus to your Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

\r\n

You learn an additional cantrip from the wizard spell list.

\r\n

You learn two 4th level spells from the wizard spell list.   

\r\n

You have one 4th level spell slot.  

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221769,"label":"Mummified Eye (Necrograft)","description":"

You tear out one of your eyes and replace it with one that pierces cloud, shadow, earth, and flesh. 

\r\n

Whether you have to make Medicine checks to perform the surgery and whether you had to go on a quest to acquire the eye, are details best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first.  If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC. Any spells that you cast through this necrograft require no verbal, somatic, or material components, even expensive ones. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond. 

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

You can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, up to a distance of 120 feet. 

\r\n

You can cast Baleful Gaze at will (see DnDBeyond).

\r\n

You gain a 1st level spell slot that you regain whenever you finish a short or long rest.  You know the spells Detect Magic (which you can perform as a ritual), Detect Evil and Good, and Detect Poison and Disease.

\r\n

Your magical eye is also constantly looking for danger, giving you a +2 bonus to initiative.

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

Baleful Gaze deals additional damage equal to your Constitution modifier.

\r\n

You gain a 2nd level spell slot that you regain whenever you finish a short or long rest.  You know the spells Find Traps, Locate Object, and See Invisibility. 

\r\n

You gain the See Beyond ability.  You can make either an initiative roll, Intelligence (Investigation) check involving sight, or Wisdom (Perception) check involving sight with advantage.  Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

Baleful Gaze deals half damage on a successful saving throw instead of no damage.

\r\n

You can use See Beyond twice between rests.

\r\n

You can perform a Flesh-Piercing Gaze as a bonus action.  Choose one creature that you can see within 150 feet.  You learn either its strengths or its weaknesses.

\r\n

If you learn its strengths, you learn its Damage Resistances, Damage Immunities, Condition Immunities, , and its best saving throw.  If two or more of the creature’s saving throws are tied for highest, you learn them all.

\r\n

If you learn its weaknesses, you learn its Damage Vulnerabilities and its worst saving throw.  If two or more of the creature’s saving throws are tied for lowest, you learn them all.

\r\n

Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

\r\n

You gain a 4th level spell slot that you regain when you finish a long rest. You know the spells Arcane Eye, Clairvoyance, and Locate Creature.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

You gain a 5th level spell slot that you regain when you finish a long rest.  You know the spell Scrying.

\r\n

In addition, you can reroll initiative and take the higher result.  If initiative was rolled with advantage, reroll only one of the dice.

\r\n

Flesh-Piercing Gaze now tells you both a creature’s strengths and weaknesses.

\r\n

You gain the All-Seeing Eye ability.  This has many possible uses:

\r\n

You can cast Eyebite, Find the Path, or True Seeing on yourself.

\r\n

When you cast Baleful Gaze, you can target any number of creatures within range.  It does double damage  and the targets have disadvantage on their saving throw.

\r\n

When you use Flesh-Piercing Gaze, you can target any number of creatures in range.

\r\n

Until the beginning of your next turn, all attacks against you are at disadvantage and you have advantage on all attack rolls, saving throws, and ability checks.  This requires no action.

\r\n

Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221771,"label":"Paladin's Tomb (Necrograft)","description":"

You have committed a shocking blasphemy: you have exhumed a slain paladin, devoured it whole, shattered its crypt, and grafted to your flesh the stony fragments.  Corpses that are not buried or have only a headstone are insufficient; the paladin must have been surrounded by worked stone.  Additionally, the paladin must have been of pure heart.

\r\n

Whether you have to make Medicine checks to perform the surgery and whether you had to go on a quest to find the paladin and its tomb, are details best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first.  If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC. Any spells that you cast through this necrograft require no verbal, somatic, or material components, even expensive ones. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed to go with the Dead Sage and Necrografter classes, which can be found on DnDBeyond. It is intended to be used with the spell Unhallowed Arts, which can also be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

You gain the ability to cast some of the spells that the paladin you consumed knew as well as the power to curse your foes.  You know the following spells: Bane, Bless, Searing Smite, Thunderous Smite, and Wrathful Smite.

\r\n

You have three 1st level spell slots.  You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest. 

\r\n

You gain the Profane Smite ability.  When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can expend one spell slot to deal extra damage to the target, in addition to the weapon’s damage.  The extra damage is half necrotic and half radiant. The extra damage is 2d8 for a 1st-level spell slot, plus 1d8 for each spell level higher than 1st, to a maximum of 5d8.  The damage increases by 1d8 if the target is an undead, celestial or fiend, to a maximum of 6d8.  You may use spell slots you receive from other classes or necrografts.

\r\n

When you use Profane Smite, you cannot simultaneously use Ghoul Strike (from the Ghoul Claws necrograft) or Wight Strike (from the Wight's Heart necrograft).

\r\n

You understand the writings and inscriptions on any grave, tomb, or similar structure regardless of what language it is. You also understand magical runes on such structures. 

\r\n

You can cast the Paladin’s Anguish cantrip at will.  This acts like the Toll the Dead cantrip, but half the damage is necrotic and half is radiant.   

\r\n

You gain the Profane Sense ability.  The presence of both strong evil and good registers on your senses like rotting flesh.  As an action, you can open your awareness to detect such forces. Until the end of your next turn, you know the location of any celestial, fiend, or undead within 100 feet of you.  This sense can penetrate most barriers, but it is blocked by 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood or dirt.  You know the type (celestial, fiend, or undead) of any being whose presence you sense, but not its identity (the vampire Count Strahd von Zarovich, for instance). Within the same radius, you also detect the presence of any place or object that has been consecrated or desecrated, as with the hallow spell.

\r\n

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier. When you finish a long rest, you regain all expended uses.

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

You gain one 2nd level spell slot.  You learn the following spells: Aid, Branding Smite, Ray of Enfeeblement.  

\r\n

You gain the Roar of the Fallen Crusader ability. As a bonus action, you unleash a battle cry infused with both divine and profane energy.   Up to ten other creatures of your choice within 60 feet of you that can hear you are affected differently depending on whether they are friendly or hostile.

\r\n

Friendly creatures can roll a d4 and add the result to a single attack roll or saving throw they make before the start of your next turn. If you have the Vampiric Soul necrograft, any swarms you summon can be affected by this.

\r\n

Hostile creatures must succeed at a Charisma saving throw or roll 1d4 and subtract the result from the next attack roll or saving throw they make before the start of your next turn. 

\r\n

Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

You learn the Celestial language, but speak it in a twisted way.

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

Creatures that succeed on their saving throw against Paladin's Anguish take half damage instead of no damage.

\r\n

You gain one 3rd level spell slot.  You learn the following spells: Aura of Vitality, Bestow Curse, Blinding Smite.  

\r\n

When you use Roar of the Fallen Crusader, friendly targets can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the result when they make an attack roll or a saving throw until the beginning of your next turn.

\r\n

You never forget the writings, inscriptions, and runes on any grave, tomb, or similar structure.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

You gain one 4th level spell slot.  You learn the following spells:  Aura of Life, Blight, Staggering Smite.

\r\n

You can spend an action to summon a twisted visage of the paladin you devoured long ago.  You gain the Summon Corrupted Crusader ability.  Choose a 10-foot square within 60 feet of you.  A grave or tomb identical to the one you destroyed bursts from the ground.  Any creatures in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw.  A creature takes 8d8 bludgeoning damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.  This counts as damage from a magical source.

\r\n

At the start of your next turn, the ghostly paladin emerges from its tomb and begins assailing your enemies for 1 minute.  Each turn, the paladin makes an unerring attack against an enemy within 5 feet of it.  The attack automatically hits and deals 2d8 + your Constitution modifier damage, half necrotic and half radiant.  The paladin acts independently; you need not spend any bonus actions commanding it.  The paladin has a fly speed of 40 feet (hover).  It can be affected by Turn Undead, but is otherwise immune to attacks, spells, and abilities.  Its Wisdom saving throw bonus is +10.

\r\n

Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

When you use Roar of the Fallen Crusader, hostile creatures that fail their saving throw roll a d4 and subtract the number rolled when they make an attack roll or a saving throw until the beginning of your next turn.

\r\n

Your attacks deal twice as much damage against graves, tombs, or similar structures.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221778,"label":"Two Corpses in One Grave (Necrograft)","description":"

You are not alone.  Another soul, or fragments of it, inhabits your body along with your own.  This may be the result of deliberate action on your part. In this situation, you ritualistically consumed a humanoid corpse.  However, this necrograft could also be caused by a lost soul attaching itself to you without your knowledge.

\r\n

This is a unique necrograft.  Normally, you temporarily activate a necrograft by expending a spell slot.  However, because you actually invite in (or are effectively possessed by) another creature's soul, it cannot be turned on and off.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

When you first cast this spell, you no longer regain one 3rd level spell slot when you regain your other spell slots.  You can regain it only by expending a spell slot high enough to activate the necrograft at the next stage, but then you no longer regain a spell slot of that level.  For example, Larry the necromancer acquired this necrograft at 5th level. He is now 11th level and he wants to activate this necrograft at Stage 2. He expends a 5th or 6th level spell slot.  When he regains his spell slots, he regains one fewer 5th level spell slot.  However, he now regains the 3rd spell slot that he expended to originally gain this necrograft.

\r\n

Additionally, while other necrografts can simply be acquired and activated at any Stage that the spellcaster has enough power to reach, this necrograft works differently.  It must originally be cast at Stage 1.  The caster must wait at least 1 month before advancing the necrograft to the next Stage.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

You gain the Another’s Flesh ability.  At will, you can spend an action to physically take on the form of the soul that shares your body.  Once you select the appearance of that soul, it cannot be changed.

\r\n

This acts like the Change Appearance benefit of Alter Self, with three key differences.  First, this ability requires no concentration.  Second, there are no restrictions on adopting a different size; a halfling can physically transform into a goliath and vice versa.  Your clothes and equipment adjust to your new size.  While this transformation affects your height and weight, the only mechanical difference is your carrying capacity.  Your stats are not changed as though affected by Enlarge or Reduce.  Third, while this transformation does not actually change the clothes and equipment you are wearing beyond their size, if you wish, they can appear to change as if you had cast Disguise Self.  This effect is an illusion and can be changed at will by spending an action.  Only your clothes’ and equipment’s appearance can change; your body cannot. 

\r\n

When you use Another’s Flesh, you appear as a normal person without any necrografts, should you have any others.  However, you may still use all of the abilities granted by your necrografts.  Some, like the speed increase of Vampiric Grace, won’t appear to be unnatural, but many, like using the powers granted by the Bone Spikes necrograft, will clearly reveal that you are not what you appear to be.

\r\n

Returning to your original form takes a bonus action, while dropping an illusion of clothes and equipment takes no action.  If killed, you revert to your original form.  However, when you are in your altered form, you can spend an action to return to your original form in an extremely disturbing manner.  Your original form appears to erupt from the flesh of your altered form.

\r\n

Any enemies that witness your Violent Transformation must make a Wisdom saving throw.  If they fail, they take psychic damage equal to your necrografter level +10 and are frightened of you until the end of their next turn.  Creatures that succeed take half damage and aren’t frightened. Once you use this feature, you can’t use again it until you finish a short or long rest.

\r\n

At Stage 1, you and the other soul are definitely aware of each other.  If you didn’t already know, you learn their name and some broad, general details about them such as their age and where they are from.  You cannot directly communicate with the soul, but might hear whispers from it once or twice a day. You also occasionally have dreams about their life.  

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

Any creature that fails its saving throw against Violent Transformation is frightened for 1 minute.  At the end of its turn, it can make a Wisdom saving throw to end the effect.

\r\n

At Stage 2, you learn more details about the other soul, and vice-versa.  You roughly know the same information about them as you would a casual acquaintance.  You can also communicate directly with it, although this method of communication is cumbersome and slow.  Your relationship with the soul could vary wildly depending who they were and on the actions you take as an adventurer.  They are under no obligation to answer any questions you ask.  You probably have a dream about their life once a week.

\r\n

If the soul is that of a child, you cannot help but be subtly influenced by its youthful qualities.  You gain proficiency in Performance and advantage on Deception checks to appear helpless or innocent.

\r\n

If the soul is that of an adult, you subconsciously learn how to perform certain tasks.  You gain proficiency in any one tool or skill that the soul was proficient with.

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

Creatures that are frightened by Violent Transformation take psychic damage equal to your Constitution modifier at the start of their turns as they are mentally scarred by your grotesque metamorphosis.

\r\n

You have learned enough about the other soul to persuasively imitate them. You gain advantage on any Charisma (Deception checks) to convince others that you are the other soul.

\r\n

At Stage 3, you and the other soul know as much information about each other as good friends do. You can communicate with each other more efficiently.  You frequently dream about their life and they might choose to talk to you in your dreams.

\r\n

If the soul is that of a child, you gain the ability to wield a shard of their lost destiny.  Once per long rest, you can reroll any attack roll, ability check, or saving throw and take the higher result.  If the roll was made with advantage, reroll only one of the dice.

\r\n

If the soul is that of an adult, you gain more of their abilities.  You gain proficiency in one language, tool, and skill they were proficient in.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

Violent Transformation now does psychic damage equal to twice your necrografter level.

\r\n

Any creature that fails its saving throw against Violent Transformation and is frightened must immediately use its reaction, if available, to move as far as its speed allows away from you. The creature doesn’t move into obviously dangerous ground, such as a fire or a pit.

\r\n

At Stage 4, you and the other soul have almost total access to each other’s memories. You can communicate with each other as though you were talking face to face.  It may choose to appear before your waking eyes.  No one else can see it.

\r\n

If the soul chooses, it can make you dream about it every night.

\r\n

If the soul wants to, it can prevent you from dying.  Once per day, you can effectively ignore a death saving throw failure.  Generally, only souls that you have a good relationship with will grant you this favor. 

\r\n

If your relationship with the soul is more rocky, as is often the case, and the failed death saving throw will kill you, the GM may give you and the soul a chance to bargain for your life.  This will likely require significant action on your part, if the soul is willing at all.  If the soul decides to save your life in return for a request, it has the power to kill you if you fail to perform as requested.  However, unless the GM decides otherwise, it cannot kill you while you are sincerely trying to perform the request or after you have completed the request.

\r\n

Unless the GM decides otherwise, if a soul saves your life without demanding a favor because it likes you, and later your relationship sours, it cannot kill you.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221784,"label":"Wight Heart (Necrograft)","description":"

You do not remove your own heart, but implant next to it the heart of a slain wight.  You always feel its icy presence.

\r\n

Whether you have to make a Medicine check to implant the heart and whether you had to go on a quest to acquire the heart are details best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first.  If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond. It is intended to be used with the spell Unhallowed Arts, which can also be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

Once per round, you can make a Wight Strike when you hit a creature with an unarmed strike.  An affected creature takes an additional Unhallowed Arts die of necrotic damage and must make a Constitution saving throw or deal half damage with its next successful weapon attack before the end of its next turn.

\r\n

You use Wight Strike three times between rests. When you finish a short or long rest, you regain your expended uses.

\r\n

When you use Wight Strike, you cannot simultaneously use Ghoul Strike (from the Ghoul Claws necrograft) or Profane Smite (from the Paladin's Tomb necrograft).

\r\n

You also gain some of a wight’s ability to ambush its prey.  You gain proficiency in Stealth.

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

You gain the Wight’s Spite ability. The first unarmed attack you hit with on each of your turns deals an additional 1d6 plus your Constitution modifier necrotic damage.

\r\n

A creature that fails its saving throw against Wight Strike deals half damage with weapon attacks until the end of its next turn. 

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

Your deadliest attacks become even more powerful. A creature that you critically hit with an unarmed strike cannot take reactions or regain any hit points until the end of your next turn.

\r\n

If a creature fails its saving throw against Wight Strike, you gain 1d4+5 temporary hit points as you drain some of its life.

\r\n

Your necrotic damage ignores any resistance that the target has.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

You gain the Darkest Heart ability. You can spend a bonus action to make your implanted wight heart beat for 1 minute, filling you with unlife.  While it beats, the damage of Wight’s Spite is doubled, and you gain advantage on Constitution saving throws.  In addition, you can use Wight Strike every round.  These uses do not count against the three times between rests limit. Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

You roll two additional dice when you use Wight Strike, and you gain 1d6+5 temporary hit points when a creature fails its saving throw against Wight Strike. 

\r\n

Your necrotic damage affects creature immune to necrotic as though they instead have resistance to it.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221785,"label":"Vampiric Grace (Necrograft)","description":"

You consume the blood of a vampire, blessing you with its unholy agility and vile fangs.    How you acquired this blood is a detail best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first.  If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC. Any spells that you cast through this necrograft require no verbal, somatic, or material components, even expensive ones. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond. It is intended to be used with the spell Unhallowed Arts, which can also be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

Your base speed increases by 10 feet when you’re not wearing heavy armor.   

\r\n

You grow vampire-like fangs that you can reveal and retract at will.  This takes no action.  You can use these fangs as one of your unarmed strikes once per turn.  This attack deals piercing damage.  It does an extra 1 necrotic damage and you gain temporary hit points equal to this necrotic damage as you feast on the victim’s blood or essence.  Creatures that lack blood or a similar vital fluid are immune to this damage. You can feed on recently slain enemies to gain temporary hit points.

\r\n

In addition, you gain the Vampiric Grace ability. When attacked or forced to make a Dexterity saving throw against an effect for half or no damage, you can use your reaction to move up to your speed.  This movement does not provoke attacks of opportunity.  If done in response to an attack, the attack is at disadvantage.  If forced to make a Dexterity saving throw, and your movement removes you from the affected area, you have advantage on the saving throw. If the GM so decides, this could also grant advantage on saving throws against area effects like Stinking Cloud.   

\r\n

You may instead use Vampiric Grace to dash or disengage as a bonus action or to reroll an Acrobatics check and take the higher result.  If you made the check with advantage, reroll only one of the dice. You can use this feature three times. When you finish a long rest, you regain all expended uses.

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

You can use a bonus action to give yourself the ability to climb as if you had cast Spider Climb on yourself.  This ability does not require concentration.  You can do this for up to 10 minutes per day in increments of 1 minute, so you could activate it once for 10 minutes, or five separate times of 2 minutes each, for example.

\r\n

During your turn, if you hit a creature with a melee attack, that creature can't make opportunity attacks against you for the rest of your turn.

\r\n

Your vampiric fangs now deal an additional 2 necrotic damage.

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

You gain the Bat Form ability.  You can magically assume the shape of a bat.  This functions as the Wild Shape ability of a druid, except that you don’t assume the bat’s hit points and hit dice; you retain your own.  Additionally, your bite attack deals the additional damage of your vampiric fangs.  You cannot activate the abilities of any other necrografts while in the form of a bat save the Children of the Night ability of the Vampiric Soul necrograft. Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest. 

\r\n

Your vampiric fangs now deal an additional 3 necrotic damage.

\r\n

You can climb as if you had cast Spider Climb on yourself for up to 1 hour per day.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

You gain the permanent Spider Climb ability of a vampire.

\r\n

You can use Bat Form twice between rests.

\r\n

Your vampiric fangs now deal an additional 4 necrotic damage.

\r\n

You understand that vampires are not only graceful hunters of the night, but vicious, ever-starving predators.  You gain the Vampiric Frenzy ability.  With a bonus action, you can unleash your undying hunger to become a relentless combatant.

\r\n

You gain the benefits of Haste, but you are not stunned once the effect ends.  While affected, you also gain the following powers:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • You gain the Evasion ability of a rogue.
    • \r\n
  • You gain the benefits of Freedom of Movement.
    • \r\n
  • You cannot be charmed.  Any charm effects on you immediately end. 
    • \r\n
  • Finally, you also have advantage on all Strength checks, Strength saving throws, and Acrobatics checks made while affected.
    • \r\n
\r\n

Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221788,"label":"Vampiric Soul (Necrograft)","description":"

You consume the ashy remains of a vampire, bestowing upon you its silver tongue and gift of mental domination.  How you acquired these remains is a detail best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first.  If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC. Any spells that you cast through this necrograft require no verbal, somatic, or material components, even expensive ones. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

You gain proficiency in Deception and Persuasion.

\r\n

You gain the Dominate ability.  You can cast several spells on creatures that meet your gaze, and if you have the Vampiric Grace necrograft, you can use them to make a creature willing for you to use your Vampiric Fangs on it to give you temporary hit points.

\r\n

You can cast the Friends cantrip at will.

\r\n

You can cast Charm Person, Command, or Suggestion. Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest. 

\r\n

You gain the Children of the Night ability. You can magically call a swarm of bats or rats to serve you, provided that the sun isn’t up.  If you are outside, you call two wolves instead. The called creatures arrive in 1d4 rounds, acting as your ally and obeying your spoken commands.  You can communicate with them as though you spoke a common tongue. The beasts remain for 1 hour, until you die, or until you dismiss them as a bonus action. Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The weapon attacks of any creatures that are summoned with Children of the Night are magical.

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

You gain darkvision with a range of 30 feet.

\r\n

You can reroll a Charisma ability check and take the higher result if the target(s) of your ability check can see you and is not immune to being charmed.  If the check was made with advantage, reroll only one of the dice. Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

You can cast Charm Person, Command, or Suggestion twice between rests.

\r\n

When you use Children of the Night, you can summon two swarms of bats or rats or four wolves.

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

Your darkvision now has a range of 60 feet.

\r\n

Whenever you make a Charisma ability check against a creature that can see you and is not immune to being charmed, add 1d4 to the roll.

\r\n

As part of your Dominate ability, you can cast Charm Monster once between long rests.

\r\n

When you use Children of the Night, you can summon up to three bat or rat swarms or six wolves.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

You can reroll a Charisma ability check twice between long rests.

\r\n

As part of your Dominate ability, you can cast Dominate Person once between long rests.

\r\n

When you use Children of the Night, you can summon up to four bat or rat swarms or eight wolves.

\r\n

If you summon bat swarms, you also summon a bat queen.  This has the statistics as a bat, but with the following changes:

\r\n

Its size is Small.

\r\n

It has 45 hit points, an Intelligence of 8, and adds an additional +5 to all its saving throws. 

\r\n

Its bite attack is +10 to hit and does 2d4+4 damage.

\r\n

As long as it is conscious, friendly bats and bat swarms (excluding itself) that can see or hear it have advantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

\r\n

If you summon rat swarms, you also summon a rat king.  This has the statistics as a giant rat, but with the following changes:

\r\n

It has 45 hit points, an Intelligence of 8, and adds an additional +5 to all its saving throws.   

\r\n

Its bite attack is +10 to hit and does 2d4+4 damage .

\r\n

As long as it is conscious, friendly rats and rat swarms (excluding itself) that can see or hear it have advantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

\r\n

If you summon wolves, you also summon a wolf lord.  This has the statistics as a dire wolf, but with the following changes:

\r\n

It has 45 hit points, an Intelligence of 8, and adds an additional +2 to all its saving throws.

\r\n

Its bite attack is +10 to hit.

\r\n

As long as it is conscious, friendly wolves and dire wolves (excluding itself) that can see or hear it have advantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

","sourceId":null},{"id":221795,"label":"Zombie Hulk (Necrograft)","description":"

In a very lengthy and agonizing operation, you graft onto yourself a significant portion of a slain zombie’s muscles. Your weight increases by 50%.

\r\n

Whether you have to make Medicine checks to perform the surgery and whether you had to go on a quest to acquire the zombie, are details best left up to your GM.

\r\n

You can expend a spell slot to activate the necrograft.  The more powerful the spell slot is, the more powerful the necrograft is.  When you expend a spell slot, the necrograft is active for 24 hours or until you finish a long rest, whichever comes first.  If you are a warlock, any spell slot that you expend to cast this spell is not regained until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

The necrograft has four different power levels: Stage 1, Stage 2, Stage 3, and the most powerful, Stage 4.  The benefits are cumulative, if you activate the necrograft at Stage 2, you also gain the benefits described in Stage 1.  The DC of any features gained through this necrograft is your spell DC.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 1 requires expending a spell slot of at least 3rd level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 2 requires expending a spell slot of at least 5th level.

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 3 requires expending a spell slot of at least 7th level. 

\r\n

Activating the necrograft at Stage 4 requires expending a 9th level spell slot.

\r\n

At any given time, you can have up to four necrografts active.  One cannot exceed Stage 1, one can be up to Stage 2, one can be up to Stage 3, and one can be up to Stage 4.

\r\n

This spell was originally designed as part of the Necrografter class, which can be found on DnDBeyond. It is intended to be used with the spell Unhallowed Arts, which can also be found on DnDBeyond.

\r\n

Stage 1

\r\n

You gain the Powerful Build ability.  You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

\r\n

You gain the Invoke Abomination ability.  You can spend a bonus action to swell in size, becoming a looming monstrosity.  This acts as the Enlarge spell and has the same duration, but requires no concentration.  However, only your unarmed strikes (including Bone Spikes) deal the additional 1d4 damage.  Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or a long rest. 

\r\n

You can reroll a Strength saving throw or ability check that you fail.  If you do so, you must use the new roll, and you can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

Stage 2

\r\n

When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike on your turn, you can use a bonus action to attempt to grapple the target.

\r\n

You can make a special bite attack that rattles the enemy’s psyche. You gain the Brain Gnaw ability.  When you are grappling a creature and hit it with an unarmed strike, it takes additional piercing damage equal to your character level and must make a Constitution saving throw.  If the target fails, the first time in the next minute when it makes an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw, it must roll a d4 and subtract the number rolled from the saving throw.

\r\n

Creatures without a head or brain are immune to this ability.  Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

\r\n

You can use Invoke Abomination for up to 10 minutes between rests.  You use it in increments of 1 minute.

\r\n

Stage 3

\r\n

Zombies keep on coming. You gain the Relentless ability. You can reroll a saving throw against being paralyzed or stunned that you fail. If you do so, you must use the new roll, and you can't use this feature again until you finish a short or long rest.

\r\n

You are exceptionally good at smashing things.  You gain the Door-Breaker ability.  Your unarmed melee attacks against objects, vehicles, and structures deal an additional 50% damage.  Add 5 to any Strength checks you make to destroy things. 

\r\n

You can use Invoke Abomination for up to 1 hour between rests.

\r\n

Stage 4

\r\n

You can use Invoke Abomination at will.  It has an unlimited duration.

\r\n

If you have cast the spell Unhallowed Arts (see DnDBeyond), your unarmed strike base damage increases to 1d10.

\r\n

When you are using Invoke Abomination, you can make a nigh-unstoppable charge.  You gain the Zombie Rampage ability.  You can spend an action to move up to twice your speed in a straight line.  You can move through creatures.  A creature size Huge or smaller that you move through must make a Dexterity saving throw or take 6d10 + 10 bludgeoning damage on a failed save or half on a success as you barrel straight into it.  If you have the Elemental Cadaver necrograft, you can use Elemental Surge to increase this damage.  Creatures that fail their save are also knocked prone.

\r\n

While moving, you can also make unarmed attacks against any number of creatures within range, although you can attack a given creature only once and cannot attack a creature that you have moved through.  Any creature that you hit must succeed at a Strength saving throw or be knocked prone and moved up to 15 feet in any direction of your choice.  You can choose to move a creature into the path of your charge, forcing it to then make a Dexterity saving throw or take damage as described above. 

\r\n

If a Gargantuan creature is in your path, your charge ends, but make an attack against it with advantage. If it hits, the target suffers additional damage equal to twice your necrografter level.

\r\n

If an object, vehicle, or structure blocks your path, it similarly takes 6d10 +10 bludgeoning damage, which is increased by Door-Breaker.  If you destroy it, you can continue your charge.  If not, your charge ends.

\r\n

Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

\r\n

Other necrografts can be found on DnDBeyond.  Here is the complete list:

\r\n

Abomination Gut: You can vomit acid and belch poison.

\r\n

Bonemail: You can better protect yourself and your allies.

\r\n

Bone Spikes: You gain long-range attacks and can retaliate against foes.

\r\n

Elemental Cadaver: You can channel fire, frost, or lightning.

\r\n

Ghoul Claws: You can gouge and paralyze your foes as well as swim through the ground.

\r\n

Mummified Eye: You gain a fearsome gaze, bonuses to initiative, and access to some divination spells. 

\r\n

Lich’s Skull: You heighten your mental defenses and gain minor spellcasting plus knowledge.

\r\n

Paladin’s Tomb: You’re the opposite of a holy man, but you can fight like one.

\r\n

Two Corpses in One Grave: Sharing your body with another soul, you can change your appearance and shock your opponents with a hideous metamorphosis.

\r\n

Wight Heart: Your attacks deal extra damage and can weaken your enemies.

\r\n

Vampiric Grace: You can move fast, crawl on walls, and drink the blood of your foes.

\r\n

Vampiric Soul: You can bend the minds of others to your will and call creatures of the night to serve your bidding.

\r\n

Zombie Hulk: You can increase your size and use special melee attacks.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":226363,"label":"Alternative uses of Bestow Curse","description":"

You touch a creature, and that creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become cursed for the duration of the spell. When you cast this spell, choose the nature of the curse from the following options:

\r\n

1) Curse of Masculinity/Femininity: For the duration of the spell the cursed victim changes sex; male to female, female to male, (I miss the girdle of masculinity/femininity magic item and thought it should return in some fashion).

\r\n


2) Curse of Withering: The victim has one ability score reduced by 1d4 points for the duration of the spell.

\r\n


3) Curse of Vulnerability: For the duration of the spell the cursed Victim becomes vulnerable to one type of elemental energy (Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, Poison or Thunder).

\r\n


4) Curse of Sloth: For the duration of the spell the cursed victim has their speed (walking, dashing, climbing, swimming, flying) reduced by 50%.

\r\n


5) Curse of Fools Gold: For the duration of the spell the cursed victim regards all mundane items as valuable and will hoard/collect anything and everything believing it to be valuable.

\r\n


6) Babble Curse: For the duration of the spell whenever the victim speaks they emit a stream of incoherent nonsense. The victim believes they are speaking normally and they can cast spells as normal.

\r\n


7) Dissonant Curse: For the duration of the spell the cursed victim hears the speech of other people as incoherent nonsense.

\r\n


8) Curse of Blood Weakness: For the duration of the spell the cursed victim bleeds profusely from any wound caused by slashing, piercing or bludgeoning damage. Each round they take 1d4 extra bleeding damage per wound they have suffered.

\r\n


9) Curse of blighted vision: For the duration of the spell the cursed victim is struck blind as per the level 2 spell.

\r\n


10) Curse of Unluck: For the duration of the spell the cursed victim has a reverse Lucky Feat. At any time the DM can ask the victim to re-roll a D20 and they have to take the lowest of the two, this is to a maximum of three rolls per long rest.

\r\n

11) Sleep Curse: For the duration of the spell the cursed victim falls asleep. The victim can be woken by being roughly shaken or if they take damage but will otherwise sleep through loud noises and commotions, Should the duration extend for 24 hours or be a permanent duration, then every time the victim sleeps they will remain asleep unless they are shaken awake, take damage, the spell duration ends or the curse is removed. Creatures immune to magical sleep or that do not sleep are immune to this effect.

\r\n

12) Curse of the Poisoned Touch: For the duration of the spell the cursed victim become deathly allergic to one item or substance of the casters choice. For the duration of the spell, at the start of the victims turn they takes 1d8 poison damage every time they touch the item or become exposed to the substance (max once per turn). In addition, the victim loses any resistance or immunity to poison or the poisoned condition for the duration of the spell.

\r\n

13) Curse of the Poisoned Heart: For the duration of the spell, whenever the cursed victim approaches within 10ft or starts their turn within 10ft of a particular person or object they suffer severe chest pains and take 1d8 necrotic damage and must make a constitution saving throw or have to use their reaction and at least 10ft of their movement and move away from the person or object.

\r\n
