","sourceId":null},{"id":6404,"label":"Plague of Devestation","description":"

You inflict a withering disease upon a creature you touch. The creature must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is infected by the disease. If the creature is a celestial, construct, or undead, it is unaffected. It takes 1d4 hours for the first symptoms to show. Once they do, the creature is poisoned. Every time an hour passes, the creature takes 4d10 necrotic damage. For each day after you cast this spell, the infected creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw. On a success, it loses one level of exhaustion caused by the disease. On a failure, it gains one level of exhaustion. Whenever a creature comes within 5 feet of an infected creature, it must make a Constitution saving throw or become infected with the disease also. If an infected creature drops to 0 hit points, it dies and comes back 1d12 hours later as a zombie. Only a successful dispel magic, greater restoration, or wish can end the disease.

","sourceId":null},{"id":7311,"label":"Permanency","description":"

This spell makes certain other spells, of 5th Level or lower, last until Permanency is dispelled. As part of this spell, you must expend all resources required to cast the spell you intend to effect, as well as materials worth an amount dependant on the spell you're affecting (see below).

\r\n

After casting Permanency, you immediately gain four levels of Exhaustion, and your spell-casting DC is reduced by 2 per level of exhaustion gained this way. The DC penalty lowers by 2 when a level of exhaustion is removed. This condition cannot be removed magically.

\r\n

Permanency has a few special qualities that it bestows upon the spell it targets:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • The spell's effects persist for as long as Permanency does. And so a spell effected by Permanency is not effected by Dispel Magic, instead, the opposing caster can attempt to dispel the Permanency associated with the spell.
    • \r\n
  • Spells with the Concentration tag no longer require concentration.
    • \r\n
  • The spell you cast Permanency on cannot affect more than one creature, even if the spell otherwise might be able to do so.
    • \r\n
  • The same spell cannot be permanently applied to the same target multiple times, even if it has different effects.
    • \r\n
  • Special: If a spell targeted by Permanency is of a Spell School that matches your Wizard School (if you have a Wizard Archetype), the material cost to cast Permanency is halved.
    • \r\n
\r\n

The following spells can only be cast targeting yourself:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Level 1: Comprehend Languages (2'000 GP), Detect Magic (10'000 GP), Mage Armor (2'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 2: Alter Self (6'000 GP), Darkvision (4'000 GP), See Invisibility (4'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 3: Tongues (8'000 GP)
    • \r\n
\r\n

The following spells may be cast on yourself, a creature, or an object (as appropriate):

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Level 1: Longstrider (10'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 2: Enhance Ability* (6'000 GP), Enlarge/Reduce (10'000 GP), Gentle Repose (8'000 GP), Arcanist's Magic Aura (4'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 5: Telepathic Bond (16'000 GP)
    • \r\n
\r\n

*Specifically for Bear's Endurance, a Character can regain 2d6 temporary HP after each long rest.

\r\n

The following spells can be cast upon areas or objects only (as appropriate):

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Level 1: Alarm (1'000 GP), Illusory Script (1'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 2: Darkness (4'000 GP), Gust of Wind (4'000 GP), Magic Mouth (4'000 GP), Magic Weapon** (+1 for 2'000 GP, +2 for 20'000 GP), Web (4'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 3: Magic Circle (8'000 GP), Stinking Cloud (8'000 GP), Wall of Sand (6'000 GP), Wall of Water (6'000 GP), Wind Wall (6'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 4: Wall of Fire (16'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 5: Passwall (32'000 GP), Teleportation Circle (32'000 GP), Wall of Force*** (32'000 GP), Wall of Stone (32'000 GP)
    • \r\n
\r\n

**+3 is unavailable, as it would be a 6th Level spell.

\r\n

***As Wall of Force is immune to Dispel Magic, so is Permanency when applied to it.

\r\n

Permanency can also effect the following spells:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Cantrips: Dancing Lights (1'000 GP), Minor Illusion (1'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 1: Unseen Servant (2'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 2: Rope Trick (8'000 GP)
    • \r\n
  • Level 4: Arcane Eye (16'000 GP), Private Sanctum (16' 000 GP)
    • \r\n
\r\n
\r\n

 

\r\n

Gold cost scaling, and exceptions.

\r\n
\r\n

The base cost for each tier, up to Level 5, is double the Gold cost of the previous tier. It goes as follows: Cantrip: 1'000 GP; Level 1: 2'000 GP; Level 2: 4'000 GP; Level 3: 8000 GP; Level 4: 16'000 GP; Level 5: 32'000 GP.

\r\n
Exceptions:
\r\n
    \r\n
  • Alarm and Illusory Script are both half-priced due to their niche utility-based purposes.
    • \r\n
  • Detect Magic is quintupled as it essentially gives a new ability to a base action (Search).
    • \r\n
  • Enhance Ability is 50% more, as it gives you advantage on all associated Skill Checks, and often another buff.
    • \r\n
  • Enlarge/Reduce is doubled because it increases a base stat (Size), and directly effects things such as carry weight, damage, and weight.
    • \r\n
  • Longstrider is quintupled as it increases a base stat (Speed) which can strongly benefit characters, or their mounts.
    • \r\n
  • Magic Weapon quadruples the maximum crafting price of the Magic Items of the associated rarity(s).
    • \r\n
  • Teleportation Circle is doubled because it accelerates casting time from 360 days (a Faerunian year), down to 2 hours.
    • \r\n
  • Wall of Sand, Wall of Water, and Wind Wall are all 25% off due to their specific nature(s) as debuff based walls with various utility
    • \r\n
\r\n
\r\n
\r\n

 Note to Dungeon Masters.

\r\n
\r\n

Be aware that permanency can alter/disrupt a campaign's entire direction, as the party instead buckles down to make a fortress, or chooses to lay siege to an enemy rather than go forth and knock down the door. Nonetheless, I feel this spell is a worthwhile addition to a Wizards' arsenal, and deserves a place in at least a few wizards spellbooks, be it to build a fortress, or become an all-knowing Archmage.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Some spells that might deserve to be on this list (but aren't for various reasons) are simply swept aside due to not fitting my vision of the spell, as I planned Permanency to fit (mostly) a Augmentation, Building, and Utility role. Furthermore, I discourage allowing spells of 6th level or higher from being made available for use with this enhancement (with the exception below), due to Augmentation and Utility spells becoming abruptly more powerful after 5th level.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Nonetheless, the most honourable mention for said excluded spells would be Magnificent Mansion the 7th Level spell, (estimated 125'000 GP) which is a truly amazing spell that creates a wonderful hideaway in an extra dimensional space. The Mansion presents no outward problems, as it may be completely impregnable, it is also completely immovable, thus implementing it would be fine; It could be an adventure in and of itself to give the wizard enough Gold to cast such an amazing spell.

\r\n
","sourceId":null},{"id":7583,"label":"Control Lava","description":"

Until the spell ends, you control any freestanding lava inside an area you choose that is a cube up to 100 feet on a side. You can choose from any of the following effects when you cast this spell. As an action on your turn, you can repeat the same effect or choose a different one.

\r\n

Flood. You cause the lava level of all standing lava in the area to rise by as much as 20 feet. If the area includes a shore, the flooding lava spills over onto dry land.

\r\n

If you choose an area in a large body of lava, you instead create a 20-foot tall wave that travels from one side of the area to the other and then crashes down. Any Huge or smaller vehicles in the wave's path are carried with it to the other side. Any Huge or smaller vehicles struck by the wave have a 25 percent chance of capsizing.

\r\n

The lava level remains elevated until the spell ends or you choose a different effect. If this effect produced a wave, the wave repeats on the start of your next turn while the flood effect lasts.

\r\n

Eruption. You may cause a 10-foot wide, 20-foot tall pillar of lava to erupt out of the ground at a location of choice. If a creature is located with 10 feet of the pillar, it must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC or take 3d8 bludgeoning damage and 2d6 fire damage.

\r\n

Part Lava. You cause Lava in the area to move apart and create a trench. The trench extends across the spell's area, and the separated lava forms a wall to either side. The trench remains until the spell ends or you choose a different effect. The lava then slowly fills in the trench over the course of the next round until the normal lava level is restored.

\r\n

Redirect Flow. You cause flowing lava in the area to move in a direction you choose, even if the lava has to flow over obstacles, up walls, or in other unlikely directions. The lava in the area moves as you direct it, but once it moves beyond the spell's area, it resumes its flow based on the terrain conditions. The lava continues to move in the direction you chose until the spell ends or you choose a different effect.

\r\n

Whirlpool. This effect requires a body of lava at least 50 feet square and 25 feet deep. You cause a whirlpool to form in the center of the area. The whirlpool forms a vortex that is 5 feet wide at the base, up to 50 feet wide at the top, and 25 feet tall. Any creature or object in the lava and within 25 feet of the vortex is pulled 10 feet toward it. A creature can swim away from the vortex by making a Strength (Athletics) check against your spell save DC.

\r\n

When a creature enters the vortex for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 2d8 bludgeoning damage and is caught in the vortex until the spell ends. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage, and isn't caught in the vortex. A creature caught in the vortex can use its action to try to swim away from the vortex as described above, but has disadvantage on the Strength (Athletics) check to do so.

\r\n

The first time each turn that an object enters the vortex, the object takes 2d8 bludgeoning damage; this damage occurs each round it remains in the vortex.

","sourceId":null},{"id":7930,"label":"Arcane Anchor","description":"

Choose a humanoid that you can see within range. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be anchored to their current location. For the duration of the spell, the target's movement speed becomes 0. If a spell removes the target from its current location, such as a Teleportation or Planeshift spell, the creature immediately returns to the original location of the Arcane Anchor. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the spell ends on the target.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, you can target one additional humanoid for each slot level above 5th. The humanoids must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

","sourceId":null},{"id":8327,"label":"Enduring Magic","description":"

You bend time to your will, extending magical effects and abilities far beyond what was ever thought to be possible. You can cast this spell on a creature or object that is currently under the effect of a 8th level spell or lower with a continuous effect lasting one round or longer. Once the casting begins the lower level spell will begin to appear on the subject, formed with arcane runes from the material components. Upon completion of the casting the tattoo solidifies, and the spell effect will not fade for 100 years. The subject may only have one tattoo of Enduring Magic at a time, and it may only be removed by a wish or miracle spell, or by a greater restoration on a subject willing to lose the tattoo. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":9297,"label":"Gargam's Surveillance Drone","description":"

You create an invisible, magical sensor within range that hovers in the air for the duration.  It cannot be detected by Divination magics.

\r\n

You mentally receive visual and audio information from the sensor, which has truesight out to 30 feet. The sensor can look in every direction.

\r\n

As an action, you can move the sensor up to 30 feet in any direction until you attach it to its target which must occur within 1 minute or the spell fails. The target is permitted a Wisdom save with Disadvantage.  On a failed save, the invisible sensor stays within 5 feet of its target, moving at the target's movement rate, and relays everything it hears and sees for the duration.  There is no limit to how far away from you the sensor can travel, but it can't enter another plane of existence. The sensor will move closer to its target to avoid getting locked out of a room or left behind if the target travels by teleportation circle or similar magic.  A solid barrier blocks the sensor's movement, but it can pass through an opening as small as 1 inch in diameter.

\r\n

The spell lasts until your Concentration ends, you disconnect the sensor from its target, or 8 hours have elapsed.

","sourceId":null},{"id":11043,"label":"Gutwrench","description":"

The intestines of the target creature are brutally twisted, lurching within their body. The target must make a Constitution saving throw. It takes 10D8+10 necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

\r\n

If the target is killed by the attack, their innards burst forth from their body and are absorbed by the necromantic power of the caster, granting them 4d8 temporary hit points.

\r\n

A creature with no discernible anatomy is unaffected by this spell.  

\r\n

 

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":11347,"label":"Apocalypse from the Sky","description":"

You rip open a tear in the fabric of the material plain raining absolute death and destruction on the land.

\r\n

All creatures and objects within 10 miles per caster level (in an area centered on the caster) takes 12d12 fire, acid or force damage (this includes the caster of the spell). This damage will level forests, topple mountains and destroy cities.

\r\n

However, the scale and magical force of this spell take a toll on the caster, who is mentally drained. For 2d10 days after casting this spell, the casters Intelligence and Charisma are reduced to 5.  The only thing that can reduce the time needed to recover is a boon from a God or the Wish spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":11496,"label":"Cone of Decay","description":"

A blast of necrotic energy erupts from your hands. Each creature in a 60-foot cone must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 8d8 necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

\r\n

A creature killed by this spell decays and breaks apart at the point of their demise.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 5th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":13340,"label":"Power Word Pleasure","description":"

You speak a word of power that can overwhelm the mind of one creature you can see within range, leaving it unconditionally in love with the caster. If the target has fewer than 100 hit points, the target is overcome with a powerful feeling of lust. The target is incapacitated due to immense pleasure form seeing their loved one.

On each turn the target must make a successful charisma saving throw or be madly in love to the point of incapacitation. The spell ends on a successful save.

","sourceId":null},{"id":13392,"label":"Aging","description":"

A sickly gray bolt of energy shoots out from your outstretched hand towards a creature within range. A creature that doesn’t age or is immortal is immune to this spell. Make a ranged spell attack. On a hit, the target must make a Constitution saving throw. The target takes 6d10 necrotic damage and instantly ages that many years on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage and years on a successful one. In either case, the creature is also knocked unconscious for 1 minute. If the target dies from this damage, it is considered to have died of old age and can only be brought back through a wish.

\r\n

The aging is permanent unless reversed with a greater restoration spell. The aging has no game affects unless the DM determines that the target has been pushed into extreme old age. In that case, the creature takes one level of exhaustion, which cannot be removed unless the spell is reversed.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":13406,"label":"Conjure Deep Abomination","description":"

You summon aberrations from the depths of the sea that appear in unoccupied spaces that you can see within range. Choose one of the following options for what appears:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • One aberration of challenge rating 4 or lower (friendly to you but not your companions)
    • \r\n
  • One aberration of challenge rating 3 or lower (friendly to you but not your companions)
    • \r\n
  • Two aberrations of challenge rating 2 or lower (friendly to you and your companions)
    • \r\n
  • Four aberrations of challenge rating 1 or lower (friendly to you and your companions)
    • \r\n
\r\n

A summoned creature disappears when it drops to 0 hit points. If the spell ends for any other reason, the creature immediately becomes hostile to all non-aberration creatures it can see. Summoned creatures are neutral toward you and your companions unless the option you choose specifies otherwise.
Roll initiative for the summoned creatures as a group, which has its own turns. While they are friendly, they obey any verbal commands you issue to them (no action required by you). If you don’t issue commands to them, or if they are neither friendly nor hostile to you, they defend themselves from hostile creatures, but otherwise take no actions. Unfriendly or neutral deep aberrations are willing to negotiate, though their requests are typically distasteful. The GM has the creatures’ statistics.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using an 8th-level spell slot, you choose one of the summoning options above, and twice as many creatures appear.

","sourceId":null},{"id":13436,"label":"Advanced Teleport","description":"

You and up to 8 allies teleport to any location you are familiar with. Each creature/ally must be willing.

","sourceId":null},{"id":13485,"label":"Summon Demon","description":"

Casting the spell summons a demon after 1 hour, deals damage equal to half your max hp, reduces you max hp to 3/4 the original value.

\r\n

Once the demon appears it will consume the animal, then you must offer the vial of blood then the heart to the demon. The demon will drink the blood an absorb the heart. If the blood is from one of your allies, you gains control over the demon. If the blood is from someone neutral to you, you gains the demon's protection. If the blood is from someone that is hostile towards you, you gains its enmity.

\r\n

The demon gains the form of the creature that the heart came from, and their stats

\r\n

If you gain control over the demon:

\r\n

[The demon has chaotic evil alignment and acts independently unless given a command. In combat, it rolls its own initiative and acts on its own turn.

\r\n

When the demon drops to 0 hit points, it explodes, all creatures within 20 feet must succeed on a dexterity or constitution saving throw or take 1d6 necrotic + 1d6 fire damage.

\r\n

You can summon your demon to anywhere within 30 feet of you if it strays over 100 feet away, in addition it must carry out any commands you issue it.

\r\n

As an action, you can temporarily dismiss the demon. It disappears into a hellish pocket dimension where it can leech life off any creatures it finds. Alternatively, you can dismiss it forever. As an action while it is temporarily dismissed, you can cause it to reappear in any unoccupied space within 30 feet of you. This pocket dimension is the only dimension where the demon can be summoned from, if it is in a different dimension from you it gains its freedom.

\r\n

You can't have more than one familiar at a time. If you cast this spell while you already have a familiar, the demon consumes it.

\r\n

Finally, when you cast a spell with a range of touch, your familiar can deliver the spell as if it had cast the spell. Your familiar must be within 50 feet of you, and it must use its reaction to deliver the spell when you cast it. If the spell requires an attack roll, you use the demon's modifier for the roll.]

\r\n

If you gain the demon's protection:

\r\n

[The demon must follow you and protect you during combat, you cannot command it, the demon can talk to you telepathically at any time but you cannot talk back, the demon will perish if you fall below 0 hp, instantly bringing you up to full health. The demon has a chaotic evil alignment and will often cause chaos, trouble, and misfortune in your wake. It gains +2 to every stat

\r\n

When the demon drops to 0 hit points, it explodes, all creatures within 20 feet must succeed on a dexterity or constitution saving throw or take 1d6 necrotic + 1d6 fire damage.]

\r\n

If you gain the demon's enmity:

\r\n

[The demon will immediately try to kill you, and succeed on the initiative roll, If you manage to defeat the demon you can cast the spell again using the demon's heart, blood, and corpse, the demon will reappear absorb its body and you gain it's gratitude and control over it, and the demon gains +5 to all stats.

\r\n

When the demon drops to 0 hit points, it explodes, all creatures within 20 feet must succeed on a dexterity or constitution saving throw or take 1d6 necrotic + 1d6 fire damage.

\r\n

he demon has 15 +1 per player level, It's the same level as the player. The demon knows Prestidigitation, Unseen Servant, Blindness/Deafness, Darkness, Invisibility, Fly, Gaseous Form, Vampiric Touch, Burning Hands, Eldritch Blast and Hellish Rebuke. The demon learns more at higher levels, 3, 5, 15, 18, 20. [3]Fireball, False Life. [5] Dimension Door, Fire Shield, Wall of Fire, Conjure Elemental, Hallow, Flame Strike, [15] Circle of Death, Finger of Death. [18] Power Word Stun. [20] True Polymorph. ]

\r\n

If you gain the demon's gratitude, decided by the DM or by killing and re-summoning

\r\n

[When the demon drops to 0 hit points, it explodes, all creatures within 20 feet must succeed on a dexterity or constitution saving throw or take 1d6 necrotic + 1d6 fire damage.

\r\n

You can summon the demon to anywhere within 30 feet of you if it strays over 100 feet away.

\r\n

As an action, you can temporarily dismiss the demon. It disappears into a hellish pocket dimension where it can leech life off any creatures it finds. Alternatively, you can dismiss it forever. As an action while it is temporarily dismissed, you can cause it to reappear in any unoccupied space within 30 feet of you. This pocket dimension is the only dimension where the demon can be summoned from.

\r\n

You can't have more than one familiar at a time. If you have the demon's gratitude it can still follow you as a free creature, but you cannot issue commands or gain any benefits from the demon

\r\n

Finally, when you cast a spell with a range of touch, the demon can deliver the spell as if it had cast the spell. The demon must be within 50 feet of you, and it must use its reaction to deliver the spell when you cast it. If the spell requires an attack roll, you use the demon's modifier for the roll.]

","sourceId":null},{"id":13871,"label":"Whispers On The Wind","description":"

Listen to every physically spoken word not magically obfuscated within a mile (including underground and in the air) so long as the spell is maintained. Every conversation is at once remembered by the caster and can be recalled in perfect detail up to a week later if not written down. The caster will also recognize every voice they have heard before, regardless of the conversation's volume or attempts to hide their voice by using an affectation. The spell does not, however, reveal a location. Any creature that has been under the effects of scrying before or who knows Divination magic will immediately know that they have been listened to, but not from where. If this spell is not done as a ritual, the caster must meet or beat a DC 15 Intelligence check on a d20 to not be overloaded by information and go insane for twelve hours.

","sourceId":null},{"id":14490,"label":"Fiendish Polymorph","description":"

Transform a willing creature you can see within range into a fiend. A creature can roll a wisdom save to resist the effect. Does not work on shape shifters or creatures with  0 hp.

\r\n

The transformation lasts for the duration, Or until the target drops to 0 hit points. Filled with rampaging necrotic energy the targets assumes the form of any fiend whose challenge rating is equal to or less than the targets (or the targets level, if it doesn't have a CR)

\r\n

The target's game statistics, including mental ability scores, are replaced by the statistics of the chosen beast. It retains its alignment and personality.

\r\n

The target assumes the hit points of its new form. If the spell is dispelled as a result of concentration loss or the form reaching 0 hit points, the creature returns to its original form with its original hp it had before transforming and falls unconscious and must pass two saving throws to wake up. If it reverts as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to its normal form. 

\r\n

The creature is limited in the actions it can perform by the nature of its new form, and it can't speak, cast spells it had before transforming, or take any other action that requires hands or speech.

\r\n

The target's gear melds into the new form. The creature can't activate, use, wield, or otherwise benefit from any of its equipment.

","sourceId":null},{"id":14565,"label":"Explosion","description":"

You gather a massive amount of magical energy and release it in a single beam, which flies through the air and strikes down at a point you can see within range, causing a powerful explosion on impact. Once you begin casting this spell, moving or taking any other actions or reactions before the casting is finished interrupts the casting. Make a single ranged spell attack roll, and use this roll to attack every creature within a 60-foot-radius sphere centered on the point you targeted, ignoring advantage/disadvantage. You can use a spellcasting focus when casting to gain a +2 bonus to this attack roll. Every creature that is hit takes 15d12 fire damage, as well as (3 * your spellcasting ability modifier)d10 force damage. On a miss, targets takes half damage. The sphere spreads around corners, damages objects in the area, and ignites flammable objects that aren't being worn or carried.

\r\n

Casting this spell puts a large strain on your body. Once the spell is finished, make a CON save against your own spell save DC. On a fail, you fall prone, and are paralyzed for 1d4 turns. You can repeat the saving throw at the beginning of each of your turns to recover early (the DC decreases by 1 for every failure, including the initial one).

","sourceId":null},{"id":14864,"label":"True Contagion","description":"

Your touch inflicts disease.  Make a melee spell attack against a creature within your reach.  On a hit, you afflict the creature with a disease of your choice from any of the ones described below.  The disease's effects take place immediately. 

\r\n

At the end of each of the target's turns, it must make a Constitution saving throw.  After failing three of these saving throws, the disease's effects last for the duration, and the creature stops making these saves.  After succeeding on three of these saving throws, the creature recovers from the disease, and the spell ends.

\r\n

Since this spell induces a natural disease in its target, any effect that removes a disease or otherwise ameliorates a disease's effects apply to it.

\r\n

Blinding Sickness.  Pain grips the creature's mind, and its eyes turn milky white.  The creature has disadvantage on Wisdom checks and Wisdom saving throws and is blinded.

\r\n

Filth Fever.  A raging fever sweeps through the creature's body.  The creature has disadvantage on Strength checks, Strength saving throws, and attack rolls that use Strength.

\r\n

Flesh Rot.  The creature's flesh decays.  The creature has disadvantage on Charisma checks and vulnerability to all damage.

\r\n

Mindfire.  The creature's mind becomes feverish.  The creature has disadvantage on Intelligence checks and Intelligence saving throws, and the creature behaves as if under the effects of the confusion spell during combat.

\r\n

Seizure.  The creature is overcome with shaking.  The creature has disadvantage on Dexterity checks, Dexterity saving throws, and attack rolls that use Dexterity.

\r\n

Slimy Doom.  The creature begins to bleed uncontrollably.  The creature has disadvantage on Constitution checks and Constitution saving throws.  In addition, whenever the creature takes damage, it is stunned until the end of its next turn.

","sourceId":null},{"id":15037,"label":"Wizards Seal","description":"

By means of this spell, a wizard enchants the sealing wax so when it is used - by anyone with the proper ring - to seal a document, package, or chest, only the wizard who cast the spell, or someone the wizard identified by name while enchanting the wax, can open the item. Forcing the seal on a document or package destroys the document or package. While affected by this spell, a chest or box is more difficult to break or force open; the DC to break it or pick any locks on it increases by 20.

This spell may be removed by casting Dispel Magic cast at level 4 or higher.

It's not obvious that the spell has been cast on an object. The only indication is a wax seal on the item, which is common. Detect Magic will reveal that there is a spell, but not which one. Identify will reveal that this spell has been cast on the object.

","sourceId":null},{"id":17313,"label":"Entropic Well","description":"

This spell conjures a well of entropic energy around the caster that saps the life of those trapped inside. The area generated does 3d10 damage to any creature that starts its turn within the area. Living creatures take Necrotic damage, as the entropic forces compel them to age without renewal. Constructs and undead take Force damage, as they are subjected to years of natural decay in the matter of seconds. Immaterial creatures and those who do not fall into either category above take Psychic damage as their essence endures the experience of years of idleness. If a creature is subject to multiple damage types, they take the type of damage they are least inured to but still only take 3d10 damage. Creatures can save with Constitution for half damage. The area is marked by wilted grass, damaged objects, and other signs of age, but in certain cases may be undetectable to mundane senses.

\r\n

The well is a cylinder with a height of 20 feet and a radius of 30 feet. Even if the caster has an ability that should resist the effect, there is no escaping entropy.

","sourceId":null},{"id":18268,"label":"Wither","description":"

You unleash a virulent disease on a creature that is on the same plane as you. The target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target begins wasting away from the disease, taking 5d6 necrotic damage per day for three days. On a successful save, the target suffers no damage. Healing spells can cure the target and end the effect at any time during the three days. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":19248,"label":"Chain Contingency","description":"

Choose up to 3 spells of 8th level or lower that you can cast, that have a casting time of 1 action, and that can target you or another creature. You cast those spells--called the contingent spells--as part of casting chain contingency, expending spell slots for all spells chosen, but the contingent spells don't come into effect. Instead, they take effect when a certain circumstance occurs. You describe that circumstance when you cast the four spells. For example, a chain contingency cast with water breathing might stipulate that water breathing comes into effect when you are engulfed in water or a similar liquid.

\r\n

The contingent spells take effect immediately after the circumstance is met for the first time, whether or not you want them to, and then chain contingency ends. The contingent spells take effect only on you, even if they can normally target others, unless the specified condition involves being attacked by another creature in which case you can choose the target to be the attacking creature instead for up to one of the contingent spells, as long as the attacker is within range of the contingent spell. If more then one contingent spell targets someone other then the original caster for any reason, the material component becomes overloaded as soon as the chosen circumstance occurs and explodes dealing 5d10 piercing damage to the caster, and all contingent spells fail to activate. You can use only one chain contingency spell at a time.

\r\n


If you cast this spell again, the effect of another chain contingency spell on you ends. Also, chain contingency ends on you if its material component is ever not on your person.

\r\n

Unlike the 6th level spell contingency, chain contingency will last until it is dispelled or triggered as long as the material component remains on the caster's person.

","sourceId":null},{"id":19254,"label":"Vehk's Extra-Dimensional Pit","description":"

An extra-dimensional pit opens on a point you choose within range. You can choose an area that is a 25-foot square or a 10-foot by 50-foot rectangle. The pit extends into a pocket dimension, so it can just as easily be created in the air or a body of water as it can on the ground. If the pit is opened under water it will only temporarily displace the water from the space it occupies. All surrounding water, including any above the pit, will stay in place magically. Any huge or smaller creature without a flight speed that is in or enters the area for the duration falls into the pit. Creatures inside can neither see other trapped creatures nor out of the pit itself, regardless of their size. Any other physical object not held or worn by a creature, including any terrain, will be unaffected; the pit is unable to displace it. 

\r\n

Any creature that falls into the pit may use an Action to make a Strength, Dexterity, or Intelligence check (its choice) against your spell save DC. On a success, it is able to free itself from the pit on a side of its choice using half of its movement. Teleportation abilities and spells are unable to free a creature from this pocket dimension, though effects that would move a creature to another plane (such as the Plane Shift spell) are unhindered. If an affected creature gains a flight speed (such as by the \">Fly spell), it is instead easily able to free itself using 15 feet of movement.

","sourceId":null},{"id":19344,"label":"Graviton Hammer","description":"

You massively increase the gravity in a 20-foot-radius, 80-foot-tall cylinder within range. Creatures that enter the cylinder or start their turn their must make a Strength saving throw or be smashed under their own weight. Flying creatures make this save with disadvantage. On a failed save, creatures take 3d10 force damage and half that on a successful one. In addition, creatures that fail their saving throw are knocked prone and flying creatures that fail automatically fall to the ground taking double the normal fall damage.

\r\n

When this spell is cast any ice structures, weakened structures, or  wooden bridges are instantly destroyed. Any trees entirely inside the area will fall and unsupported caverns with collapse. Any difficult terrain in the area is packed down and after the spell ends is considered normal terrain.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, increase the radius and height of the cylinder by 20 feet for each spell slot above the 4th.

\r\n

","sourceId":null},{"id":21711,"label":"Life Hunt Scythe","description":"

You draw upon the Plane of Negative Energy, forming a sickly scythe in your right hand. The scythe is a 2-handed weapon, and attacking with it counts as a melee spell attack. On a hit, the target takes 3d6 necrotic damage, and you regain hit points equal to half the amount of necrotic damage dealt. Your attacks ignore physical objects in their path (cover is ignored and non-magic armor is not added to your target's AC). On a successful hit, the target must make a Constitution saving throw or gain 1 level of exhaustion. 

\r\n

The scythe can not effect targets in bright light, and is destroyed (ending the spell) when exposed to sunlight.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 5th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":26478,"label":"Earthwrench","description":"

You call upon the earth on which you stand to throw off the shackles of gravity and float majestically into the air. Draw a circle, no more than 700 feet across or 2000 feet around, around the area of land you wish to levitate, and place the sapphire at the center of this circle. You must then spend 24 hours touching the sapphire while you cast the spell, with no other creatures within the circle, otherwise the spell will fail instantly.

\r\n

Once the spell has been cast, the area inscribed within the circle begins to rise gentle into the air, pulling a hemisphere of earth up 100 feet. The spell holds together the earth and soil, preventing it from crumbling, creating a floating island in the air. As an action once per day, you may touch the sapphire and issue one of the following commands:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Rise: The floating island rises to an altitude you specify at a rate of approximately 4 feet per second (about 3 miles an hour). The effects of moving to this altitude depend on the nature of the plane it occurs on; temperature may drop, the air may thin or you reach the edge of the plane.
    • \r\n
  • Descend: The floating island descends to an altitude you specify at a rate of approximately 4 feet per second (about 3 miles an hour), stopping if it comes within 50 feet of a solid object such as a mountain or building for example.
    • \r\n
  • Move: The floating island moves in a straight line at a rate of approximately 4 feet per second (about 3 miles an hour). This can be either to a point you can visualise, at which point the floating island begins to move in a straight line, or in a direction for a specified time or distance. If the island comes within 50 feet of a solid object, such as building or mountain, it immediately comes to a gentle stop.
    • \r\n
\r\n

Should the spell be ended, such as with dispel magic or a similar effect being cast on the sapphire, or by destroying the sapphire itself, the spell will slowly wear off. This will cause the island to float down gentle at a rate of approximately 4 feet per second (about 3 miles an hour) until it reaches the ground, at which point the magic holding the earth and stone together will fade, causing the mass to crumble. This will likely destroy any structures built upon the island as the ground falls apart.

\r\n

As the spell dissipates, the floating island will naturally gravitate towards the nearest open space of land, away from hills, mountains or structures.

","sourceId":null},{"id":27093,"label":"Book of Remembered Flesh","description":"

Choose one humanoid that you can see within range. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it is restrained as its flesh painfully begins to unbind from its body and rebind as a book in your hand. On a successful save, the target isn't affected.

\r\n

A humanoid restrained by this spell must make another Wisdom saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If it successfully saves against this spell three times, the spell ends. If it fails its saves three times, it is transformed, along with whatever it is wearing and carrying, into a book for the duration. The successes and failures don't need to be consecutive; keep track of both until the target collects three of a kind.

\r\n

The book weighs 10 pounds, has one page for every day of the target's life, and is as durable as a normal book. The cover and binding of the book appear to be made of the target's flesh and are adorned with minor details reflecting the target's appearance, interests, and tastes. Every thought and memory of the target is perfectly transcribed within the pages of the book, even those the target may have forgotten long ago. Such transcription is done in the language the target was thinking or speaking in when the event occurred. If a memory includes dialogue in a language the target didn't understand, that dialogue is reproduced phonetically and must be translated by a reader who knows that language. Any alterations to the target's memories, such as by a modify memory spell, appear in a subtly different script; however, a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check made against the save DC of the memory altering effect uncovers this subtle difference.

\r\n

Any alterations you make to the target's memories, such as by erasing or adding text or by removing entire pages, persist after the target reverts to its original state. A page containing a target's memories that is removed quickly disintegrates into nothing. The target does not get to make saving throws against any spells cast on it while it is a book, but the target is still considered an object for the purpose of determining which spells affect it. Once returned to its original state, modify memory can be used to repair the target's memories if text was erased or added, but only a wish spell can repair the target's memories if one or more pages were removed.

\r\n

This spell has no effect on a shapechanger or a creature with 0 hit points. If you maintain your concentration on this spell for the entire possible duration, the transformation lasts until removed by remove curse or similar magic.

\r\n

Destroying the book immediately slays the target.

","sourceId":null},{"id":28646,"label":"Summon Lesser Aberration","description":"

\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
d6Aberrations Summoned
1–2One Aberration of challenge rating 3 or lower
3–4Two Aberrations of challenge rating 2 or lower
5–6Four Aberrations of challenge rating 1 or lower
\r\n
\r\n

The DM chooses the Aberration and you choose the unoccupied spaces you can see within range where they appear. A summoned Aberration disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The Aberrations are non-hostile to you and your party. Roll initiative for the summoned Aberrations as a group, which has its own turns. The aberrations pursue and attack the nearest non-aberration to the best of their ability.

\r\n
