\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th or 7th level, you summon twice as many aberrations. If you cast it using a spell slot of 8th or 9th level, you summon three times as many aberrations. Be warned, the DC is raised by 2 and the physic damage is multiplied by the summoned aberrations as well

","sourceId":null},{"id":28867,"label":"Fantastic Machine","description":"

With a plea to Gond, god of craft and artifice, you create a Huge-sized mechanical construct within range. Constructed of magical force, the machine is translucent and appears glasslike. The construct cannot be damaged by normal means. Creatures can freely move through its space, though it cannot pass through areas smaller than itself. A critical hit from Mordenkainen’s Sword, a successful dispel magic, or a disintegrate spell destroys it. 

\r\n

When created, choose one of the following tasks. The machine’s design is adapted to completing that task only. If desired, the machine applies its force evenly across the surface of objects it interacts with so as not to damage them. It includes sufficient hooks and chains of force to attach to objects as necessary to fulfill its purpose.

\r\n
    \r\n
      \r\n
    • Push: The machine travels on great wheels and its large, flat ram can push with a force of up to 10,000 pounds at a speed of up to 20 feet per round in ideal conditions. Loose rock and soil reduces the speed to 15 feet and rubble or mud reduces it to 10 feet. The ram can push through brick and fieldstone walls up to 3 feet thick, and fell trees up to 1 foot in diameter.
      • \r\n
    • Pull: As above, but it can pull loads of up to 10,000 pounds up a slope or cliff at the same speed as pushing.
      • \r\n
    • Lift: The machine hovers at a fly speed of 5 feet, and can lift loads of up to 10,000 pounds.
      • \r\n
    • Dig: The machine digs a 10-foot diameter hole or tunnel 20 feet deep per round through loose earth or ice. The speed is reduced to 15 feet through solid earth and loose rock, or 10 feet through solid stone or masonry. You can choose to double the diameter, but the resulting dig speed is halved.
      • \r\n
    • Throw: Once every five rounds, the machine can load and hurl an adjacent inanimate object weighing up to 500 pounds to a range of up to 1,000 feet. Aside from obvious use as a siege weapon, the machine could throw a spear with a trailing rope over a chasm to help build a bridge, for example.
      • \r\n
    • Level: The machine travels on wheels at the same speed as described under the push entry. Swinging blades and crushing rollers clear brush and saplings or smite creatures that start their turn within 10 feet of the machine, dealing 5d6 force damage. A successful Dexterity saving throw reduces the damage by half. Difficult terrain caused by overgrowth and rough ground is eliminated in a path 30 feet wide as the machine travels.
      • \r\n
    • Span: The machine forms a stationary arch bridge up to 100 feet long, 20% as high as its length, and up to 20 feet wide that supports up to 20,000 lb. at a time.
      • \r\n
    • Convey: A stationary conveyor or water screw that moves up to 1,000 lb. of objects or 100 gallons of water at a rate of 10 feet each round a distance up to 100 feet.
      • \r\n
    • Other: Additional options are available at the DM’s option, but they must be limited to a single task.
      • \r\n
    \r\n
","sourceId":null},{"id":30332,"label":"Shadow Step","description":"

When in dim light or darkness, you teleport up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space you can see that is also in dim light or darkness. On each of your turns before the spell ends, you can use a bonus action to teleport in this way again.

","sourceId":null},{"id":32280,"label":"Bazuso's Indentured Servitude","description":"

You touch one willing humanoid creature or one unwilling humanoid creature that is unconscious (see below) and preform a ritual that lasts 6 hours. During this ritual, you meld a pair of onyx cuffs to the creature, branding them as your personal servant. For the next year, they must obey your commands as a servant. When the spell ends, the creature is no longer bound to you as a servant, but may continue serving you if they so please, but they are no longer magically obligated to obey you.

\r\n

The servant can perform simple tasks, such as fetching things, cleaning, mending, folding clothes, lighting fires, serving food, and pouring wine. Once you give the command, the servant performs the task to the best of its ability until it completes the task. Even tasks that are degrading or questionable, no matter how the creature feels personally about the tasks, it is magically obligated to preform to the best of their ability.

\r\n

When trying to cast the spell on a unwilling humanoid creature, they must first be restrained, incapacitated, or unconscious. Then, once the ritual is complete the creature then must make a Wisdom saving throw. If they fail, the spell takes effect. If they succeed, however, the spell fails and the components are burned away and lost.

\r\n

At higher levels: For each level above the original, you can preform the ritual to an additional creature. However, this will take an additional pair of onyx cuffs.  

","sourceId":null},{"id":32366,"label":"Demonic Door","description":"

An angry ripping sound tears open a portal next to the caster. An identical rip in space appears next to the desired target creature or object. It can be a place you can see, one you can visualize, or one you can describe by stating distance and direction, such as \"200 feet straight downward\" or \"upward to the northwest at a 45- degree angle, 300 feet.\"

\r\n

You may use this spell to magically grab an object that is able to be held by one or two hands. The item's weight may not exceed 200 lbs and can be no larger than a medium sized creature. Also the object must be able to be lifted or moved, objects nailed down or fixed to a space can't be pulled through the portal.

\r\n

You can bring a creature you can see forcibly through the portal. The creature can not be bigger than the caster. The targeted creature may make a Charisma Saving Throw to attempt to resist the grasping fiendish hand that reaches through the portal. On a fail, the target is pulled through and appears in the caster's hand, grappled, or may be thrown through the portal and land prone adjacent to the caster, this is entirely the caster's choice.

\r\n

You may also attempt to wretch an item from a creature's hand, the wielder of the targeted object may choose to resist and attempt a Strength Saving Throw. On a fail, the item is ripped from their hands and is transported to the open hand of the caster.

\r\n

If the object or creature would arrive in a place already occupied by another object or a creature, caster and any object/creature traveling would each take 4d6 force damage, and the spell fails to teleport the target.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":35322,"label":"Hyperbolic Time Sphere","description":"

You surround yourself in an opaque sphere that stretches out 60 ft. from the Caster. While inside the sphere they are unsearchable and invisible, even to divination of the highest level. They will spend 8 hours inside the sphere and are completely immune to all effects and conditions while inside the sphere, if a character has a condition prior to being inside the sphere it is halted until the sphere is dispelled 8 hours later. 

\r\n

On the outside of the Sphere only 1 minute passes, it can not dispelled unless by wish spell

","sourceId":null},{"id":35975,"label":"Bend Nature","description":"

You can bend the will of nature within 5 miles, shaping the land and creatures. By spending a period longer than 3 weeks concentrating on the natural land within five miles, which includes studying the creatures and plants, meditating watching weather patterns etc, you can change natures will itself. You can do a variety of things, talk to your dm about what your allowed to do. You can change weather patterns. Making it snow or halting all precipation. You can change the animals in the area habits and instincts. You can move and form the earth and stone beneath into new shapes. You can grow forests or have them die. However you cannot change anything that has been crafted by humanoids or things that are unnatural, such as a city or tower. You can change whats around it but not the settlement itself.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":36784,"label":"Summon Dimensional Entity","description":"

You cast your consciousness across all of existence and form a contract with a willing entity to bring it into reality in front of you. This entity remains in existence until the caster or summoned entity choose to dispel, or if the caster or summoned entity drop to 0 hit points. 

\r\n

For each consecutive day that the summoning is maintained, the caster suffers one point of exhaustion, as well as a spell slot of the highest level available being consumed by the summoning. When the summoning is dispelled, all consumed spell slots are returned after the next long rest. 

\r\n

If the summoned entity is of a higher level than the summoner, the caster suffers two points of exhaustion and the loss of two spells slots per consecutive days the summoning is maintained. 

\r\n

A deity may be summoned using this spell, but the summoner suffers one point of exhaustion and the loss of one spell slot per turn, and for each turn the summoning is maintained the caster must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to their own spell save DC. On a success the summoning is maintained, but on a failure the summoning is lost and the caster's hit points immediately drop to 0. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":37598,"label":"Conjure Greater Elemental","description":"

This spell creates a greater elemental servant. Choose the material component relating to the desired elemental, for the spells casting time to produce the relating elemental. The elemental appropriate to the material component you chose, appears in an unoccupied space within the spells range. (E.g.: An Efreeti emerges from its bottled smoke) The elemental disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

For the purpose of this spell, none of the created elementals have access to their Wish feature, or any feature that would conjure additional creatures. In addition the created elementals can not speak, read, or write, and only understands the spellcasters verbal commands.

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Alternatively you can use this spell to replicate the effects of the Conjure Elemental, limited to CR 5 or lower, for twice the amount of elementals. This feature uses an additional spell slot according to the chosen CR.
    • \r\n
\r\n

The elemental is friendly to you and your companions for the duration. Roll initiative for the elemental, which has its own turns. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to the elemental, it defends itself from hostile creatures but otherwise takes no actions.

\r\n

If your concentration is broken, the elemental doesn't disappear. Instead, you lose control of the elemental, it becomes hostile toward you and your companions, and it might attack. An uncontrolled elemental can't be dismissed by you, and it disappears 1 hour after you created it.

\r\n

The GM has the elemental's statistics. Sample elementals can be found below.

\r\n
Elemental Options:
\r\n
    \r\n
  • Dao
    • \r\n
  • Djinni
    • \r\n
  • Efreeti
    • \r\n
  • Marid
    • \r\n
\r\n

This spell does not create a real genie but the closest magical replication of one, therefore does not include any possible consequences it comes with. E.g.: Creating an Efreeti that hails from the City of Brass, might draw its, or the Great Sultans ire. The created creature will for all intense and purpose be perceived as its real equivalent, even under the sense of Truesight, and can therefore have consequential implications depending on aligned factions.

","sourceId":null},{"id":40842,"label":"Temporal Push","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

Upon casting Temporal Push, the caster opens a partially-formed slipgate to the demiplane of time and attempts to force a creature through it. Because this slipgate is not fully formed, the subject automatically slips back to reality at a later time. The creature is thrown forward up to 1 round + 1 round per caster level. The amount must be decided when the spell is cast. The spell removes the creature from reality for a limited time, allowing the caster to deal with other problems or prepare a \"welcome\" for the returning creature. The affected creature is aware of no passage of time. Everything seems to suddenly blip or shift about, as if they instantaneously teleported forward in time. If a physical presence is occupying the space to be returned to, the creature is displaced slightly on return. At the time of the casting, both the caster and target make separate Wisdom checks; first the caster, then the target. For every point by which the caster succeeds their own check, assign a -1 penalty to the target's roll (up to a max of -4). If the caster fails the check, or if the target succeeds (after penalties), then it is the caster who ends up getting pushed through the slipgate instead.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell of the same name, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40843,"label":"Timeheal","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

This spell takes the creature it was cast upon and rolls back its body to an earlier point in time. If it was in better health in the past, this simulates a healing ability without using clerical powers. Time is of the essence when using this spell, though, as the farther into the past the body is to be pushed, the greater the chance of failure.

\r\n

The caster is able to unerringly push the body back one minute in time for every caster level. For example, a 9th-level caster is guaranteed to restore a person to the state of health its body was in up to nine minutes ago. For every additional minute that the caster attempts to push the body backward in time, there is a cumulative 5% chance of failure. If the 9th-level caster tried to use this spell to heal a warrior wounded just under 20 minutes before the spell was cast, that would be 11 minutes further than he could guarantee success, so the spell would have a 55% chance of failing.

\r\n

Multiple Timeheals cannot be cast to increase number of minutes that the caster can guarantee pushing the body backward in time. The 9th-level wizard cannot cast three consecutive Timeheals to roll the patient back 27 minutes in time. This is because the caster is actually bringing the patient's past body into the present with each casting. Each time, that example spell goes back only nine minutes, and it brings back the same nine-minute-old version of the body.

\r\n

Timeheal cannot recall a spirit from death (unless DM rules it has not yet departed, within a single round, within the last few seconds, for example) and therefore is only useful on a still-living character. A dead body that has Timeheal cast on it may be entirely healed of damage, but it remains dead, as the body's spirit has fled. If the spirit can somehow be reunited with the body, though (say through Raise Dead, or a ghost possessing its own body), the patient will then be alive and as well as the Timeheal can make him.

\r\n

Timeheal can also be used to hurt an opponent that has recently healed itself. In this case, the caster must successfully touch the target (with an attack roll), and the target gets a Wisdom save. Any healing (or damage) done to the target since the moment that the body is being rolled back to is negated, but all the damage the body had at that point is immediately reapplied. The resources used to heal the target are entirely wasted. The standard chances of failure based on time and level still apply.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell of the same name, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40844,"label":"Temporal Disjunction","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Enchantment)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Duration: 1d10 + 5 days

\r\n

When this spell is cast, the affected creature loses all sense of time. It is perpetually late, unable to function under any time restraints. This spell is merely an annoyance unless accurate timing is crucial. Creatures afflicted by this spell automatically lose initiative and are always surprised if attacked from stealth. In combat, creatures with multiple Actions automatically lose one Action, and Bonus Actions and Reactions cannot be used. A Wisdom save negates the spell.

\r\n

Against another spellcaster, or a creature of the demiplane of time, this spell is particularly effective. Any spellcaster under the effects of the Temporal Disjunction who attempts to cast a time-affecting spell automatically fails. Any native creature of the demiplane of time also loses any time-related abilities, and suffers 2d6 + 1 point per caster level points of damage. In both cases, any ability (natural or spell effect) to slip between reality and the demiplane of time is lost. Chronomancers and creatures native to the demiplane of time gain a +1 to their Wisdom save against this spell.

\r\n

The Time Dimielemental is the hardest hit by the Temporal Disjunction: In addition to the above penalties, it also loses its ability to slip in more copies of itself.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell of the same name, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40846,"label":"Devolution","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Duration: 5 rounds + 1 round / level, or Permanent*

\r\n

When this spell is cast, the evolutionary clock of the target is reversed, and its fighting ability is increased at the cost of its mind. The target gains 1d6 in each of Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution (maximums of 22), while losing 3d6 in each of Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma (minimums of 2). Nails and teeth become sharper and usable as weapons. There is a marked increase in body hair, and other body changes might be notices (longer arms, hunched posture, thicker bones, pronounced brow, etc). At any Intelligence below 5, the creature automatically shuns weapons in favor of a claw/claw/bite attack (1d6/1d6/1d8; if a creature already had these attacks, increase the size of each damage die by one). The creature must roll a Death Save until it either fails twice, or succeeds once. If it fails twice, this change is permanent. Unwilling targets may attempt a Constitution save to negate the spell.

\r\n

For an unknown reason, Devolutionary Warrior does not have any effect on Elves. Some Chronomancers hypothesize that perhaps elves were created whole by the gods, without evolution, rather than simply having an innate resistance.  Others suppose the inherrent magic of Elves somehow interferes with this particular spell.

\r\n

Half-Elves are weakly affected, and gain only 1d3 in each of Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution, and lose only 2d6 in each of Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma.

\r\n

The material component for this spell is the tooth of a gorilla or carnivorous ape.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell Devolutionary Warrior, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40849,"label":"Create Timegate","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Area of Effect: A surface area of 20 square feet

\r\n

Upon casting this spell, the caster twists the momentum of time to create a permanent gate between reality and the demiplane of time. The gateway is totally flat (2-dimensional), but can be in any contiguous shape the caster desires, up to 20 square feet in area. Care must be exercised, since denizens of the timestreams are attracted to this portal and may be lying in wait on the demiplane of time, or possibly even attempt to come through into reality. Timegates are a liability as much as a convenience.

\r\n

The material component for this spell is a diamond worth 5,000 gp that has been on the demiplane of time for at least one subjective day.

\r\n

The caster must make a Wisdom save once the spell has been cast. Failure means the gateway collapses. Whatever the result, the diamond is consumed and lost in the process.

\r\n

Based on 2e AD&D spell Slipgate, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40851,"label":"Temporal Wall","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

Temporal Wall creates a thin barrier composed of the mist-smoke of the demiplane of time. The wall cannot be moved once created, but it can be shaped in any way (circles, domes, and so on) and placed anywhere within the spell's range. Anyone trying to pass through this wall in either direction suffers the effects of two cumulative Slow spells and a Temporal Disjunction (Creatures afflicted automatically lose initiative, and are automatically surprised if attacked from stealth. Creatures with multiple Actions automatically lose one Action, all Bonus Actions and all Reactions. Natives to the demiplane of time take 2d6 + 1 per caster level damage). Creatures can make saves against each Slow to avoid their effects, but not against the Temporal Disjunction. Missiles, breath weapons, and spell effects are also slowed by the wall, allowing victims a Dexterity save for half damage. Dispel Magic cannot destroy the wall, but any sort of magical items which destroy magic can affect this spell. Pass Wall, Dimension Door, Teleport, and other travelling spells can be used to bypass or destroy the wall.

\r\n

The material component is a strand of webbing from a Timeweaver Spider's web.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell of the same name, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40852,"label":"Conceal Temporal Anomaly","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Illusion)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

The caster splits the flow of time around a temporal disturbance. This reduces the turbulence it causes and shields it against the efforts of magical detection. A Detect Temporal Anomaly (or an item or ability with the same effect) retains any normal bonus chance of detecting the hidden effect, but its base chance is now lowered to 25%. Other detection spells (True Seeing, Detect Invisibility, etc) also have a 25% chance to detect the anomaly, but those uninitiated in the mysteries of Chronomancy are unlikely to know just what it is they are seeing.

\r\n

Temporal vortices on the demiplane of time can be hidden in this way, but the forces involved become extremely hazardous. The caster must make a Wisdom ability check with a -4 penalty. Failure destroys the vortex, ages the caster 1d20 years, and reduces the caster's Wisdom permanently by 1 point.  The destruction of a vortex will also create significant amounts of turbulence downstream in the timeline on the demiplane of time, which may attract all manor of unwanted attention from its inhabitants.

\r\n

The material component is a glass bulb filled with the blood of a Timeweaver Spider. This spell cannot be used cumulatively with itself.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell of the same name, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40854,"label":"Create Paradox","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Range: 1 month into the past / level

\r\n

When Create Paradox is cast, the caster may alter a minor event from their past, which may affect the present. Such an event could be exchanging one memorized spell for a more useful one, having brought a cask of ale instead of a cask of oil, or deciding that, instead of insulting the orcs' chieftain (who has been harboring a grudge, and now the characters need his help), the heroes insulted their finest warrior. The event to be changed should not be more than 3 hours long in duration, and it must be something that was personally done by the caster, or something the caster could have directly influenced. (Perhaps the party's Rogue actually made the insult, and the caster uses Create Paradox to explain it away at the expense of the orc warrior.) Something should always be given up in trade for whatever is gained when this spell is used. The caster can change an event as far back as 1 month per caster level into the past. It is the DM's call as to how that change propagates forward, if at all. Often, things will not work out as neatly as the caster might hope. The orc chieftain could still bear a grudge (that the warrior was insulted), or the warrior might wish now for personal satisfaction.

\r\n

Turbulence created by casting Create Paradox has a 5% per month affected chance of attracting a Time Demielemental or Chronomancer guardian from the demiplane of time.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell Paradox, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40857,"label":"Permanent Magic","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

Self-Affecting Spells:
This spell affixes the effects of certain other spells in time, affecting the duration and essentially making their effect permanent. The types of self-affecting spells upon which a Permanent Magic is known to be effect are as follows: Comprehend Languages, Detect Good/Evil, Detect Invisibility, Detect Magic, Darkvision, Protection from Cantrips, Protection from Good/Evil, Protection from Normal Missiles, Tongues, Unseen Servant, as well as any others the DM sees fit to allow.

\r\n

This spell is cast, taking about 1 minute to complete (10 minutes if cast as an unprepared ritual).  If another spell is active at time of completion, it may be targeted by the caster for making permanent with this spell.  If not, there is a brief window following the casting of this spell for the caster to cast another spell to be made permanent.  It is easiest for short-lived spells and long-casting time spells to pair with another spellcaster who can cast the target spell, so the casting times may be overlapped to allow for the effect to be active upon completion of Permanent Magic.

\r\n

Cost: The caster casts the desired spell and then follows it with the Permanent Magic spell. Each time the caster casts this spell to make a magic effect permanent on themselves, their Constitution is permanently lowered by 1 point. The caster cannot make permanent the above spells for other persons, only for themselves. This application of Permanent Magic can only be dispelled by a spellcaster of greater level than the caster was at the time Permanent Magic was cast.

\r\n

Creature-Affecting Spells:
Permanent Magic may also be used to make certain magical effects on other creatures permanent.  Spells such as: Enlarge, Shrink, Fear, Invisibility, Protection spells, Prismatic Sphere, Stinking Cloud, and others as allowed by the DM can be made permanent on a target creature.

\r\n

Cost: Like with a self-affecting application, the caster may cast this spell with a 1 minute casting time (10 minutes if cast as an unprepared ritual).  Doing so will similarly drain 1 point of Constitution from the caster, as they use their own vitality to fuel the casting on the fly.  However, there is another way to cast this spell when targeting another creature.  If the target creature is willing (or mentally incapable of objecting), then the spell may be prepared and cast like it is on objects or locations (see below).  The caster may spend 1 week in preperation per spell level, and at least 10,000 gp in goods or coin are consumed.  Cantrips require 4 days and at least 5,000 gp.  This method may not be used by the caster on themselves, as the preparation work requires the caster to move and interact with magical energies that would spoil and invalidate the prep-work.

\r\n

Other-Affecting Spells:
In addition to a self- and creature-affecting use, the Permanent Magic spell can be used to make the following object- and area-affecting spells permanent: Alarm, Audible Glamer, Dancing Lights, Distance Distortion, Enlarge, Gust of Wind, Invisibility, Magic Mouth, Prismatic Sphere, Solid Fog, Stinking Cloud, Teleport, Temporal Wall, Wall of Fire, Wall of Force, Web, again plus or minus any the DM sees fit to allow.

\r\n

For this final non-living application, the target spell and Permanent Magic may be cast simultaneously together by the caster alone, overlapping, but any spell or effect that causes casting failure during this process would cause both simultaneous spells to fail together.

\r\n

Cost: Casting Permanent Magic for this purpose does not consume Constitution, but still exacts a steep price.  High quality goods or gold in values of at least 10,000 gp per spell level of the target magic effect to be made permanent are required for the casting, and consumed by it.  Cantrip effects targeted by Permanent Magic require no less than 5,000 gp.  Additionally, while the casting time for this spell remains 1 minute, this application requires a significant amount of prep time.  1 week per target spell level must be spent in preparation before casting the spell.  Cantrips require at least 4 days of preparation.

\r\n

Magic Item Creation:
The Permanent Magic spell has also been rumored to have been used in the fabrication of certain old, powerful magic items. As the effect is not being made permanent on the caster themselves in these cases, Permanent Magic does not result in a loss of Constitution for the caster.  The cost required for this much more complex and advanced application of weaving magics into the essence of objects is sure to wildly vary for each specific application.  DMs should decide required time, cost, resources, and components for each proposed magic item a player wishes to create.

\r\n

DM Notes:
At the DM's option, any application of Permanent Magic might become unstable or fail after very long periods of activity, such as having been in effect for at 1,000 years or more. Unstable effects might operate intermittently, might produce strange or unexpected side effects, or might simply fail altogether. The DM may determine that certain spells cannot be made permanent with this spell, or that custom variants of specific spells must first be researched before Permanent Magic can be used on them by a player. In the latter case, researching the special variant of a spell costs as much time and money as independently researching the original spell itself would. If the DM has already determined that the application is not possible, this research, if attempted, automatically fails. The caster should never learn what is possible except by the success or failure of their research.

\r\n

A non-Chronomancy variant of this spell may have once existed, but it is currently believed to be lost lore.

","sourceId":null},{"id":40859,"label":"Temporal Eye","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Divination)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

This spell allows the caster to scry people or places in other times. This operates within the caster's mind, and any innate abilities or permanent spell effects placed on the caster apply. Spells like Comprehend Languages, Read Magic, and Darkvision work through Temporal Eye. Spells like Tongues, Detect Magic, Detect Good/Evil, and Message have a 5% chance per caster level of working correctly through the Temporal Eye. Spells such as Locate Object, Domination, Suggestion, and True Seeing have a 5% chance per 2 caster levels of working correctly through the Temporal Eye. The chance for scrying success, as well as the chance for detection, are the same as those for the Scrying spell. Scrying into a different time offers no further penalty. In any case, a spell or effect capable of detecting scrying attempts will detect a Temporal Eye, but does not necessarily reveal its anachronistic nature.

\r\n

There are many material components required. The eye of a far-seeing creature (eagle, hawk, etc) is held in the left hand. Blood from a Time Dog is mixed with a concoction of alcohol, sodium, and strychnine. Finally, hundreds of Strands must be collected from the demiplane of time, enchanted, woven into a veil, and worn over the face. All items are consumed by the spell, except the veil, which may be reused.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell of the same name, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40861,"label":"Delayed Damage","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Abjuration)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

This spell creates a field of temporal flux about the caster. This field intercepts physical attacks, and shifts all or part of the effects of physically applied spells into the future, allowing the caster more time to prepare. The magnitude of the shift depends on the type of attack.

\r\n

If the incoming attack deals damage, half the damage is applied immediately, and the other half is put off for the duration of the spell. This delays the need for healing, but casters of this spell must be careful not to lose track of time since casting. After the first turn, the spell could expire at any moment, and all deferred damage is then applied at once. This could easily kill a caster low on health.

\r\n

Healing potions and spells are applied first to already received damage, then to deferred damage. If the attack produces a spell effect (Imprisonment and Energy Drain deal no physical damage, for example, but require a touch), then those spells' effects are delayed for half the remainder of Delayed Damage's duration. Any prevention action taken (someone casting Freedom before Imprisonment takes effect, for instance) negates the upcoming effect.

\r\n

This spell cannot be used in conjunction with any contingency spells (spells that intentionally delay or defer self-cast spells from taking effect). Any spell of this nature placed on the caster dispels Delayed Damage automatically.

\r\n

At Higher Levels:
If a 9th level spell slot is used to cast this spell, all damage and spell effects are delayed until the end of the effect (instead of half damage taken immediately, and spell effects being delayed half the remaining duration).

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell Delay Damage, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40867,"label":"Temporal Stasis/Reinstatement","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

Temporal Stasis:
Upon casting this spell, the caster places the target into a state of suspended animation. This cessation of time means that the creature does not grow older. Its body functions virtually cease. This state persists until the magic is removed by a Dispel Magic spell or reverse of this spell, Temporal Reinstatement, is uttered.

\r\n

The material component of a Temporal Stasis spell is a powder composed of diamond, emerald, ruby, and sapphire dust, with each crushed stone worth at least 100 gp.

\r\n

Temporal Reinstatement:
The reverse, Temporal Reinstatement, requires only a single word, and no somatic or material components.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D Wizard spell Temporal Stasis.

","sourceId":null},{"id":40868,"label":"Temporal Incontinuity","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Area of Effect: 10 feet radius

\r\n

This spell sends those in its area of effect backward or forward in time, up to 5 years per the caster's level. In effect, it encases those affected in a null-time bubble and pushes them into the demiplane of time. The bubble then moves along the timestream in the predetermined direction, reenters reality at the desired time, and releases the travelers. To the travelers, no time has passed. Things simply blink around them from one moment to a sudden future or past moment. This is the only known way a caster can cause others to travel extensively throughout time without actually accompanying them.

\r\n

This can cause a real problem for subjects that end up in another time with no way back. Of course, if they happen to cause enough trouble to the natural order in their new time, the guardians of the demiplane of time may show up and give them a free ride home. The person who sent them there is likely in for a visit then, too.

\r\n

If a caster casts the spell on themselves, this can be used as an easy way to travel through time quickly with little or no risk from the dangers of the demiplane of time. It is not a cheap ride, though.

\r\n

The material component is a ruby worth 10,000 gp or more, which must be crushed into dust.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell Timereaver, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40869,"label":"Moment In Time","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

The caster focuses on a single moment in time - right now - and moves about within it. Objective time ceases to pass while they exist wholly within this moment, and all other creatures, objects, spells, and temporal events hang frozen.  From the caster's subjective perspective, this single moment in time seems to go on for 1d4 + 1 turns, during which the caster can use actions and move about more or less as normal.

\r\n

The caster's subjective jaunt through a frozen moment in time ends prematurely if any action or effect that they take or create affects another creature, or any object they wear or carry, as the effects of this perception of time at that point are no longer purely subjective. Additionally, time and space being intertwined, the effect ends if the caster moves farther than 1,000 feet away from the point in space where they began this moment in time.

\r\n

This spell is similar to a common 9th level wizard spell, except that it differs in the exact implementation of the effect, and is available to practitioners of Chronomancy as an 8th level spell, due to the caster's advanced grasp of the nature of time.

","sourceId":null},{"id":40871,"label":"Create Major Paradox","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Range: 1 year into the past / level

\r\n

This spell changes an important event in the caster's past. This is just like Create Paradox, but the event can be as far back as one year past. Such an event could be changing from a Historian to a Seer, acquiring a proficiency in Prophecy rather than Alchemy, or deciding to research a new spell rather than create a new magical item, to name a few examples. The event must be one the caster had adequate control of at the time, and something should always be given up for whatever is gained. The change should always be evident, but not necessarily work out the way the caster/player expects. The DM should also feel free to remove any items or relationships he feels would not have been found as a result of the caster's meddling, and add any items or relationships that now would have been instead, for better and for worse. After all, the things that are changed were likely important to the caster at one time. The turbulence caused by casting Create Major Paradox has a 50% chance of attracting a Time Demielemental or a Chronomancer guardian from the demiplane of time.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell Major Paradox, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40872,"label":"Lifeline Severence","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

This spell permanently detaches the caster from his lifeline. This negates the rule concerning doubling lifelines, and that's all most casters should know.

\r\n

The material components are a small silver knife enchanted to store a Lifeline Tether, and diamond dust worth 10,000 gp, sprinkled across the blade. This spell is cast while the caster is on the demiplane of time, and the knife is used to physically sever the caster's lifeline at the point it turns into the insubstantial silver mist trail.

\r\n

 

\r\n

 

\r\n

 

\r\n

DMs should know: severing one's lifeline essentially ends a character's life... at least in the traditional sense.  In some ways, this is analogous for the Chronomancer as lichdom is for a wizard, though they are not undead, nor does their alignment change as a result of the procedure.  Their mortal lifeline no longer extends into the future.  They are no longer considered \"natives\" of the Prime Material, and are instead now considered natives of the demiplane of time.  If they are destroyed, their essence returns to the demiplane of time, and their soul is lost.  They can no longer go to any heaven or hell, nor become petitioners to any of the gods or Outer Planes, as they are already essentially \"petitioners\" of Time. This is true unless direct intervention from one of the Major Powers (or a DM-decided method of altering this state of existence) occurs.  They are no longer temporally linear beings, and can be banished from the Prime Material as though Outsiders.  They can no longer be affected by paradoxes, and no longer cause paradoxes by visiting their own past history.  They are now susceptible to any spell or effect that damages or disrupts a native creature of the demiplane of time.  Their fate and ultimate well-being is now directly linked to the fate and well-being of the temiplane of time and the Timestreams.  Guardians of the demiplane of time will almost certainly attempt to contact any Chronomancer who severs their own lifeline as soon as possible, for better or worse.

\r\n

Inspired by the 2e AD&D spell Sever Lifeline, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":40873,"label":"Temporal Bubble","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)
Duration: 10 minutes / level
Area of Effect: 5 feet radius

\r\n

This spell creates a temporary bubble around the caster, which is excluded from the flow of time. While inside the bubble, the caster is immune to the passage of time, except as it applies directly to himself. The effect is that the world has frozen between seconds. This gives the caster an opportunity for actions like drinking Healing Potions, or letting a harmful spell, potion, or poison wear off. Once created, the bubble cannot be moved, and the caster cannot leave it without automatically dispelling the effect. Any creatures within the 5-foot radius are considered inside the bubble, and can interact with the caster as if normal time is passing. If they step outside the radius, they are immediately frozen in time until the spell expires, or the caster dispels it. The spell's duration is measured by the caster's subjective time.

\r\n

The material components of this spell require preparation. A crystal sphere valued at 1,000 gp or better is necessary. A diamond worth at least 5,000 gp must be enchanted with a Temporal Stasis spell and placed within the sphere. The entire device must then be touched by a Time Dimielemental while on the demiplane of time (touching does not have to be made voluntarily). When this spell is cast, the device is consumed by the magical energies.

\r\n

Based on the 2e AD&D spell Temporal Shell, from the Chronomancer suppliment (TSR 9506).

","sourceId":null},{"id":42768,"label":"Black Exhalation","description":"

You exhale a 30-foot cone of deadly spores.

\r\n

Each creature in the cone must make a Constitution saving throw against poison. If the saving throw fails, the creature takes 6d6 poison damage and loses 1d4 points of Intelligence. With a successful save, the creature takes half damage and loses no Intelligence.

\r\n

A creature that loses Intelligence because of black exhalation must repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If the saving throw fails, it loses an additional point of Intelligence to a minimum of 0; if the save succeeds, the spell effect ends.

\r\n
    \r\n
  • If the creatures inteligence drops to 3 or below the creature can't cast spells, activate magic items. 
    • \r\n
  • If the creatures inteligence drops to 1 the creature also can't understand language, or communicate in any intelligible way. The creature can, however, identify its friends, follow them, and even protect them.
    • \r\n
  • If the creatures inteligence drops to 0 the creature is stunned until it regains at least one point of Intelligence.
    • \r\n
\r\n

Intelligence loss is permanent until restored by magic such as greater restoration or more powerful magic.

","sourceId":null},{"id":42874,"label":"Blood Purge","description":"

You choose a creature you can see and try to make it violently disgorge blood from its body.

\r\n

The creature must make a Constitution saving throw. If the saving throw fails, it takes 6d6 necrotic damage and it loses 2d4 points of Constitution. On a successful save it takes half damage and does not lose any points of Constitution. A creature reduced to 0 Constitution dies immediately.

\r\n

The loose of Constitution is permanent. It can be undone by magic like Greater Restoration or more powerful magic like Wish.

\r\n

Creatures without blood are immune to this spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":43452,"label":"Xin's Creation Ritual","description":"

Created by the famed artificer and spellwright Xin al-Qasim, this ritual pulls positive and elemental energies into the Prime Material, to coalesce into high grade vegetable or mineral matter. Finding himself constantly running out of the needed materials for his creations, Xin created this spell to remove the need to hunt down crafting materials at the local bazaar, and as a way to pad his coin purse during lean times.

\r\n

When this ritual is preformed, the caster pulls energies from beyond the Prime Material, and focuses it through a sample of the desired material*. The energy is converted into matter, and takes the form of the focus material (note: the focus material is NOT used up by the ritual). The amount of matter created cannot exceed 1 cubic foot, per level of the caster, though the rough shape** of the mass is determined by the caster. The process of creating materials is gradual, with the caster creating their maximum amount with the completion of the ritual***. While more commonly available materials (i.e. iron, quartz, oak) and somewhat rarer materials (i.e. mercury, topaz, blackthorn) can be fully completed in an hour's time, rarer materials (i.e. Platinum, diamond, ebony) require twice as long to create. Materials that are somewhat or completely magical in nature (i.e. Mithril, Adamant) require three hours.

\r\n

 

\r\n

*This focus sample can be almost anything, provided that it is entirely made of the desired material, at least the size of a human knuckle and is not enchanted. It is also worth noting that using unrefined or unprocessed materials cannot yield the refined or processed material. For example, using a piece of iron ore cannot yield refined iron.

\r\n

**The shape of the mass created can be shaped into simple, basic forms. A good example is using a piece of spun hemp, and forming the created mass into a braid to form a stout rope., or a wide flat weave to make a bolt of cloth.

\r\n

***As a result, if a lesser amount of the material is desired, the entire hour is not required. The exact amount of this truncated time is decided by the GM.

","sourceId":null},{"id":43616,"label":"Gangrene","description":"

The target does a constitution saving throw. If the target fails they take 6d12 necrotic damage and a peice of their body rots away based on the amount of damage dealt and their strength score decrees by 2. But if the target is killed by this damage the head always rots away. If the target succeeds they take half the damage. A greater restoration spell will restore the body part and the strength sore to normal

\r\n

at higher levels the damage delt increases by 1d12 every level above 6. And at level 9 their strength score is decreased by 4

","sourceId":null},{"id":44632,"label":"Transfer Enchantment","description":"

This spell transfers the enchantment of one magic item onto another object, the object must be of similar or greater value and capable of carrying out the transferred abilities. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":45379,"label":"Beltyn's Burning Blood","description":"

A target of this spell must contain blood and must have taken piercing or slashing damage within the last minute. Using this wound as a point of infiltration into the body for this horrific spell, you attempt to transform their blood into a caustic, volatile acid that bursts into sickening flames on exposure to air.

\r\n

The target takes 3d8 fire damage and 2d8 acid damage and is incapacitated. A successful Constitution saving throw reduces the damage by half and allows the creature to act normally. On its turn, a creature incapacitated by this spell stumbles or crawls half their speed in a random direction. At the start of your turn in subsequent rounds, the effects repeat and the target can attempt another saving throw.

\r\n

An aura of caustic flames harms creatures and objects within 5 feet of the target and moves with the target. Creatures who enter the aura (whether through their movement or the target’s) or end their turn in the aura take half as many dice of acid and fire damage as the primary target (though no more than once per round). A successful Dexterity saving throw reduces this damage by half.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the spell’s fire and acid damage each increase by 1d8 for each slot level above 4th.

\r\n

Adapted from the AD&D 2nd edition book Volo's Guide to All Things Magical.

","sourceId":null},{"id":45604,"label":"Pesta","description":"

A gaseous green cloud expands outward in a circular radius of 60 feet from your chosen target dealing 6d6 necrotic damage to the target.  All creatures within 60 feet must make a constitution saving throw against the players Spell Save DC; taking 4d6 necrotic damage on a failed save and half as much on a successful one.  Creatures who fail the saving throw are inflicted with the \"Plague\" condition.  At the beginning of their turn, creatures inflicted with the plague condition may choose to repeat the saving throw and on a failed save take 3d6 necrotic damage; and remove the \"Plague\" condition and take no damage on a successful one.  

\r\n

If a creature afflicted with \"Plague\" is dealt fatal damage by this spell, their body explodes outward in a gaseous green cloud in a 30 ft. circular radius.  Creatures within this radius must make a Constitution saving throw against the players Spell Save DC, and on a failed save take 4d6 necrotic damage and are afflicted with the \"Plague\" condition, and take half as much damage on a successful one.  The Plague condition does not effect creatures with the undead tag.  

\r\n

*This spell was designed for a friend of mine in our home brew campaign; it is literally designed to act like plague.  It is currently named after a monster from the Witcher 3, and it is where the spell got its ingredients and its horror vibe from.  PS, this spell is not friendly fire, it can indeed TPK and this was intentional on my part.  I ask any who feel like it to leave criticism for me here, as this was the first spell I've ever brewed up for a game.  

","sourceId":null},{"id":46125,"label":"Debilitating Word","description":"

You speak a word of arcane hatred meant to mutilate the bodice of thine enemies. You choose a creature with in range and cause it to roll five constitution saving throws. For every failed save the creature or person loses a limb with the head always being the last limb to go. This spell does not function on celestial, undead, aberrations, or constructs. If the creature lacks limbs, it instead loses something of equal importance to its vital systems. The removed limbs or other parts cannot be regenerated except by means of a greater restoration spell or similar magic. If a creature's head is removed, they die outright in one round. The removed limbs appear or fall to spaces within 5 feet of the victim and rot away beyond any recognition or salvageable state so as to be useless in any necromancy or healing attempted.

","sourceId":null},{"id":46908,"label":"Selachian Cyclone (Sharknado)","description":"

A strong wind bearing the scents of fish, kelp, and the sea kicks up as the skies darken and fill with roiling green-tinted clouds. A whirlwind full of sharks howls down to a point that you can see on the ground. The whirlwind is a 10-foot-radius, 120-foot-high cylinder centered on that point. Until the spell ends, you can use your action to move the whirlwind up to 30 feet in any direction along the ground. The whirlwind sucks up any Large or smaller objects that aren’t secured to anything and that aren’t worn or carried by anyone.

\r\n

A creature must make a Dexterity saving throw the first time on a turn that it enters the cyclone or that the cyclone enters its space, including when the cyclone first appears. A creature takes 10d6 bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. In addition, a Huge or smaller creature that fails the save must succeed on a Strength saving throw or become restrained in the cyclone until the spell ends. When a creature starts its turn restrained by the cyclone, the creature is pulled 5 feet higher inside it, unless the creature is at the top. A restrained creature moves with the cyclone and falls when the spell ends, unless the creature has some means to stay aloft.

\r\n

A restrained creature can use an action to make a Strength or Dexterity check against your spell save DC. If successful, the creature is no longer restrained by the cyclone and is hurled 3d6 × 10 feet away from it in a random direction.

\r\n

Additionally, each round you maintain concentration on this spell, the storm rains down viscous predatory fish on your turn. Roll on the following table to determine what appears

\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
d6Sharks Summoned
11d4 giant shark
21d6 hunter shark
31d8 swarm of quippers
41d10 reef shark
51d12 quipper
6The storm summons two groups. Roll twice more, rerolling any 6.
\r\n
\r\n

You choose the unoccupied spaces within 30 feet of the cyclone where they appear, and may select spaces within the cyclone's area.

\r\n

The sharks are hostile to all creatures, including you. Roll initiative for the summoned sharks as a group, which has its own turns. The sharks pursue and attack the nearest non-sharks to the best of their ability.

\r\n

Sharks summoned by this spell gain a walking speed of 10 feet, and are immune to any damage or condition inflicted by the spell, but are sucked up by the cyclone when they enter its area or the cyclone enters theirs as though they were Large or smaller objects, regardless of a shark's actual size.  While in the area of the spell's cyclone, a shark summoned by this spell gains a fly speed equal to its swim speed, moves with the cyclone when the cyclone moves, and can move freely within the cyclone's area during its turn.  If the shark leaves the cyclone's area, it drops to the ground.  A shark that ends its turn outside of water or outside the area of the cyclone begins suffocating.

","sourceId":null},{"id":51304,"label":"Chain Enervation","description":"

You fire a bolt of negative energy at one creature you can see.

\r\n

Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the bolt does 10d6 necrotic damage and the creature must make a successful Constitution saving throw or gain two levels of exhaustion.

\r\n

The bolt then immediately leaps to another target within 30 feet of the previous target that hasn’t already been targeted by the spell; you choose which target to attack, if more than one is available. Make another ranged spell attack for that target.

\r\n

The effect continues attacking creatures one after another in a chain until it misses or there are no more creatures eligible to be hit.

","sourceId":null},{"id":51354,"label":"Claws of Digging","description":"

You transform one willing creature’s hands into thick, wide claws that enable it to burrow through earth and stone.

\r\n

The creature can burrow through earth at a rate equal to its land speed, and through rock or stone at one-quarter of that rate.

\r\n

A creature that burrows through stone leaves a tunnel behind it. If it burrows through soft earth, the tunnel fills in behind it (with earth excavated from ahead of the creature) unless the creature slows down to half speed.

\r\n

In addition, the creature’s unarmed attacks do 2d6 slashing damage. The claws are considered adamantine.

","sourceId":null},{"id":52212,"label":"Elasmobranchian Eruption (Sharkcano)","description":"

The temperature rises dramatically as the ground begins to shake.  With a violent blast, a volcano brimming with elementals sharks bursts from the earth at a point that you can see on the ground. The volcano is a 40-foot-radius sphere of earth and stone coated in lava centered on that point. When the volcano first appears each creature in its area must make a Dexterity saving throw.  A creature takes 20d6 fire damage and 20d6 bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. 

\r\n

The volcano's area is difficult terrain that is covered in lava, which ignites flammable objects on contact.  A creature that enters the volcano's area or starts its turn in there must make a Constitution saving throw, taking 6d10 fire damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

\r\n

Each round you maintain concentration on this spell, you can use an action to cause the volcano to gush, making lava flow down its slope and spread out across the ground in all directions, increasing the radius of the volcano's area by 10 feet.

\r\n

Spells that deal cold damage or produce water that make contact with lava cause the area of lava they touch to cool and harden into solid stone (at least a 5-foot-square section is cooled). Each 5-foot-square cooled lava section has AC 5 and 15 hit points. Reducing a section of cooled lava to 0 hit points breaks it up, causing it to be remelted into lava.  Each 5-foot-section of cooled lava is considered outside the volcano's area until it is destroyed.

\r\n

A creature occupying a lava-filled space when it is cooled must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw.  On a failed save, the creature is petrified until the cooled lava is destroyed.  On a successful save, the creature immediately leaps on top of the newly cooled lava.

\r\n

Additionally, each round you maintain concentration on this spell, the volcano hurls out magma elementals in the form of sharks on your turn.  Lava sharks summoned by this spell use the statistics of the sharks listed below, though they are elementals instead of beasts, immune to fire and poison damage, vulnerable to cold damage, and possess the following traits:

\r\n

Heated Body. A creature that touches the shark or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 3 (1d6) fire damage.

\r\n

Volcanic Camouflage. The shark has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made while in lava.

\r\n

Roll on the following table to determine what appears:

\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
d6Sharks Summoned
11d4 giant sharks
21d6 hunter sharks
31d8 swarm of quippers
41d10 reef sharks
51d12 quippers
6The volcano summons two groups. Roll twice more, rerolling any 6.
\r\n
\r\n

You choose the unoccupied spaces within the volcano's area where they appear.

\r\n

The lava sharks are hostile to all creatures, including you. Roll initiative for the summoned lava sharks as a group, which has its own turns. The lava sharks pursue and attack the nearest non-lava sharks to the best of their ability.

\r\n

Lava sharks summoned by this spell treat lava like water for the purpose of their swimming speed and Waterbreathing trait, and are immune to any damage inflicted by the spell.  A lava shark that ends its turn outside of lava, takes cold damage, or makes contact with water is restrained until the end of its next turn. If a restrained lava shark ends its turn outside of lava, it must make a Constitution saving throw.  If a lava shark fails its save three times, it permanently turns to stone and is subjected to the petrified condition. The failures don't need to be consecutive; keep track of them until the lava shark accrues three failures or ends its turn in lava, resetting the count.

\r\n

When the spell ends, the lava it produced cools and hardens into stone after 1 minute.  Any lava sharks remaining when the lava cools are instantly petrified.

","sourceId":null},{"id":52548,"label":"Nuke","description":"

The caster snaps their fingers and an explosion powered by nuclear fission radiates from them.

\r\n

 All creatures within a 20 mile radius of the caster take 50d20 thunder damage and all creatures in a 15 mile radius takes 50d20 fire damage.

All creatures within a 20 mile radius of the caster must make a constitution save (spell save dc) or become permanently deafened.

\r\n

After the explosion, a the 15 mile radius will become irradiated for 2d4 months, and any creatures within it take 1 necrotic damage per round.

","sourceId":null},{"id":57056,"label":"Tomas' Temporal Tombing • HB-MDM","description":"

The caster coats the body of a creature in oil and natron after painting ritualistic symbols upon them, and creates a knot in the thread of the target's life. The target becomes incapacitated. Until the target is awakened by a \"Cue\", they do not age, and become immune to the effects of curses, diseases, and poisons, though not the conditions or curses themselves. 

\r\n

The caster may choose a \"Cue\". This may be a word, action, or ritual that must be performed within 30 feet of the target in order to wake them, and end the effects of this spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":57970,"label":"Transmute Wood to Sand","description":"

You choose an area of 40 cubic feet around you made of wood and turn it into sand or vice-versa.

\r\n

This spell was first created by Abramelinus, the mage.

\r\n
