","sourceId":null},{"id":61369,"label":"Cacharian Quake (Sharkquake)","description":"

You create a seismic disturbance which unleashes voracious elemental sharks at a point on the ground that you can see within range. For the duration, an intense tremor rips through the ground in a 100-foot-radius circle centered on that point and shakes creatures and structures in contact with the ground in that area.

\r\n

The ground in the area becomes difficult terrain. Each creature on the ground that is concentrating must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature's concentration is broken.

\r\n

When you cast this spell and at the end of each turn you spend concentrating on it, each creature on the ground in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is knocked prone.

\r\n

This spell has the following additional effects:

\r\n

Fissures. When you cast the spell and at the start of each of your turns, a new fissure opens in the spell's area. These fissures open in locations chosen by the GM.  Each is 1d10 × 10 feet deep, 10 feet wide, and extends from one edge of the spell's area to the opposite side. A creature standing on a spot where a fissure opens must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or fall in. A creature that successfully saves moves with the fissure's edge as it opens.

\r\n

Land Sharks.  Each time a fissure opens, it unleashes earth elementals in the form of sharks on your turn.  Land sharks summoned by this spell use the statistics of the sharks listed in the table below, though with the following alteration:  They are elementals instead of beasts, have a +2 bonus to AC, are resistant to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks, are immune to poison damage and the conditions: exhaustion, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, unconscious;  are vulnerable to thunder damage, and possess the following traits:

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n

Earth Glide. The land shark can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone, and have a burrow speed equal to their swim speed. While doing so, the elemental doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

\r\n

Siege Monster.  The land shark deals double damage to objects and structures.

\r\n
\r\n
\r\n

Roll on the following table to determine what appears:

\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n
d6Sharks Summoned
11d4 giant shark
21d6 hunter shark
31d8 swarm of quippers
41d10 reef shark
51d12 quipper
6The fissure summons two groups. Roll twice more, rerolling any 6.
\r\n
\r\n

You choose the unoccupied spaces within the quake's area where they appear.

\r\n

The land sharks are hostile to all creatures, including you. Roll initiative for the summoned land sharks as a group, which has its own turns. The land sharks pursue and attack the nearest non-land sharks to the best of their ability.

\r\n

Land sharks summoned by this spell treat earth like water for the purpose of their swimming speed and Waterbreathing trait, and automatically succeed on all saving throws incurred by this spell, including those to avoid collapsing buildings.  A land shark that ends its turn above ground or immersed in water begins suffocating.

\r\n

A fissure that opens beneath a structure causes it to automatically collapse (see below).

\r\n

Structures. The tremor deals 50 bludgeoning damage to any structure in contact with the ground in the area when you cast the spell and at the start of each of your turns until the spell ends. If a structure drops to 0 hit points, it collapses and potentially damages nearby creatures. A creature within half the distance of a structure's height must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 5d6 bludgeoning damage, is knocked prone, and is buried in the rubble, requiring a DC 20 Strength (Athletics) check as an action to escape. The GM can adjust the DC higher or lower, depending on the nature of the rubble. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and doesn't fall prone or become buried.

","sourceId":null},{"id":62349,"label":"Greater Earthbind","description":"

Choose one airborne creature you can see within range.  Yellow strips of magical energy loop around the creature.  The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or fall. 

\r\n

The target's flying speed is reduced to 0 feet for the spell’s duration.  Additionally, once the target hits the ground, it becomes restrained until the spell ends. 

\r\n

At Higher Levels.  When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 5th. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":67265,"label":"Conjure Devil","description":"

You summon a devil of challenge rating 10 or lower, which appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. The devil disappears when it drops to 0 hit points, when the summoner successfully damages the devil or the combat encounter ends. When the encounter is longer than the time given by the duration, the devil simply leaves.

\r\n

The devil is friendly to you and your companions, except those who are considered enemies (enemies are considered any creatures, who are hostile or any good alignment (party members included)), for the duration. \"Enemy party members\" won't be attacked by the devil, unless ordered, but same goes for saving them. Roll initiative for the devil, which has its own turns. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you), as long as they don't violate its alignment. If you don't issue any commands to the devil, it defends itself from hostile creatures but otherwise takes no actions.

\r\n

The GM has the devil's statistics.

\r\n

 A further prerequisite is that only creatures with lawful/neutral evil/neutral alignment can cast this spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":67823,"label":"Conjure Magical Beasts","description":"

You summon fey spirits that take the form of beasts or monstrosities (without legendary actions) and appear in unoccupied spaces that you can see within range. Choose one of the following options for what appears:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • One beast or monstrosity of challenge rating 15 or lower
    • \r\n
  • Two beasts or monstrosities of challenge rating 7 or lower
    • \r\n
  • Four beasts or monstrosities of challenge rating 3 or lower
    • \r\n
  • Eight beasts or monstrosities of challenge rating 1 or lower
    • \r\n
\r\n


Each beast and monstosity is also considered fey, and it disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The summoned creatures are friendly to you and your companions. Roll initiative for the summoned creatures as a group, which has its own turns. They obey any verbal commands that you issue to them (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to them, they defend themselves from hostile creatures, but otherwise take no actions.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":71394,"label":"Hollow Earth","description":"

Hollow Earth is a 7th level spell which creates a 20’ radius spherical void starting 2 to 20 ft away, at the discretion of the caster – usually below him, but if facing sheer cliff, it can be cast forward. The size and distance vary by the level at which the spell is actually cast:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • 7th Level - 20 ft radius - 2 to 20 ft from caster touch
    • \r\n
  • 8th Level - 30 ft radius - 7 to 32 ft from caster touch
    • \r\n
  • 9th Level - 40 ft radius - 24 to 35 ft from caster touch
    • \r\n
\r\n

The void is created by compaction and heat, regardless of the material being manipulated as long as it is solid matter. If the majority of the material is liquid or already a void, the spell will fail, and the caster will be generally aware of why the spell failed, for example, he may get the impression that the location is liquid saturated, but may not know if it is because of water, lava, or green ink. Minor imperfections in the target area will be of no consequence. The spell will also fail if cast on living matter or an area that contains significant amounts of living matter. Fundamentally, the spell works on dirt and rock. The spell only works on the Prime Material plane, and takes about a day to cool.

\r\n

The spell will produce a perfect sphere with a smooth load-bearing outer shell. The spell also creates an indelible marker in the caster’s mind which is equivalent for teleportation purposes to a \"permanent circle\". Generally a flat flooring surface is installed, followed shortly by a Teleportation Circle.

","sourceId":null},{"id":72028,"label":"Improved Teleportation Circle","description":"

As you cast the spell, you draw a 10-foot diameter circle outlined in a unique sequence of arcane sigils. You then stand in the Circle and recite the sigil sequence of another Teleportation Circle known to you. A shimmering portal opens within the circle you drew and remains open until the end of your next turn. Any creature that enters the portal instantly appears in the destination circle (or within the nearest unoccupied space). This means of transit is one-way.

\r\n

Casting Teleportation Circle from scratch in this manner leaves a temporary circle behind, also called a Node. This existing Circle can be reused (as a departure point or destination) as long as the circle is undisturbed. Under normal circumstances, a Node has a cumulative 10% per day of becoming unusable unless a spellcaster with knowledge of this spell inspects it and corrects any disturbances in the drawing (1 minute). If a significant disruption of the pattern occurs, a spellcaster must re-cast Teleportation Circle to restore the Node.  

\r\n

When you first gain the ability to cast this spell, you learn the sigil sequences for two destinations on the Material Plane, determined by the DM. You can learn additional sigil sequences during your adventures. You can commit a new sigil sequence to memory after studying it for 1 minute.

\r\n

Creating a Nexus

\r\n

A semi-permanent Teleportation Circle, called a Nexus, is created through the ongoing maintenance and use of a Node. Each time a Node is used to travel to a different destination, it becomes stronger, burning the arcane sigils into the surface they were drawn on. Using a Node to teleport to 20+ different destinations transforms it into a Nexus . A Nexus is no longer subject to daily wear.

\r\n

A Nexus isn’t truly permanent, however. It draws power from its destinations. If all of its destinations are simple Nodes , the Nexus will fade as each of its destination Nodes erode. If a network of interconnected Nexus is created, however, they become a self-sustaining. Only by deliberate sabotage can a Teleportation Circle network be disrupted. Such sabotage is sometimes called for, however.  

\r\n

The sigil sequences of Nexus are closely guarded secrets, as they can leave fortresses and sanctums open to magical intrusion. Once the sequence of a Nexus is known to one’s enemies, the only option is to physically destroy the circle and redraw a new one with a different sequence of symbols. This can have cascading effects on an entire teleportation network if other Nexus were drawing power from it.

","sourceId":null},{"id":77388,"label":"Harmful Bond","description":"

This spell binds a target creature you touch and forces it to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the spell fails. On a failure, the spell creates a parasitic connection between you and the target. While the target is within 60 feet of you, you have resistance to all damage. Also, each time you take damage, the target takes the same amount of damage.

\r\n

Additionally, if you are a subject to a harmful condition (such as poisoned, paralyzed etc.) caused by magic (such as spells, magical poisons etc.) while under the effect of this spell, you can use your reaction to try and redirect the condition onto the bonded target. If you do so, the target must make a saving throw against the condition as normal - on a failure, it is afflicted by the condition, and on a success, it resists and you must make a saving throw against the condition as you normally would. Either way, the target can then repeat its saving throw against your bond.

\r\n

At the start of each of the target turns, if it has taken any damage as a result of your bond since its last turn, it can repeat its saving throw. On a success, the spell ends.

\r\n

The spell ends if either you or the target drop to 0 hit points or if you and the target become separated by more than 60 feet. It also ends if you cast the spell again or if its cast on you. You can also dismiss the spell as a bonus action.

","sourceId":null},{"id":78297,"label":"Rip and Tear","description":"
\r\n
This spell forcibly rips the target's blood out through their skin. The target may make Constitution saving throw, taking 10d8+20 piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful save. This spell cannot be used against creatures who lack blood, such as constructs or most undead.
\r\n
\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":78850,"label":"Light Travel","description":"

When you cast this spell you and up to 8 willing creatures you can see within 15 feet of you are transformed into small orbs of light of half a foot in diameter. Equipment and anything you or the targeted creatures, hereafter referred to as your companions, are carrying are merged into the new form and become inaccessible.

\r\n

While in the light form the following applies to you and your companions:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Cannot cast spells, attack or take any actions except Dash action or to revert to normal form (see below about reverting).
    • \r\n
  • Cannot use objects, speak or interact with environment in any way.
    • \r\n
  • Gain the ability to take Dash action as a bonus action.
    • \r\n
  • Gain flying speed 400 feet with hover that also provides immunity to being prone.
    • \r\n
  • Gain resistance to all forms of damage.
    • \r\n
  • Cannot gain any levels of exhaustion as a result of travel no matter how fast or far travelled.
    • \r\n
  • Can communicate telepathically with the other creatures affected by this spell cast by you no matter the distance as long as they are on the same plane of existence.
    • \r\n
  • Can use an action to revert to normal form.
    • \r\n
\r\n

In addition to the above you, as the caster, can use an action to force a companion to revert to normal form. Any creature affected by this spell will also revert to normal form if they receive any damage, fall unconscious or die.

\r\n

When a creature affected by this spell reverts to normal form the spell ends for them.

\r\n

If the light form ends for a creature affected by this spell while it is still in the air then the creature will descend at a rate of 60 feet per round for 1 minute or until they land. If they land during this time they do so safely without fall damage. If they do not land within 1 minute then they begin to fall as normal.

","sourceId":null},{"id":79822,"label":"Blasphemous Embodiment","description":"

A blasphemous and forbidden ritual once sealed away by Ioun, this spell allows the caster to draw the essence of a god into a mortal body which can then be slain, killing the god. Once you have the components prepared, the caster must maintain their concentration and perform the unholy incantation for twenty four hours without rest. The deity being summoned knows the spell is being cast on them, but not where the spells is being cast. They may immediately send servants to locate and stop the ritual before it is completed.

\r\n

When the ritual has reached its completion, the caster must touch a willing creature. That creature's soul is destroyed and is replaced with the essence of the god the caster has chosen to embody. The body transforms to take on the aspects of the deity that now inhabits it, and the stats change accordingly. However the new body is mortal and shares the limitations of mortal creatures. It can have no more than 33d20 + 330 hit points and an Armor Class no greater than 25.

\r\n

If the caster touches an unwilling creature, you must first make an unarmed attack to hit the creature; then that creature must make a Charisma saving throw vs your spell save DC. On a succesful save, the target takes 12d12 + 20 psychic damage, you take half as much psychic damage, and the spell is expended. On a failed saving throw, the target's soul is destroyed and the god is incarnated as normal.

","sourceId":null},{"id":79931,"label":"Terrible Rend","description":"

You blast a creature that you can see within range with a flurry of magical slashes. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw against the caster's spell DC. On a failed save, it takes 8d8 slashing damage, or half as much damage on a successful save. If the target fails the saving throw, the target is afflicted with Bleeding status. 

\r\n

Bleeding:

\r\n

- At the start of every round, the afflicted target takes 2d8 necrotic damage. Whenever the afflicted target takes an Action, Bonus Action, Reaction or moves more than 10ft of movement, the target takes 2d8 necrotic damage. The effect can be ended prematurely through healing half of all initial slashing damage received.

\r\n

- Constructs and Undead are immune to the Bleeding effect.

\r\n

At higher levels:

\r\n

For every level above 6, increase initial damage by 2d8 and increase rounds afflicted by 1.

","sourceId":null},{"id":81159,"label":"Harden Armor/Weapon","description":"

Harden Armor/Weapon can only be used on armor or weapons that would fit inside a 3 ft cube or in a prism with a volume of 27 cubic feet. If the target armor/weapon doesn't fit completely within the cube/prism it gains no benefit from this spell. The affected armor/weapon retains its original weight, size, and flexibility, and it is also considered to be magical.

\r\n

The material component used must be as hard as or harder than the target armor/weapon, otherwise the spell fails.

\r\n

Clothes that are targeted by this spell give the wearer a base AC of 12(stone), 13(steel), or 14(diamond). Affected light armor gives the wearer a +2(stone), +3(steel), or +4(diamond) boost to AC. Affected medium armor gives the wearer a +2(steel) or +3(diamond) boost to AC. Affected heavy armor gives the wearer a +1(steel) or +2(diamond) boost to AC.

\r\n

Wooden objects/weapons that are affected by this spell gain  a +2(stone), +3(steel), or +4(diamond) Attack Bonus. Stone objects/weapons gain a +1(stone), +2(steel), or +3(diamond) Attack Bonus. Metal objects/weapons gain a +1(steel) or +2(diamond) Attack Bonus.

\r\n

Harden Armor/Weapon can become permanent if diamond is the material component used and if the spell is cast consecutively so as to remain active for 36 hours.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":84097,"label":"Unbound Contingency","description":"

Choose any spell that you can cast. You cast that spell--called the contingent spell--as part of casting unbound contingency, expending spell slots for both, but the contingent spell doesn't come into effect. Instead, it takes effect when one or more specific circumstances occur. You describe (those) circumstances when you cast the two spells. For example, an unbound contingency cast with water breathing might stipulate that water breathing comes into effect whenever you are engulfed in water or a similar liquid, until the spell ends.

\r\n

The contingent spell takes effect immediately after the circumstances are met, whether or not you want it to. The unbound contingency spell ends when it is dispelled.

\r\n

The unbound contingency spell can only be dispelled when the caster speaks a certain phrase, which the caster decides beforehand, or by divine means.

\r\n

Unlike the 6th level contingency spell, unbound contingency has no time limits, and will continue to repeat its effect until the spell ends.

\r\n

When casting unbound contingency, the caster must perform a wisdom saving throw. If failed, the caster drops to 1 hp, but the spell is still cast.

\r\n

The contingent spell takes effect only on you, even if it can normally target others. You can use only one unbound contingency spell at a time.
If you cast this spell again, the effect of another unbound contingency spell on you ends. Also, unbound contingency ends on you if its material component is ever not on your person.

","sourceId":null},{"id":84223,"label":"Adderson's Hemorrhaging Gaze","description":"

 A creature you can see must make a Constitution save. It takes 4d8 necrotic damage on a fail, or half on a success. Also on a fail, the extreme pain deals another 2d8 and forces it prone at the end of each its turns. After this it can make another Constitution save, ending the spell on a success. This spell has no effect on undead or constructs.

\r\n

At Higher Levels: You can target one additional creature for each slot level above 4st. The creatures must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

","sourceId":null},{"id":86450,"label":"Enervating Strike","description":"

Empower a melee weapon with Necrotic energy. The weapon will remain empowered for 24 hours or until the wielder of the weapon decides to expend the energy on a successful melee attack.

\r\n

When expended, the necrotic energy flows into the wound created by the attack, infecting the target and withering them from within, dealing 4d8 instantly and 2d8 Necrotic damage at the start of the victims next turn and every turn thereafter. The victim can make a CON saving throw with disadvantage before the recurring damage is dealt. On a successful save, the spell is ended. If the victim fails three saves in a row or critically fails a saving throw, this spell takes hold and can only be removed by using Dispel Magic with disadvantage or with a Wish.

\r\n

Damage dealt by this ability heals the user for half of the damage dealt.

\r\n

At Higher Levels: Every spell slot expended beyond 5th level increases the initial Necrotic damage by 1d8, and every second spell slot expended beyond 5th increases the damage over time component by 1d8 Necrotic damage.

","sourceId":null},{"id":87428,"label":"Bonetwister","description":"

You target one creature within 120 feet that has a normal bone structure. That creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw. On a failure the creature is incapacitated until the end of it's next turn, takes 45 (10d8) piercing damage, and if it fails by five or more, must roll on this table. On a success, the creature takes 36 (8d8) piercing damage and suffers no other effects.

\r\n

1. Organ damage. The target takes another 36 (8d8) piercing damage and make another save. On a success the creature suffers no adverse effects and on a failure the creature is stunned for one minute. If it fails the save by five or more it dies.

\r\n

2. Limb loss. The target loses 1d4 of it's limbs, or at least cannot use them.

\r\n

3. Spine/brain damage. The creature must make another save. If it fails the save it dies. On a success the creature suffers major brain damage. Work with your GM to find out the effects, eg always is under the equivalent of a confusion spell, permanently paralyzed, loses control of a limb, forgets everything.

\r\n

4.Muscle damage. The target takes an additional 9 (2d8) piercing damage and loses 1d4 points of strength.

","sourceId":null},{"id":88418,"label":"Rusting Grasp","description":"

Any nonmagial metal item you touch becomes instantaneously rusted, pitted and worthless, effectively destroyed.

\r\n

Make a melee spell attack against a creature or nonmagical object no greater than 3 feet in any dimension.

\r\n

If the target was an object, on a hit all metal components of that object are instantly destroyed.

\r\n

If the target was a creature, on a hit choose either a metal shield or weapon it is wielding, or metal armor it is wearing. That item takes a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to the AC it offers. The armor is destroyed when it has an AC of 10 or a shield that drops to a +0 bonus is destroyed. Metal weapons in use by an opponent targeted by this spell are more difficult to grasp. If you hit the weapon with this attack (not the other way around) the metal weapon takes a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to -5, the weapon is destroyed. Use the AC of the creature wielding the weapon to determine the AC of the weapon. Using this spell to damage weapons provokes an opportunity attack.

\r\n

Note: Striking at an opponent’s weapon provokes an attack of opportunity. Also, you must touch the weapon and not the other way around.

\r\n

Against a ferrous creature, rusting grasp instantaneously deals 3d6 points of damage +1 per caster level (maximum +15) per successful attack. The spell lasts for 1 round per level, and you can make one melee touch attack per round.

","sourceId":null},{"id":90385,"label":"Partial Polymorph","description":"

Choose one part of a creature or humanoid that you want to meld onto or replace on yourself or a willing subject (ie. give yourself wings or claws without changing your entire physical appearance). The transformation lasts for the duration, or until the target drops to 0 hit points or dies. If you concentrate on this spell for the full duration, the transformation lasts until it is dispelled.

\r\n

This spell has no effect on a shapechanger or a creature with 0 hit points. An unwilling creature can make a Wisdom saving throw, and if it succeeds, it isn't affected by this spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":96608,"label":"Summon Aberration","description":"

Uttering an incomprehensible incantation, you conjure an aberration from beyond the stars. You choose the aberration’s type, which must be one of challenge rating 6 or lower, such as a chuul or otyugh. The aberration appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. The aberration disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The aberration is unfriendly toward you and your companions. Roll initiative for the aberration, which has its own turns. It is under the Dungeon Master’s control and acts according to its alien nature on each of its turns. The DM has the creature’s statistics.

\r\n

On each of your turns, you can try to issue a mental command to the aberration (no action required by you). It obeys the command if the likely outcome is in accordance with its desires. Otherwise, you must make a Charisma (Deception, Intimidation, or Persuasion) check contested by its Wisdom (Insight) check. If your check fails, the aberration becomes immune to your mental commands for the duration of the spell, though it can still carry out your commands if it chooses. If your check succeeds, the aberration carries out your command — such as “consume the flesh of my enemies,” “scour the depths of the ebon fortress,” or “bear my ultimatum to the emperor” — until it completes the activity, at which point it returns to you to report having done so.

\r\n

If your concentration ends before the spell reaches its full duration, the aberration doesn’t disappear if it has become immune to your mental commands. Instead, it acts in whatever manner it chooses for 3d6 minutes, and then it disappears.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the challenge rating increases by 1 for each slot level above 5th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":97112,"label":"Rigor Mortis","description":"

This spell creates the affects of stiff muscles after death- known as Rigor Mortis- in a still living person. First, select which enemy body part you want to target. ex) Arm, leg. Make an attack roll, and the enemy must make a dex save. On fail, the selected body part becomes stiff and paralyzed, locking it up. This spell does 4d6 necrotic damage due to rapid cellular death, and the enemy must make a con save. On fail, the condition becomes more permanent, and only spells like Wish and Greater Restoration can cure the malignant magic. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":100473,"label":"Lifeline Bifurcation","description":"

School: Chronomancy (Transmutation)
(Intended for use with the Chronomancer subclass)

\r\n

Quick Description:
On casting...
- Pick a target creature within 60' (or self) : There are now two of the target creature, for the next minute.
- Roll percentile : base 30% chance that hostile creatures from the demiplane of time are summoned.
- Roll percentile : base 10% chance of Temporal Storm for each powerful/historically pivotal item duplicated.
On spell end...
- Flip a coin to pick a copy : that copy and all gear they appeared with vanishes.  Now only spells/charges/abilities the remaining copy used count as spent.
- Target makes Wisdom save vs base DC 15, or suffers Disadvantage on all rolls for 1d6 days.

\r\n

Full Description:
There are now two of the target creature, for the next minute...  This dangerous spell causes a single target creature in range that the caster can see to begin to exist in two mutually exclusive states of probability, causing the target's lifeline to fork temporarily.  For the next minute, that creature exists in two places at once, each instance of it acting according to their own subjective perspective and circumstance, until reality is able to correct the anomaly.  Each instance of the target creature has all of their non-magical (see At Higher Levels for magic items effected with higher level slots) equipment and items, their unspent spell slots, and unused abilities.  Any magical items that were not bifurcated are evenly divided between the two creature instances as their controller sees fit, but must be decided upon immediately as the spell is cast.  Each instance of the target creature may use any or all of their independent resources, without effecting the quantity of the other instance.  Keep track of consumables, charges, spells, and abilities used separately for each instance of the target creature.  This is essentially like having a twin of the target creature for the duration of the spell, as well as a second piece of every affected item they were carrying when the spell was cast.

\r\n

Control:
Both instances of the target creature share all initiatives, and are both controlled by the original character's owner (DM if NPC, Player if PC, etc), though the group may decide to allow two people to separately control each instance, with the owner's explicit permission, if it would simplify things or enhance fun.

\r\n

Spell End:
One random copy, and all gear they started with vanishes; the other remains.  Only spells/charges/abilities the remaining copy used were spent...  At the end of this spell's duration, one of the two instances is chosen at random.  The selected instance and all their original bifurcated gear (regardless of who currently holds it) vanishes, and only the other instance now remains.  Only item charges, spells, abilities, consumables, damage, healing, status effects, afflictions, etc that the remaining creature has used or is suffering now apply.  (It may be helpful to refer to the copies as \"Heads\" and \"Tails\", \"Evens\" and \"Odds\", \"High\" and \"Low\", etc as soon as the spell is cast, to help track which copy vanishes when the spell ends.)

\r\n

This spell ends prematurely if either of the creature instances is slain, destroyed, petrified, imprisoned (via the spell Imprisonment), or afflicted by any other similar character-ending effect.  If this happens, immediately select one of the two creature instances at random, as you normally would.  If the afflicted instance ends up being the one that remains, the creature is now suffering the affliction.

\r\n

This spell also ends immediately if anyone casts Lifeline Bifurcation on a creature already affected by this spell.

\r\n

Any non-bifurcated items that the vanished instance might have picked up or been given during the duration of the spell are left on the ground where they vanished.  Any duplicated items dropped or given to another character by the vanished instance before the spell ended vanish along with the creature.

\r\n

Risks:
A base 30% chance that hostile creatures from the demiplane of time are summoned...  Casting this spell is a severe violation of the natural order of temporal mechanics, and essentially creates a short-lived, but very real paradox.  Much of the magic power of this spell is, in fact, spent simply containing this paradox so that it doesn't damage reality.  Large amounts of turbulence are created in the time-stream of the demiplane of time.  There is a 30% chance that this attracts the attention of some inhabitants of that demiplane.

\r\n

A Base 10% chance of Temporal Storm for each powerful item duplicated...  Additionally, powerful or important items that get bifurcated by this spell carry a risk of inflating this paradoxical event to the point that it exceeds the spell's constraints and damages the fabric of reality.  The DM decides what items are famous, historically influential, or powerful enough to be considered \"troublesome\" should two instances of them exist simultaneously.  For each \"troublesome\" item bifurcated in this way, there is a cumulative 10% chance that a hole is torn in reality.  If this should happen, a massive Temporal Storm of tornadoes and mist-smoke will form, immediately pulling the caster, the target creature, and any living creatures within 100 feet of them out of reality, leaving them stranded in the demiplane of time.  Artifacts (allowed at higher level castings) are automatically considered \"troublesome\", unless the DM rules otherwise (such as might be the case for certain Chronomancer Artifacts).  Roll this probability as the spell is cast.

\r\n

A Wisdom save vs base DC 15, or suffers Disadvantage on all rolls for 1d6 days...  Finally, when this spell ends, the target must make a Wisdom save to avoid long term scarring to their lifeline.  On a failed save, the target's fate is damaged, and as a result, they suffer Disadvantage on all rolls they make for the next 1d6 days.  This rotten run of luck due to damaged fate can be repaired at any time by spending all charges of the Lucky feat, by having Greater Restoration, Wish, or a similar restorative or reality-altering spell cast, or by spending an Inspiration token.  Otherwise, the damage mends itself naturally after the 1d6 days have elapsed.  Note: any character may spend their Lucky charges or use their Inspiration to heal another character's damaged fate.  The base DC for this save is 15.

\r\n

The spell component is a tiny silver pitcher with two spouts.

\r\n

At Higher Levels:
5th level slot - Common magic items on target are now also bifurcated.  Save at end of spell is DC 14.  Chance of Temporal Storm is 8% per troublesome item.
6th level slot - Uncommon magic items on target are now also bifurcated.  Save at end of spell is DC 13.  Chance of Temporal Storm is 6% per troublesome item.
7th level slot - Rare magic items on target are now also bifurcated.  Save at end of spell is DC 12.  Chance of Temporal Storm is 4% per troublesome item.
8th level slot - Legendary magic items on target are now also bifurcated.  Save at end of spell is DC 11.  Chance of Temporal Storm is 2% per troublesome item.
9th level slot - Artifacts on target are now also bifurcated.  Save at end of spell is DC 10.  Chance of Temporal Storm is 1% per troublesome item.

\r\n

\"Oh gods, now there are TWO of him!\" - \"Grumpy Gus\", Dwarf Wizard

\r\n

This spell is an original work.

","sourceId":null},{"id":104101,"label":"Toxic Torrent","description":"

You exhale a torrent of virulent gas. Each creature in a 60-foot cone must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 8d8 poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

\r\n

A creature killed by this spell is wracked by seizures and chokes on its own bile, turning purple-black as it dies.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 5th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":104875,"label":"Conjure Elder Elemental","description":"

You open a portal pulling an elder elemental from its native plane to an unoccupied space you can see within range. Which creature is dependent on the material used: Phoenix for ruby, Leviathan for sapphire, Zaratan for emerald, and Elder Tempest for diamond. The elder elemental disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The elder elemental does not prioritize targeting you and your companions for the duration. Roll initiative for the elder elemental, which has its own turns. It attacks any hostile creatures to you, ignoring any verbal commands. If no hostile creatures are present, the elder elemental targets you and your companions.

\r\n

If your concentration is broken, the elder elemental doesn't disappear. Instead, it treats all creatures as hostile. An elder elemental can't be dismissed by you and disappears one hour after you summon it.

","sourceId":null},{"id":105363,"label":"Elemental Body","description":"

You transform yourself into either an Earth Elemental, a Fire Elemental, an Air Elemental or a Water Elemental for the duration or until you lose concentration. While you are transformed, the following rules apply:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the elemental, but you retain your alignment, personality, memory, and Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiencies, in addition to gaining those of the elemental. If the elemental has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the elemental’s bonus instead of yours.
    • \r\n
  • You keep your class features, can still speak normally and can still cast spells but only spells cast at 2nd level or lower. You retain the languages you know and while in the form of the elemental you know its language as well (such as Ignan if a Fire Elemental, for example).
    • \r\n
  • You keep your hit dice and hit points.
    • \r\n
  • Items you are wearing or carrying will be merged into your new form and can no longer be accessed or used and you lose any benefit provided by them (attunement, if you are attuned to magic items, is not broken) until you revert back to your normal form.
    • \r\n
  • You can end the spell early, reverting back to normal form, with a bonus action.
    • \r\n
","sourceId":null},{"id":105710,"label":"Stasis Field (Haste/Slow)","description":"

You create a chrono-spacial disturbance centered on a point within range. Select the Haste or Slow effect when you cast this spell. For the duration, any creature in the area of the spell gains the benefit, or detriment, of the selected spell as long as they are inside the area. They lose this effect immediately upon leaving the spell's area.

\r\n

Also, as the differing speeds of movement and action make it difficult to aim ranged weapons in and out of the field, creatures using a ranged weapon to attack from inside the field out or from the outside in make the roll with disadvantage.

","sourceId":null},{"id":107316,"label":"Advanced Transmogrification","description":"

You begin to alter the fundamental nature of an object enchanted or transmuted by magic. You select a single object under the effect of a spell of 3rd level or lower from the Enchantment or Transmutation schools with a duration of at least 1 minute, such as the magic weapon spell. Doing so allows you to attempt to strengthen the bindings of the magic affecting the object. If you are successful, the original spell's duration increases to 8 hours and if that spell previously required its caster's concentration, it no longer does. 

\r\n

The type of objects you can transmogrify with this spell has some restrictions. The object can be no larger than 5ft in any dimension. Alternatively, you can transmogrify up to 20 pieces of ammunition affected by the same spell. If it is a magic object or wondrous items, the spell becomes more complicated, which is explained below. If you attempt to cast this spell on a object with a qualifying effect that would fade before you finish casting this spell, its duration is extended at least until you finish casting this spell.

\r\n

Alternatively, you can cast this spell on an object conjured or created with magic, providing it has the appropriate minimum duration, it has no Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma scores, is not alive, and meets the other normal requirements of this spell. The conjured object cannot be used or wielded while you cast this spell. If the magic conjuring or creating the object requires it to remain in contact with its conjurer or creator, that creature must do so for the duration of your casting. 

\r\n

To perform the transmogrification, you must supply material components which correspond to the magical effect you are targeting. The cost of the materials is based on the power and complexity of the spell. You can transmogrify an object conjured or affected by a spell of 1st level or higher by providing 75gp worth of materials per spell level. If the target spell was cast at a higher level, you must provide material components according to the level at which it was cast. 

\r\n

The type of material components you must provide for the spell changes according to the nature of the spell. For magics of the Evocation and Enchantment schools, you can provide rubies, opals, fine quartz, or other similarly hued gems. For spells from the Abjuration or Divination schools of magic, you must provide pearls, clear crystals, or fine silver of appropriate value. For spells from the Transmutation or Illusion schools of magic, you may provide any fine material of appropriate value. 

\r\n

Objects made of exquisite materials more readily accept the power of such spells and can retain them more easily. 

Unblessed or otherwise mundane wood, lead, iron, steel, or stone: DC 15
Objects ritually blessed or prepared for permanent enchantment, or an object of great significance to the creature who cast the original spell: DC 14
An object made wholly or partially of gold, silver, or electrum: DC 13
An object made wholly or partially of platinum, mithril, or adamantine: DC 12

\r\n

When you finish casting this spell, you make a spellcasting ability check. You may apply any proficiency you have with Arcana, tinker's tools, jeweler's tools, or smith's tools. On a success, the magic is bound into the item for the duration of the spell. The magic cannot be dispelled by spells such as dispel magic. If the object enters an area that nullifies the effects of magic items, such as an antimagic field, it functions as a normal magical item would.

\r\n

If the object is a wondrous or magic item already, you must make a Charisma saving throw as you alter the essence of a powerful magic object. The saving throw's DC is based on the object's rarity. An uncommon or common item requires a DC of 13. Rare items require a DC of 15, very rare items have a DC of 20. You cannot modify legendary items or artifacts with this spell. If your saving throw is successful, you need not make the spellcasting ability check as you weave the new magic into the existing properties of the item.

If you fail you ability check or saving throw, the spell slot is wasted, any effect you were attempting to make permanent is removed, and the provided materials are destroyed. 

Weapons, armor, or ammunition you successfully transmogrify are considered magical for the purposes of overcoming resistance to nonmagical weapon damage for the duration or ignoring effects that target nonmagical objects. The effect lasts for the duration of the spell or until you cast this spell again. If you do, the effect fades from the original object and you transmogrify the new object.

At higher levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, you can extend the duration of the transmogrification to 24 hours or until you cast this spell again. You can make the effect permanent by casting the spell on the same object every day for 1 year and 1 day. To do so, you must cast the spell on the same object before it ends as though targeting a 7th level transmutation effect, providing the appropriate material components. Expending a spell slot of 8th level counts as 30 days worth of casting. Expending a spell slot of 9th level this way counts as 120 days worth of casting.

","sourceId":null},{"id":109684,"label":"Miasmic Breath","description":"

You inhale a large quantity of air and the Phylactery powder, imbuing it with magic before breathing it out in a 200 ft. cone in front of you. The air transforms into a dense fog of decay. Any creature that gets caught in the fog when cast or walks into it must make a Dexterity Saving Throw. On a failed save, the target takes 18d20+50 Necrotic damage, or half the damage on a successful save. While living creatures are in the fog, they cannot heal, and have Disadvantage on all attack rolls and all checks that require sight. Creatures that die from this spell become an undead of your choice with a Challenge Rating of 4 or lower permanently under your control. While the undead under your control remain in the fog, they have Advantage on all attack rolls and heal 2d6+10 health if possible per round. The fog is dispelled if targeted by a 7th level or higher Divination spell or if you inhale any of the fog.

","sourceId":null},{"id":112135,"label":"Atomic Blast Fireball","description":"

A large roaring ball of fire erupts within your hands, growing in size for every round not cast. When this spell ends willingly, chose a point within range. The ball from your hands is thrown forward, and each creature in a 60-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes fire damage equal to the total accumulated damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the spells concentration is broken unwillingly before you cast it, the target is centered on yourself and the spell is immediately cast.

\r\n

The spell's base damage is 20d6. If at the end of your turn the ball has not yet detonated, the damage increases by 4d6. If you successfully release the spell after 5 rounds of concentrating on it (the maximum amount of time that you can concentrate on it), the damage dealt is automatically max.

\r\n

The fire damages objects in the area and ignites flammable objects that aren't being worn or carried.

","sourceId":null},{"id":112143,"label":"Dr Longfellow's Lavish Laboritorium","description":"

You create a 20ft by 20ft room in an unoccupied space you can see within range. The rooms outward appearance can be specified by you and any number of creatures (up to a maximum of 9 medium or smaller creatures) that you allow may enter the room through the door, provided there is space for them.

\r\n

Inside the room is any equipment you will need to undertake a scientific or magical experiment you have in mind at the time of casting and that may fit within the rooms space and 1 spectral lab assistant whose appearance is chosen by the caster and can perform the actions any basic human can but cannot attack and is unable to leave the laboratory. The equipment can be multiple machines you need or 1 singular device/tool. For instance you could choose to have a work table against 1 wall and a set of shelves against another with useful components for potion creation or choose to have a large equipment set for deciphering runes on an item to determine its magical properties.

\r\n

Any materials or objects which originated in the room disappear when the spell ends or when it is taken more than 10ft from the room. Any piece of the outer wall of the room that is removed disappears after it is taken more than 10ft from the room or when the spell ends. Each 5ft length of wall of the room has an AC equal to your spell save DC and 20HP. Once this HP is reduced to 0 that portion of the wall is destroyed however the lab and any equipment within will remain until the spell ends or until it is subsequently destroyed (this is at your DM's discretion depending on nature and type of equipment).

","sourceId":null},{"id":113813,"label":"Geodesic Convergence","description":"

Using your power to warp space and time, you cause the very notion of a straight line to bend.  Choose a point within range you can see, that point becomes the center of a sphere with a radius of 60ft.  All creatures within the sphere have their movement speed reduced by half, and any creature or object within the sphere may never move (or be moved) in a direction that takes them farther away from the center of the sphere.  These effects apply to all movement types except teleportation, and projectiles are not effected.  

\r\n

On your turn you may use a bonus action to create two gravity waves that ripple out from the center of the sphere.  Choose one creature within the sphere for each wave to make a Strength saving throw.  You may target the same creature for each wave, or different ones.  If the target fails its saving throw, you pull them up to 10ft toward the center of the sphere, or up to 20ft if they fail the save by 5 or more. 

\r\n

Creatures that start their turn in the same space as the center of the sphere or adjacent to such a creature, must make a Strength saving throw at the start of their turns.  A creature takes 8d8 bludgeoning damage on a failed save and becomes restrained, or half damage and the creature is not restrained on a successful save.  

\r\n

At Higher Levels:  When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher you may create one additional gravity wave for each slot level above 5th, and the damage dealt by the center of the sphere also increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 5th.

By touching a mountain, you can tear it from the land and move it anywhere, even into the sky, creating a floating island.

\r\n

Note: This spell is part of a series of spells created to be stronger than the ninth level, as such, casting them takes a heavy toll on the user.

\r\n

When cast, the user rolls a d20, a fifteen or less bestows three levels of exhaustion; a sixteen or higher only gives two.

","sourceId":null},{"id":114758,"label":"Summon Demon Lord","description":"

You utter foul words, summoning one demon from the chaos of the Abyss who's CR is less than or equal to your level. The demon appears in an unoccupied space you can see within range, and the demon holds itself to this plane by its own power until it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

Roll initiative for the demon, which has its own turns. When you summon it and on each of your turns thereafter, you can issue a verbal command to it (requiring no action on your part), telling it what it must do on its next turn. If you issue no command, it spends its turn attacking any creature within reach that has attacked it.

\r\n

At the end of each of the demon’s turns, it makes a Charisma saving throw. The demon has advantage on this saving throw if it has legendary actions. However, the demon has disadvantage on this saving throw if you say its true name. On a failed save, the demon continues to obey you. On a successful save, your control of the demon ends for the rest of the duration, and the demon spends its turns pursuing and attacking the nearest non-demons to the best of its ability.

\r\n

As part of casting the spell, you can form a circle on the ground with the blood used as a material component and place the heart in the middle. The circle is large enough to encompass your space. While the spell lasts, the summoned demon can’t cross the circle or harm it, and it can’t target anyone within it. Using the material component in this manner consumes it when the spell ends.

The next time you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack during this spell's duration, your weapon becomes shrouded in negative energy, and the attack deals an additional 4d10 necrotic damage. Additionally, the creature must make a Constitution saving throw or their hit point maximum is reduced by that much as well until the end of their next long rest or if cured by greater restoration (or similar spell).

","sourceId":null},{"id":119133,"label":"Dissolve Innards","description":"

You touch a creature, attempting to destroy their innards by converting it all to potent acid. The spell fails if the target creature is a construct, elemental, plant, undead, or is immune to acid damage. The target creature must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature begins to immediately begins to die, taking 6d10 acid damage and becoming incapacitated. At the end of each of the creature's turns, the creature takes an additional 4d10 acid damage. This spell continues to damage and incapacitate the creature until they are reduced to 0 hit points or the caster dispels it. If the creature receives any magical healing, or have greater restoration cast on them, this spell immediately ends.

\r\n

On a successful save, a creature only takes the initial 6d10 acid damage and then the spell ends.

","sourceId":null},{"id":119193,"label":"Raise land","description":"

Upon the completion of this spell, the land beneath you and whatever else may be upon that land rises skyward 100 feet into the air. The area affected by the spell may have up to 1,250 feet radius. 

\r\n

","sourceId":null},{"id":121681,"label":"Plague (ver. 2)","description":"

You release a savage plague upon the enemy, sapping their mortality and spreading through their ranks until they are no more. Pick three enemies that you can see, those enemies must succeed on a constitution saving throws or become diseased with the plague. Abilities or traits cannot defend against this plague (immunity to disease). There are three stages of the plague that an enemy progresses through on each of its turn before it takes any actions. The plague can be cured only by a 9th level spell that can cure diseases. You may also cure any creature of the plague if their disease was a result of you casting this spell (no action required).

\r\n

Stage 1: The diseased target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or its strength, dexterity and constitution scores decrease by 2. If any of its scores drop below 0 because of this, it dies.

\r\n

Stage 2: The diseased target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take 9d10 poison damage as well as 9d10 necrotic damage.

\r\n

Stage 3: The diseased target spreads the plague. All creatures within 10 feet of the diseased target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become diseased with the plague.

\r\n

Stage 4: The diseased target must succeed on a constitution saving throw or become paralized. It may repeat this saving throw on each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

","sourceId":null},{"id":122717,"label":"Mariguard's Stolen Knowledge","description":"

Slowly burning a pair of bay leaves on a rod of incense you allow yourself to open your mind as you use the powers of the arcane weave to open your sixth sense to the world around you. Leeching out, directed by the teachings of Mariguard the Sixth of Seven you allow your mind to momentarily blend with that of another and experiences that they have become yours if even for a fleeting moment. 

\r\n

 

\r\n

You, with the fading power of the third eye given to you by the spell, manage to leech from the experience of the area around you information that, while fleeting, can temporarily make you more proficient in your endeavours. For the next day you gain proficiency in two skills of your choice that you are not already proficient, or may double your proficiency bonus in two skills that you are proficient in. You may also select one saving throw that you are not proficient in and gain proficiency with that saving throw for the day as well. 

\r\n

When this spell ends you take 3d4 psychic damage. If this spell is removed by a dispelling effect you are stunned for one round. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":125201,"label":"Azanor's Mental Lubrication","description":"

Using arcane formulae and complex incantations you expand your mind's ability to focus on thaumaturgical minutiae.  This spell allows you to concentrate on up to two other spells at the same time.  The total level of these two new spells must be equal to or less than the level at which you cast this spell.  For example: if you cast this spell using a 5th level spell slot, you could concentrate on Wall of Water (3rd level) and Levitate (2nd level) at the same time.  Cantrips that require concentration count a 0 level spells. 

\r\n

While this spell is in effect and you are maintaining concentration on exactly one other spell, you make Constitution saving throws to maintain concentration as normal when you take damage.  If you fail such a saving throw, you lose concentration that spell as normal.  

\r\n

While this spell is in effect and you are maintaining concentration on two other spells, you make Constitution saving throws to maintain concentration from taking damage with disadvantage.  If you fail such a saving throw while concentrating on two spells, roll a d10 to determine what happens: 

\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
d10Result 
1Both spells and this one all catastrophically collapse.  The spells all end immediately and you take 1d12 psychic damage per level at which you cast this spell.
2-3Your mind reels and you lose concentration on both other spells. 
4-6The distraction jars you, your concentration is broken on one of the other two spells, determined randomly.
7-10You are forced to limit the scope of your concentration.  Your concentration is broken on one of the other two spells, your choice.
\r\n
\r\n

This spell ends if it catastrophically collapses as described above, if you become stunned, incapacitated, or unconscious, or if you cast it again.  

\r\n

At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher the maximum number of spell levels on which you can maintain concentration increases by 1 for each slot level above 5th.  

","sourceId":null},{"id":128746,"label":"Melt Flesh","description":"

Choose a target creature with flesh you can see within range. It must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or the flesh partially melts off the victim’s body. On a failed save, the target's current and maximum hit points are reduced by 2d10. If this reduces its maximum hit points to 0,  ot dies and can't be revived except by reincarnate, resurrection, or true resurrection  (all of which undo the effects of this spell). The target's ears, lips, eyelids, and nostrils run away or partially seal up; any ability checks that would require the use of these body parts are made with disadvantage. One of these orifices (chosen by the DM) is sealed completely, which might blind  or deafen the creature, prevent it from speaking or using a bite attach, or removed other senses or actions as appropriate for the body part. The orifice can't be opened without cutting the creature as an action which deals 1d8 slashing damage to the target. The effects of this spells otherwise last until ended by greater restoration, regenerate, or wish.

\r\n

When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the target's current and maximum hit points are reduced by another 1d10 and another orifice seals up completely for each slot above 5th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":128963,"label":"Explosion","description":"

A bright flash as you snaps your fingers toward a point you choose within range that then ignites into an thunderous  explosion. Each creature in a 10-foot-radius sphere centred on that point must make a Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 10d6 fire damage and 10d6 force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Any creature within the blast zone are knocked prone.

\r\n

The spells deals double damage against structures.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":131116,"label":"Temporal Divergence","description":"

You briefly create a warp in time within a 30 foot radius sphere centered on a creature you touch. Time stops for everyone within the 30 foot radius sphere but the target creature. No time passes for other creatures within 30 feet, while your target takes 1d4 turns in a row, during which the target creature can use actions and move as normal.

\r\n

The target creature can cast spells or use weapons but all spell effects or weapon attacks remain frozen in time and space until this spell ends. Creatures within the temporal divergence sphere are effectively paralyzed. Creatures automatically fail Strength and Dexterity saving throws, attack rolls against the creatures have advantage, and any attack that hits an affected creature is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature.

\r\n

The target creature can move, take, or otherwise affect objects being worn or carried by paralyzed creatures within the sphere. 

\r\n

The spell ends if you or the target creature move outside of the 30 foot radius sphere. The sphere remains stationary on the exact location where the target creature was when this spell was cast.

\r\n

After the spell duration is finished any attacks or spells aimed at paralyzed creatures all go off simultaneously and immediately.

","sourceId":null},{"id":135746,"label":"Reopen Wounds","description":"

You make a melee spell attack against a creature within range, coating them in the slurry on a success. At the start of your next turn, for each instance of Bludgeoning, Piercing and Slashing damage the creature has taken since being marked, they take 1d6 of that type again and 1d6 necrotic damage, as their wounds reopen.

\r\n

Should they take more than 10d6 damage from this effect, they must make a Constitution saving throw or be stunned until the start of their next turn.

","sourceId":null},{"id":141885,"label":"Create Monstrosity","description":"

In addition to the material cost for this spell, you must also have a living but incapacitated beast that closely resembles the desired monstrosity (at the DM's discretion). The beast must remain incapacitated and within 5 feet of you for the duration of the casting time. 

\r\n

When the spell is complete, the creature is transmuted into a monstrosity with a challenge rating 2 or lower and with a maximum Intelligence score of 7. If you desire a monstrosity not in the Monster Manual or other sourcebook, you may (with the DM's permission) edit or create a statblock for the creature with the same previously mentioned restrictions. The creature appears in an open space within 5 feet of you. 

\r\n

You are not in control of the monstrosity, and it will act according to it's nature and alignment described in the Monster Manual or other sourcebook. If it is domesticable, like a griffon or hippogriff, you may however attempt to train it if desired. When the creature is reduced to 0 hit points, it dies or becomes unconscious (dependent on the intention of the attacker).

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the maximum challenge rating increases by 1 for each slot level above 6th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":146333,"label":"Alter Gravity","description":"

You permanently alter the gravity within a circle of up to 100ft diameter centered around the caster. Choose one of the following effects:

\r\n

Reduced Gravity: Gravity is weaker in this area. The weight of all objects and creatures in this area is halved and jump distance of all creatures are doubled.

\r\n

Increased Gravity: Gravity is stronger in this area. The weight of all objects and creatures in this area is doubled and the area counts as difficult terrain. The flight speed of all creatures is halved.

\r\n

Repelling Gravity: Gravity pushes all things and creatures towards the edges of the area. Movement speed of all creatures attempting to move towards the center is halved and movement speed of creatures moving towards its edges is doubled. Any objects not attached to the ground or not heavy enough are pushed outside the area.

\r\n

Gravitational Well: Gravity pulls all things and creatures towards the center of the area. Movement speed of all creatures moving towards the edges of the area is halved and movement speed of creatures moving towards its center is doubled. Any objects not attached to the ground or not heavy enough are pulled into the middle of the area.

\r\n

If Alter Gravity is used with two opposing effects in the same area, the effects cancel out. If it is cast with the same effect twice, the effects do not stack.

","sourceId":null},{"id":149225,"label":"Blood to Acid","description":"

You attempt to raise the acidity in a target's blood. Target a single creature within range; they must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 6d12 Acid damage, drops prone, and falls unconscious. It can make another save at the start of each of it's turns to attempt to regain consciousness. On a successful save, the target takes half damage, does not drop prone and does not fall unconscious.

","sourceId":null},{"id":151558,"label":"Guthrie's Greenhouse","description":"

You conjure an extradimensional dwelling in range that lasts for the duration. You choose where its one entrance is located. The entrance shimmers faintly and is 5 feet wide and 10 feet tall. You and any creature you designate when you cast the spell can enter the extradimensional dwelling as long as the portal remains open. You can open or close the portal if you are within 30 feet of it. While closed, the portal is invisible.

\r\n

Beyond the portal is a magnificent Greenhouse with numerous areas to plant any herb you may need, the contents remain. The atmosphere is clean, fresh, and warm.

\r\n

The place is furnished and decorated as you choose. When the spell ends, any creatures inside the extra-dimensional space are expelled into the open spaces nearest to the entrance.

    • \r\n
  • Lesser earth elemental (1pt each)
    • \r\n
\r\n


An elemental summoned by this spell disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The summoned creatures are friendly to you and your companions. Roll initiative for the summoned creatures as a group, which has its own turns. They obey any verbal commands that you issue to them (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to them, they defend themselves and nature from hostile creatures, but otherwise take no actions.

","sourceId":null},{"id":153540,"label":"Siphon Magic","description":"

You point your open hand forward, and drain the magical power from your targets mind, drawing it out from their eyes, nose, and mouth in thick blue streams.

\r\n

The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the target loses one spell slot of its choice as if it had cast a spell. At the start of each of its turns, the target can make a Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the spell ends. The spell also ends if the target has no remaining spell slots to siphon.

\r\n

For every two spell slots siphoned from the creature, you regain one expended spell slot. The caster chooses which of their expended spell slots to recover. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than the amount siphoned, and none of the slots can be 6th level or higher.

\r\n

For example, if you’re siphoned two spell slots, you can recover up to two levels worth of spell slots. You can recover either a single 2nd-level spell slot or two 1st-level spell slots.

","sourceId":null},{"id":153703,"label":"Despairing Shroud","description":"

Choose up to 5 creatures. They must make a Charisma saving throw; a creature can choose to fail this saving throw if it wishes. On a success, the creature cannot be affected by this spell for 24 hrs.  If a creature fails its saving throw, they are surrounded by a shroud of swirling dark whisps and discouraging voices whisper and speak in the mind of the creature. The target is affected by the following effects:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • The world seems dark and pointless. The target receives a special condition called Despairing. While despairing, creatures must roll a d6 at the start of each turn, the effects lasting until the start of its next turn or the spell stops.\r\n
      \r\n
    • 1-3 : The character has disadvantage on death saving throws and on Dexterity checks for initiative.
      • \r\n
    • 4-5 : The character has disadvantage on all saving throws.
      • \r\n
    • 6 :     The character has disadvantage on all attacks, ability checks, and saving throws that use Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma.
      • \r\n
    \r\n
    • \r\n
  • The voices reverberate in the ears of the affected, keeping them from hearing others voices. The target is also Deafened. 
    • \r\n
\r\n

The spell takes one action to cast. You concentrate on the spell for up to one minute. At the end of their turns, the affected can reroll their save. On a success, the spell no longer affects them for 24 hours. After the minute of concentration, the effects will persist for an hour with no more opportunities to save.

","sourceId":null},{"id":155065,"label":"Agony of the Fallen","description":"

Choose a target (or 1d4 targets) within the caster's line of sight.

\r\n

The caster cups a piece of bone between their hands (as if praying) and crosses opposing fingers relative to how many targets they are focusing on (e.g., two \"pointer\" fingers stay in a \"prayer\" position with all other fingers crossed for one target).  The caster chants and their hands glow a mixture of bight, neon green mixed with swirls of black mist.  The caster then pushes their hands outward and releases their intent upon the desired target(s) and the piece of bone explodes into tiny particles to seek vengeance upon the chosen.

\r\n

All affected targets immediately fall to the ground.  For the duration of this spell, all affected targets are incapacitated while their bodies flail around where they fell; experiencing morbid, terrifying hallucinations as well as intense pain and suffering.  All affected targets take 4d6 Necrotic damage as their life force is violently wracked by the trauma.

\r\n

All potential targets that successfully made their CON Save... fall to the ground prone, and take half damage.

\r\n

When this spell is cast with a 5th level spell slot or higher, the damage increases by 2d6 for each spell slot above the 4th (e.g., a 5th level slot would add 2d6, while a 6th level slot would add 4d6, etc.).

","sourceId":null},{"id":163311,"label":"Rizor's Personal Subspace","description":"

You spend 12 hours crafting a diorama with various decorations or magics. At the end of the construction, you close the box and press the gemstone against it whilst speaking an incantation. The gemstone liquefies and coats the box in an intricate pattern, and the box shrinks down into a ½ inch cube. The cube is the physical representation of the subspace. It is indestructible, and immune to all forms of magic other than Wish and Rizor's Personal Subspace.

\r\n

When the spell is fully cast, you procure a 100 foot cube of extradimensional space, with the following specifications:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • The subspace is enclosed within the adamantine cube.
    • \r\n
  • You choose the climate inside of the subspace, what level of light is inside of it, and what general time of day it is, otherwise it mimics the environment the cube is in.
    • \r\n
  • The subspace matches the general description of the diorama you made of it, indistinguishable from reality.
    • \r\n
  • The subspace is located on the same plane as the cube.
    • \r\n
  • Your subspace has a specific structure of your choosing. There are no limits as to what the structure is, or what it is made out of, aside from it being non-magical and able to fit within the space. If pieces or furnishings of this structure leave the subspace, they harmlessly teleport back into their original location.
    • \r\n
\r\n

When making this subspace, you can choose two special effects for it. These effects cannot be dispelled, and do not interfere with eachother.

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Restorative. While in the subspace, creatures are under the effects of the Regenerate spell, with the exception that they do not regain hit points instantly. Additionally, creatures that take a long rest in the area are subject to the effects of both Lesser Restoration and Greater Restoration .
    • \r\n
  • Antimagic. The effects of the Antimagic Field spell fill the entire subspace. Rizor's Personal Subspace can still be cast within this effect, but only by the creator of the subspace.
    • \r\n
  • Private. Private Sanctum is in effect within the entire subspace.
    • \r\n
  • Upsized. The allocated space is instead 5 times larger (500 by 500 by 500 feet).
    • \r\n
  • Cornucopia. The space is extremely fertile, and magically procures a wide variety of foods. Plants and animals flourish in the space, and at any given time you have enough food and water to feed a dozen humanoids. The ecology can sustain itself without needing care.
    • \r\n
  • Servant. The subspace has a caretaker, a single humanoid of your specifications. The servant has a personality and character as you specify when you make it, and is willing to perform any commands you give it. The servant cannot leave the subspace, fight, or do anything an ordinary member of that race could not reasonably do. If killed or destroyed, it reappears the next time you cast Rizor's Personal Subspace.
    • \r\n
  • Easy Access. The caster and up to 4 other willing targets can teleport inside of the subspace without having to cast Rizor's Personal Subspace. Entering this way requires an action, during which an incantation is murmured into the cube and having the targets within 10 feet of the caster. Creatures can leave the subspace by simply willing it.
    • \r\n
\r\n

The space is accessible by casting Rizor's Personal Subspace whilst holding the cube. Doing this requires 1 minute, and creates a pair of adamantine doors, each 5 feet wide and 10 feet tall, within range in a place of your choosing. These doors last for one hour.

\r\n

If you are inside of the subspace when these doors disappear, you are stuck until either Rizor's Personal Subspace is cast again, or you teleport beyond the boundaries of the cube. Exiting the cube by teleporting outside of it means you appear adjacent to its miniature representation, regardless of the distance traveled via teleportation. If the cube is within its own subspace, you appear where you were before you entered the subspace.

\r\n

If dispelled by the caster or the Wish spell, the subspace returns to the diorama form and all of the contents brought into it are harmlessly teleported to the nearest adjacent space.

\r\n



","sourceId":null},{"id":164989,"label":"Aura of Evasion","description":"

You imbue yourself and up to 6 allies within range with improved reflexes. Affected creatures gain a bonus to Dexterity saves equal to your spellcasting ability modifier, and when they are subjected to an effect that allows them to make a Dexterity save for half damage, they instead take no damage on a success.

","sourceId":null},{"id":166791,"label":"Abyssal Prison","description":"

The target must make a wisdom saving throw, on a failed save the target is permanently sent to the deepest, darkest corners of the abyss where their soul will be slowly devoured by the infinite demons and other horrors found within the abyss.

\r\n

While in the abyss, the target does not have access to any magic or magical effects or abilities, and cannot leave or be summoned from the abyss by anything other than someone going into the abyss and finding/rescuing the imprisoned target.

\r\n

If the target is not released or rescued within 7 days, their soul will be completely consumed within the abyss and the character will be permanently dead with no spell able to revive or resurrect them.

\r\n

Should this spell be used to send a creature from the abyss back to its plane of origin, that creature does not die, and is instead bound to the abyss for 100 years and cannot leave until that period of time is up.

","sourceId":null},{"id":168598,"label":"Greater Infernal Calling","description":"

You choose the devil's type when you cast this spell. The devil appears in an unoccupied spot that you can see within range. It disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The devil is unfriendly towards you and your companions. Roll initiative for the devil, which has its own turns. It is under the Dungeon Master's control and acts according to its nature on each of its turns, which might result in it attacking you if it thinks it can prevail, or trying to tempt you to tempt you to undertake an evil act for limited service. The DM has the creature's statistics.

On an initial success, the creature becomes immune to the effects of this spell for 24 hours.  A creature with an Intelligence score of 4 or less isn't affected. While a creature is incapacitated by this spell you may recall the surface memories of the creature from the past 24 hours.

\r\n

\r\n
