1/4Axe Beak, Blink Dog, Boar, Constrictor Snake, Draft Horse, Elk, Giant Badger, Giant Bat, Giant Centipede, Giant Frog, Giant Lizard, Giant Owl, Giant Poisonous Snake, Giant Wolf Spider, Panther, Riding Horse, Sprite, Swarm of Bats, Swarm of Rats, Swarm of Ravens, Wolf
1/2Ape, Black Bear, Crocodile, Giant Goat, Giant Sea Horse, Giant Wasp, Reef Shark, Satyr, Swarm of Insects, Warhorse
1Brown Bear, Dire Wolf, Dryad, Giant Eagle, Giant Hyena, Giant Octopus, Giant Spider, Giant Toad, Giant Vulture, Lion, Swarm of Quippers, Tiger
2Giant Boar, Giant Constrictor Snake, Giant Elk, Hunter Shark, Plesiosaurus, Polar Bear, Rhinoceros, Saber-toothed Tiger, Sea Hag, Swarm of Poisonous Snakes
3Giant Scorpion, Naganasu, Killer Whale
4Elephant
5Giant Crocodile, Giant Shark
  
  
  
\r\n

 

\r\n

 

\r\n

Your familiar acts independently of you, but it always obeys your commands. In combat, it rolls its own initiative and acts on its own turn. A greater familiar can attack as normal.

\r\n

 

\r\n

When the familiar drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. It reappears after you cast this spell again.

\r\n

 

\r\n

While your familiar is within 100 feet of you, you can communicate with it telepathically. Additionally, as an action, you can see through your familiar's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of your next turn, gaining the benefits of any special senses that the familiar has. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses.

\r\n

 

\r\n

As an action, you can temporarily dismiss your familiar. It disappears into a pocket dimension where it awaits your summons. Alternatively, you can dismiss it forever. As an action while it is temporarily dismissed, you can cause it to reappear in any unoccupied space within 30 feet of you.

\r\n

 

\r\n

You can't have more than one familiar at a time. If you cast this spell while you already have a familiar, you instead cause it to adopt a new form. Choose one of the forms from the above list. Your familiar transforms into the chosen creature.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Finally, when you cast a spell with a range of touch, your familiar can deliver the spell as if it had cast the spell. Your familiar must be within 100 feet of you, and it must use its reaction to deliver the spell when you cast it. If the spell requires an attack roll, you use your attack modifier for the roll.

","sourceId":null},{"id":227832,"label":"Graft Flesh","description":"

Your necromantic powers allow you to knit flesh back together. You can reattach one severed or detached body part to its original owner. Any hit point loss is not restored, but lingering effects of an injury (such as blindness from the loss of an eye) are alleviated and hit points can be regained normally. 

\r\n

If the original body part is not available, you can graft flesh from a member of the same species as the target, such as a different severed limb. The graft can also include cosmetic change, such as covering scars or even completely fashioning a new face for the recipient. If the grafted flesh is not from the same individual, however, the duration is only 24 hours. After the duration expires, the grafted flesh withers and decays and cannot be used again. Grafted flesh cannot benefit from spells like gentle repose. True seeing and similar means cannot penetrate disguises made from the use of this spell because it is not an illusion, though it can be dispelled as normal. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":230782,"label":"True Creation","description":"

You create a nonmagical, unattended object made of any sort of matter that you have seen before. The object created must be no larger than a 5-foot cube, and be worth 25 000 gp or less. The object created is permanent and cannot be dispelled or affected by spells such as antimagic field or similar magical effects.

\r\n

Unlike the materials conjured by creation, the object created by this spell can be used as a material component for spells.

","sourceId":null},{"id":234107,"label":"Dimensional Anchor","description":"

A green ray springs from your outstretched hand. You must make a spell attack roll to hit the target. Any creature or object struck by the ray is covered with a shimmering emerald field that completely blocks extradimensional travel. Forms of movement barred by a dimensional anchor include astral projection, blink, dimension door, , etherealness, gate, maze, misty step, plane shift, teleport, and similar abilities. The spell also prevents the use of a gate or teleportation circle for the duration of the spell.

\r\n

A dimensional anchor does not interfere with the movement of creatures already in ethereal or astral form when the spell is cast, nor does it block extradimensional perception or attack forms. Also, dimensional anchor does not prevent summoned creatures from disappearing at the end of a summoning spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":235308,"label":"Alter Substance","description":"

You convert one type of material into a similar type of material. For example, you can change one type of metal into another, one type of liquid into another, one type of fabric into another, one type of stone or gem into another, one type of wood into another, etc.

\r\n

Choose an object or objects that you can touch for the duration. You can alter the type of material of a medium or smaller object (contained within a 5-foot cube). The size and shape of the object do not change, only the properties of the material. Any flaws in the original object will remain after being altered.

\r\n

Creatures or magic items can't be altered by this spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":244038,"label":"Temporary Demon Contract","description":"

You slice open the palm of your hand and begin to utter foul words, summoning demons from the chaos of the Abyss. As your blood hits the floor a dark crimson light begins to shine from the ground in front of you. Roll 2d12 and add your Charisma modifier to the number. Take the resulting number as damage. Then summon a demon according to the damage based on the chart below.

\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
Damage TakenDemons Summoned
0-12One demon of challenge rating 5 or lower
13-23One demon of challenge rating 6 or lower
24+One demon of challenge rating 7 or lower
\r\n
\r\n

You choose the demon's type, such as a chasme or a maurezhi. The contracted demon appears 5 feet in front of you.

\r\n

Roll initiative for the demon, which has its own turns. When you summon it and on each of your turns thereafter, you can issue a verbal command to it (requiring no action on your part), telling it what it must do on its next turn. If you issue no command, it spends its turn attacking any creature within reach that has attacked it.

\r\n

If dispel magic is cast and succeeds the demon is freed from the contract but is not banished to the abyss. Instead, your control of the demon ends and the demon spends its turns pursuing and attacking the nearest non-demons to the best of its ability. An uncontrolled demon doesn’t disappear for 1d12 rounds if it still has hit points.

\r\n

The spell can be ended at any time by commanding the contracted demon to return to the abyss. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":249022,"label":"Aumvor's Soulshatter (10th Level)","description":"

Aumvor's Soulshatter causes the separation of body and soul of a target within 300 feet. The separated soul went to the afterlife, but the body continued to live. This body could be made into a secure target of possessions, like that of the magic jar spell, and domination, like that of dominate person. The hollow body could not protect itself from these effects and while its physical capacities were the ones of the original body, the mental capacities were those of the caster.
If the soulless body was not possessed or dominated, it was in a dormant but alive state.
Reverting the process was possible by retrieving the body and then casting raise dead or resurrection on the body. The body, if alive, could be soulless for any length time and these two spells would work.

","sourceId":null},{"id":250782,"label":"True Transformation","description":"

This spell transforms a willing creature that you can see within range into a new form.

\r\n

The transformation lasts forever, and is only reversible by a wish spell. The target's game statistics, including mental ability scores, are replaced by the statistics of the chosen beast. It retains its alignment and personality.

\r\n

The target assumes the hit points of its new form.

\r\n

The creature is limited in the actions it can perform by the nature of its new form, and it can't speak, cast spells, or take any other action that requires hands or speech, unless the new form is capable of said action.

\r\n

Anything the target is wearing or carrying is destroyed.

","sourceId":null},{"id":259257,"label":"Create Companions","description":"

 

\r\n

   

\r\n

     As you complete this ritual, several medium creatures, between 1 and 5, appear within 10 feet of you. You can only summon small, medium or large creatures with this spell. These creatures are spirits that assumes the form of a creature of your choice so long as you have seen it and it is of your CR or below. The creature has the statistics of the chosen form, though it is a celestial, fey, or fiend (your choice) in addition to its normal type. Additionally, if the creature has an Intelligence less than 10, its Intelligence becomes 10, and it gains the ability to understand and speak one language of your choice that you speak.

\r\n

     When the creatures created by this spell appear the spirits that they are formed from become the form determined by the caster. These spirits become living entities with their own thoughts, feeling, and even their own, newly created, souls.

\r\n

     Even the created creature’s appearance can be in part determined by the caster. You decide what the creature will look like, including height, weight, facial features, sound of their voice, hair length, coloration, and distinguishing characteristics, if any. If the creature being created is bipedal, you can't use this spell to make them quadrupedal, and vice versa. You cannot use this spell to create undead and most forms of constructs, excluding warforged. You may choose to have the creatures created be wearing mundane clothes with an appearance of your choice upon their creation.

\r\n

     You may bestow abilities upon these creature that they wouldn’t otherwise have. For example, you humans with troll’s regeneration, or the ability to breath underwater. However, in order to do this, you require a piece of a creature that had that ability at the time the piece was taken, that material must be fresh. Casting gentle repose on a fresh material, to keep it fresh, works for the purposes of this spell.

\r\n

     The created creatures regard you, the caster, as a trusted friend. These creatures are inclined to accompany the caster to almost any place. However, these creatures do have a sense of self preservation, and will not actively comply with any action they decide could be a danger to their life. For example, they will not willingly walk off a cliff, go to certain planes of existence, or otherwise endanger their own life within reason. Each created creature can attack and will defend themselves, if able. Each creature can perform any task a normal human could perform, if their form allows for it.

\r\n

     For every creature that is made by this spell the material cost of this spell is increased. 1 creature 1 platinum coin, 2 creatures 2 platinum coins, three creatures 4 platinum coins, and so on. The cost of this spell is also affected by the size of the creature, no bigger than large.

\r\n

     Creatures of medium size and below have the same material cost, but the cost is doubled for creatures of size large. You may even make creatures that are normally of a smaller size bigger, up to large. This also works in reverse to some degree. For example, large creatures can be made medium this way. You can create a creature that would normally be huge by reducing its size. Changes in any of the created creatures’ size cannot be greater than two size categories greater or less than what their “normal form” would be. Normal form is defined as the average size of the race they appear to be, if they appear to be of any known race.

\r\n

     Size is set as part of the ritual before the creatures have been created. Increasing or decreasing a creature’s size when creating them with this spell can affect how many creatures you can create with this spell. The base limit for the number of creatures you can create with a single casting of this spell is five. Medium creatures take one slot, small creatures take ½ of one slot, large creatures require 2 slots, and so on. For example, if you only make small creature the max you can summon is 10. The more you reduce the size of the creatures the more of them you can make.

\r\n

     You may bestow up to 5 levels of experience to each creature you create, however, the source of that experience is you, you must sacrifice your own experience in order to empower your creations. If you wish to give your creations class levels, you must source the experience from a sufficiently powerful being of that class. (You must have the caster touch someone of that class.) The creature with the class levels that is losing their experience must be willing for the spell to have an effect.

\r\n

     When created each creature can gain experience of their own. Each creature gains an alignment of the caster’s choice, but their starting alignment must always be in part neutral. Therefore, the creature created can be true neutral, chaotic neutral, neutral good, and so on. The creatures created by this spell have the same requirements to live as the creature whose form they are given, the need to eat, to breath be it water or air, and so on. They can learn new things as well.

\r\n

     You have an instinctive bond with your created creatures that allows you to fight as a seamless team. While within 100 feet of any of your creatures created by this spell, you can make any spell you cast that targets only you also target you’re the creatures created by this spell. While your creatures are within 1 mile of you, you can communicate with them telepathically.

\r\n

     When the created creature drops to 0 Hit Points, the creature disappears, leaving behind no trace. If the caster has an orb of crystal worth between 100-500 GP on their person, or in an extra-dimensional storage space that is on their person, when a creature the caster created with this spell dies the spirit flows into that crystal. If multiple of the caster’s creatures, created by this spell, die the spirits all flow into the same crystal, each crystal can hold one spirit for every 100 GP the crystal orb is worth. You may use this orb multiple times, should you choose to summon the spirits one at a time, you may also choose to increase the creatures level when re summoning them, the maximum level any creature created by this spell can be created as or brought up to is level 5.

\r\n

     Casting this spell again can re summon a creature previously created by this spell from the same caster. To do so requires the soul of the created creature. Upon its re summoning it appears within 10 feet of the caster at full health.

\r\n

     You may choose to summon new creatures instead of changing a previously created creature. However, using the orb containing the soul of a dead creature created by this spell will always result in that creature being revived.

\r\n

     You may choose to change the level of a creature that is being revived via this spell. You may reduce that creatures’ level to zero, however you may not increase its level to more than 5. When reducing the level of a creature during the process of reviving it via this spell the caster must have a place to store those levels the creature is losing. This experience can be transferred to another creature that the caster is touching or can be given to a new creature being created alongside the creature being revived.

\r\n

     You may use the orb as part of a resurrection spell in order to bring back the creature. However, if this is done the creature is no longer bound to you and is free to be its own person. If the creature dies after being resurrected, not by use of this spell, that creature’s soul departs for the afterlife. This creature can be raised from the dead as normal.

\r\n

     If you the caster dies, all creature you have created by this spell are set free.

\r\n

After casting this spell, you gain 5 levels of exhaustion. You decide whether to give class levels to any of the creatures you summon with this spell.

\r\n

    

","sourceId":null},{"id":260887,"label":"Truesight","description":"

Through a powerful ritual, you bestow upon one creature you touch the gift of truesight. This blessing remains on that creature until dispelled or you until you cast this spell on another creature. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":261442,"label":"Raise Volcano","description":"

The potent raise volcano spell opens a fissure deep in the earth that leads down to an underlying pool of magma and causes it to explode upward, creating a relatively small (but still quite devastating) artificial volcano.

\r\n

You select a point to be the center of the volcano you create. Immediately, the ground in a 10-foot radius around that point swells into a cone 10 feet high, with a small vent at the peak. Every creature in this area must make a Dexterity Saving Throw or fall to the base of the cone, taking 4 (1d6) points of damage. Structures in the area take 28 (8d6) points of damage.

\r\n

One round after the vent appears, an 80-foot-radius area around the center of the spell's effect is struck with a terrific tremor that duplicates the effect of an earthquake spell. At the same time, gouts of lava and ash blast from the central cone. Any creature inside of the cone (falling or flying up) takes 70 (20d6) fire damage each round they remain inside the cone with no saving throw. Creatures and objects directly above the cone's rim (to a height of 200 ft.) and within 10 feet of the cone's rim also suffer this fire damage, but they can make Dexterity Saving Throws each round they remain in the danger zone to take half damage.

\r\n

Each round you concentrate, the radius of cone and the radius of the earthquake effect grows by 15 feet, and the top of cone rises 10 feet.

\r\n

Starting on round 4, the earthquake zone is pelted with burning chunks of molten rock. All creatures must make a Dexterity Saving Throw, taking 7 (2d6) points of fire damage on a failure. This save is repeated at the start of each of their turns while within the area of effect. Objects in this area take 7 (2d6) points of fire damage per round.

\r\n

Starting on round 8, the entire earthquake zone is blanketed in a thick cloud of ash and smoke to a height of 100 ft. The area within the smoke is heavily obscured and creatures within the smoke that re not holding their breath must make a Constitution  Saving Throw or be poisoned. Creatures that do not need to breath are immune to this effect.

\r\n

The volcano ceases to grow once it reaches its maximum height of 100 ft. The earthquake zone ceases to grow once it reaches its maximum radius of 1,600ft. The volcano's growth also ends if the spell's magic is dispelled or you cease concentrating on the spell. Once the spell's duration ends, the volcano stops erupting, and the cone collapses into a pit as deep and wide as the cone. One round later the pit closes up; anything inside the pit when it closes is crushed. Those inside the pit take 70 (20d6) points of damage and become entombed in the ground; if they cannot escape via magic or burrowing, they remain there until they suffocate, die of thirst or hunger, or are rescued by outside forces.

","sourceId":null},{"id":264778,"label":"Power Word Revive","description":"

You utter a word of power that can compel one dead creature you can see within range to be revived instantly. If the creature you choose has been dead for 7 days or less, it is revived, and all missing body parts are restored. Otherwise, the spell has no effect.

","sourceId":null},{"id":265521,"label":"Fizzlewix's Wondrous Workshop","description":"

You conjure a doorway within range that leads to an extradimensional workshop that lasts for the duration. This doorway is a large metallic door that looks as if it is brightly light from behind. You and any creature you designate when you cast the spell can enter the workshop as long as the entrance remains open. You can open or close the door if you are within 30 feet of it. While closed, the door is locked and is impervious to damage the outside.

\r\n

You can create any floor plan you like, but the space can't exceed 20 cubes, each being 15 feet on each side. The workshop is furnished and decorated as you choose. You and any creature you designated on casting, all their gear repaired instantly upon entering the workshop. Additionally, you and any creature you designated on casting, may choose 1 item (cannot choose an item that belongs to another creature) to gain a bonus for the next 24 hours. If the chosen item is an armor and shield, then it gains a +1 bonus to its AC. If the chosen item is a simple or martial weapon, then it gains a bonus +1 to attack and damage rolls, plus they count as magical weapons for the purpose of overcoming resistances.

\r\n

While in the workshop, you and the creatures you designated on casting, has access to any artisan tool of choice and may create any common or uncommon magic item after an allotted time designated by your DM. If the chosen item is of a higher rarity, it may require additional materials that would be required to be brought from outside the workshop. Additional restrictions for crafting may be applied by your DM depending on the chosen item.

\r\n

Any item, with the exception of crafted items, created by this spell dissipates into smoke if removed from the workshop. When the spell ends, any creature inside the workshop is expelled into the nears open space to the entrance.

","sourceId":null},{"id":272205,"label":"Fillie's Expansive Demiplane","description":"

You permanently connect two different demiplanes that you have created. You can create a door, gate or similar opening attaching to a surface within each plane and connect the two permanently. You can also choose to instead connect the planes directly, stacking them onto or next to each other and making the wall between crumble away, Effectively turning your two demiplanes into one larger demiplane. This process can be repeated with several castings of the spell, to create demiplanes of varying shapes and sizes.

\r\n

Alternatively, You can use this spell to sever the connection between demiplanes you have connected in this way. Either permanently or temporarily disconnecting, a number of your choice, demiplanes from each other.

\r\n

If you cast this spell at 9th level, You may also choose to furnish one of your demiplanes, but doing so consumes the dollhouse material component. Furnishings created in this way are permanent, more expensive furnishings require a more valuable dollhouse component, divided up into three tiers.

\r\n

Tier 1 (300 gold) Allows for furnishings of basic wood structures, including but not limited to: Bed frames, benches, chairs, chests, crates, dressers, stools, and tables.

\r\n

Tier 2 (600 gold) Allows for furnishings of metal and stone structures, excluding precious metals, including but not limited to: Cells, chains, chandeliers, pillars, platforms, spikes, and wells.

\r\n

Tier 3 (1000 gold) Allows for extravagant and luxurious furnishings, including but not limited to: Alchemical stations, clockwork, fancy cutlery, and gold in lined beds with silken sheets.

\r\n

Additionally you can include other spells you have prepared in the casting to provide additional ephemeral or magical effects to the furnishings. This casting ignores material components of the additional spells and the duration of the effect is permanent. These effects include but are not limited to: An illusory sky using Hallucinatory Terrain, several braziers of Continual Flame, an everflowing fountain using Watery Sphere or Control Water, and a room filled with magical darkness using Darkness.

","sourceId":null},{"id":277586,"label":"Abdul's Planar Armaments","description":"

Powdered gemstones spiral around the casters hand, coalescing in a maelstrom around 2 spinning silver rods, alight with planar fury. These disks serve two purposes, combat and defense. When the spell is successfully cast, you choose their damage type between fire, cold, lightning, acid, necrotic, radiant, bludgeoning or slashing. This can be changed as a bonus action as well. You gain resistance and advantage on saving throws against the chosen element. As a reaction, you can choose to gain +2 AC. As a bonus action(this can be part of the same bonus action to change elements) you can hurl a rippling disk of the chosen element as a ranged spell attack, imparting an effect below based on the chosen damage type on a hit:

\r\n

Fire: this disk deals 6d6 fire damage upon impact as its scores the body of its victim with the power of the Plane of Fire. If hit, the target must make a Constitution Saving Throw or take 1d6 damage on each of its turn, repeating the saving throw at the end of their turn until they succeed, thus ending the effect.

\r\n

Cold: This arctic disk deals 6d6 cold damage on impact as it tears and freezes its target with the power of the Plane of Ice. The afflicted target must make a Constitution Saving Throw or have its movement speed halved until the save is passed. It can repeat the saving throw on the end of each of its turns.

\r\n

Lightning: This disk borne of the Plane of Storms deals 6d6 lightning damage on impact. The target must make a Constitution Saving Throw or be unable to make reactions until the start of its next turn.

\r\n

Acid: This disk formed from the fetid dirge of Hades deals 6d6 acid damage and reduces its AC by 1 until its next turn. The acid damage can be replaced with the effects of a different acid if the DM allows if asked for this option by the caster.

\r\n

Radiant and Necrotic: these disks respectively borne of the Positive and Negative Energy Planes deal 6d6 of their damage types. As an action, you can hurl radiance at a target to heal then 6d6 instead or if necrotic, raise one body as an undead according the effect Create Undead. These extraneous effects can only be used once per casting of this spell.

\r\n

Bludgeoning and Slashing: These disks are formed from the Planes of Water or Air respectively can deal 6d6 of their respective damage type on impact. As a reaction you can make these disks ricochet to a new target and repeating the spell attack. These disks can only ricochet once by this effect.

","sourceId":null},{"id":278101,"label":"Summon Yugoloth","description":"

You create a summoning circle using either chalk, salt, blood or holly water. After the circle is drawn the decorated container is placed next to it, with the appropriate payment for the Yugoloth you wish to summon. You choose either a Yugoloth you know, the name of the specific species of Yugoloth you require, or a Yagnoloth to aid you further in finding the perfect Yugoloth for your request. Upon the completion of the spell, the contents of the container are sent to the chosen Yugoloth.

\r\n

If the Yugoloth is willing, they will be summoned to your circle. If they refuse the spell fails and half of the payment used as a request for the Yugoloth's aid reapers inside the container, while the other half remains within the possessions of the Yugoloth. The reasons for a Yugoloth to refuse this summoning can vary, but the usual causes are that the Yugoloth is preoccupied at the moment, that the offered amount is too little for the chosen Yugoloth or that the Yugoloth doesn't like or trust the summoner. 

\r\n

Even if a Yugoloth is summoned with this spell, the fiend isn't necessarily friendly. It is up to you to explain what is wished from this Yugoloth and convince them to take the job. It is possible the Yugoloth requests more payment than the offered amount. It is also possible the Yugoloth doesn't accept your terms and does as they please. Even after a deal is made and both parties agree on the conditions the Yugoloth might still do as they please.

\r\n

At Higher Levels: You can summon 1 additional Yugoloth for each spell level above 4th. They must all be of the same species. They will require separate payments in different containers.

\r\n

 

\r\n
 
","sourceId":null},{"id":280460,"label":"Mass Dimension Door","description":"

You select as many creatures that you wish within 30 feet. Each target must be wearing a glass pendant like in the description of the spell. You and the chosen creatures teleport from your current location to a spot within range. You don't have to see the point that you teleport to. If you teleport into an object you sustain 6d6 force damage as you as shunted out. You can bring any items equal to what you can carry with you.

","sourceId":null},{"id":284217,"label":"Summon Creature","description":"

You utter a sequence of incantations, summoning one creature from a different plane or dimension. You choose the creature's type, which must be one of challenge rating 10 or lower. The creature appears in an unoccupied space you can see within range, and the creature disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

Roll initiative for the creature, which has its own turns. When you summon it and on each of your turns thereafter, you can issue a verbal command to it (requiring no action on your part), telling it what it must do on its next turn. If you issue no command, it spends its turn attacking any creature within reach that has attacked it.

\r\n

At the end of each of the creature's turns, it makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature becomes insane and is inactive for one round. On a successful save, your control of the creature keeps going for the rest of the duration, and the creature spends its turns listening to your commands to the best of its ability.

\r\n

As part of casting the spell, you can form a circle on the ground with the blood used as a material component. The circle is large enough to encompass your space. While the spell lasts, the summoned creature can’t cross the circle or harm it, and it can’t target anyone within it. Using the material component in this manner consumes it when the spell ends.

","sourceId":null},{"id":285738,"label":"Nuclear Explosion","description":"

Choose a location within 10 miles that you have a line of sight to or can recall. After concentrating for 1 hour on that location, a portal from an unknown dimension appears above the area and a small bright ball of fire falls to the ground on that location and explodes in a devastating nuclear blast. Each creature and object excluding the caster in a 3-mile-radius sphere centered on that point must make a Constitution saving throw. A target within 1 mile of the center of the blast takes 15d6 fire damage and 20d6 force damage, and targets beyond 1 mile take only the force damage. Any creature that fails the Constitution saving throw is pushed 60 away from the center of the blast, is knocked prone, and takes an extra 10d6 bludgeoning damage.  

\r\n

Additionally, each creature in the blast has its maximum HP reduced by half. This effect counts as a disease.

\r\n

The blast spreads around corners. It ignites flammable objects in the area even if they are being worn or carried.

\r\n

Once used, this spell cannot be used again until 1d8 weeks have passed.

","sourceId":null},{"id":289262,"label":"Abraxis's Grasp","description":"

You have uncovered the secret knowledge of Abraxis's research, and with it, you can bend reality to your will. This spell allows you to bend gravity around creatures in certain ways. A creature you touch must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be affected by the spell. You choose one of the following effects.

\r\n

Augment. You augment the force of gravity in an area around the target, causing it to fall prone taking 4d6 of bludgeoning damage. While prone this way the target has disadvantage in melee and ranged weapon attacks. a creature that attempts to stand up must make a strength check, ending the spell effect on a success.

\r\n

Nullify. You counter the force of gravity causing it to act like it never existed, the target of the spell float aimlessly for the duration, like if affected by the levitate spell. While floating this way the targets must propel themselves of objects to move, air swimming is allowed, but the targets move at half speed.

\r\n

Invert. You invert the direction of gravity, up is down and down is up, for the duration of the spell the target fall upward at a rate of 180 ft. per round (30 ft. a second), it may attempt at dexterity saving throw to grab onto a fixed object it can reach, thus avoiding the fall. The creature may repeat the saving throw at the end of its turn, and it does so with advantage.

","sourceId":null},{"id":291940,"label":"Blacksphere","description":"

Upon casting this spell, a sphere of pure darkness appears in an area within range of the caster. Comprising pure force energy, the sphere appears black as night and has a radius of 20'.  All creatures inside the sphere must make a Strength Saving Throw. On a fail, they take 8d8 points of force damage and are trapped in the sphere, being pulled into the center and becoming restrained for the duration. On a success they take half damage and are still pulled to the center but may use an action to leave the sphere.

\r\n

A creature who failed its save can't leave it by nonmagical means. If the creature tries to use teleportation or interplanar travel to leave the sphere, it must first make a Charisma saving throw. On a success, the creature can use that magic to exit the sphere. On a failure, the creature can't exit the sphere and wastes the use of the spell or effect. The sphere also extends into the Ethereal Plane, blocking ethereal travel

Cast at a 9th level this spell last an hour and does not require concentration

","sourceId":null},{"id":292602,"label":"Alchemy (Constructing, deconstructing, reconstructing)","description":"

Choose an area of terrain no larger than 20 feet square within range. You can reshape dirt, sand, stone, metal, wood, or clay in the area in any manner you choose for the duration. You can raise or lower the area's elevation, create or fill in a trench, erect or flatten a wall, form a pillar, or just create a random object. The extent of any such changes can't exceed half the area's largest dimension. So, if you affect a 20-foot by 20-foot by 20-foot cube, you can create a pillar up to 20 feet high and 10 feet thick, raise or lower the cube's elevation by up to 30 feet, dig a trench up to 20 feet deep and 10 feet wide, and so on. It takes 2 rounds of combat for these changes to complete.

\r\n

You may not cast this spell on a different area until the next round of combat finishes.

\r\n

Entities (both players, NPCs and enemies) may be trapped or injured by the changing object's movement.

\r\n

Rocks and structures shift to accommodate the new terrain. If the way you shape the terrain would make a structure unstable, it might collapse.

\r\n

Similarly, this spell doesn't directly affect plant growth. The moved earth carries any plants along with it.

","sourceId":null},{"id":299701,"label":"Extinction Event (10th level spell)","description":"

A giant sphere of rock plummets to the ground at a point you choose on an accurate map. Each creature in a 500-foot-radius sphere centered on the point you choose must make a Dexterity saving throw. The sphere spreads around corners. A creature takes 20d20 bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature in the area of more than one fiery burst is affected only once.

\r\n

The spell damages all objects in the area.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":302752,"label":"Summon Abberation","description":"

 

\r\n

You utter foul words, summoning one abberation from the Far Realm. You choose the Abberation's type, which must be one of challenge rating 5 or lower, such as a Star Spawn Mangler or an Otyugh. The abberation appears in an unoccupied space you can see within range, and the abberation disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

Roll initiative for the Abberation, which has its own turns. When you summon it and on each of your turns thereafter, you can issue a verbal command to it (requiring no action on your part), telling it what it must do on its next turn. If you issue no command, it spends its turn attacking any creature within reach that has attacked it.

\r\n

At the end of each of the abberation's turns, it makes a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the abberation continues to obey you. On a successful save, your control of the abberation ends for the rest of the duration, and the abberation spends its turns pursuing and attacking the nearest non-abberations to the best of its ability. If you stop concentrating on the spell before it reaches its full duration, an uncontrolled abberation doesn’t disappear for 1d6 rounds if it still has hit points.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the challenge rating increases by 1 for each slot level above 5th.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":302754,"label":"Summon Minor Abberations","description":"

You utter foul words, summoning abberations from the Far Realm. Roll on the following table to determine what appears.

\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
d6Abberations Summoned
1–2Two abberations of challenge rating 1 or lower
3–4Four abberations of challenge rating 1/2 or lower
5–6Eight abberations of challenge rating 1/4 or lower
\r\n
\r\n

The DM chooses the abberations, such as Flumphs or Star Spawn Grues, and you choose the unoccupied spaces you can see within range where they appear. A summoned abberation disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The abberations are hostile to all creatures, including you. Roll initiative for the summoned abberation as a group, which has its own turns. The abberations pursue and attack the nearest non-abberations to the best of their ability.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th or 7th level, you summon twice as many abberations. If you cast it using a spell slot of 8th or 9th level, you summon three times as many abberations.

","sourceId":null},{"id":302781,"label":"Create Construct","description":"

You infuse a material with a form of magic that grants it life. Shaping into a living construct that obey's your command. 

\r\n

The construct is friendly to you and your companions for the duration. Roll initiative for the construct, which has its own turns. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to the construct, it defends itself from hostile creatures but otherwise takes no actions.

\r\n

The GM has the constructs statistics. Sample constructs can be found below. 

\r\n

!LIMITATIONS!:Creating life is hard. You may only create life which constructs CR equals or is below your Character level.  Your character level also serves as a capacity to how many you may control. Example: A level 9 character may only have 9 CR 1's, while a level 20 may have 20 CR 1's. Going further than your cap will result in a creation hostile to everyone around it. (Also, 0 CR counts a 0.5, so a level 20 character can only have 40 CR 0's, not infinite)

\r\n

Sample Constructs

\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
CRCreature Name
0Homunculus *Requires a dead small reptile, dead flying creature, and 25GP
1Animated Armor *Requires a set of plate armor, and 110GP
2Rug of Smothering *Requires a rug (no larger than 16ft by 16ft), a sack, and 200GP
5Flesh Golem *Requires three corpses of medium size or larger, a drop of casters blood, and 800GP
7Shield Guardian *Requires a set of plate armor,a shield,an amulet the caster must wear to control the construct, and 1500GP
9 Clay Golem *Requires enough clay or mud to cover 2 medium creatures, a nearby fire, a circular wooden ball, and 2200GP
10 Stone Golem *Requires 600LBS of stone, a gem worth atleast 1000GP, a drop of the casters blood, and 5000GP
16 Iron Golem *Requires 600 LBS of iron or steel, a diamond worth atleast 2000GP, a cup of magma/lava, a drop of the casters blood, and 15000GP
\r\n

 

\r\n 
 Notes: Your GM is free to alter this spell, and the two of you should discuss any changes or additional creations if you choose to use this in your game.
","sourceId":null},{"id":302941,"label":"Khazarod's Greater Demiplane","description":"

You create a swirling portal of blue and purple arcane energy at a point which you can see within range. The portal will allow Large creatures to pass through unhindered if the caster allows their entry. The caster may designate up to 50 creatures at a time to be allowed entry, and any without permission will simply pass through the portals space as if it wasn't there. The portal leads to a Greater Demiplane that appears to be a vast empty void, 15 Miles in each dimension.  When the spell ends, the portal disappears, and any creatures or objects inside the Demiplane remain trapped there, as the portal also disappears from the other side. Casting this spell again whilst within the Demiplane, will reopen the portal on the material realm at the original location.

\r\n

Upon entering the Greater Demiplane for the first time, the caster may create and manipulate matter within the space as long as the caster has a small sample to seed the creation. The caster may will into being a landscape to fill the Demiplane, with specific biomes such as a grassland born from a single blade of grass (e.g. Desert, Mountains, Forest, Caverns). The caster may then fill this landscape using the same method, forming natural foliage from a single acorn or an orchard from an apple pip, and certain minor creatures such as insects may be conjured in much the same way (Apple Trees, Flowers, Bees), and finally, the caster may expend an 8th level spell slot to cast a permanent version of the Mighty Fortress spell without requiring any additional spell components. This version of the Fortress allows the caster to manipulate the interior at will, changing the form and function of rooms as required, as long as no creatures currently occupy the room.

\r\n

Subsequent castings of this spell reopens the portal to allow entry to the caster's Demiplane but cannot create new Greater Demiplanes, and does not require or consume spell components. However, the further castings do increase the size of the plane by 1 mile and allows the caster to create and manipulate their growing realm further. The caster's Demiplane is also accessible by use of the Plane Shift spell. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":306793,"label":"Aethaldin's Portable Railgun","description":"

You imbue an object with arcane force. As you chant the incarnation, the object begins hovering and spinning until it is too turbulent to contain. You throw the object at great speed, causing a loud boom that can be heard from 200ft away. Any creatures in a 60ft line must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target(s) take 6d8 force damage and are flung 30ft backwards and fall prone. On a successful save, the target(s) take half damage.

","sourceId":null},{"id":312001,"label":"Create Spellstone","description":"

When you cast this spell, you create a Spellstone, a crystal sphere up to foot in diameter that connects directly to the Weave. When you cast a spell of 4th level or lower that has a duration that isn't instantaneous, you can link it to a Spellstone within 30 feet of you. A spell linked to a Spellstone becomes permanent until its connection is broken, which causes the spell to immediately end. The connection is broken if:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • The Spellstone is not within 30 feet of any effect of the linked spell.
    • \r\n
  • The spell or Spellstone enter an Anti-Magic Field.
    • \r\n
  • Dispel Magic is successfully cast on either the Spellstone or spell effect.
    • \r\n
\r\n

In addition, if the spell would allow a Saving Throw to remove the effects, the target of the spell may repeat the saving throw each time the spell would expire. For example, if Dominate Person was made permanent this way, the target would get a saving throw every minute. Finally, a Spellstone cannot be used on more than one spell at a time, though it is not consumed when cast.

","sourceId":null},{"id":314977,"label":"Forge Familiar","description":"

You mold metal plates into the form of any Small or smaller beast or elemental of CR 1 or lower (excluding the homunculus) in an unoccupied space within range and transfer the spirit of your familiar into this form. The pseudodragon is also a valid choice. If you are proficient with Smith's Tools or Tinker's Tools, casting time for this spell is reduced by half.

\r\n

While in its forged form, your familiar still functions as per the find familiar spell, its statistics are replaced with those of the form you created (the appearance of which you choose), and it gains the following benefits:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Its type changes to construct instead of beast, celestial, elemental, fiend, fey, or undead
    • \r\n
  • Its hit point maximum increases by a number equal to 3 times your spellcasting ability modifier
    • \r\n
  • It is able to make attacks as well as any other actions granted by its new form
    • \r\n
  • Its AC becomes 17 if it isn't already higher
    • \r\n
  • It has advantage on saving throws against poison, and it has resistance to poison damage if it does not already have resistance or immunity
    • \r\n
  • The ranges at which you can use any of the features granted to you and your familiar by the find familiar spell are doubled
    • \r\n
  • It gets a bonus to saving throws and attacks rolls equal to your spellcasting ability modifier
    • \r\n
\r\n

If your familiar drops to 0 hp, the forged form is destroyed and its spirit appears in the nearest unoccupied space in whichever form it was in before you cast this spell. If your familiar's forged form is able to cast any spells, it can only do so if you know that spell and/or have it prepared.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the forged form's hit points increase by an additional amount equal to your spellcasting ability modifier for each level above 4th and its AC increases by 1 for every two slot levels above 4th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":319706,"label":"Amnesia","description":"

You attempt to wipe the memories from the mind of one creature that you touch. The target must make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed saving throw, the target takes 12d6 psychic damage and the target's mind is sent reeling as it attempts to hold onto its memories. On a successful saving throw, the target takes half damage and can't take reactions until the start of its next turn, but is otherwise not affected by the spell, and the spell ends.

\r\n

Creatures whose minds are reeling from this spell are stunned. A creature reeling from this spell must also make another Intelligence saving throw at the end of each of its turns. On a failed saving throw, it takes 6d6 psychic damage. If it saves against this spell three times, the spell ends. If it fails saves three times, it becomes unconscious until the spell ends and it stops making these saving throws. The successes and failures don’t need to be consecutive; keep track of both until the target collects three of a kind.

\r\n

If you maintain your concentration on this spell for the entire possible duration, the target loses all of its memories and the spell ends. It gains one level of exhaustion, and if it isn't unconscious, it becomes unconscious. It stays unconscious for at least 1 hour after losing its memories, regardless of its hit points.

\r\n

A creature who has lost its memories knows nothing about themselves or their past, but it remembers most general ideas about the way the world is arranged and how things work. It retains its inclinations, likes, dislikes, and fears (towards food, ideas, people, etc.), but it will not know of these feelings until it encounters them, and these feelings are much more malleable and easier to change than a creature who has memories to ground its feelings in. It retains all its skills and abilities, including spellcasting, though it will not initially remember that it has most skills or abilities.

\r\n

Once a creature has lost its memories due to this spell, it will develop a new (perhaps similar) identity and begin forming new memories without any issue, but it will not naturally regain the memories it lost. Once a year it must make an Intelligence saving throw with disadvantage. It may also make this saving throw on rare occasions where it encounters something that might spark its memory, at your DM's discretion. On a successful saving throw, it recovers all its lost memories, which causes it to become stunned until the end of its next turn.

\r\n

The spell can also be ended by greater restoration, heal, or wish cast as an 8th-level or higher spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":320334,"label":"Koko's Create Vacuum","description":"

You create a vacuum in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you choose within range. For the duration, no sound can be created within or pass through the area and any creature or object entirely inside the sphere is immune to thunder damage, and creatures are deafened while entirely inside it. Casting a spell that includes a verbal component is impossible there.

\r\n

Additionally all flames within the area are extinguished and no creature can breathe while remaining in the space. Any creature who needs to breathe begins suffocating at the start of their next turn.

\r\n

If the vacuum is created entirely within a body of water, a cavitation bubble is created. When the spell ends, the bubble collapses and all creatures within 30 feet of the center of the bubble must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 4d6 thunder damage and is stunned until the end of its next turn on a failed save, or half as much damage and is not stunned on a successful one.

","sourceId":null},{"id":321122,"label":"Ashe's Arcane Seal","description":"

You touch a closed container no larger than 2 cubic feet, such as a chest or box, and it becomes locked for the duration. You designate any number of creatures and/or conditions when you cast this spell. The contain is only able to be opened when these creatures attempt to open it, or when the conditions have been met. Otherwise, the container cannot be opened until it is broken or the spell is dispelled or suppressed.Additionally the container becomes magically trapped. When a creature not named when the spell was cast attempts to open the container a glyph is placed on the inside of the container that erupts when triggered, causing magical energy causing everything inside the container to take damage. All objects inside the container take 10d8 force damage.

Casting knock on the object using a spell slot equal to, or higher than the spell slot used to cast this spell suppresses Ashe's Arcane Seal for 10 minutes.

\r\n

While affected by this spell, the container is more difficult to break or force open; the DC to break it or pick any locks on it increases by 12.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage caused inside the container increases by 2d8 for each slot level above 4th. Additionally the DC to break or force open the object increases by 2 for each spell slot above 4th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":324012,"label":"Aberrant Call","description":"

You temporarily open a rift to the Far Realm, mentally assaulting all creatures in a location that you specify. Each creature in a 20-foot radius centered on a point within range must make an Intelligence saving throw. Each creature targeted by the spell takes 6d6 psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. On a failed save, the target is also incapacitated until the start of your next turn.

\r\n

At higher levels: When you cast this spell at a higher level, it does an additional 1d6 psychic damage per spell level above 5th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":327932,"label":"Widogast’s Fiery Familiar","description":"

To cast this spell you must have in your service a familiar conjured from the find familiar spell. Upon  touching your familiar when you cast this spell, the familiar’s chosen form changes, growing into a large or huge creature at the casters discretion and taking on a fiery appearance. While in this form the familiar is considered an elemental, and gains the following benefits: 30 additional hit points, +2 to all of its stats, and the Fire Form ability.

\r\n

Fire Form. The Fiery familiar can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing. A creature that touches the Flaming familiar or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 (1d10) fire damage. In addition, the Fiery familiar can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. The first time it enters a creature's space on a turn, that creature takes 5 (1d10) fire damage and catches fire; until it takes an action to douse the fire, the creature takes 5 (1d10) fire damage at the start of each of its turns.

\r\n

Your Fiery familiar acts independently of you, but it always obeys your commands. In combat, it rolls its own initiative and acts on its own turn. A familiar in this form regains the ability to attack, Dealing 1D8 piercing or slashing damage as appropriate as well as an additional 2D8 fire damage.

\r\n

When the Fiery Familiar drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form, however as long as your concentration hasn’t been broken it can be resummoned using a bonus action by sacrificing a spell slot of 2nd level or higher.

\r\n

While your Fiery familiar is within 100 feet of you, you can communicate with it telepathically. Furthermore when you cast a spell you can choose to cast it as if your familiar had cast the spell. Your Fiery familiar must be within 100 feet of you, and it must use its reaction to deliver the spell when you cast it. If the spell requires an attack roll, you use your attack modifier for the roll.

","sourceId":null},{"id":330918,"label":"Mole Scroll","description":"

You touch a scroll of parchment and imbue it with a semblance of life, causing it to float in the air and become invisible.  In casting the spell you can give direct orders to the scroll on whom to listen to by giving a specific name or a vague explanation; for example \"Listen to Lord Gillroon as he speaks to his servant\" or \"Keep track on the conversations that take place in this room between people of authority\".  The scroll will then write out a word for word transcript of whatever it was told to listen to using the provided quill, magically fueling itself with ink.   The scroll will only listen to conversations in the room it was cast in, and won't move out of that area until the spell is over.

\r\n

Once the duration of the spell has transpired, or upon your request, the scroll ceases writing, and returns to the caster, losing its sentience.

","sourceId":null},{"id":332705,"label":"Milo's Transporting Familiar","description":"

You call a spirit that takes the shape of a Huge familiar and appears in an unoccupied space of your choice within range. You decide it's appearance and control it's movements, pace and direction of travel (no actions required). You are always aware of it's surroundings, as if you were right next to it.

\r\n

The familiar has walking speed of 100 feet and your choice of either a climbing, swimming or flying speed of 300 feet allowing it to travel up to 30 miles in an hour, or 40 miles at a fast pace.

\r\n

A creature or object must enter the pocket dimension within the familiar to travel with it as it moves. For the duration, you and up to nine creatures you choose within range can enter or go out of the familiar as an action, along with anything they are carrying. Entering the familiar takes 1 minute, during which time a creature is incapacitated and must remain within range.

\r\n

Additionally,  you can touch an object or a container within it or within 30 ft of it as an action to make it instantly enter or leave it's inner pocket dimension along with it's contents.The pocket dimension can hold up to 3 tons of cargo within it.

\r\n

Other creatures and undesired objects are barred from entering the familiar. Spells and other magical effects can’t extend through it's form or be cast through it. You decide it's inner pocket dimension's atmosphere, looks and shape when you cast the spell.

\r\n

Any creatures or objects that are still within the familiar when the spell ends appear in it's closest unoccupied space of your choice within range as it dissipates.

","sourceId":null},{"id":335114,"label":"Dimensional Anchor","description":"

A green ray springs from your outstretched hand at a creature or object you can see within range. You must make a ranged spell attack to hit the target. This ray automatically hits objects that are not being worn or carried. On a hit, the target is unable to be affected by teleportation spells (such as \">dimension door and \">teleport), plane shifting, astral travel and ethereal travel.

\r\n

A dimensional anchor does not interfere with the movement of creatures already in ethereal or astral form when the spell is cast, nor does it block the ability to see into other planes of existence or affect them. Also, dimensional anchor does not prevent summoned creatures from disappearing at the end of a summoning spell.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a 5th level spell slot, the duration increases to 10 minutes. When you cast this spell using a 6th level spell slot, the duration increases to 1 hour. When you cast this spell using a 7th level spell slot, the duration increases to 4 hours. When you cast this spell using an 8th level spell slot, the duration increases to 8 hours. When you cast this spell using a 9th level spell slot, the duration increases to 24 hours.

","sourceId":null},{"id":337622,"label":"Anthropomorph","description":"

You transform up to five beasts of challenge rating 1 or lower that you can see within range. A hostile target can make a Wisdom saving throw. On a successful save, it resists the transformation. 

\r\n

Each target assumes a clothed humanoid form. You can choose the same appearance or a different one for each target. The new form can look like any humanoid you have seen before, and you choose their set of clothes, which can include footwear, gloves, and other everyday, nonmagical accessories. The target’s game statistics, including mental ability scores, are replaced by the statistics of a commoner, except the target retains its creature type, its hit points, alignment, personality, and gains an Intelligence score of 4. The target can't speak, but it understands Common. At the DM's option, a target repeatedly transformed this way could learn a few words and basic expressions.

\r\n

Each target gains 5 temporary hit points. These temporary hit points can’t be replaced by temporary hit points from another source. A target reverts to its normal form when it has no more temporary hit points or it dies. If the spell ends before then, the creature loses all its temporary hit points and reverts to its normal form. Articles of clothing created with this spell turn to dust if removed from a target or when the spell ends. 

\r\n

The knowledge and awareness of the targets is limited by their intelligence, but they can recognize friends and foes and follow simple instructions. Targets that were hostile when casting the spell remain hostile, and social interaction (e.g. deception, persuasion) or magic might be required to change their attitude. Otherwise, a target's starting attitude is either indifferent or friendly. See DMG chapter 8 for social interaction guidelines.

\r\n

In combat, roll initiative for the creatures as a group, which has its own turns. Friendly targets will obey any verbal commands that you issue to them (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to them, they defend themselves from hostile creatures, but otherwise take no actions. The targets are proficient with their unarmed strikes. 

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the duration is Concentration, up to 8 hours. If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 8th level or higher, the duration is Concentration, up to 24 hours. If you cast this spell using a 9th level slot, the duration is up to 7 days, no Concentration required.

","sourceId":null},{"id":340761,"label":"Summon Greater Eldritch Horror","description":"

You mutter words in an ancient forgotten language, calling out to children of the Great Old Ones. You summon an aberration in service of your Patron, up to a CR of 5. It will appear in an unoccupied space you can see within range, and the aberration disappears when it falls to 0 HP or when the spell ends.

\r\n

Roll an initiative for the aberration, which has its own turns. When you summon it and on each of your turns thereafter, you can issue a verbal command to it (requiring no action on your part), telling it what it must do on its next turn. If you issue no command, it spends its turn attacking any creature within reach that has attacked it.

\r\n

If you are in good standing with your patron, the creature will listen to your commands with no issue. However, if you are opposed to your patron, or have ignored its commands and tenants, at the end of each of its terms it makes a Wisdom saving throw. If it fails than it continues to follow your commands, but if it succeeds it will go on a rampage attacking anything but other aberrations under the command of its master to the best of its ability. If you stop concentrating on the spell before it reaches its full duration, an uncontrolled aberration doesn’t disappear for 1d6 rounds if it still has hit points.

\r\n

As a part of casting the spell, you can draw a circle with chalk with sulfur and copper powder, with eldritch runes encompassing the circle and an all-seeing eye in the center. The circle is large enough to encompass your space. While the spell lasts, the summoned aberration can’t cross the circle or harm it, and it can’t target anyone within it. Using the material component in this manner consumes it when the spell ends.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the challenge rating increases by 1 for each slot level above 4th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":341096,"label":"Arcanist's Versatility","description":"

Taking a moment to meditate on a task, you use your magic to gain an understanding of how to better proceed. Choose one tool or skill and gain proficiency in it until the spell ends.

","sourceId":null},{"id":352272,"label":"Conjure Aberration","description":"

You summon an aberration of challenge rating 5 or lower. It appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. The aberration disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The aberration is friendly to you and your companions for the duration. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to the aberration, it defends itself from hostile creatures but otherwise takes no actions.

\r\n

If your concentration is broken, the aberration doesn't disappear. Instead, you lose control of the aberration, it becomes hostile toward you and your companions, and it might attack. An uncontrolled aberration can't be dismissed by you, and it disappears 1 hour after you summoned it.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the challenge rating increases by 1 for each slot level above 5th.

\r\n

This is also designed to be used with the homebrew Summoner wizard tradition uploaded to D&D Beyond by AudibleShrug.

","sourceId":null},{"id":354641,"label":"Leomund's Secure Shelter","description":"

You conjure a sturdy cottage or lodge made of material that is common in the area where the spell is cast in a 20 foot cube. The floor is level, clean, and dry. In all respects the lodging resembles a normal cottage, with a sturdy door, two shuttered windows, and a small fireplace.

\r\n

The shelter has no heating or cooling source (other than natural insulation qualities). Therefore, it must be heated as a normal dwelling, and extreme heat adversely affects it and its occupants. The dwelling does, however, provide considerable security otherwise—it is as strong as a normal stone building, regardless of its material composition. The dwelling resists flames and fire as if it were stone. It is impervious to normal missiles (but not the sort cast by siege engines or giants).

\r\n

The door, shutters, and even chimney are secure against intrusion, the former two being locked with a arcane lock spell and the latter secured by an iron grate at the top and a narrow flue. In addition, these three areas are protected by an alarm spell. Finally, an unseen servant is conjured to provide service to you for the duration of the shelter.

\r\n

The secure shelter contains rude furnishings —eight bunks, a trestle table, eight stools, and a writing desk.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the duration increases by 2 hours for each slot level above 4th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":361048,"label":"Greater Find Familiar","description":"

Prerequisite: Must know the \"Find Familiar\" spell.

\r\n

 Variant: Using an enchanted gem worth 100gp, you can store this spell to be used as an action when not in combat (which also keeps the spirit of your familiar within it until released). Therefore not using any of the duration given for a familiar change such as changing your familiar for only four hours just to have 2 of them wasted looking for something.

\r\n

Description: You gain the service of a familiar, a spirit that takes a creature form you choose that is up to a max size of medium and at the DM's discretion. The duration that the creature is in that particular form depends on the DM's discretion as well, but a general idea of it is provided below. Appearing in an unoccupied space within range, the familiar has the statistics of the chosen form, though it is a celestial, fey, or fiend (your choice) instead of a beast.

\r\n

Your familiar acts independently of you, but it always obeys your commands. In combat, it rolls its own initiative and acts on its own turn. A familiar can't attack, but it can take other actions as normal.

\r\n

When the familiar drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. It reappears after you cast this spell again.

\r\n

While your familiar is within 200 feet of you, you can communicate with it telepathically. Additionally, as an action, you can see through your familiar's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of your next turn, gaining the benefits of any special senses that the familiar has. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses.

\r\n

As an action, you can temporarily dismiss your familiar. It disappears into a pocket dimension where it awaits your summons. Alternatively, you can dismiss it forever. As an action, while it is temporarily dismissed, you can cause it to reappear in any unoccupied space within 30 feet of you.

\r\n

You can't have more than one familiar at a time. If you cast this spell while you already have a familiar, you instead cause it to adopt a new form. Choose one of the forms from the above list. Your familiar transforms into the chosen creature.

\r\n

Finally, when you cast a spell with a range of touch, your familiar can deliver the spell as if it had cast the spell. Your familiar must be within 100 feet of you, and it must use its reaction to deliver the spell when you cast it. If the spell requires an attack roll, you use your attack modifier for the roll.

\r\n

Durations of each type of creature are found below:

\r\n

(Casting this spell to its maximum capability for each of its levels [CR 1, 2, and 3 for slots 4, 7, and 9 respectively] give a point of exhaustion and cost and extra 200 gp per spell slot tier. Along with, whenever the duration of the spell is over, you roll a d20. If the number on the die is 1-18 the familiar returns to its original form. If the number lands on 19 or 20, your familiar changes to another available permanent form determined by the DM.)

","sourceId":null},{"id":364736,"label":"Elemental Invocation","description":"

You reach out to the Elemental Planes, dragging them closer in order to shape the landscape in an up to 1-mile radius sphere around you. You establish the radius of the spell when you cast it, and it remains anchored to where you cast it for the duration. Choose earth, fire, water, air, ice, acid, or poison when you cast this spell to determine the nature of the plane you draw on. When you cast this spell, and using an action on subsequent turns until the spell ends, you can cause one of the following effects to occur, provided you are in the area of the spell:

\r\n

Walls. You create up to four segments of wall attached to solid ground in unoccupied places you can see within the area. The walls are made out of the element of your choice, although mixed with elements of the terrain that was around the walls when they were raised for structural stability. Each segment can be up to 10 feet tall and wide, and can be up to 2 feet deep. You can orient the walls however you choose, and crudely shape it, within the size constraints above. Each segment is an object that can be damaged and breached. It has an AC of 15, and 100 hit points. You describe how the wall is created, and its appearance, but its statistics remain the same no matter its form. The wall lasts until its segments are destroyed.

\r\n

Obscuring Weather. The weather within the area shifts to match the elemental plane you drew upon. Any number of 5-foot squares that you can see within the area become your choice of Heavily Obscured or Lightly Obscured. This weather condition persists for 6d10 hours after this spell ends, until you take this action again, or until it is dispersed by a strong wind.

\r\n

Deadly Environment. Each creature within the area must make a Dexterity saving throw or Constitution saving throw (your choice), or take 1d4 damage, choosing from acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, poison, bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage (your choice) as the elements assault it. You must choose the same options for every creature.

\r\n

Difficult Terrain. The area becomes difficult terrain until the start of your next turn. You can choose to affect either the air, the land, bodies of water, or any combination of them. If you take this action for 5 rounds, the changes last until dispelled.

\r\n

Spikes. Up to twelve spikes burst from points you can see within the area, oriented however you like. Each spike is made of the element of your choice, and is 5 feet in diameter and up to 20 feet long. You can choose to force any creature in an area where the spikes appeared to make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 2d10 damage, choosing from acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder, poison, bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage (your choice) on a failure. Regardless of whether you force a saving throw, any creature in the way of the spikes is pushed to one end, or to the side (their choice). A creature is always pushed to the end if they fail their saving throw. The spikes vanish at the end of your turn.

\r\n

This spell can't overlap with the area of any spells or abilities, such as Mordenkainen's Private Sanctum, that prevent planar travel. This spell simply has no effect in the overlapping area.

","sourceId":null},{"id":369209,"label":"Absorb Object","description":"

You cause a small object of up to a pound in weight to sink harmlessly into the flesh of the target. Magical rings, amulets, or other items melded in this way still give their benefits to the wearer as if they were being worn. A slight warping of the flesh and a magical aura are the only clues to the item’s existence. Items carried in this way are considered attuned to the recipient and count toward the limit of how many items can be attuned. If the creature is already at the limit, the spell fails to take effect.

\r\n

If absorb object is dispelled or otherwise ends early, the object tears itself free of its recipient, doing 2d8 piercing damage in the process. The original spell-caster can end the spell as an action, causing the item to be expelled harmlessly.

","sourceId":null},{"id":369557,"label":"True Locate Creature","description":"

This ritual was created to truly locate a creature, regardless of distance or magical barriers. To locate a specific creature, you must have seen this creature up close within 30 feet, at least once. Pour the six different blood types that are not the targets on each point of the hexagram. Pour the blood of the targets race that you wish to locate into the center while stating their name and picturing their image. 

\r\n

You sense the direction to the creature's location, as well knowing if they are on another plane. If the creature is moving, you know the direction of its movement. For the spell duration, if you touch the rune, you will suffer the conditions blinded and deafened but you will be able to see and hear what your target can. While in this state you cast the spell message to this target while negating the range limitation.

\r\n

If you do not know the name or image of your target, you will locate the nearest creature of the specific blood type poured in the center (such as the nearest Elk or Boar if the beast blood poured was from an Elk or a Boar).

\r\n

If the creature you described or named is in a different form, such as being under the effects of a polymorph or polymorph spell, you can see through this disguise and see their true form.

","sourceId":null},{"id":370215,"label":"Burrow","description":"

You become magically attuned to the earth and ground around you, enabling you to traverse it like a fish in water. Until the spell ends, you have tremorsense that extends out to 60 feet around you, you gain a burrowing speed of 60 feet, and you can hold your breath for 10 times the normal limit.

\r\n

While burrowing using this spell, you can use an action on your turn to make a melee spell attack against another creature that is above the ground within 5 feet of you.
On a hit, if the target doesn't have a burrowing speed, you pull the target's legs (or similar appendages) beneath the ground, causing them to become grappled (escape DC equal to your spell saving throw DC) and restrained while grappled, though it is not a magical effect, and they are grappled by the earth, not a creature or spell.

\r\n

If this spell ends while you are still underground and you lack a burrowing speed, you become trapped underground until you are excavated or you manage some way out on your own. The effects are as if you had a living burial spell cast on you to completion.

","sourceId":null},{"id":372699,"label":"Milo's Private Tome","description":"

You touch a spellbook and the container you use as a material component, which must be big enough to hold the spellbook. As you cast this spell, you create a pocket dimension connected to both. The spellbook you touch then becomes your private tome.

\r\n

At any time thereafter, you can use your action to touch and temporarily dismiss your private tome into it's pocket dimension. As an action while it is temporarily dismissed, you can cause it to reappear in an unoccupied space you choose within 10 feet of you.

\r\n

If the private tome is destroyed, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. It reappears after you cast this spell again, although any additions made to the private tome's contents since it was last dismissed are lost.

\r\n

If you die while the book is dismissed, it appears within the container you used to cast the spell and the spell ends.

\r\n

A container can't be used for more than one instance of this spell at a time. If the container is destroyed or Dispel magic or a similar effect is successfully applied to it, this spell's effects end and the spellbook appears in the nearest unoccupied space next to you.

\r\n

You can't have more than one private tome at a time. If you cast this spell on another spellbook while you already have a private tome, you instead replace your private tome for the new spellbook. Your previous tome falls to the ground next to you if it was dismissed when you replaced it.

","sourceId":null},{"id":383120,"label":"Permanency","description":"

This spell makes the duration of certain other spells permanent. You first cast the desired spell and then follow it with the permanency spell. Permanent spells cannot be dispelled.

\r\n

Depending on the spell, you must be of a minimum caster level and must expend a 2000 gp value of diamond dust per spell level (1000 for cantrips) being made permanent as a material component.

\r\n

Available spells for permanency are as follows.

\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
