6-9Frost Giant, Tyrannosaurus Rex, or Treant
10-13Adult White Dragon, Guardian Naga, or Storm Giant
14-17Dragon Turtle, Iron Golem, or Adult Black Dragon
18+Ancient Blue Dragon, Ancient Green Dragon, or Ancient Red Dragon
","sourceId":null},{"id":525386,"label":"Power Word Sleep","description":"

You utter a word of power that can compel one creature you can see within range to instantly fall asleep for the duration of the spell. If the creature you chose has 150 hit points or fewer, it falls asleep. Otherwise, the spell has no effect. Undead and creatures immune to being charmed aren’t affected by this spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":555952,"label":"Arrest","description":"

You attempt to magically subdue a humanoid creature. The creature must be incapacitated or unconscious for this spell to work. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be bound by the spell; if it succeeds, it is immune to this spell for 24 hours. While affected by this spell, symbols spread out across the creature, wrapping around its body and binding it as if wrapped in chains, restraining the creature. The creature is unable to cast spells while bound this way.

\r\n

You can end this spell at any time before its duration ends.

","sourceId":null},{"id":556578,"label":"Ender's Chest","description":"

You conjure a small dark wooden chest that has a large eye where the clasp would be. The chest is roughly 2 feet in diameter at the mouth and 4 feet deep. The chest can hold up to 500 pounds, not exceeding a volume of 64 cubic feet. Items placed in the chest are stored in a pocket dimension. There is no air within the chest so creatures who need oxygen to survive cannot enter the chest.

\r\n

The chest can be used to store items that are too large or heavy to be carried. if someone else opens the chest and places items in it their items are unique to them and can not be accessed by another person. When a person dies the items they have placed in the chest are scattered to the astral plane. 

\r\n

Once the chest is sent away it remains on another plane until it is re-summoned and its contents remains in tact. It requires an action to remove an item from the chest.

","sourceId":null},{"id":565222,"label":"Absolute Polymorph","description":"

Choose one creature that you can see within range. You transform the creature into a different creature. The spell lasts until it is dispelled.

\r\n

This spell has no effect on a shapechanger or a creature with 0 hit points. An unwilling creature can make a Wisdom saving throw, and if it succeeds, it isn't affected by this spell.

\r\n

You turn a creature into another kind of creature , the new form can be any kind you choose whose challenge rating is equal to or less than the target's plus the casters spell modifier (or its level, if the target doesn't have a challenge rating). The target's game statistics, excluding mental ability scores, are replaced by the statistics of the new form. It retains its alignment and personality.

\r\n

The target assumes the hit points of its new form, and when it reverts to its normal form, the creature returns to the number of hit points it had before it transformed.

\r\n

The creature is limited in the actions it can perform by the nature of its new form, and it can't speak, cast spells, or take any other action that requires hands or speech, unless its new form is capable of such actions.

\r\n

The target's gear melds into the new form. The creature can't activate, use, wield, or otherwise benefit from any of its equipment.

\r\n

If the spell becomes permanent, you no longer control the creature. It might remain friendly to you, depending on how you have treated it.

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":570135,"label":"Create Wizard's Tower","description":"

You conjure an physical and extradimensional dwelling in range. You choose where its one entrance is located. The outside appearance and entrance takes a form and size of your choosing.

\r\n

Beyond the door is a magnificent foyer with numerous chambers and floors beyond. The atmosphere is clean, fresh, and warm.

\r\n

You can create any floor plan you like of any length, width, and height with any amount of rooms. The place is furnished and decorated as you choose including work benches and ingredients. It contains sufficient food to serve a nine-course banquet for up to 100 people. A staff of 100 near-transparent servants attends all who enter. You decide the visual appearance of these servants and their attire. They are completely obedient to your orders. Each servant can perform any task a normal human servant could perform, but they can't attack or take any action that would directly harm another creature. Thus the servants can fetch things, clean, mend, fold clothes, light fires, serve food, pour wine, and so on. The servants can go anywhere in the tower, mansion, etx, but can't leave it. Furnishings and other objects created by this spell retain their form.

\r\n

This spell can recast at any time to teleport this abode with its previous appearance and layout to a new location and will adjust to the surroundings if needed.

","sourceId":null},{"id":582837,"label":"Create Flesh Golem","description":"

You begin the rigorous process of creating a flesh golem. You filter your magic throughout a period of 60 days without interruption and keeping a manual of flesh golems in hand. If you require sleep, you must do so for no longer than 8 hours. As you are casting this spell, you do not gain the benefits of a short or long rest nor gain any penalties for any lack of sleep. You also use this time to gather materials to construct your golem.

\r\n

Once the duration period has finished, the book in your hand is consumed in eldritch flames, and your 5th level spell slot is finally expended. Within 1 hour of your golem's creation, you must follow up with casting another spell of 5th level (such as animate objects, awaken, geas, hold monster, planar binding, raise dead, or telepathic bond) targeted at the golem, using the ashes of the manual as the material component. Failing to do so causes you to receive 6d6 psychic damage, and the golem will become permanently hostile to you the moment it becomes animated.

\r\n

Should you succeed, the golem will be under your control, and it will understand and obey your spoken commands until it either dies or is destroyed.

","sourceId":null},{"id":584670,"label":"Fiendform","description":"

This spell transforms the caster into a fiendish form. 

\r\n

The transformation lasts for the duration, or until the target drops to 0 hit points or dies. The new form can be any fiend whose challenge rating is equal to or less than the caster's (or the caster's level, if it doesn't have a challenge rating). The target's game statistics, including mental ability scores, are replaced by the statistics of the chosen beast. Upon transformation, the caster must make a Charisma saving throw with a DC equal to the 8 + the fiend's challenge rating. On a failed save, the caster's alignment changes to that fiend's alignment for the duration of the spell.

\r\n

The target assumes the hit points of its new form. When it reverts to its normal form, the creature returns to the number of hit points it had before it transformed. If it reverts as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to its normal form. As long as the excess damage doesn't reduce the creature's normal form to 0 hit points, it isn't knocked unconscious.

\r\n

While in this form, the caster is the fiend type and has all abilities, resistances, and immunities of the fiend, but cannot cast spells that would be available to the fiend. 

\r\n

The target's gear melds into the new form. The creature can't activate, use, wield, or otherwise benefit from any of its equipment.

","sourceId":null},{"id":584897,"label":"Arresting Sphere","description":"

You slow the flow of time to a crawl within a sphere. Target a point you can see within range. All objects and creatures within a 30 foot radius sphere, weighing up to 3000 pounds, are suspended in time. Any unwilling creatures must make a Strength saving throw. If they succeed, they can continue to move as normal, but cannot interact with the objects contained within the sphere. On a failed save, they are suspended in time and cannot be targeted by any attacks or damaging effects that would violate the continuity of their frozen time. For the duration, or until dispelled, any additional objects that enter the sphere are also suspended, up to the weight limit. In addition, any creatures that enter the spell must also make the Strength saving throw. Once the spell ends, all objects resume movement as normal, and their momentum is conserved from when they entered the sphere. 

\r\n

Any objects that go over the weight capacity of the sphere are unaffected and fall or move as normal. 

\r\n

At Higher Levels: When cast at a spell level of 6th level or above, the amount of weight that the sphere can contain increases by 500 pounds per spell level

","sourceId":null},{"id":585737,"label":"Salem's Crawling Abode","description":"

You conjure a one-story mobile building made of stone, wood, or similar suitably sturdy materials. Each level of the building is 10 feet tall and has an area of up to 120 square feet. Each level is divided into four rooms, and each can have one of the following forms, chosen by you when you cast the spell:

\r\n

• A bedroom with beds, chairs, chest, and magical fireplace
• A study with desks, books, bookshelves, parchments, ink, and ink pens
• A dining space with a table, chairs, cauldron, magical fireplace, containers, and cooking utensils
• A lounge with couches, armchairs, side tables and footstools
• A washroom with toilets, washtubs, a magical brazier, and sauna benches.
• A morgue, magically cooled and separated from the others
• An observatory with a telescope and maps of the night sky

\r\n

Any given room can instead be something else, at the discretion of the DM. The interior of the building is warm and dry, regardless of conditions outside. Any equipment or furnishings conjured with the building dissipate into smoke if removed from it. At the end of the spell’s duration, all creatures and objects within the building that were not created by the spell appear safely outside on the ground, and all traces of the building and its furnishings disappear.

\r\n

The spire is a construct with a movement speed of 20 feet, as it has a form of locomotion (such as legs or wheels), the appearance decided by the caster. The building has HP equal to 10 times your spell save DC and is immune to psychic and poison damage, as well as being Blinded, Charmed, Deafened, Exhausted, Frightened, Paralyzed, Petrified, Poisoned, or Prone. The abode can become stationary, causing the form of locomotion to disappear, embedding itself into the ground. To deploy the movement mechanism takes 1 minute. There is one front entrance with a simple locked door. The caster and any chosen creature can open the door, but it can also be picked, its difficulty equal to your spellcasting DC. The spire cannot attack, take actions or reactions, and can only move if the caster is inside. It has a 10 in every ability score apart from Strength and Dexterity, which are both 18.

\r\n

You can cast this spell again while it is active to maintain the spire's existence for another 24 hours. You can create a permanent spire by casting this spell in the same location and with the same configuration every day for one year.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the building can have one additional story for each slot level beyond 5th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":586191,"label":"Zone of Altered Time","description":"

You create a transparent magical zone where time flows differently in a 50-foot cube centered on a point of your choice within range. No material, spell or effect can pass into or out of the zone unless it travels through another plane of existence to do so (such as by using the misty step, etherealness, or dimension door spells). Choose one of the following effects for the zone.

\r\n

Dilated Time. Time passes slower inside the zone, so that any creatures inside it experience 10 minutes for every hour that passes outside.

\r\n

Hyperbolic Time. Time passes faster inside the zone, so that any creatures inside it experience 24 hours for every hour that passes outside.

","sourceId":null},{"id":588495,"label":"Summon Fiends","description":"

You utter foul words, summoning fiends from the lower planes. Roll on the following table to determine what appears.

\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
d6Demons Summoned
1–2Two fiends of challenge rating 3 or lower
3–4Four fiends of challenge rating 2 or lower
5–6Eight fiends of challenge rating 1 or lower
\r\n
\r\n

The DM chooses the demons, such as hell hound, spined devil or imp, and you choose the unoccupied spaces you can see within range where they appear. A summoned fiend disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The fiends are hostile to all creatures, including you. Roll initiative for the summoned fiends as a group, which has its own turns. The fiends pursue and attack the nearest non-demons to the best of their ability.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th or 8th level, you summon twice as many demons.

","sourceId":null},{"id":591615,"label":"Create Major Helm","description":"

By casting this spell, the spellcaster can transform a normal chair or seat into a major spelljammer helm suitable for powering a ship through space. This does not replace the need for a permanent magical helm on board, and is used primarily in emergency situations.

\r\n

The major helm can power a ship up to 100 tons. In operation a major helm is identical to regular, permanent spelljamming helm, with one exception. If a helm created by this spell is successfully dispelled, it will disappear and must be created anew.

\r\n

A ship powered by this spell travels at a speed based on the type of ship (using the ship's stat block) within the phlogiston, a crystal sphere, or in the sky or ocean of a planet and 100 million miles per day when at spelljamming speed while in the phlogiston.

\r\n

This spell's duration increases by an additional 7 days when you reach 11th level, and 17th level.

","sourceId":null},{"id":594197,"label":"Gilderoy's Private Pathway","description":"

As you cast the spell, you draw a 10 foot by 10 foot doorway onto a solid surface inscribed with sigils that link your location to another within 100 miles of you that you are familiar with. Upon completing the spell, a magical portal of pure darkness appears within the doorway and on another solid surface at the target location, linking the two until the spell ends.

\r\n

Any creature that enters the portal from one side appears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the opposite doorway. If no unoccupied spaces exist within 5 feet of the exit portal, creatures are barred from entering the passageway until at least one such space becomes available. 

\r\n

After successfully completing the spell, you create a command word that, when uttered within 30 feet of either portal, can hide or reveal the its entrances at both ends with an illusion you decide. This illusion must reasonably be able to fit in a 10 foot cube, and completely obscures both doorways. Creatures can attempt to discern the true nature of the illusion with an Intelligence (Investigation) check made against your spell save DC.

","sourceId":null},{"id":614272,"label":"Greater Create Food and Water","description":"

You conjure 90 pounds of food and 60 gallons of water contained in magic containers and cups, enough to sustain up to thirty humanoids or ten steeds for 24 hours. It summons common food such as cheese and bacon. The food and water disappear after 24 hours.

","sourceId":null},{"id":626280,"label":"Ethereal Palace","description":"

You conjure an ethereal palace in range that lasts for the duration. You choose where it is located. The palace shimmers and glows faintly with an ethereal light. The palace can be placed anywhere within range, including intersecting with solid objects. The palace itself is not solid, instead appearing to be made of a thick mist upon close inspection. However, the windows and doors, of which there must be at least one, may be passed through by creatures from the material plane as though they where the windows and doors of an normal structure.

\r\n

The inside of the palace is a demiplane which can only be accessed by the palaces' doors and windows. The interior of the palace is warm, dry, and softly lit by glowing magical orbs or floating candles. It is furnished to accommodate the caster and their companions. The caster can arrange the palace to have furnishings and a floor-plan of their choosing, including up to 100 rooms totalling no more than 250,000 sqft (or 10,000 5x5ft squares) and ceilings no higher than 50 ft. The appearance of the palace does not have to correspond to the floor plan; for example, the caster could create a palace with a totally flat floor plan, but choose to have the ethereal palace appear as a skinny tower to the exterior observer.

\r\n

The palace may be furnished with all manner of tools and facilities required by the caster, such as a forge, a brewery, an apothecary, ect. in order to preform any artisinal downtime activity or for the creation of any item or magic item. Such facilities are also staffed with servants able to assist in such activities.

\r\n

The palace has at least one exit onto an open \"exterior\" space that is also part of the demiplane. If not specified, this space can be taken to be gentle, grassy hills with the occasional tree. This space can only be composed of natural features, such as trees, beaches, caves, ect., and it is about 4 sq Km in size, with a misty barrier of force around its edges.

\r\n

The palace is staffed with servants of the casters' choosing. They can be fey, fiends, constructs, elementals, or humanoids. Regardless of the type or servants chosen, they are artificial life forms bound to the demiplane of the palace and cannot leave it of their own will. They do not age or grow weary while on the demiplane, and if they are brought to another plane of existence, they take 1d12 necrotic damage for each minute they spend outside the palace's demiplane. There are between 50 and 200 servants present in the palace at any one time, depending on the size and needs of the palace. Each servant can perform any task a normal human servant could perform, but they can't attack or take any action that would directly harm another creature. Thus the servants can fetch things, clean, mend, fold clothes, light fires, serve food, pour wine, and so on.

\r\n

The palace is defended from intruders by 10 guards who have the same appearance as the servants, but use the stat block of the \"guard\" (MM pg 347) and two leaders who use the stat block of the \"knight\" (MM 347). These defenders can be instructed to attack any creature who is not the caster, any creature who is not a creature specified by the caster, or any creature who cannot produce a pass-word defined by the caster. However, by default they will only defend themselves, other servants, and the spellcaster from attack.

\r\n

The caster can also choose to place traps around the palace or fake doors and windows on the outside of the palace that lead trap rooms. Traps can be defined by the spellcaster but they should have a DC investigation check to find and a DC dexterity or arcana check to disarm equal to the spellcasters' spell save DC. a trap should also have a base damage of 5d10 damage of the given damage type.

\r\n

Creatures who rest in the palace for one week regain all of their hit points, even if they are suffering from a condition that would normally prevent them from regaining these hit points. The effects of curses, poisons, and diseases are suppressed while a creature remains in the palace after this amount of time as well. Creatures do not age while they reside in the palace, and the palace is always able to provide food, clothing, and other necessities to its residents, up to 100 residents. The palace is also able to provide its residents with mundane items that they require, such as ammunition, so long as the total value of items acquired this way does not exceed 500 gold.

\r\n

Once the duration has ended, the demiplane doe not cease to exist, but the ethereal palace does disappear. Any items or creatures in the palace remain there until they leave. The servants stop regarding the caster as the master of the palace, although they continue to follow the last orders they where given and serve any creatures inside the palace. The caster can no longer change the appearance, layout, or location of the palace until they cast the spell again. Any creature who attempts to leave the palace while the ethereal palace is no longer present in the plane it was conjured on previously will be placed in the nearest available free space to the palace's previous location, although there is a 5% chance (1 on a d20) that they are teleported to a random plane of existence instead.

\r\n

The only way for the caster, or any other creature, to re-enter the ethereal palace after it has disappeared, is to use the same silver key that was originally used to create the palace. The servants and guards will obey the instructions of a creature who holds the palaces' key, and a creature with they key can make a DC 20 (or the casters' spell save DC, whichever is higher) arcana check to find and open the portal to the palace if they are in the last location that it was summoned to. If a caster uses the same key to cast this spell a second time, they will summon the same ethereal palace, complete with any creatures or items that remain inside.  If it has been more than 30 days since the last time the caster summoned the palace, there is a 5% chance that the spell fails to summon the same palace, and instead creates a new one. In this case, the original demiplane can only be linked back to the key by the use of a wish spell or similar magic.

","sourceId":null},{"id":630041,"label":"Gravity Sinkhole (Homebrew)","description":"

A 20-foot-radius sphere of crushing force forms at a point you can see within range and tugs at the creatures there. Each creature in the sphere must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 5d10 force damage and is pulled in a straight line toward the center of the sphere, ending in an unoccupied space as close to the center as possible (even if that space is in the air). On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn’t pulled.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d10 for each slot level above 4th.

","sourceId":null},{"id":630049,"label":"Temporal Shunt (Homebrew)","description":"

You target the triggering creature, which must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or vanish, being thrown to another point in time and causing the attack to miss or the spell to be wasted. At the start of its next turn, the target reappears where it was or in the closest unoccupied space. The target doesn’t remember you casting the spell or being affected by it.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 5th. All targets must be within 30 feet of each other.

","sourceId":null},{"id":630057,"label":"Tether Essence (Homebrew)","description":"

Two creatures you can see within range must make a Constitution saving throw, with disadvantage if they are within 30 feet of each other. Either creature can willingly fail the save. If either save succeeds, the spell has no effect. If both saves fail, the creatures are magically linked for the duration, regardless of the distance between them. When damage is dealt to one of them, the same damage is dealt to the other one. If hit points are restored to one of them, the same number of hit points are restored to the other one. If either of the tethered creatures is reduced to 0 hit points, the spell ends on both. If the spell ends on one creature, it ends on both.

","sourceId":null},{"id":630060,"label":"Dark Star (Homebrew)","description":"

This spell creates a sphere centered on a point you choose within range. The sphere can have a radius of up to 40 feet. The area within this sphere is filled with magical darkness and crushing gravitational force.

\r\n

For the duration, the spell’s area is difficult terrain. A creature with darkvision can’t see through the magical darkness, and nonmagical light can’t illuminate it. No sound can be created within or pass through the area. Any creature or object entirely inside the sphere is immune to thunder damage, and creatures are deafened while entirely inside it. Casting a spell that includes a verbal component is impossible there.

\r\n

Any creature that enters the spell’s area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a Constitution saving throw. The creature takes 8d10 force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature reduced to 0 hit points by this damage is disintegrated. A disintegrated creature and everything it is wearing and carrying, except magic items, are reduced to a pile of fine gray dust.

","sourceId":null},{"id":630063,"label":"Reality Break (Homebrew)","description":"

You shatter the barriers between realities and timelines, thrusting a creature into turmoil and madness. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw, or it can’t take reactions until the spell ends. The affected target must also roll a d10 at the start of each of its turns; the number rolled determines what happens to the target, as shown on the Reality Break Effects table.

\r\n

At the end of each of its turns, the affected target can repeat the Wisdom saving throw, ending the spell on itself on a success.

\r\n

Reality Break Effects

\r\n
\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
D10Effect
1-2Vision of the Far Realm. The target takes 6d12 psychic damage, and it is stunned until the end of the turn.
3-5Rending Rift. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 8d12 force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
6-8Wormhole. The target is teleported, along with everything it is wearing and carrying, up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space of your choice that you can see. The target also takes 10d12 force damage and is knocked prone.
9-10Chill of the Dark Void. The target takes 10d12 cold damage, and it is blinded until the end of the turn.
\r\n
","sourceId":null},{"id":630066,"label":"Ravenous Void (Homebrew)","description":"

You create a 20-foot-radius sphere of destructive gravitational force centered on a point you can see within range. For the spell’s duration, the sphere and any space within 100 feet of it are difficult terrain, and nonmagical objects fully inside the sphere are destroyed if they aren’t being worn or carried.

\r\n

When the sphere appears and at the start of each of your turns until the spell ends, unsecured objects within 100 feet of the sphere are pulled toward the sphere’s center, ending in an unoccupied space as close to the center as possible.

\r\n

A creature that starts its turn within 100 feet of the sphere must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pulled straight toward the sphere’s center, ending in an unoccupied space as close to the center as possible. A creature that enters the sphere for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there takes 5d10 force damage and is restrained until it is no longer in the sphere. If the sphere is in the air, the restrained creature hovers inside the sphere. A creature can use its action to make a Strength check against your spell save DC, ending this restrained condition on itself or another creature in the sphere that it can reach. A creature reduced to 0 hit points by this spell is annihilated, along with any nonmagical items it is wearing or carrying.

","sourceId":null},{"id":630071,"label":"Time Ravage (Homebrew)","description":"

You target a creature you can see within range, putting its physical form through the devastation of rapid aging. The target must make a Constitution saving throw, taking 10d12 necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the save fails, the target also ages to the point where it has only 30 days left before it dies of old age. In this aged state, the target has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws, and its walking speed is halved. Only the wish spell or the greater restoration cast with a 9th-level spell slot can end these effects and restore the target to its previous age.

","sourceId":null},{"id":634714,"label":"Ancestral Advice","description":"

You contact the spirits of your ancestors in order to draw on their experiences and ask their advice. You cannot choose which ancestor you will come into contact with and that ancestor does not necessarily know the answer to your questions. The ancestor may be as stubborn or as helpful as they would have been in life and though they must answer truthfully to the best of their knowledge, they can choose to be cryptic if it suits them. When the caster is satisfied the ancestor returns to their rest.

","sourceId":null},{"id":635599,"label":"Find Location","description":"

The recipient of this spell can find the shortest, most direct physical route to a specified destination, be it the way into or out of a locale. The locale can be outdoors, underground, or even inside. Find Location works with respect to locations, not objects or creatures at a locale. The location must be on the same plane as you are at the time of casting.

\r\n

The spell enables the subject to sense the correct direction that will eventually lead it to its destination, indicating at appropriate times the exact path to follow and barriers from reaching your destination, such as mechanical or arcane traps. This spell does not tell you how to disarm the trap but will let you know its nature. For example, if it is a pit trap or the spell inside a glyph of warding; the DM has discretion to give advantage on disarming the trap. The spell ends when the destination is reached or the duration expires, whichever comes first. Find Location can be used to remove the subject from the effect of a maze spell in a single round.

\r\n

This divination is keyed to the creature affected by the spell, not its companions, and its effect does not predict or allow for the actions of creatures (including guardians). The recall point must be either a designated sanctuary from the spell word of recall, known permanent teleportation circle, or similar.

\r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n \r\n
FamiliarityWrong DirectionGeneral AreaSimilar LocationOn
Target
Recall Point———01-100
Associated object———01-100
Very familiar01-0506-1314-2425-100
Seen casually01-3334-4344-5354-100
Viewed once01-4344-5354-7374-100
Description01-4344-5354-7374-100
False destination01-5051-100——
\r\n

 

\r\n

On Target: You are led to where you want to go.

General Area: You are led in a random distance away from the location in a random direction. The DM determines the direction off target randomly by rolling a d8 and designating 1 as north, 2 as north-east, 3 as east, and so on around the points of the compass. Distance off target is 1d10 + 1 miles from your destination

Similar Location: You are led to a different area that's visually or thematically similar to the target area. If you are heading for your home temple, for example, you might wind up in another god's temple or your god's temple in another location. Generally, you are led to the closest similar place, but since the spell has no range limit, you could conceivably wind up being led anywhere.

Wrong Direction: The spell's unpredictable magic results in you being led in a completely wrong direction. Alternatively, the DM can send you to a completely wrong location. For example, if you were trying to get to a port city you may be led to a small orc village in the mountains or the lair of an aboleth.

\r\n

(Basically what find the path should have been based on older versions of the spell and 5e rules, in my opinion.)

","sourceId":null},{"id":640876,"label":"Sovereign's Security","description":"

You touch a doorway that leads to an enclosed room throughout the casting of this spell. If the doorway already has a door, this spell will replace it.
The entire room is sent to a demiplane, accessible by the doorway the spell was cast through. In its place is just empty space, only the doorway now remains.

\r\n

In the doorway is now a door with an appearance you may choose. The door must have a single keyway. The key can appear to be any shape you want it to be, but only keys you create will work. Nothing besides the appropriate key can even pass into the keyhole.

\r\n

When you first cast this spell, you get a single key that cannot be removed without dispelling the entire spell.
For each key you wish to create, you must spend one minute and one level five spell slot. The keys can look however you wish, and needn't to match each other. You can end the existence of any given key at any moment.
If you hold a key made by this spell and you know this spell yourself, you can spend one long rest and one level five spell slot to duplicate the key you have.

\r\n

To open the door, simply insert a key and the door will fade away. The door re-appears to block passage once whoever inserted the key wants it to close (Or the original spellcaster).
When the door is open, the doorway and room behind it appears no different than as it was before the spell was cast. A clean link to the demiplane holding the room. It is considered a different plane however, when the threshold of the doorway is crossed.

\r\n

For each day the caster spends re-casting this spell, the spell's effective level for the purposes of \"Dispel Magic\" raises by +1.
If the spell is re-cast repeatedly for a full year, it is considered permanent, and nobody besides the original caster may remove the effect without a Wish spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":643711,"label":"Rokku's Sapphire Shackles","description":"

When casting this spell, azure chains, the size of which varies depending on the size of the target, coil around a selected creature, attempting to ensare them and bind them to an unbreakable prision which whispers into their ear to break their will. The target must be inside the spell's range for the entire casting or the spell slot is wasted. Any creature affected by this spell must make a Wisdom saving throw to avoid capture. If a creature fails the saving throw, they are subject to the Shackled effect. They can repeat the saving throw every 5 days and break out on a success. 

\r\n

Shackled: The creature affected is considered Restrained. They also cannot be broken out of the magical manacles, as any attempt to damage them deals 8d6 lightning damage to the assailant, while any casting of a spell which might set the prisoner free, such as teleportation or shape-changing spells like Plane Shift, Dimension Door, Polymorph, Enlarge/Reduce or Gaseous Form deals 10d8 necrotic damage to the caster. However, if the prisoner themselves is the caster of said spells or the one attacking the shackles and the feedback effect would have killed them, they are left at 1 Hit Point from death instead. Any creature who has been Shackled for over a month also becomes Delusional. 

\r\n

Delusional: As isolation creeps its way into a target's mind and all hope of rescue leaves them, their spirit shatters completely. From the moment they reach this state on, they have disadvantage on the Wisdom saving throw to escape the spell. Additionally, the aforementioned saving throw can only be repeated once each month. If they do manage to pass the save, they must also pass a Charisma saving throw or be left believeing that after so long, escape could not be real and that the whole situation is product of their imagination. On another success, the creature is free, but still suffers the mental consequences of the experience. If they fail the secondary Charisma save, they are chained once again and maintain their Delusional and Shackled status. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":645829,"label":"Colossification","description":"

You touch a willing creature, of size Tiny or Small, and gently whisper words of ancient power to it. The creature grows to incredible proportions, gaining the following benefits for the duration of the spell:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • The creature's size becomes Gargantuan. If it is in a space not large for this size change, the creature makes a Strength check, using the colossifcation Strength score, to break through the surrounding material. (DM determines DC based on characteristics of the space) The creature otherwise attains the maximum possible size in the space available.
    • \r\n
  • The creature gains an additional 20 feet in height.
    • \r\n
  • The creature's Strength and Constitution Scores increase to 26.
    • \r\n
  • The creature's hit point maximum increases by 200.
    • \r\n
  • The creature can take an additional Attack action on each of its turns.
    • \r\n
  • The creature gains an unarmed strike attack that deals 34 (4d12 +8) bludgeoning damage.
    • \r\n
  • The creature ignores difficult terrain when taking a movement.
    • \r\n
","sourceId":null},{"id":651076,"label":"Widowgast's Amber Vault","description":"

You arrange the amber spell components in a loose circle around any non-living materials and complete the circle around them with runes and sigils.  Upon completion of the spell all the materials within the circle are drawn into the largest gem and stored there in stasis.  Materials stored in this way do not age, weather, or decompose.  Up to 500 lbs of material can be stored in a single gem in this manner.

\r\n

As an action the caster can speak a single word chosen when the spell is cast and release the gem's contents onto the ground in front of them.  The contents are also released if a dispel magic targeting the amber is successful.

","sourceId":null},{"id":655610,"label":"Dimensional Schackles","description":"

An abundance of heavy and glowing chains springs from your outstretched hand at a creature or object you can see within range and envelops it until it is engulfed. The chains starts to sink in to the flesh or material of the target until the only thing you see are a few that attaches to the ground. Any creature or object engulfed by the chains is covered with a shimmering emerald field that completely blocks extradimensional travel. The chains automatically hits objects that are not being worn or carried. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or it is unable to be affected by teleportation spells (such as dimension door, teleport, plane shift, etherealness, blink,astral projection etc) and cannot be percieved or located by Divination spells for the spell’s duration. It also becomes restrained. It may try to succeed on it's saving throw at the end of it's every turn.

\r\n

Dimensional schackles does not interfere with the movement of creatures already in ethereal or astral form when the spell is cast, nor does it block the ability to see into other planes of existence or affect them. Also, dimensional schackles does not prevent summoned creatures from disappearing at the end of a summoning spell.

\r\n

Furthermore you may cast it as a Reaction at the moment a target is killed and upon the effects described above it also hinders creatures whose bodies returns to their homeplane. Cast this way there is no saving throw.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a 5th level spell slot, the duration increases to 10 minutes. When you cast this spell using a 6th level spell slot, the duration increases to 1 hour. When you cast this spell using a 7th level spell slot, the duration increases to 4 hours. When you cast this spell using an 8th level spell slot, the duration increases to 8 hours. When you cast this spell using a 9th level spell slot, the duration increases to 24 hours.

","sourceId":null},{"id":656386,"label":"Create","description":"

 You create something of your choosing, however you must meet the following restrictions:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • your creation must be less than 25,000 gp in value.
    • \r\n
  • The object can be no more than 300 feet in any dimension.
    • \r\n
  • You must be able to at least give a general description of your creation.
    • \r\n
  • It must have existed at some point in time, past or future.
    • \r\n
  • This creation cannot help you ascend to godhood.
    • \r\n
\r\n

 You then create what you desire in its entirety, appearing within 10 feet of you in an unoccupied space.

","sourceId":null},{"id":656921,"label":"Primal Instinct","description":"

This spell summons forth the natural instinctive forces within you to allocate the basic impulse possessed by your ancestors. You gain a +5 bonus on Dexterity (Initiative) and Wisdom (Survival) checks.

\r\n

If primal instinct is active at the same time as primal hunter, primal senses, or primal speed, you gain danger sense (as the barbarian class feature). If all four spells are active at the same time, you gain fast movement (as the barbarian class feature).

","sourceId":null},{"id":656931,"label":"Primal Speed","description":"

This spell draws the natural reflexes of hunters and prey, granting you the ability to counter the threat as more primitive beings might. You gain a +5 bonus to Dexterity saving throws, and your speed is doubled.

\r\n

If primal speed is active at the same time as primal hunter, primal instinct, or primal senses, you gain danger sense (as the barbarian class feature). If all four spells are active at the same time, you gain fast movement (as the barbarian class feature).

","sourceId":null},{"id":662996,"label":"Conjure Monstrosity","description":"

You summon a Monstrosity creature, or creatures, of challenge rating 7 or lower (combined). It appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. The Monstrosity disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

\r\n

The Monstrosity  is friendly to you and your companions for the duration. Roll initiative for the creature, which has its own turns. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you), as long as they don't violate its alignment. If you don't issue any commands to the fey creature, it defends itself from hostile creatures but otherwise takes no actions.

\r\n

If your concentration is broken, the Monstrosity doesn't disappear. Instead, you lose control of the Monstrosity , it becomes hostile toward you and your companions, and it might attack. An uncontrolled Monstrosity can't be dismissed by you, and it disappears 1 hour after you summoned it.

\r\n

The GM has the Monstrosity's statistics. Some sample creatures are listed below.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the challenge rating increases by 1 for each slot level above 6th.

\r\n

Sample Creatures

\r\n

 

","sourceId":null},{"id":696956,"label":"Find Greater Familiar","description":"

You gain the service of a familiar, a spirit that takes an animal form you choose:ape,black bear, boar, deer, giant badger, giant crab, giant fire beetle, giant frog, giant poisonous snake, giant sea horse, giant weasel, goat, hyena, mastiff, octopus, panther, reef shark, vulture, wolf. Appearing in an unoccupied space within range, the familiar has the statistics of the chosen form, though it is a celestial, fey, or fiend (your choice) instead of a beast.

\r\n

Your familiar acts independently of you, but it always obeys your commands. In combat, it rolls its own initiative and acts on its own turn. A familiar can attack and can take other actions as normal.

\r\n

When the familiar drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. It reappears after you cast this spell again.

\r\n

While your familiar is within 500 feet of you, you can communicate with it telepathically. Additionally, as an action, you can see through your familiar's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of your next turn, gaining the benefits of any special senses that the familiar has. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses.

\r\n

As an action, you can temporarily dismiss your familiar. It disappears into a pocket dimension where it awaits your summons. Alternatively, you can dismiss it forever. As an action while it is temporarily dismissed, you can cause it to reappear in any unoccupied space within 100 feet of you.

\r\n

You can have two familiars at a time if you use creatures of the find familiar spell. If you cast this spell while you already have a greater familiar, you instead cause it to adopt a new form. Choose one of the forms from the above list. Your familiar transforms into the chosen creature. However if you have two familiars from the Find Familiar you change the form of one you choose, additionaly if you want to make a Greater Familiar the two familiars shift into the new greater one.

\r\n

Finally, when you cast a spell with a range of touch, your familiar can deliver the spell as if it had cast the spell. Your familiar must be within 175 feet of you, and it must use its reaction to deliver the spell when you cast it. If the spell requires an attack roll, you use your attack modifier for the roll.

","sourceId":null},{"id":697722,"label":"Deprivation Field","description":"

You create an invisible forcefield around a building of your choice, which allows entry only to an individual with the possession of a key to said place, and any other creatures only if the door is unlocked. Any creature trying to forcefully enter the locked building without a a key will suffer complete sensory deprivation, that will lead it to confusion and unintentional self-harming behavior, which can lead to death. This effect will stay up to d6 minutes after the creature is taken out of the range of the forcefield.

\r\n

Another key can be created by the caster, which allows more people with it's possession to accesses the building unharmed. It is very challenging yet possible to navigate through the space, even with complete sensory deprivation.

\r\n

The spell can last for years, even after the original casters death. The spell can end by destroying or taking the horn that has been used for the spell outside of the field's range or destroying it.

\r\n

\"As I entered the shack and slowly made my way inside I suddenly felt a crunch in my mouth, looking down I saw that one of my teeth was broken, and seen blood dripping down my face. I did not feel any pain, but just confusion. I felt my surroundings slowly melt away as I tried to look around, trying to discern up from down, slowly loosing my sense of place. I reached to hold my head only to not find anything. Reaching further into where my head was supposed to be, I began lost the ability to discern where my limbs are. As I kept searching I suddenly regained all of my senses back and felt intense pain... I clawed one of my eyes out and bit down on my tongue and teeth and even broke some of them. I later found out from my crew that dragged me away from that place that I didn't even made it inside but collapsed at the entrance.\" 

","sourceId":null},{"id":703614,"label":"True Polymorph Revised","description":"

Choose up to 6 creatures or nonmagical objects that you can see within range. You transform the creature into a different creature, the creature into a nonmagical object, or the object into a creature (the object can't be worn or carried by another creature if the end result is heavier than 50lbs/restrictive or damaging to the wearer or carrier). The spell lasts for the duration, and if the target hits 0hp, there is a 2 percent chance of turning back. This spell has no effect on a shapechanger or a creature with 0 hit points. An unwilling creature can make a Wisdom saving throw with disadvantage and if it succeeds, it isn't affected by this spell.The affected creature can only be reverted by a wish spell or a dispel magic of 8th level or 9th. 

\r\n

Creature into Creature. If you turn a creature into another kind of creature, the new form can be any kind you choose whose challenge rating is equal to or less than the target's (or its level, if the target doesn't have a challenge rating).

\r\n
    \r\n
  • The target's game statistics, including mental ability scores, are replaced by the statistics of the new form. You can shift either one core aspect of it's personality, or three minor aspects, and you can shift it's alignment along the spectrum of chaotic to lawful, and can hide memories from them, but not replace them. 
    • \r\n
  • You can also choose to either have the subjects frightened, charmed, or completely obey you, and if they completely obey you, each command you give to them will control their bodies, but it is up to them if they agree with your orders (eg. you can tell them to kill their parents, and they will do it, but they most likely won't want to). 
    • \r\n
  • The target assumes the hit points of its new form, and when it reverts to its normal form, the creature returns to the number of hit points it had before it transformed, and goes unconscious for 1d4-1 days. If it reverts as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to its normal form. As long as the excess damage doesn't reduce the creature's normal form to 0 hit points, it won't have to make death saves, but still goes unconscious.
    • \r\n
  • The creature is limited in the actions it can perform by the nature of its new form, and it can't speak, cast spells, or take any other action that requires hands or speech, unless its new form is capable of such actions.
    • \r\n
  • The target's gear melds into the new form. The creature can't activate, use, wield, or otherwise benefit from any of its equipment, but can take off it's equipment then put it back on.
    • \r\n
\r\n

Object into Creature. You can turn an object into any kind of creature, as long as the creature's size is no larger than the object's size and the creature's challenge rating is 9 or lower.

\r\n
    \r\n
  • The creature is friendly to you and your companions. It acts on each of your turns, but it has a mind of it's own, and is controlled by the DM.
    • \r\n
  • If the spell becomes permanent, you no longer control the creature. It might remain friendly to you, depending on how you have treated it.
    • \r\n
\r\n

Creature into Object. If you turn a creature into an object, it transforms along with whatever it is wearing and carrying into that form, as long as the object's size is no larger than the creature's size. The creature's statistics become those of the object, and the creature has no memory of time spent in this form, unless specifically stated (eg. you could turn them into a pickled jar of eyeballs, and they could see stuff and float around, but only that), after the spell ends and it returns to its normal form.

","sourceId":null},{"id":711171,"label":"Meld into Shadows","description":"

You step into shadows or darkness large enough to fully contain your body, melding yourself and all the equipment you carry with the shadow for the duration. Using your movement, you step into the shadow at a point you can touch. Nothing of your presence remains visible or otherwise detectable by non-magical senses.

\r\n

While merged with the shadow, you can see what occurs outside it, but any Wisdom (Perception) checks you make to hear sounds outside it are made with disadvantage. You remain aware of the passage of time and can cast spells on yourself while merged in the shadow. You can keep moving wherever there still is shadow, until you step out of it or are hit with a light, which ends the spell.

","sourceId":null},{"id":747568,"label":"Osmar’s Organ Summons","description":"

You attempt to extract an essential organ from a specific type of target you can see within range. If the target type matches the anatomical drawing used in the casting, the creature must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it is restrained as the organ begins to fail. On a successful save, the spell does not affect the creature and ends immediately.

\r\n

A creature restrained by this spell must make another Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If it successfully saves against this spell three times, the spell ends. If it fails saves three times, it is instantly killed as the organ appears in the hands of the caster. The successes and failures don't need to be consecutive, keep track of both until the target collects three of a kind.

\r\n

This spell has no effect on Constructs, Elementals, Oozes, Plants, and Undead creature types.

\r\n

Component note: If the drawing incorporated a piece of the target creature’s body (blood, hair, nail clippings, etc…) into the preparation, the target must attempt the Constitution saving throws at Disadvantage.

","sourceId":null},{"id":753752,"label":"Mobile Workshop","description":"

You conjure an extradimensional workshop in range that lasts for the duration. You choose where its one entrance is located. The entrance shimmers faintly and is 5 feet wide and 10 feet tall. You and any creature you designate when you cast the spell can enter the extradimensional workshop as long as the portal remains open. You can open or close the portal if you are within 30 feet of it. While closed, the portal is invisible.

\r\n

Beyond the portal is a fully functional workshop with spaces for working on a variety of craftsmanship projects. The atmosphere is clean and warm and bustling with creative energy.

\r\n

You can choose the order of the floor plan to meet your needs, but the space can't exceed 50 cubes, each cube being 10 feet on each side. The workshop is furnished and decorated as you choose. It includes space for a woodshop, a tannery, a fully functional forge and smithy, an armory, and storage space. A staff of 5 near-transparent servants attends all who enter. You decide the visual appearance of these servants and their attire. They are completely obedient to your orders. Each servant can assist with any task a normal human servant could perform, but they can't attack or take any action that would directly harm another creature. Thus the servants can fetch things, assist with projects, clean equipment, and so on, but they cannot begin or complete major crafting projects independently. Projects undertaken with assistance of all 5 servants can be completed in half the time of a normal project. The servants can go anywhere in the mansion but can't leave it. 
Tools and other objects created by this spell dissipate into smoke if removed from the workshop. When the spell ends, any creatures inside the extradimensional space are expelled into the open spaces nearest to the entrance. Items, crafting supplies, and magical objects left inside of the armory or storage areas remain contained in the extra dimensional space for safe keeping.

","sourceId":null},{"id":774265,"label":"Temporary Resurrection","description":"

The spirit of a non-undead corpse you touch returns to its body. The creature must have died within the last minute. Roll a contested Wisdom check against the creature as if it was alive. If you succeed, the creature is revived and restores all its hitpoints. It is considered Undead but retains all other features, ability scores, and proficiencies it had in life. While it is alive this way, it is considered Charmed. While charmed this way, the creature acts as it would normally, but it considers you and your allies friends. If the creature is damaged by you or one of your allies, or if the creature reaches 0 hit points, the spell ends. When the spell ends, the corpse vanishes to dust.

","sourceId":null},{"id":991485,"label":"Summon Elder Elemental","description":"

You attempt to summon forth either an elder tempest, a leviathan, a phoenix, or a zaratan, your choice. Roll a d100, adding your spellcasting modifier to it. On a roll of 100 or higher, the elemental appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. The elemental disappears when it drops to 0 hit points. If it is summoned, roll another d100 with your spellcasting modifier added. On a roll of 100 or higher, you are not killed instantly upon the summoning, otherwise you are.

\r\n

The elemental acts neutral towards you and your companions, meaning it won't harm you unless you harm it. Other than that, it acts in whatever manner it chooses until it is killed.

","sourceId":null},{"id":1052406,"label":"Greater Speak with Dead","description":"

You grant the semblance of life and intelligence to a corpse of your choice within range, allowing it to answer the questions you pose. The corpse cannot be currently undead. While you need the head to be intact, the magic of the spell allows for vocalization, and thus the musculature of the remains is not needed for this spell to succeed. The spell fails if the corpse was the target of this spell within the last 10 days.

\r\n

Until the spell ends, you can ask the corpse up to five questions. The corpse knows only what it knew in life. This greater spell transcends language and can communicate empathetically, if required or if the corpse chooses to. The corpse is compelled to offer a truthful answer and acts as if also under the spell Zone of Truth, so long as the creature did not die as a result of the player's actions. If it did, it is up to your GM's discretion if the corpse is compelled to be truthful. Regardless, the corpse is compelled to answer up to five questions. This spell doesn't return the creature's soul to its body, only its animating spirit. Thus, the corpse can't learn new information, doesn't comprehend anything that has happened since it died, and can't speculate about future events.

","sourceId":null},{"id":1102701,"label":"Mass Misremember","description":"

You attempt to erase yourself from another creatures memory. You magically influence up to twelve creatures of your choice that you can see within range. They must make a Wisdom saving throw. If you are fighting the creature, it has advantage on the saving throw. On a failed save, you can affect the target's memory of an event that it experienced within the last hour. You can permanently eliminate all memory of yourself in the event, the target's filling the void you left in its memory with another plausible explanation. 

\r\n

A remove curse or greater restoration spell cast on the target restores the creature's true memory. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":1209024,"label":"Power Word Command","description":"

You command a creature within sight, the creature must make a Wisdom saving throw or fall under the command of your voice.

\r\n

Any creature that fails the saving throw must obey the command of the caster, regardless of the command. 

\r\n

The creature is under the command of the caster, until the caster dispels the spell.

\r\n

The command can is only limited to the imagination of the caster. Examples of commands are as follows:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Tell the target to harm/kill itself, others (regardless of relation), or any variation.
    • \r\n
  • Tell the target to serve you for the rest of its life.
    • \r\n
  • Tell the target to obtain an item.
    • \r\n
  • Tell the target to go on a mission for you regardless if it is able to be completed. 
    • \r\n
  • Betray any of the creatures alliances, cults, religions, guilds, or family.
    • \r\n
\r\n

At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell at higher levels you are able to command more than one creature.

\r\n
    \r\n
  • At 8th level,  you are able to command up to 5 creatures within range of the spell.
    • \r\n
  • At 9th level, you are able to command up to 10 creatures within range of the spell. 
    • \r\n
","sourceId":null},{"id":1233031,"label":"Awaken the Dead","description":"

You call to the dead and beckon them to rise again as undead. Each corpse of a Small or Medium humanoid within range becomes animated as either a skeleton or a zombie, depending on the state of the remains (the DM has the creatures’ game statistics). The spell's effect can reach through up to six feet of total cover, but it can only animate up to 100 undead creatures. If there are too many targets, it prefers to animate the closer corpses.

\r\n

Each undead uses its action on its first turn to escape the confines of death, such as opening its coffin, digging itself out of the ground, or unwrapping itself from within its funeral pyre. When the spell ends, the undead cease to be animated and instantly return to being corpses.

\r\n

The undead created by this spell wander of their own accord, seeking to slay living creatures, especially humanoids. You have no control over these undead, but you and any creatures of your choice that you can see when the spell is cast are protected. The undead will refuse to harm a protected creature unless someone that magically controls them commands them to do so.

","sourceId":null},{"id":1500941,"label":"Restore","description":"

This spell will completely restore one non-magical object to pristine condition. This includes, but is not limited to, fixing multiple tears, replacing any missing components, rejoining any breaks, resealing any leaks, and rewriting the writing on pages in a written document. It will also restore the object to a condition as if it was brand new. This includes, but is not limited to, removing rust, fixing dents, rebinding fraying, and recoloring any staining.  

\r\n

The spell does not work on magical objects and if used on a non-magical item that used to be magical it will not restore any magical properties. 

","sourceId":null},{"id":1522511,"label":"Power Word Obey","description":"

You speak a word of power, that commands weak creatures to obey all your commands. All creatures with 50 hit points or less within 50 miles of you becomes a mindless thrall, telepathically controlled by you. As bonus action, you can command any number of your thralls to do any number of actions, make attacks, give help actions, etc. Anything one thrall knows, they all know, including you. For example, if a thrall spots an enemy creature, they all know its location and so do you. As an action you can posses and speak through a thrall of your choice.

\r\n

The thralls can't be freed by any magical means, not even a Dispel Magic but only through the use of a Wish spell. The other way to free any of the thralls, is for you to be killed outright at which point all the thralls are freed. Alternatively, you can chose to free the thralls either individually or all at once.

\r\n

To cast the spell again, you must first release all thralls from the previous casting.

","sourceId":null},{"id":1747536,"label":"Steal Soul","description":"

In this spell the caster holds up a gemstone, says a magic word, and points at the creature to be affected.  The target creature must make a Wisdom Saving Throw at disadvantage.  If the creature fails this, their body is stored in the gemstone in a magical stasis and unaffected by time.  The creature will be held within the stone until the caster decides to release it with a command word, a successful Dispel Magic is cast, the gemstone is physically destroyed, or the caster dies.  If the creature is released by command word, the creature will emerge from the stone and be subject to a one-sentence command of no more than twenty words by the caster as if by Geas cast as a 5th level spell, and the command is subject to the same requirements.

","sourceId":null},{"id":1815258,"label":"Amnesia","description":"

You twist the memories of a creature within range, causing them to forget the events of the past.

\r\n

Choose a creature you can see within range. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw, or have its memories of the events it has experienced within the last hour be erased. The target regains its memories at the end of the spell's duration. A creature immune to the Charmed has advantage on its saving throw against this spell.

\r\n

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level, the target forgets the past 24 hours it has experienced, and the spell's duration becomes \"8 hours\". When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 8th level, the target forgets the events of the past week, and the spell's duration becomes \"24 hours\". When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 9th level, the target forgets the entirety of its life up to the moment it fails its saving throw against this spell - the spell's duration subsequently becomes \"Until Dispelled\".

of the Far Realm","description":"

You can speak telepathically to any creature or a creature you can see, provided the creature is within 30 ft adding 10 feets per your level after the first to a maximum of 120 ft. You don’t need to share a language with the creature for it to understand your telepathic utterances, but the creature must be able to understand at least one language.

\r\n

When you’re using this trait to speak telepathically to a creature, you can use your action to give that creature the ability to speak telepathically with you for 30 minures or until you end this effect as an action. To use this ability, the creature must be able to see you and must be within this trait’s range. You can give this ability to only one creature at a time; giving it to a creature takes it away from another creature who has it.

\r\n

Spells with verbal components still works for you.

\r\n","snippet":"When you’re using Toch of the Far Realm to speak telepathically to a creature, you can use your action to give that creature the ability to speak telepathically with you for 1 hour or until you end this effect as an action. To use this ability, the creature must be able to see you and must be within {{30+10*characterlevel@max:120}} ft to a maximum of 120 ft.\r\nYou can give this ability to only one creature at a time; giving it to a creature takes it away from another creature who has it.","abilityModifierStatId":4,"onMissDescription":"","saveFailDescription":"","saveSuccessDescription":"","saveStatId":5,"fixedSaveDc":null,"attackTypeRange":1,"actionType":1,"attackSubtype":null,"dice":{"diceCount":2,"diceValue":4,"diceMultiplier":null,"fixedValue":null,"diceString":"2d4"},"value":null,"damageTypeId":11,"isMartialArts":false,"isProficient":false,"spellRangeType":null,"displayAsAttack":true,"range":{"range":null,"longRange":null,"aoeType":null,"aoeSize":null,"hasAoeSpecialDescription":false,"minimumRange":null},"activation":{"activationTime":null,"activationType":1},"numberOfTargets":null,"fixedToHit":null,"ammunition":null},{"componentId":4289640,"componentTypeId":1960452172,"id":"2275693","entityTypeId":"222216831","limitedUse":{"name":null,"statModifierUsesId":3,"resetType":2,"numberUsed":0,"minNumberConsumed":1,"maxNumberConsumed":1,"maxUses":3,"operator":1,"useProficiencyBonus":false,"proficiencyBonusOperator":1,"resetDice":null},"name":"Shapechanger","description":"

As an action, you can change your appearance and your voice equal to your Constitution modifier + your proficiency modifier per day minimum of 1. You determine the specifics of the changes, including your coloration, hair length, and sex. You can also adjust your height and weight, but not so much that your size changes. You can make yourself appear as a member of another race, though none of your game statistics change. You can’t duplicate the appearance of a creature you’ve never seen, and you must adopt a form that has the same basic arrangement of limbs that you have. Your clothing and equipment aren’t changed by this trait.

You stay in the new form until you use an action to revert to your true form or until you die.

","snippet":"As an action, you can change your appearance and your voice equal to your {{limiteduse}} per day. You determine the specifics of the changes, including your coloration, hair length, and sex. You can also adjust your height and weight, but not so much that your size changes. You can make yourself appear as a member of another race, though none of your game statistics change. \r\n","snippet":"","abilityModifierStatId":null,"onMissDescription":"","saveFailDescription":"","saveSuccessDescription":"","saveStatId":null,"fixedSaveDc":null,"attackTypeRange":null,"actionType":3,"attackSubtype":null,"dice":null,"value":null,"damageTypeId":null,"isMartialArts":false,"isProficient":false,"spellRangeType":null,"displayAsAttack":null,"range":{"range":30,"longRange":null,"aoeType":null,"aoeSize":null,"hasAoeSpecialDescription":false,"minimumRange":null},"activation":{"activationTime":60,"activationType":null},"numberOfTargets":null,"fixedToHit":null,"ammunition":null}],"class":[{"componentId":1131400,"componentTypeId":12168134,"id":"856513","entityTypeId":"222216831","limitedUse":{"name":null,"statModifierUsesId":4,"resetType":4,"numberUsed":0,"minNumberConsumed":1,"maxNumberConsumed":1,"maxUses":0,"operator":1,"useProficiencyBonus":false,"proficiencyBonusOperator":1,"resetDice":null},"name":"Magical Tinkering","description":"

At 1st level, you learn how to invest a spark of magic into mundane objects. To use this ability, you must have thieves’ tools or artisan’s tools in hand. You then touch a Tiny nonmagical object as an action and give it one of the following magical properties of your choice:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • The object sheds bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet.
    • \r\n
  • Whenever tapped by a creature, the object emits a recorded message that can be heard up to 10 feet away. You utter the message when you bestow this property on the object, and the recording can be no more than 6 seconds long.
    • \r\n
  • The object continuously emits your choice of an odor or a nonverbal sound (wind, waves, chirping, or the like). The chosen phenomenon is perceivable up to 10 feet away.
    • \r\n
  • A static visual effect appears on one of the object’s surfaces. This effect can be a picture, up to 25 words of text, lines and shapes, or a mixture of these elements, as you like.
    • \r\n
\r\n

The chosen property lasts indefinitely. As an action, you can touch the object and end the property early.

\r\n

You can bestow magic on multiple objects, touching one object each time you use this feature, though a single object can only bear one property at a time. The maximum number of objects you can affect with this feature at one time is equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of one object). If you try to exceed your maximum, the oldest property immediately ends, and then the new property applies.

","snippet":"Imbue a Tiny nonmagical object with a magical property of your choice: 5ft. radius light, up to 6 second long recorded message, emits odor or nonverbal sound, static visual effect including up to 25 words of text. You can affect a maximum of {{modifier:int@min:1#unsigned}} objects at a time.","abilityModifierStatId":null,"onMissDescription":"","saveFailDescription":"","saveSuccessDescription":"","saveStatId":null,"fixedSaveDc":null,"attackTypeRange":null,"actionType":3,"attackSubtype":null,"dice":null,"value":null,"damageTypeId":null,"isMartialArts":false,"isProficient":false,"spellRangeType":null,"displayAsAttack":null,"range":{"range":null,"longRange":null,"aoeType":null,"aoeSize":null,"hasAoeSpecialDescription":false,"minimumRange":null},"activation":{"activationTime":null,"activationType":1},"numberOfTargets":null,"fixedToHit":null,"ammunition":null},{"componentId":1131631,"componentTypeId":12168134,"id":"856673","entityTypeId":"222216831","limitedUse":{"name":null,"statModifierUsesId":null,"resetType":4,"numberUsed":0,"minNumberConsumed":1,"maxNumberConsumed":1,"maxUses":3,"operator":1,"useProficiencyBonus":false,"proficiencyBonusOperator":1,"resetDice":null},"name":"Infuse Item","description":"

At 2nd level, you gain the ability to imbue mundane items with certain magical infusions. The magic items you create with this feature are effectively prototypes of permanent items.

\r\n
Infusions Known
\r\n

When you gain this feature, pick four artificer infusions to learn, choosing from the “Artificer Infusions” section at the end of the class’s description. You learn additional infusions of your choice when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Infusions Known column of the Artificer table.

\r\n

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the artificer infusions you learned with a new one.

\r\n
Infusing an Item
\r\n

Whenever you finish a long rest, you can touch a non-magical object and imbue it with one of your artificer infusions, turning it into a magic item. An infusion works on only certain kinds of objects, as specified in the infusion’s description. If the item requires attunement, you can attune yourself to it the instant you infuse the item. If you decide to attune to the item later, you must do so using the normal process for attunement (see “Attunement” in chapter 7 of the Dungeon Master’s Guide).

\r\n

Your infusion remains in an item indefinitely, but when you die, the infusion vanishes after a number of days have passed equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1 day). The infusion also vanishes if you give up your knowledge of the infusion for another one.

\r\n

You can infuse more than one nonmagical object at the end of a long rest; the maximum number of objects appears in the Infused Items column of the Artificer table. You must touch each of the objects, and each of your infusions can be in only one object at a time. Moreover, no object can bear more than one of your infusions at a time. If you try to exceed your maximum number of infusions, the oldest infusion immediately ends, and then the new infusion applies.

\r\n

If an infusion ends on an item that contains other things, like a bag of holding, its contents harmlessly appear in and around its space.

","snippet":"Whenever you finish a long rest, you can touch up to {{scalevalue}} nonmagical objects, imbuing each of them with one of your artificer infusions, turning it into a magic item. ","snippet":"Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses your proficiency with a tool.","abilityModifierStatId":null,"onMissDescription":"","saveFailDescription":"","saveSuccessDescription":"","saveStatId":null,"fixedSaveDc":null,"attackTypeRange":null,"actionType":3,"attackSubtype":null,"dice":null,"value":null,"damageTypeId":null,"isMartialArts":false,"isProficient":false,"spellRangeType":null,"displayAsAttack":null,"range":{"range":null,"longRange":null,"aoeType":null,"aoeSize":null,"hasAoeSpecialDescription":false,"minimumRange":null},"activation":{"activationTime":null,"activationType":8},"numberOfTargets":null,"fixedToHit":null,"ammunition":null},{"componentId":1131786,"componentTypeId":12168134,"id":"1038632","entityTypeId":"222216831","limitedUse":null,"name":"The Right Tool for the Job","description":"

At 3rd level, you learn how to produce exactly the tool you need: with thieves’ tools or artisan’s tools in hand, you can magically create one set of artisan’s tools in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you. This creation requires 1 hour of uninterrupted work, which can coincide with a short or long rest. Though the product of magic, the tools are nonmagical, and they vanish when you use this feature again.

","snippet":"With thieves’ tools or artisan’s tools in hand, you can magically create one set of nonmagical artisan’s tools. They vanish when you use this feature again.","abilityModifierStatId":null,"onMissDescription":"","saveFailDescription":"","saveSuccessDescription":"","saveStatId":null,"fixedSaveDc":null,"attackTypeRange":null,"actionType":3,"attackSubtype":null,"dice":null,"value":null,"damageTypeId":null,"isMartialArts":false,"isProficient":false,"spellRangeType":null,"displayAsAttack":null,"range":{"range":null,"longRange":null,"aoeType":null,"aoeSize":null,"hasAoeSpecialDescription":false,"minimumRange":null},"activation":{"activationTime":1,"activationType":7},"numberOfTargets":null,"fixedToHit":null,"ammunition":null},{"componentId":2911244,"componentTypeId":12168134,"id":"2340032","entityTypeId":"222216831","limitedUse":{"name":null,"statModifierUsesId":4,"resetType":2,"numberUsed":0,"minNumberConsumed":1,"maxNumberConsumed":1,"maxUses":5,"operator":1,"useProficiencyBonus":false,"proficiencyBonusOperator":1,"resetDice":null},"name":"Subsystem Charges","description":"

While equipped with the arcane powered armor you may equip subsystems up to your Artificer level + Intelligence modifier with a minimum of one. You may install two subsystems for free when you gain this feature. When you create a new armor and you still own your current one you can transfer all subsystems for no cost.

The powered armor comes with a limited set of charges equal to your proficiency modifier + Intelligence modifier. These charges power the subsystems the powered armor can be equipped with and used, if no charges remain the user can expend spellslots to regain charges, a level 1 spell slot is 1 charge, a level 2 spell slot is 2 charges and so on. Charges can be regained after a long rest, the player rolls a 1d4 + Intelligence modifier to regain charges, this die becomes a 1d6 at level 9 and a 1d8 at level 15.

\r\n

A short rest also regains charges but then you don't add any modifier. Using a charge is done so as a free action unless noted and each subsystem in the list below uses 1 charge unless it says Passive meaning that the system is always active.

Every other level (5th, 7th, 9th... etc) you may choose to create an additional subsystem to grant yourself bonuses and abilities presumably that you have the sufficient material, at DM's discretion. Each installation takes 4 hours. Some systems that can be researched and/or is more mechanical may be added to the armor if it doesn't affect the game's mechanic too much, at DM's discretion. (The rule of cool is above all rules after all, right?)
